Title: Column: Tongue in Check
Content: Want the latest buzz on the gossip front? A peep into the lives of the rich and famous? A wind of Chennai’s best-kept secrets? Writer, activist, anchor, and queen bee Apsara Reddy fills you in...As Women’s Day approaches, everyone is planning their line-up of events and guests. It seems some of the big NGOs and corporates are gunning for danseuse Shobana to be their chief guest. Shobana is even being requested by an international royal family who want to fly her to Dubai for a workshop with women. Buzz is top image managers in Mumbai have been contacted to reach out to Shobana.One of the heirs of a construction tycoon, Sanjay is London-made so to speak, with a body to brag and royalty as friends. His posts on social media, a collection of photographs shot during his visits to the country, promote Indian culture and the rustic sights of India. Sources in top industry circles say a director has approached this lad for a lead role in a romcom. However, the scion is focused on getting into townships rather than tinsel world.At a popular gym in the city where so-called ‘beasts’ workout, a leading businessman has spotted a pattern. It seems these men promote the videos of only middle-aged women who buy them gifts. And it’s become like a competition for these women to feature in the videos of these reasonably well-known trainers. The businessman in question is offended as one of the trainers had put up a video of his mother with the title ‘Hottie on the floor’!Among some of Wendell Rodricks’s high-profile friends in the city, Dr Priya Selvaraj penned a tearful farewell for the designer. The two had met multiple times when he had come to Chennai and when she had visited Goa. It seems they bonded over books, food and a mutual thought process on love and life.An actor, who is married to a beautiful social media influencer, likes emails to communicate with colleagues and business associates. He’s been sourcing furniture for his beach house, and in an email to his Chinese agent, who is a petite lass, he happened to send a naughty smiley! And the girl sent an equally racy symbol back. Last heard, he’s been planning a solo trip to China and has told his wife that he’s rerouting his plans because of shoot commitments.( Views expressed above are the author’s own)

Title: Understanding your addictions
Content: Addictions come in many forms. It is no longer only about drinking or substance abuse. It could be an addiction for sugar, social media, partying, socialising – either out of habit or to feel better. In my career of consulting people and breaking down the root cause of these addictions, the commonalities I have observed mostly stem from emotional issues – stress, anxiety, unresolved emotional issues, low self-esteem, loneliness, loss, grief, rejection. So, for someone going through emotional distress, it’s easy to find solace in addictions because they are great at altering brain signals and providing a false escape from the current situation.To begin with, it’s necessary to identify the “root cause” of your addiction. What happened (an event or situation) before you actually got into an addiction? Only when we identify the root cause, can we successfully work towards weaning off the habit. We need to understand that a decrease in anxiety or stress levels achieved by using the above-mentioned stuff is for a very short time. You will need another fix very soon if you are not working towards eliminating the root cause.It’s easy to put the blame on alcohol or cigarettes for your own addictions, but the truth is that alcohol or smoking is never the problem. It’s the person abusing it, using it with the wrong state of mind, wrong attitude, lack of discipline and the inability to handle emotions in a matured way. There are so many who do it but they are also aware of where to stop and draw the line.You shouldn’t do something just because your friends are doing it and it is trendy. You may lose many friends and social groups if you decide not to indulge in these things, but you should also know that these are the people worth moving away from. Friends who expect you to be a certain way so that you can “fit in” are not the kind of people you want to be with.Most people live in denial and are unable to accept having a bad day or a bad event. They are unable to accept and go through an unpleasant emotion that results from it and hence resort to external aids to numb these feelings. If you are having a bad day, go through the feeling. Feel the downs. The more you feel these emotions, the easier it is for you to process it and let it die its natural death. When you numb sadness through addictions, you also numb feelings of true happiness and joy.This is one of the most common reasons why people give in to addictions even after deciding to give it up. There is no magic pill for this, but the lack of will power is not to be blamed. Self-discipline comes from within.Dopamine or the motivation molecule is a neurotransmitter/ chemical messenger that our brain produces naturally. We lose it over time due to a poor lifestyle or heavy medications. Whenever you think about motivation/demotivation, pleasure, focus, intention, feel-good factors or are constantly stuck in the victim mode, you should think about dopamine. Social media surfing, moving from page to page, picture to picture, checking for notifications every 15-30 minutes are all symptoms of low dopamine – each one stimulates dopamine production and bring about excitement and thrill.So, be aware of your vices and whether they are controlling you, your behaviour, decision, health, and lifestyle. Take professional help if you need to.Low self-esteem: Confidence in one’s ability decides his or her self-esteem. People with low self-esteem and self-worth have difficulty overcoming negative thoughts and converting them into positive ones. This, in turn, makes them vulnerable to the outside environment. If you have low self-esteem, you feel everything is impossible for you; there is no motivation or energy. This leads to destructive behaviour and most commonly to addiction.

Title: “Brush your hair well”- Jonita Gandhi, Singer
Content: Fashion to me is - Expression5 essentials of a woman’s wardrobe - Black tank, a good pair of jeans, white sneakers, a smart blazer to dress up any look and a pair of black pumps.My everyday outfit - Jeans or leggings with an off-shoulder top or a comfortable tee.My shopping strategy - Shop on a need basis, not a want basis. Of course, I don’t always follow this strategy (laughs). I am usually a conscious shopper, but if it’s unique and it looks good, it’ll probably come home with me.A grooming tip for women - Keep a hairbrush with you at all times. It’s surprising what brushing your hair well can do for you.Favourite style hack - Mix-and-match pieces from different outfits to create a totally new look.A fashion trend I hate - Top-knot buns – probably because I don’t like how it looks on me!A fashion trend I love - Neons – love, love, love ’em.Biggest fashion blunder I’ve committed - I probably do this way more often than I notice but the worst I can think of is wearing (visible) socks with flats. In my defence, it was really cold!My style philosophy - Style is such a subjective thing. I prefer to look at style as an individual expression – and if it makes you feel good when you wear it, it’s part of your style, and it’s stylish.My must-have grooming essential - Hair straightener and eyelash curler.An advice I swear by - Either bold eye or bold lip – never both.A skincare advice that my mom passed on - Moisturise often and well.Can a star hack it without a stylist... - If acting or singing is your main job, it’s pretty tough to handle styling all on your own. I think stylists make our lives easier. For me at least, it would be a logistical and practical nightmare to completely avoid getting help from stylists. I’ve got too much other stuff to juggle already.Airport looks... - I like to be comfortable, especially when I’m travelling. For me that trumps “style”.Paparazzi is... - A business. But also the reason for the weirdest photos of many of us on the internet (LOL).My fitness regimen - YogaMy guilty indulgence - Backpacks and shoes are turning into guilty pleasures, but I try not to cave in too often.One word for me - FunWhat makes you feel sexy - Luscious lashesUltimate fashion destination - ParisMost stylish person in showbiz - For me, a person I look up to is Alia Bhatt. No matter what look she sports, she always seems comfortable in her own skin

Title: Ain’t no sunshine
Content: Firstly, the largely sedentary lifestyle we lead, mostly glued to a screen, is limiting our exposure to the natural Vitamin D we can get from the outdoors. Secondly, because of the low-fat epidemic that began in the 1980s, dietary fats gradually began disappearing from everyone’s plate due to concerns over heart health and obesity by nutritionists and doctors. Since Vitamin D is a fat-soluble vitamin, now after almost 40 years, we are witnessing a marked deficiency of this vitamin in people of all ages and genders.Vitamin D keeps bones healthy and strong, benefits the immune system and is important for brain health as well. People with low Vitamin D are at a much greater risk of depression and increased susceptibility to infections.: New research from the Harvard School of Public Health (HSPH) suggests that exercising two or three hours per week boosts the levels of Vitamin D in the body.: Avoid going fat-free with your food since Vitamin D3 is a fat soluble vitamin. Instead, add generous amounts of desi ghee, home-churned butter, kacchi ghani (cold pressed) oils, nuts, dry fruits and dairy products originating from indigenous breeds of cows.As the name suggests, supplements are only to supplement or aid and enhance. They are in no way a replacement for your baseline diet, which needs to be addressed first.

Title: Kshanam Remake: Aadyaa allowed me to work with great performers: Chaitanya KM
Content: Like most filmmakers worth their salt, Chaitanya KM is a sucker for original stories. Yet, when a refreshing tale from across the border comes to him to be retold for Kannada audiences, he does not shy away from it, provided the narrative has scope for improvisation. His next, Aadyaa , is one such, says Chaitanya. The official remake of the Telugu film , Kshanam, Aadyaa follows the protagonist, who nurses a broken heart, and the journey he sets on when someone from his past seeks his help. “I take the liberty to change the scripts of all my films. There is no way that I will do a photocopy of another film for the Kannada market. I will only take up a remake if I can do something with it and truly own it. With Aadyaa, I saw that there is a phenomenon in psychology that I could use, which was not explored in the original. I have also introduced a new character to the narrative. Add to that the writing by writer-filmmaker Rohit Padaki and I knew I could give this story a new flavour,” says Chaitanya. In making Aadyaa, Chaitanya got to work with a bunch of “great performers”. “That is the highlight of the film, because, ultimately, what people watch on the screen, no matter what you as a director do, is actors. And a thriller really depends on good acting. I am blessed in that department — there’s Chiranjeevi Sarja Sangeetha Bhat , Ravishankar Gowda, Shashank Purushottam and Pramod Shetty, among others. Acting apart, music and editing play a huge part in a thriller and I got Sridhar V Sambhram to compose and Akshay Rao to edit, both of who have elevated the film to another level,” adds the filmmaker.

Title: How I Start My Day
Content: If you are a night owl, and that works for you, it’s great. There’s no reason to change. But for me, switching from being a night owl to an early riser has been godsend. It has helped me in so many ways that I’d never go back. I like to get up early in the morning and beat the sun and the birds to it. I ban all electronics, social media, email and phone calls for a set amount of time. Instead, I read a book or magazine, go for a walk, or simply stare out and daydream. Being an OCD planner, I spend 15 minutes every morning to prioritise and plan my day with breathing time in-between. I am mindful of the surprises that crop up. Being curious, introspecting and learning from mistakes helps me navigate the changes through the day with a positive attitude, and sometimes, these changes work better than what I had planned. Here are 4 habits for a fulfilling day:* Start your day with a big smile, count your blessings.* Once in a while, pause from your busy life and focus on your breathing.* Charge your mobile phone in the room next to your bedroom.

Title: Vijay Sethupathi to shed weight for Vignesh Shivn's film
Content: After setting the screen on fire with their sizzling chemistry in Naanum Rowdydhaan, Vijay Sethupathi and Nayanthara are coming together again for Vignesh Shivan’s next. This time, it will be ‘three times the trouble’ as Samantha Akkineni, too, joins the cast of this project, titled Kaathuvaakula Rendu Kaadhal.Ask Vignesh about the film and he says, “The title explains everything. It will be a fun romcom that sticks to the genre. This is a script that we had planned to do two years ago. Writing takes time and we thought this was the best time to make it. Vijay, Nayan and Samantha really loved the script. They loved the way the story had been written. Vijay will also be knocking off some kilos for his role.”The team is likely to begin shoot from April. “We will be shooting in and around south India,” informs Vignesh. The music will be scored by Anirudh Ravichander. Vignesh says, “It has always been a pleasure to work with Anirudh. He gives the best for me. Everyone knows about my love for music and I am a huge Anirudh fan. I am looking forward to write songs for the film.”

Title: Kollywood producer to sue the makers of Parasite?
Content: When South Korean film Parasite swept four major awards at the 92nd Academy Awards, a few Tamil movie buffs took to social media to point out the similarities the movie shared with Tamil film Minsara Kanna , directed by KS Ravikumar and starring Vijay , which was released in 1999. However, when we reached out to Ravikumar, he told us that while he is yet to see the film, he was happy for having come up with an Oscar-winning story 20 years ago. The story of the film was penned by MA Kennady, with Ravikumar writing its screenplay.But now, things have taken a serious turn. In a strange move, PL Thenappan, who claims to be a producer of Minsara Kanna (KRG, a producer who is no more, is the only credited producer in the film’s titles), saying that he is planning to sue the makers of the Bong Joon-ho film. He told us that talks are on with a Chennai-based lawyer and that a decision on zeroing in on an international lawyer will be made in a couple of days. Thenappan says, “I watched Parasite only after the film bagged several Academy Awards. I feel the basic plot has been lifted from our movie.”When asked about the differences between both the movies, he told us, “Let the court decide that. There have been cases of a few Korean filmmakers suing makers of Tamil films. Let the court look into everything.”

Title: Play with colours
Content: When it comes to styling hacks, monochrome is on the top of the list along with the holiest of style hacks – layering. Wearing a top-to-toe same colour or pattern is a failsafe move that can change your look in interesting ways without doing too much. We have all done it at some point, especially on lazy days. You pull out a pair of black trousers, black top, black blazer and finish up with black boots for a simple single-colour look. The Guardian’s fashion writer Jess Cartner-Morley calls “monotoning the new colour blocking”. It’s all about pairing items from your own wardrobe in a fresh way – a shop-your-own-closet move, if you will. And it’s really simple to achieve. The idea is to elevate an easy-to-wear outfit into something with a bit of drama/attitude. To start, Cartner-Morley suggests picking one basic item like a bright shoe or bag and pull out everything in your closet in the same colour wheel. Hot tip: Black is one of the simplest colours to break into this trend.In fashion terms, monochromatic dressing is wearing separates of one colour that have different textures and/or similar shades of that colour for an overall tonal look. Now, many celebrities are leading the way in pairing separates in the same colour and breaking it with either a necklace or a belt or an interesting shoe to achieve high drama. Unlike pattern mixing that can look fussy and colour-blocking that may come off as kitschy, a single shade is a simpler, cleaner approach to style an outfit.Whether it’s top-to-bottom jewel tones, winter whites, or a neutral ensemble, monochromatic dressing offers visual relief. It looks sharp and put together and yet carries the element of experimentation. And the best bit: it’s easy to achieve with Indian outfits like salwar-kameez and sarees. Even as the name suggests one colour, it doesn’t mean you have to stick to that same shade. The joy of this trend is to try out shades and tints of the same colour. Start with a charcoal-grey skirt and a light grey blouse; wear dark grey booties and silver jewellery to complete the look.In her popular style blog, Stylishly Me, blogger Vanessa Rodriguez, says she considers the monochromatic trend as the easiest and trickiest style to pull off. Her advice: start with selecting the colour. Keep in mind that the colour suits your skin tone and hair. Pull out all the items you have in the colour you want to wear. Once the items are laid out, start experimenting by combining your pieces. See what looks good together, what doesn’t.Mix textures to add visual interest, depth, and dimension. Mix knits with smooth, add sequins to a plain top, or wear leather with cashmere. Accessories, especially shoes and belts, can amp up the visual element. While mixing, keep an eye on balance, let no one shade overpower the outfit. To break up the solid blocks of colour, add a print piece made of the same colour you’re working with. You can also try adding a patterned shawl or scarf for fun.Monotoning works with virtually any colour: purple, red, blue, green, brown, pinkMonotoning takes some testing to find out what you like and what looks good- You can mix clothes you already own to create a totally new look. Mix new with older pieces- Wearing multiple layers of varied textures of one colour adds depth and dimension to a look- You can highlight, or downplay, certain parts of your body. For instance, if you have long legs but are heavy around the middle, wear white skinny jeans with a white blouse and cream jacket vest to draw attention to a lean lower body. To bring the focus towards your face, go with reverse ombre with a slightly darker shade at the bottom and lighter, brighter variations upwards- Dressing mono means you have one uninterrupted line from head to toe that elongates yoursilhouette, making you appear slimmer and taller than you actually areVidya Balan wears a saree-inspired silhouette while Sophie Choudry goes for the classic pantsuit – the simplest ways to monoShilpa Shetty and Bhumi Pednekar try the yellow shade with the latter breaking it with a blue jacket and Shetty cinching it in with a beltKareena Kapoor Khan wears a shade of hot pink; Tamannaah wears soft lilac suit and Yami Gautam goes purpleDeepika Padukone mixed checks and stripes in blue for a work-ready look

Title: Heard of the 30-wears test?
Content: In 2016, Livia Firth floated the 30 wears campaign. It’s simply what it says – asking yourself “Will I wear this (any item of clothing you are buying) at least 30 times?” The idea is to promote mindfulshopping, and not giving up buying new clothes. Firth, who runs a sustainability consultancy calledEco-Age which certifies brands for their green practices, aims to change the way we approachshopping and owning clothes. The key: think of your clothes as an investment, rather thandisposable.This mindful way of shopping aims at reducing the amount of clothing ending up in landfills.Incidentally, UK studies of women’s closets have proved that the average woman keeps a piece ofclothing in her wardrobe for only five weeks. The campaign encourages you to wear your clothesagain and again, thereby being an outfit repeater.Now, 30 times may not seem like a lot. To break it down, you’d have to wear the same top once aweek over seven months before you have worn it 30 times. Even with a capsule wardrobe, peoplestruggled to find pieces that they had worn over 30 times.Before buying, ask yourself: Will I wear this at least 30 times? Is this a high-quality piece? Will it lastat least 30 washes? Will I still want to wear this in 6 months? Or in a year’s time?In an online interview she said: “The biggest message is every time you buy something, always think,‘Will I wear it a minimum of 30 times?’ If the answer is yes, then buy it. But you’d be surprised howmany times you say no.”A UK study found we only wear clothes an average of seven times — with a third of us consideringitems to be ‘old’ after three outingsRepeating is chic: Kate Middleton rewears a lot of her clothes; she wore her 2012 AlexanderMcQueen to this year’s BAFTA; Livia Firth (left) coined hashtag #30wears1.Don’t buy statement pieces that are limiting in their wears2. Invest in classics, not trends3. Pick more versatile pieces that can be styled differently

Title: It’s sad that no woman player has individual sponsorship: Bembem Devi
Content: Former Indian football team captain Bembem Devi, who has moved on to coaching, was in the city for the finale of the Indian Women’s League (IWL) recently. Known as the Durga of Indian football, Bembem has been an inspiration for many after her successful two-decade-old career that even earned her a Padma Shri this year. Bangalore Times caught up with the two captains of the finalist teams, Dangmei Grace from KRYPHSA and Michel Margaret Castanha from Gokulam Kerala FC, for a chat with the veteran player. Excerpts...Tell us about your journey...I began my professional career with the All Indian Football Federation (AIFF) in 1995. At the time, we didn’t have great sponsors. While sponsorship trickled in a few years later, the AIFF ensured that they had a good team, irrespective of the funds. All of us on the team had only one thing in our minds — represent our country. The AIFF has been equally supportive of both men’s and women’s football. My journey in football has been memorable, given that I was encouraged to lead the team seven times. I was also recommended for and won an Arjuna Award in 2017. If I have given my all to the sport, the recognition and rewards have also been encouraging. If I have played football for 21 years, it has been satisfying and rewarding.What drew you to football? Were your parents supportive?As a child, I began playing football with the boys’ team. I used to cut my hair really short to pass off for a boy, which I continued doing till Class 5. Throughout this time, my father would often reprimand me and ask me to focus on academics instead. But I didn’t pay heed and found ways to continue playing; including changing my name to a more masculine sounding Bobo to enroll with teams. This is how my love affair with football began. In 1991, a women’s football club approached me to join them. I was pleasantly surprised that there was a team for women. As luck would have it, I was selected to Manipur ’s Under-13 state team the same year.Tell us about some noteworthy changes in the sport that you have seen over the years?The biggest change I see today is in terms of exposure. Back in the day, we did not get opportunities to play with seniors or experienced players. Now, players from the Under-19 team get to play with national players and understand the nuances of the game in in friendly matches. The daily allowances, travelling allowances and other facilities have also changed for the better.How helpful is the Indian Women’s League in promoting football for women?IWL can help sort careers for girls interested in football. From six teams in the first installment, we now have 12 teams in the fourth edition; it has definitely grown. For players who excel, good contracts and support from the federation and the state governments can go a long way in stabilising their futures. It also helps the teams scout for promising and new talent.Bangalore Times: Indian men’s football has seen a growth in popularity lately. What do you think will help women’s football get there?I agree that men’s football gets a lot more help and has the fame. But this year, India is playing host to the Under-17 Football World Cup. This tournament will ensure that people know that there’s women’s football in the country. It is heartening for me to get calls from parents of girls asking about the process of selection and trials for the national team for this tournament.After 21 years in the game, do you have any administrative plans?In 2017, after I retired from active football, I was appointed the Manipur state team’s coach. Later, I was also an assistant coach for the Under-15 Indian team. I want to keep at this and help as many youngsters as possible with the sport.When we spoke to the 12 captains of the IWL, they said that players need encouragements in terms of sponsors and kits individually...Individually, no player in women’s football has a sponsor. I wish that the top brands think about this, as it helps encourage the players. The emerging players, especially, should be considered for this, as this will help take the sport to the next level.You were conferred a Padma Shri this year. People say it comes a little late in the day. What’s your take on that?I do not know whether or not it is late or early. But being the first woman in the sport to receive this honour, I’d like to dedicate it to women’s football in India. It is nice that the government has recognised the efforts of the AIFF and the sport.

Title: Bannerghatta Biological Park: Bannerghatta’s new baby elephant named after Tulasi Gowda
Content: There is a new purpose in making a visit to the Bannerghatta Biological Park — to watch the newest baby elephant’s cute struggle to find her space among the 23 other humongous members of the herd. Born on January 30, 2020, she is named after Padma Shri awardee Tulasi Gowda. Tulasi Gowda hails from the village of Honnali, located in the Ankola Taluk of North Karnataka. She is known for her extensive work in conservation of the environment and forests, this despite having no formal education. The environmentalist was honoured with the fourth highest civilian award on January 26, 2020.The baby elephant, however, is the second resident to have been named after an influential female role model, the first one being the tiger cub Hima, who was named after ace sprinter Hima Das. Tulasi’s mother Vanashree is around 13 years old, and she also has a sibling – seven-year-old Sampath, who incidentally is a fellow Aquarian. A lesser known fact is that Tulasi remained in her mother’s womb for a good 22 months before she was born — the longest period, by normal standards known, for any mammal.January 30, 2020Bannerghatta Biological Park3.27 ft104 kgsAquariusVanashree (13 years old)Sampath (7 years old)Mother’s milk, for the next 18 months

Title: A night of fashion and gastronomical experiences in Bengaluru
Content:

Content:

Things to do with Indie dogs

Watch out for emotional response from the dog if it is initially unresponsive

Allow the dog to get comfortable before training it

Get it checked for rabies, fleas, and parasites, too

Indie dogs may develop anxiety and distrust the people: give them time

They are territorial and do not trust strangers quickly, so aggression towards new people is normal. Warn the humans

They are flexible with eating habits, but overfeeding may lead to behavioural shift

Data source: India International Pet Trade Fair/WHO

People often adopt stray indie dogs as it makes them feel good about having done a good deed. But these poor mutts that look cute and cuddly when they are puppies don’t measure up to pedigreed status dogs in looks once they’re fully grown. Plus, indie dogs are quite energetic and need a stern hand when it comes to being trained. This leads to owners abandoning them once they grow up, sometimes cruelly so! Don’t do this, plead pet parents fostering many of these homeless curs, and give us a few points when it comes to keeping strays as pets...Saikiran VC, who runs a pet homestay in Chennai, has five indie dogs, all adopted under various circumstances. Aiko and Annie were adopted in 2013 and 2014, Luna and Lyka were just 3-4 days old when they were wrapped in a plastic bag and thrown inside Saikiran’s compound in 2016, and Tommy is a cancer survivor, adopted in 2019. “Indie dogs are high on energy, temperamental and territorial. So learn about the breed you’re going to adopt, get them ‘socialised’ and trained early on,” says Saikiran.Akash Tiwari, a working professional in Mumbai, brought home a pup five years ago. He says, “Think it through, especially if you’re living in a metro, as space is a challenge. Just because it’s a stray, it cannot be abandoned as per convenience. People think these dogs are easy maintenance, but the reality is they require extra care as they are prone to catching infections fast.”If you’re about to adopt an indie dog, don’t do so for their looks because they look and act a certain way as they age. But they also suffer from separation anxiety when they are abandoned, so don’t make them go through that. Indie dogs are very sharp, their immunity is better than pedigreed ones as they are accustomed to local conditions. Do keep in mind that as they start growing, they get aggressive and start tearing things around them like shoes, the couch, etc. Be patient, get pet-friendly toys, as with training, they’ll become genteel,” explains Siddharth Manoharan, a Bengaluru-based businessman who has three indie dogs at home, and has been fostering a dog mom and her litter on the street.Adds Uma Prakash, a Carnatic musician from Chennai who has three mongrels at home, “Indie dogs are no less good looking than their pedigreed counterparts. They are totally low maintenance, shed minimum and assess people in minutes. So, if you are bringing an indie dog home, make sure you spend time spend with them and only then, will they become friendly.”“I already had two pedigree dogs when I brought Puchu home. I feel indie dogs are more easygoing, low maintenance and quick to pick up things. Puchu is quite self-trained. People often think indie breeds can be fed anything since they are born on the streets, but that’s not true. They also need a different set of calories, proteins and vitamins, and certain food items need to be avoided. Mostly, they need the same kind of love and care,” opines Snigdha Bose, MSc student from Kolkata.The top three reasons why stray dogs are abandoned by owners after they adopt them as puppies:Unexpected costs, disobedience, hyperactivity, aggression towards family members

Title: Goan trio taste success with Kerala
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Panaji: No Goan team has come close to winning the Indian Women’s League ( IWL ) but three players from the state achieved the feat with Gokulam Kerala FC in Bengaluru on Friday.

Panjim Footballers had represented the state twice but never managed to proceed beyond the group stage. This year there were high expectations from Bidesh XI Sports Club who won the Goa Women’s League undefeated. The Assonora side lost all five league matches.

Michel Castanha, Karishma Shirvoikar and Linda Colado, all looked for opportunities beyond their comfort zone and it paid off. Current international Michel not only played a stellar role in defence but also captained the Kerala side in the fourth edition where they edged past Kryphsa FC 3-2 in a thrilling summit clash.

“Leading the team was a great honour and I am thankful to the management for trusting me. It was a big responsibility but handling it could only be possible because of the support I received from teammates,” Michel told TOI on Saturday.

The defender featured in seven matches for Kerala and helped goalkeeper Aditi Chauhan maintain four clean sheets. In the group stage, Michel provided the stability at the back that saw Kerala concede only two goals. They remained undefeated in five matches and scored a staggering 28. Kerala added three more in the semifinals against defending champions Sethu FC.

“Coach Prya PV really helped us throughout along with her coaching staff. Most of us are getting competitive exposure and the level of football has really gone up,” said Michel.

While the Curtorim girl flourished, Karishma was not far behind. Her appearances were restricted to only three games as Nepal striker Sabitra Bhandari often grabbed headlines with her goal-scoring prowess.

“I played for Panjim in the IWL last two seasons and it helped me. This year I played less games but learned a lot of new things from the seniors in the side. I will continue to work hard in the future,” said Karishma.

Although the forward from Odxel couldn’t get more game time, she still managed to net four goals, including one in the 5-0 win over Bidesh. Linda too had prior experience in the IWL after turning up for Panjim Footballers, but the defender did not feature for Kerala this time.

The Goan trio have set an example for other footballers from the state and hope more can follow in their footsteps next season

Title: I-League: Churchill have the last laugh
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Margao: Whatever reason Churchill Brothers coach Bernardo Tavares may have had to bench his star striker Willis Plaza, he certainly got a reaction.

Plaza looked gingerly from the bench for most part, then warmed up nervously in the second half. A few young fans cheered him, he acknowledged, and it was not until the 67th minute that he took the field. As always, he tried hard, missed a very good chance with a close-range header, but unlike previous games, this time there was a happy ending for Churchill as they put it across Aizawl FC 2-1 in a I-League clash at the Nehru Stadium in Fatorda on Saturday.

Just when everything seemed lost, it was Plaza who settled it for Churchill in the fifth minute of added time. That the winner came after Churchill had conceded an equalizer in the first minute of added time and it seemed like they would be crushed again, made the strike even sweeter.

Never mind that the winner from Plaza (90+5) came from a goalmouth melee. Never mind that it looked fortuitous. Never mind that, despite being so close, it almost didn’t happen.

The win took Churchill to the fourth spot with 16 points from 10 matches, 13 points behind league leaders Mohun Bagan who have played two extra matches and visit Goa next week. Plaza’s last-gasp winner also overshadowed an excellent strike from Paul Ramfangzauva (90+1), who had cancelled out Dawda Ceesay’s opener for Churchill in the 73rd minute.

Churchill coach Bernardo Tavares tried to shake things up by leaving Plaza on the bench. It was a bold decision to leave the league’s highest goal-scorer out, and instead show faith in Hafis Mohammed. That didn’t seem to work. Hafis tried, ran into open spaces, but when everyone thought it would be Plaza’s turn to show what he’s got, it was midfielder Quan Gomes who replaced the forward in a tactical switch.

Churchill were in better control of the proceedings than previous matches. The passing was smooth, but chances were at a premium. Aizawl FC missed the presence of Mali forward Abdoulaye Kanoute – left on the bench because of an injury – so even though there were a few chances, neither goalkeeper had anything to worry in the opening 45 minutes.

Churchill broke the deadlock in the 73rd minute through Ceesay. The Gambian midfielder and former captain intercepted a loose ball from Alfred Jaryan in Alzawl’s own half and after working his way forward, tried his luck from the edge of the box. The ball took a deflection off Joseph Adjei and dipped past goalkeeper Zothangmawia, who was caught slightly out of position.

Aizawl got the equalizer only in the first minute of added time with a strike that had beauty written all over it. Joe Zoherliana's throw-in was not cleared well by the Churchill defence and the ball fell just on top of the box for Ramfanfzauva. The young midfielder controlled the ball with his right and then executed a brilliant volley with his left that crashed into the top corner of the nets.

Expectedly, shoulders dropped. Three of the four Churchill defenders slumped to the ground. But there was still time to conjure up something and Plaza was the man to do it.

Glan Martins entered the box from the right and sent a cross into the centre where Abu Bakr's effort on goal was stopped by the goalkeeper, whose collision with his own defender allowed Plaza the time to somehow tap the ball home.

Title: Bigg Boss 13 winner: Sidharth Shukla bags the trophy, wins cash prize of Rs 40 lakh

Title: 65th Amazon Filmfare Awards 2020: Abhimanyu Dassani on Best Debut Male win, “Mom will remember it more so because she gave it to me”
Content:
The award for Best Debut Actor goes to @Abhimannyu_D for #MardKoDardNahiHota. 65th #AmazonFilmfareAwards 2020… https://t.co/Xp0PzB7BC3 — Filmfare (@filmfare) 1581788924000

It was a night to remember for actor Abhimanyu Dassani , who bagged the Best Debut (Male) Filmfare award for his stellar performance in the action-drama ‘Mard Ko Dard Nahi Hota’.Making things even more special, the organizers called upon his mom, Bhagyashree to the stage to present the award to her son. Speaking about his big win, Abhimanyu said in an exclusive chat with ETimes, “It is every actors dream of Indian film industry to hold the black lady and say your mine. I can't be more grateful to Filmfare. I would like to thank whole cast and crew of ‘Mard Ko Dard Nahi Hota'’.’Expressing his shock and joy about the win, he added, “Firstly you are nervous sitting in the audience hoping to get and award and prepping up your speech in mind. The shocker was my first Filmfare and they called my mom on stage to present the award. My mom will remember it more so because she gave it to me.”The actor, who was contending against the like of Meezaan Jaffrey for ‘Malaal’, Siddhant Chaturvedi for ‘ Gully Boy ’, Vardhan Puri for ‘Yeh Saali Aashiqui’, Vishal Jethwa for ‘Mardaani 2’ and Zaheer Iqbal for ‘Notebook’, also acknowledged his fellow nominees and wished them the best for the future. He concluded, “My (co-contender) Siddharth Chaturvedi is a fantastic actor. He deserves it as much as I do and so does Vishal Jethwa. Hopefully, in the future, I would like to work with them.”‘Mard Ko Dard Nahi Hota’ was directed by Vasan Bala and co-starred Radhika Madan in a leading role along with Gulshan Devaiah.Hosted in Awesome Assam the grand event took place at the Indira Gandhi Athletic Stadium, Sarusajai, Guwahati, Assam.

A bright and warm Friday was a lot of relief to Bhaichand Patel , who had to delay his Valentine 's Day celebrations last year after rain played spoilsport on February 14. Continuing his decades old tradition, he hosted a V-Day party at his home in Sujan Singh Park this year. For some guests, the party was a reunion of friends and for others it was an occasion to let loose and dance.Dancing is a must at Bhaichand's party and he made sure that no guest was glued to chair for long. "If you are here, you must dance. You have to pay a price for being at this party by being on the dance floor," he said. The playlist for the evening comprised classic English romantic numbers and the DJ told us that the playlist for the party hasn’t changed in the last five years. Shovana Narayan, who has been a regular at this bash, told us, "I just love coming here, meeting friends and dancing with them. I am coming straight from my performance and haven’t even changed my dancing costume. I wanted to be here as soon as I finished my performance."The dress code for the evening was red and black and the guests took it "very seriously". "I chose a black outfit and then I realised I needed to add a hint of red to my look, so I wore red lipstick. Being a designer, I take dress codes very seriously. I also think that a host plans a party keeping a certain theme in mind and guests should try to stick to the dress code as much as possible," said Leena Singh. Another guest, Renuka Khanna, made an extra effort and added a few extra roses with LED lights. "I just wanted to do something fun and look different," she told us.

Title: When John channelled his naughty side and Vidya decided to go glam for Dabboo Ratnani's annual celebrity calendar
Content: Photographer Dabboo Ratnani is all set to present his celebrity calendar’s 21st edition. For the last two decades, the calendar has showcased B-Town actors and actresses in different avatars and promises to do so once again. The photographer shared some exclusive images with BT and spoke about the thought behind them:John Abraham: John and I have done a lot of body shots. We wanted to bring out the naughty and cool side of his personality. We’ve used a lot of hard lights in the past, but here, we opted for soft lights, to make the photo look sexy and be in that desirable zone. We lit up John’s picture the way filmmakers light up a love scene in Hollywood films. His smile and the way he has posed are just amazing.Vidya Balan: Vidya has always been a part of my calendars. If I have an idea, she always enhances it and adds her own thought to it. She believes in doing something different and pushing the boundary each time we shoot together. I love it when an actor is so involved in the picture we’re shooting. We wanted the overall effect to be soft and glamourous, and Vidya lent herself beautifully to it. Anushka Sharma The thought behind her picture was to underline the fact that she is a stunning woman. In the past, we have done mood shots and black-and-white photos, but this time around, we decided to take the classic glamour photo route with her. We used the blue palate, and because it required a controlled atmosphere, we shot a suburban studio to get the right effect.Vicky and I have done pictures together; in fact, I did his first-ever photo shoot. When we met on Diwali last year, we decided to do a calendar shoot together. He’s a great actor, but people are yet to see the sexy avatar. I wanted to bring that out, and so, we did this picture in a swimming pool. We did this shoot on a cold December morning. I could sense that the nip in the air was getting to him, but he went on with the shoot. Eventually, he also dragged me in. The idea was to bring his sex appeal to the table.

Title: 'Don't worry, one democracy will settle it,' Jaishankar to US Senator on Kashmir
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Foreign minister S Jaishankar firmly rebutted attempts by a US senator to raise Kashmir at the Munich Security Conference , responding to the US politician’s remark that he hoped “two democracies” will settle the matter, saying one democracy would and there was no prize for guessing which one.

“Do not worry, senator. One democracy will settle it and you know which one,” Jaishankar told Senator Lindsey Graham , a Republican, during a panel discussion after the US politician said the best way to “sell” democracy will be to settle the Kashmir issue in a democratic way.

“In India, you are moving forward, you got your problems like we do at home, but you've chosen the democratic path. When it comes to Kashmir, I don’t know how it ends, but let’s make sure that two democracies will end it differently. If you can prove that concept here, then I think that’s probably the best way to sell democracy,” the senator said.

Jaishankar’s immediate put-down seemed to reflect India’s impatience about western commentary that either ignores the role of Pakistan in backing terror groups — and separatists — intent on carrying out attacks in Jammu & Kashmir or an assumed equivalence that places India and Pakistan on the same footing.

Graham was among four senators who wrote to US secretary of state Mike Pompeo last week, ahead of President Donald Trump ’s visit to India, expressing concern about the restrictions in Kashmir and saying that the Indian government’s action threatened the rights of certain religious minorities.

During the discussion, Jaishankar also said that the United Nations is far less credible than before and “something” should be done about it. “The United Nations is far less credible than it has been in history, which is not entirely surprising because when you think about it, there are not too many things which are 75 years old and still as good as they were. Clearly there is something that needs to be done there.”

He also spoke about “westlessness” and multilateralism at the panel discussion. “Clearly multilateralism has become weaker, and clearly westlessness is in evidence and I would suggest that there is a correlation between the two. It is not to say that multilateralism is solely dependent on the West, or that the West has been faithfully multilateral,” he said.

Jaishankar also met US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi in Munich. He said her “consistent support” to India-US ties had always been a great source of strength.

Jaishankar arrived in Munich on Friday for the prestigious security conference during which he is expected to outline India’s views on several issues of global concern. “Such a pleasure to catch up with Speaker Pelosi,” Jaishankar tweeted. He also met US ambassador to the UN Kelly Knight Craft on the sidelines of the conference on Friday.

Title: Jailed for murder while training to be a doc, man finishes course 18 yrs later
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

KALABURAGI (Karnataka): A medical student jailed for life in 2002 for murdering his lover’s husband and released for good conduct after 14 years rejoined the course and finished it last year. He was awarded an MBBS degree at the convocation on Saturday.

Subhash Tukaram Patil (40), a resident of Bhasagi village in Afzalpur taluk, 475km from Bengaluru, was not deterred by the years in jail. “I was jailed when I was doing my MBBS course at the Hyderabad Education Society’s Mahadeveppa Rampure Medical College in Kalaburagi. I worked in the jail’s OPD,” Patil said. Earlier this month, he completed a one-year mandatory internship.

On August 15, 2016, he was released from jail and continued his medical studies after getting special permission from the Rajiv Gandhi University of Health Sciences . He rejoined his old college in 2016 and cleared all subjects in the first attempt. He had been doing his housemanship since 2019 at Basaveshwar Hospital, attached to MRMC.

Patil told TOI: “I’m committed to serving society, especially relatives of prisoners and soldiers. I spent a lot of time in the jail library and never lost interest in studies.”

As a student, Patil had been in love with a married woman and, abetted by her, he shot and killed her husband, an excise contractor. For six years he was in Parappana Agrahara Central Jail, Bengaluru, and was then shifted to Kalaburagi Central Jail for the rest of his term. While in prison he also completed Karnataka State Open University ’s journalism course.

MRMC dean Umeshchandra said though Patil was about 14 years older than his classmates, he completed the course successfully. Dr Kiran Patil, an ENT specialist at Basaveshwar Hospital who lectures at MRMC, said he and Subhash Patil were classmates in 2002. “It’s remarkable that after coming out of jail he continued the same course and successfully completed it.”

Title: Trump India visit: Govt picks national flavour: Namaste President Trump wins over Kem Cho
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

GANDHINAGAR: Even as Gujarat waits with bated breath to welcome the US President with “Kem Chho Trump”, the state government has been directed to replace the Gujarati expression with “Namaste President Trump” to help the event find resonance across India.

Gujarat chief secretary Anil Mukim told TOI: “The government of India has informed us about the ‘ Namaste President Trump ’ theme and all campaign materials will be as per the Centre’s directions.”

Sources said that “Kem Chho Trump (How are you, Trump)” had a regional flavour, while the event is being planned as a massive national show.

The state government has been told to design communication material to present “namaste” as the traditional Indian welcome for Trump on his maiden visit as president to the country.

In Ahmedabad, Trump will join Prime Minister Narendra Modi to inaugurate Motera Stadium, the world’s largest cricket arena.

“A Gujarati label for Trump’s first event in India would not have been appropriate,” said a government official. “Moreover, ‘namaste’ is understood as an Indian greeting across the world.”

Deputy CM and government spokesperson Nitin Patel said India has to be the theme of the visit as it is a national event.

A source said though the Prime Minister’s Office and the foreign ministry are yet to formally approve the “Namaste President Trump” theme, all billboards, placards and hoardings are likely to feature it. “Photographs of President Trump and the first lady will be used along with images that reflect India-US ties,” the source said.

Title: If a bank chief isn't beholden to a finmin join secretary; he will behave differently, says Montek Singh Ahluwalia
Content:
Montek Singh Ahluwalia, former deputy chairperson of the erstwhile Planning Commission and one of India’s most experienced economic policymakers is the author of ‘Backstage: The Story Behind India’s High Growth Years’. He spoke to Nalin Mehta and Sanjiv Shankaran on economic reforms, India’s big economic challenges and similarities and differences between the

and the NDA governments' approaches to the economy.

You say in the first seven years of UPA, the economy grew at 8.4% and 138 million people escaped poverty. What happened later?

The rules have always been ambiguous. Even the current government is struggling.

How different has NDA been in pushing reforms?

On economic issues, does BJP seem left of centre?

In the Vodafone retrospective tax case, didn’t you advise finance minister

against it?

Isn’t the banking structure unchanged?

You were the author of an early reforms blueprint, the M document. What lessons can today’s policy makers learn from your experience?

The growth momentum of the first seven years was remarkable, but economies have ups and downs and there was a down turn in the last three years. The global downturn after the Eurozone crisis in 2011 was one explanatory factor, But the system also ran into domestic constraints. Regulatory constraints prevented large projects from taking off. That problem continues even today. Allegations of corruption after 2011 also altered the political atmosphere. By the time of the election, the mood of the country turned completely against UPA.Looking back, many positive developments in the earlier years were simply swamped. Look at the telecom story. The CAG came up with unrealistically large estimates of revenue losses and public opinion came to the view that not auctioning spectrum was a big mistake. However, the experience around the world was not that auctions were the best method and in any case, the TRAI had not recommended auctions. I have mentioned in the book that some of the decisions taken in allocating licenses were questionable but the real question to ask was whether the telecom policy succeeded in its objective of expanding telecom access. From that perspective the policy was an outstanding success but this was never brought out in the public debate.I agree that many of the problems we face arise from the fact that our rules and regulations are very poorly drafted and are open to multiple interpretations. This is true of environmental regulations and also our tax laws. We do not put enough high quality effort into converting policy intentions into specific regulations that are clear and transparent. Regulations that can be interpreted in different ways are a recipe for people trying to manipulate the rules while others claim that the rules have been violated. The result is a multiplication of disputes and litigation. It is also a vicious circle that lends itself to allegations of corruption which then acquire a life of their own.As far as programmes are concerned, the NDA has more or less maintained most of the earlier programmes though many of them have been renamed and modified in some ways. The question to ask is whether they are being better implemented. This calls for credible independent evaluation.GST is an important tax reform which was actually put on the agenda by the UPA but opposed at that time by the BJP ruled states. Be that as it may, I think it is good that the Constitution was amended to enable GST but I feel the design of the GST has got mangled with far too many rates and heavy compliance obligations on smaller firms. Demonetization is called a reform but in my view it was a negative development which imposed a huge and unnecessary burden on the informal sector.The insolvency and bankruptcy code is a very important reform. I hope it proves to be a success.There are some areas where the NDA government has actually reversed the reform process. The decision to raise import duties, with the possibility of further increases ahead, is a major reversal of the policy of gradually reducing import duties, which has been in place for thirty years and was followed by several governments including the Vajpayee government. It is not consistent with the objective of improving export performance and joining global value chains.I also think it is a pity that the government has not joined RCEP. Asia is the one part of the world in which growth is expected to be high and which still remains open. Not joining RCEP is a negation of the Act East policy which was meant to replace the Look East Policy.This right-left binary has become a little jaded. I think you are implying that the BJP was expected to be more pro private sector but it isn't. Part of the problem is because, in the words of Arvind Subramanian, the private sector is now “stigmatized”. As Amartya Sen has said, India doesn’t really have a genuine right-wing party in economic terms.I was called in to give some ideas for the budget. There was talk at the time that the government might bring in an amendment to overturn the Supreme Court judgement. I used the opportunity to say that if we wanted to change the law prospectively there could be no objection but we should not do so retrospectively to overcome the Supreme Court judgement.I have said in my book that banking sector reform is a major task ahead. We have not seen any serious reform of public sector banking. Public sector banks are subject to dual control, by the Finance Ministry and the RBI. The Reserve bank does not have as much control over public sector banks as it does over private sector banks. That asymmetry vis a vis the private sector is wrong.The PJ Nayak committee had recommended that if reducing government equity to a minority is not politically feasible the government share in public sector banks should be put into a holding company. That company should then appoint the chairman and top managers, not the ACC (cabinet). If the chairman of the bank is not beholden to a joint secretary within the finance ministry he will behave differently. I think the time has come to recognise that the bureaucracy in the finance ministry adds no value to the quality of banking.In the last year of the Rajiv Gandhi government, we felt that the economy was not responding as much as we thought it would to the reform initiatives. I came to the conclusion that it was because we were pushing individual reform initiatives and not pushing for a core set of mutually supportive reforms as a package. When V.P Singh became Prime Minister he asked me to prepare a paper proposing an integrated reform package and I prepared a 34 page paper, which proposed a set of core reforms: reducing the fiscal deficit, liberalising industrial licensing, decontrolling imports, and moving to a flexible exchange rate. The paper was discussed in a committee of secretaries. Some were totally against it, but others were supportive. It taught me that a clear statement about the direction of reforms can run into opposition but it can also meet with a lot of support.The V.P Singh government wasn't there for long enough to implement reforms but when the Narasimha Rao government came in, they were able to do quite a lot of what was proposed in that paper. The main lesson I would draw is that we need to outline a set of core reforms and allow them to be discussed so that the pros and cons are fully debated.

Title: Calling dissenters ‘anti-national’ an attack on constitutional values: SC judge
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

AHMEDABAD: Justice D Y Chandrachud of the Supreme Court on Saturday said dissenting voices cannot be labelled ‘anti-national’ or ‘anti-democratic’ and such assertions are an attack on the people’s commitment to protecting constitutional values.

“Within the bounds of law, liberal democracies ensure that citizens enjoy the right to express themselves in every conceivable manner, including the right to protest, and express dissent against prevailing laws. The blanket labelling of dissent as anti-national or anti-democratic strikes at the heart of our commitment to the protection of constitutional values and promotion of a deliberative democracy,” Justice Chandrachud said during a talk at the Gujarat high court auditorium in Ahmedabad.

Laying emphasis on retaining India’s plural traditions, he added, “What is of utmost relevance today is our ability and commitment to preserve, conserve and build on the rich pluralistic history that we have inherited. Homogeneity is not the defining feature of Indianness.”

The SC judge said India as a nation is not committed to just one language, one religion, one culture, or one assimilated race. “No single individual or institution can claim a monopoly over the idea of India,” Justice Chandrachud said, insisting that the country at present finds itself “in defence of its plural views and the multitude of its cultures”.

Later, as chief guest of the 10th convocation of the Gujarat National Law University (GNLU), the SC judge encouraged students to stand up not just to government but for those who cannot speak for themselves. He asked students to question and question often. “It is important to stand up and be dissenters. It is only through your power of expressing views and courage of stating contrary positions that you will make others stop and think,” he said.

Earlier, during his talk on the ‘Hues that make India’ organised by the Justice P D Desai Memorial Lecture Committee, Justice Chandrachud called on the audience to include communities that are pushed to the fringe of the mainstream for being minorities — based on their language, faith, culture or gender — and asserted that this was aimed for by the Constitution.

Speaking after Justice Chandrachud, SC senior advocate Dushyant Dave reminded the audience and judges present about the Karnataka police investigating schoolchildren for performing a play opposing the Citizenship (Amendment) Act and the “unfortunate incident” at a Bhuj hostel where girls were being kept in a basement because they were menstruating.

“We have these situations which are completely antithetical to constitutional beliefs and values. Why is it happening? Why is the judiciary sitting (quietly) watching them? I would request the judges to ponder upon them. These are something on which you can definitely speak. What we need is pluralism in action, not merely in thoughts,” he said.

Title: Credit flow is slowly but steadily reviving: RBI guv
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

NEW DELHI: The Reserve Bank of India ( RBI ) on Saturday said that credit flow was reviving and is expected to improve further in the coming months on the back of steps taken by the central bank and the government .

“The momentum is gathering pace... Credit flow is slowly and steadily reviving,” RBI governor Shaktikanta Das told reporters after the post-Budget board meeting that was addressed by finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman .

While latest data showed that credit growth had moderated to 7.1% at the end of January, Das said that from contracting by 1.3 lakh crore at the end of September 2019, the flow of credit was higher by Rs 2.7 lakh crore. Similarly, fund flow to the commercial sector was estimated at around Rs 1 lakh crore in September has now risen to around 7.5 lakh crore. “There is expectation of the flow to improve in coming months due to the steps announced by the government and RBI,” he said. RBI has reduced policy rates five times since February 2018 and Das said that there were indications that banks were passing on the cuts now.

Asked about the Rs 15 lakh crore target for loan flow to the farm sector, Sitharaman said that she was confident of the goal being achieved. “Credit limit has been expanded. I am sure it is based on local ground level requirement...we expect the demand to grow and credit requirements to also meet up with it. I am actually closely monitoring banks and their extension of credit facility particularly to rural areas. So I think we'll be able to meet that,” the FM said.

The RBI governor also suggested that the overall impact of the steps announced in the Budget will not be inflationary. Measures such as higher import duty on a number of products are expected to make these items more expensive. Das, however, said that the main concern was over the fiscal deficit, which the government has handled by “adhering to the principle of fiscal prudence”.

“The good part of the government borrowing is also budgeted to come from small savings. Therefore, I don’t see much of an inflationary impact... Declining crude prices has definitely positive impact on inflation...The main reason for spike in inflation is because of food inflation, mostly milk, fish, and various protein related items. Core inflation has slightly edged up because of revision of telecom tariffs,” he added.

Retail inflation based on consumer price index (CPI) soared to a near six-year high of 7.6% in January, surpassing the Reserve Bank of India's comfort range primarily on account of rising vegetable and food prices.

Title: Coronavirus: Some drugs may not last beyond February because of coronavirus crisis, says FICCI
Content: NEW DELHI: Production of several commonly used medicines such as paracetamol, ibuprofen, some antibiotics and diabetes drugs may be adversely hit along with smartphones and solar equipment if the supply disruption caused by the outbreak of coronavirus in China lasts beyond two months, lobby group FICCI has assessed based on feedback from industry.In several cases, Indian drug-makers have raw material stocks of two to three months and so do not see any immediate problem but this could change if the problem persists, the study said. “Also, if the shutdown extends beyond February, then there may be some rise in prices of pharmaceutical products made in India,” the study said.India depends on China for around 70% of its bulk drugs and drug intermediates, according to industry estimates. This is the first-of-its-kind study based on feedback from the industry. The government has said there is ample stock of medicines to continue till April. However, the health ministry is working on a plan with measures to ensure there is no crisis in case if the lockdown in China continues for another fortnight impacting supplies. The government has identified specific drugs for which APIs are sourced from Hubei province, epicentre of the outbreak, and alternate production plan is in the making, officials told TOI earlier.In certain segments, such as penicillins and their derivatives, China accounts for over 90% of India’s import of the ingredient, the study said. In several product segments such as telecom equipment and organic compounds, China’s share is around 70%. On Tuesday, finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman is scheduled to meet industry representatives to assess the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak.Apart from pharma raw materials, the Ficci study said, India's production of smartphones faces the risk of disruption in case the prevailing situation continues beyond February, the report cautioned while stating that the impact of the outbreak on the automobile sector is divided. The report said that industry estimates show that China accounts for some 85% of the total value of parts and components used in smartphones in India (cells, display panels, camera modules and printed circuit boards). India imports mobile phone components worth Rs 7,000-8,000 crore from China every month.“According to feedback received from industry, Indian industry could still manage the challenge till end-February (as inventory is expected to last for next 3-6 weeks),” the report said.“If the crisis is prolonged, then for March and April production, they will have trouble and there will be a shortage of devices. As an alternative, some components can be sourced from South Korea Vietnam or Taiwan; however, this is going to be the "last resort" only because it would require the smartphone makers to make changes in design and software,” the report said.Regarding the automotive sector, the report said opinion on the likely impact on automobile sector is divided. While Maruti Suzuki does not expect any serious impact, TATA Motors and MG Motor India think otherwise, it said.It said that according to Fitch Solutions , vehicle production in India may suffer contraction by 8.3% in 2020 in the wake of increasing risk of supply shortage due to the coronavirus outbreak in China. “With 10 to 30% share, China is one of India’s largest suppliers of automotive components and this explains the entire scenario. The downside may be much higher for the electric vehicle segment in India,” the report said.The impact of the outbreak will have severe implications for the country’s solar industry as bulk of solar cells, modules, inverters and robotic module cleaning systems for the solar energy projects are imported from China.The industry has urged the government to support solar developers by considering the situation in China as force majeure and grant extension of scheduled commissioning date without any financial implications to the developer. “The extension granted should be of sufficient time considering the date of complete recovery and the normal condition reinstated,” the report said.

Title: Keep off J&K, it’s our internal affair, India tells Turkey’s president
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

NEW DELHI: After Turkish President Recep Erdogan’s open backing of Pakistan on the Kashmir issue, the government on Saturday strongly rejected his references to J&K, while reiterating that the newly created Union Territory was an integral and inalienable part of India.

The foreign ministry also asked the “Turkish leadership” to not interfere in India’s internal affairs and to develop proper understanding of the facts, including the grave threat posed by terrorism emanating from Pakistan to India and the region.

Addressing a joint session of Pakistan’s parliament, Erdogan had not just said that Turkey will back Pakistan at FATF, where Pakistan is still facing the possibility of being blacklisted for its support to terrorist groups, but also that “Kashmiri brothers and sisters’’ were suffering because of unilateral steps taken (by India).

Erdogan went on to draw a comparison with the battle of Gallipoli, which was fought in Turkey between the Allied Powers and the Ottoman Empire , saying “there is no difference between Gallipoli and Kashmir”.

This though is only the latest in a series of run-ins which India has had with Turkey since its decision last year on August 5 to revoke the special status of J&K state. Along with Malaysia and China, Turkey has openly sided with Pakistan on the issue.

Expressing concerns over India’s decision, it has repeatedly called for resolution of the “problem” through dialogue and within the framework of the “relevant UN resolutions by observing the legitimate interests of all people of Jammu and Kashmir’’. India has in response on several occasions said that statements made by Turkey were not just biased and unwarranted but also factually incorrect.

Erdogan had, in fact, even raised the issue at the UNGA last year, saying that Kashmir was “virtually under blockade with 8 million people, unfortunately, unable to step outside of Kashmir’’. He had said that it was “imperative’’ to solve the problem through dialogue and on the basis of “justice and equity, not through clashes”.

Soon after that, PM Narendra Modi was reported to have cancelled his trip to Turkey. The visit though had never been confirmed by Indian authorities. India’s response to a Turkey offensive in northern Syria in October targeting the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces was also seen in the context of deteriorating ties with Ankara. India had said it was “deeply concerned” over the “unilateral military offensive” by Turkey in northeastern Syria and asserted that the action can undermine stability in the region as well as the fight against terrorism.

Title: Population register creates rift in Maharashtra govt
Content: MUMBAI/PUNE: After the Elgar Parishad row, a fresh rift has opened up in the three-party Maha Vikas Aghadi government in Maharashtra over the National Population Register (NPR) updation, which is set to start in the state from May 1.While Congress and NCP are opposed to NPR and have demanded a joint meeting of all the coalition partners to determine the government’s stand, Shiv Sena has said NPR is in the national interest. CM Uddhav Thackeray earlier this week consented to handing over the Elgar probe to the NIA despite NCP’s objections.The Congress Working Committee had in January passed a resolution saying updation of NPR must be stopped. NPR is a list of “usual residents” of the country but Congress has opposed NPR “in its present form.” “We are against CAA, NCR and NPR. MVA constituents will meet soon and decide the future course of action,” State Congress chief Balasaheb Thorat told TOI.Home minister Anil Deshmukh of NCP, who complained days ago that the CM had “overruled him” on handing over the Elgar probe to NIA, told TOI the three parties need to have a meeting soon to discuss implementation of NPR. “The three parties will have to discuss soon and take a final decision as only after the meeting will a final order be issued,” he said.However, Harshal Pradhan, chief media advisor to CM Thackeray and Sena, said, “NPR and NRC are two different subjects. NPR is related to the census and it is the Centre’s prerogative to implement it.” NCP spokesperson Nawab Malik said, “The entire exercise has created panic among the common people. It appears to be an exercise for harassing people.”Thorat said Congress will study the information sought by the Union home affairs ministry for NPR. “We have been told uncalled-for information has been sought,” he said.In Video: Rift in Maha govt widens over NPR rollout in state

Title: Biryani, foreign funds driving the uneducated to CAA rallies: Bengal BJP president Dilip Ghosh
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

KOLKATA: Bengal BJP president Dilip Ghosh raked up yet another controversy on Saturday by taking a dig at the “uneducated, unaware and poor people” who are “paid and fed biryani with foreign funds” for continuing with protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act. Ghosh’s comment drew scathing criticism from TMC.

Talking about the role of the party in office in Bengal and other Opposition parties in the anti-CAA protests, Ghosh said: “The ruling party (of Bengal) and others have taken to the streets but they don’t have public support. Some uneducated, unaware, poor people have been lured with money and are being fed biryani with foreign funds to continue with the protests,” he said.

Trinamool senior and state parliamentary minister Partha Chatterjee said Ghosh has taken Bengal’s political narrative to a new low. “Is this how a party leader should speak? People are the best judge. But I believe that the BJP leader is deliberately targeting a particular community for narrow political ends,” Chatterjee said. Ghosh had made similar offensive comments earlier, saying that 50 lakh Muslims will be chased out of the country.

On Saturday, explaining the Shaheen Bagh-Park Circus narrative, the Bengal BJP president pointed out how they have become the must-reach destination for those opposing the NDA move. “Park Circus has become a must-visit place for Brinda Karat and Chidambaram . They do not want to address others. Only burqa-clad women with children in their laps are their sole audience,” he added.

Ghosh also didn’t spare intellectuals and students participating in the countrywide protests, from Shaheen Bagh in Delhi to Park Circus in Kolkata. “These people are writing poems, asking people not to show papers. But you have seen during the Delhi assembly polls how the protesters flashed their voter ID cards,” he said.

Title: Rs 1 crore notice to Congress neta for Sec 144 breach
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

BAREILLY: Congress’s Imran Pratapgarhi , who had contested 2019 Lok Sabha polls from Moradabad constituency, has been issued Rs 1.04 crore show cause notice for “violating section 144” by addressing anti-CAA protesters in Moradabad. People have been protesting at the Eidgah since January 29, and such notices, according to an official, are “only precautionary measure to avert violent protests”.

Administrative sources stated that Rs 13.42 lakh is spent per day on the police and paramilitary forces, including one platoon of Rapid Action Force , half section of Provincial Armed Constabulary and police force deployed at the Eidgah. So, the eight-day expense adds up to Rs 1.04 crore.On the notice, Pratapgarhi told TOI on Saturday, “I reached Moradabad on February 7. But, the notice was issued on February 6. I had informed the SP (city) and the administration of my visit . During my address, I also appreciated both for their support.”

Title: Jyotiraditya Scindia leaves meet midway, but Congress says ‘all is well’
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

BHOPAL/DELHI: A day after AICC general secretary Jyotiraditya Scindia said he would hit the streets if manifesto promises weren’t fulfilled by Madhya Pradesh government, his early departure from a review meeting of state Congress on Saturday further deepened the impression of rift. Congress clarified that Scindia had informed in advance that he will leave the meeting early and that all was well in the state.

However, the impression of bitterness in MP Congress only gained ground when CM Kamal Nath made a terse comment in response to Scindia’s threat . Emerging from the review meeting, when Nath was asked by reporters about Scindia’s warning to hit the streets, he shot back: “Let him.”

Differences between CM Nath and Scindia have been out in the open for around eight months after Scindia criticised the Congress government in Madhya Pradesh over crop damage survey, farm loan waiver and, more recently, the demand of agitating contractual teachers to regularise their employment.

The erstwhile royal’s strong words are being linked to the jostling for the post of Madhya Pradesh Congress chief as well as to the Rajya Sabha berth falling vacant soon. The Congress coordination committee met at Nath’s house in the capital. Top state functionaries, including Nath, Digvijaya Singh , AICC general secretary in-charge of MP Deepak Babaria , former Union ministers Scindia and Arun Yadav , and higher education minister Jeetu Patwari attended the meeting.

“It was a very good meeting. Scindia had informed me on Friday that he had other appointments at 12 noon, so he would leave the meeting early,” Babaria told TOI.

“Promise letter is for five years. We have fulfilled many promises and fulfilment of other promises is underway. Scindia Ji is not against anybody. Congress is together under the leadership of Kamal Nath ji,” said Singh.

“The meeting was on the upcoming assembly bypolls in Jaura and Agar-Malwa, and the urban local body polls,” Babaria said.

Title: Haryana: Congress leaders jobless after poll loss, says Subhash Barala
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

BJP state president Subhash Barala at a meeting on Saturday

HISAR: BJP Haryana president Subhash Barala on Saturday said his party’s state government had made “many achievements” during the 100 days it had been power in the state.

In this time, the government has implemented public welfare policies and now Congress leaders are making baseless statements, he said.

Barala said the defeat in 2019 elections had left Congress leaders unemployed. “They are not able to assess the government’s welfare policies and their achievements in a state of desperation. Congress leaders do not want welfare policies to reach people,” he said.

He said the state budget will be presented in the assembly in a few days and chief minister Manohar Lal Khattar wanted it to be in accordance with the aspirations of the people. “With the same objective, the opinion of all sections of society of all districts have been taken into account,” he said.

He added all MLAs had been given Rs 5 crore for development in their constituencies as soon as the BJP came to power in the state. “Under the Parivar Samriddhi Yojana, a provision has been made to provide financial assistance to every eligible family whose annual income is lesst than Rs 1.8 lakh. We plan to open medical colleges in every district, provide 24-hour power in every village,” he said.

Title: Nine new privately run trains from Rajasthan to aid connectivity
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: The Union budget announcement of allowing private players to operate 150 trains on 100 identified routes will also benefit rail passengers of six cities in Rajasthan in getting connected to other cities. These trains, from super luxury to normal category, would operate soon after the tender process would be over by the railway board.Six trains would operate from Jaipur and one each from Ajmer, Kota and Jodhpur to various destinations across the country. “Trains would run from Jaipur to Kota, Jaipur to Ajmer, Jaipur to Udhampur, Jaipur to Mumbai, Jaipur to Delhi and Jaipur to Bengaluru to start with. The private players will have to give Rs 668 per km and will also give a bigger chunk of revenue sharing on the route. During the tenders, whoever will promise to give a bigger percentage of their revenue would be given the tenders,” said a senior officer of commercial wing of the north western railway on condition of anonymity.Asked about the composition of these trains and other logistics, an officer said, “Hopefully, these trains would run on the lines of Tejas Express, having well-dressed housekeeping staff and food and beverages staff. The private players would have two options.
