While traveling towards Karnataka on the national highway, one has to take right deviation after Tawandi ghat towards Gadhinglaj and then go towards Bagilge, crossing Mahagaon, Nesari, Adkur, Naganwadi and Tambulwadi villages to reach the ancient temple located on the road side. Along with the temple, one can also visit Mahipalgad fort and Gandharvgad fort located nearby. Ibrahimpur, located in the close vicinity of the temple also hosts the same kind of ancient Hemadpanti temples.

Legends have it

This temple is known in the vicinity as Prachin Shiv Mandir. Sadanand Gurav, the priest of the temple, said, “This temple of Lord Shiva is a perfect example of Hemadpanti architecture and thus many historians and those interested in architecture keep visiting this place. The stone carvings are one of its kinds. Proper care was taken to provide ventilation in the temple, with plenty of light vents in those eras as well. At present, the condition of the temple is not good. It has been partially damaged and the temple needs immediate restoration to conserve the beauty of the temple.”

Flora and Fauna

Bagilge and its surroundings are home to several varieties of flower and butterfly species. Sachin Mane, a wildlife photographer, said, “This place is located amidst nature and is home to several species. It has several species of medicinal plants and herbs around it. Karvee, jamun, banyan and bamboo trees can be found in plenty here. Butterflies are one of the main attractions for the tourists here with species like sleepy orange, blue tiger, grey pansy, common sailor, lemon pansy, great egg fly and common crow found flying all around here.”

Title: After CM Ashok Gehlot rap, Kota collector gives pension order to widow
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Kota collector Om Prakash Kasera

KOTA: A day after chief minister Ashok Gehlot made Kota collector Om Prakash Kasera read out the complaint of 60-year-old widow Yasmeen during a video conference, the collector on Saturday handed over the sanction order to her for pension under the government’s widow pension scheme at her residence in Anantpura. He also apologised to her for making her wait six months.

Yasmeen’s husband died on September 21, 2019 but she could not avail of the benefits of the scheme as she didn’t possess a Jan Aadhaar card.

After the death of her husband, religious restrictions kept her indoors for four months, which prevented her from fulfilling necessary formalities for pension in time.

After a complaint was lodged on the Sampark portal, district officials had to treat the case in special category. “First, I would like to apologise for making you wait for around six months for a simple issue,” said Kasera with folded hands as he handed over the pension order to her. Now, she will get Rs 700 per month.

The collector also handed over a cheque of Rs 5,000 from his personal account and assured her all possible assistance from the government.

Kasera also directed an official to arrange a contractual job for Yasmeen’s daughter in Kota Municipal Corporation. He also asked officials to add Yasmeen’s family to the Below Poverty Level (BPL) list so that they can avail of the benefits of food security and free medical schemes.

“While applying for widow pension, she did not fill up the form, which is required to be filled up at an e-mitra centre. When she was contacted, she was performing some rituals following the death of her husband. Hence, she could not step out of her house for four months. That’s why she failed to fulfill the formalities,” Kasera told TOI on Sunday.

“Treating the case in a special category, we sent the officials to Yasmeen’s residence to open her bank account and to make her Jan Adhaar card,” he added. “Issuance of Jan Adhaar card takes a certain amount of time and while the process was underway, the matter was raised during the video conference where the chief minister expressed displeasure.”

Title: Run-down BU hostel haunts students
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Bhopal: A kitchen with no utensils, stinking beds and an empty sports room. Welcome to Barkatullah University (BU)’s Jawahar hostel right in the heart of the state capital.

BU’s has three boys’ hostels on its campus—named after late Congress leader Sanjay Gandhi, writer Munshi Premchand and country’s first Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru—each with a capacity to accommodate 100 students.

Students at the Jawahar hostel say their rooms are in such a bad shape that they can easily pass off as haunted houses.

“It resembles a haunted place from some old Bollywood movie. A few days ago, a snake was found curled inside a student’s room. Wardens hardly pay any heed. We are told that huge money is being allotted for maintenance and upkeep of the hostels every year. They should come and spend a day here and see where all the money goes,” says a student requesting anonymity.

Heaps of filth, waterlogged pits and defunct lights are the order of the day, say students.

“Do we really need to raise our voice for utensils in the kitchen? Such is the situation in the hostel of a university situated right in the middle of the state capital,” said another student. Students have been drinking water from an overhead tank, which most of them say, has not been cleaned for years.

Students say the hostels are in urgent need of maintenance. On Saturday, they submitted an application to university authorities.

“Imagine a situation where you don’t have anything to sleep on. Old and stinking beds have made the situation even worst for us. In the absence of basic hygiene, many students are not keeping well,” said another student.

University’s registrar, B Bharti, said: “I have directed the officials to provide kitchen utensils immediately. Students will get it by Monday,” said Bharti.

Asked about beds in bad shape, Bharti said: “I have also accepted this demand. Students will get within a month all such stuff,” adding “sports equipment and a gym will also be made available.”

Title: After mayor frowns at tardy progress, SCTL forms panel
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: With projects entering the execution phase , Smart City Thiruvananthapuram Ltd ( SCTL ) has decided to constitute a four-member sub-committee to monitor on-site execution of works. This was decided at the board meeting, held on Friday, after mayor K Sreekumar raised apprehensions over the progress of the projects and the lack of regular updates.

In a recent review meeting at the corporation office, the mayor had pulled up SCTL staff for tardy progress. He voiced concern that nothing concrete was being done on the field and that staff had failed in updating the corporation about the timely execution of works.

On Friday, Sreekumar said it was imperative for the civic body to keep tabs on the progress of ‘Smart City’ projects. The mayor will chair the sub-committee, with representatives of the secretaries of PWD, LSGD and SCTL CEO as members.

“We are nearing completion of situation analysis, feasibility study, detailed project report, administrative and technical sanctions. We are moving into execution phase and once that begins, there would be like over 50 work sites and that would require constant monitoring. That’s why we have formed a sub-committee,” said SCTL CEO P Bala Kiran.

The city mayor said the sub-committee will go a long way in expediting implementation of works. “The execution of works has been a matter of concern and hopefully it will be addressed with the formation of the sub-committee,” Sreekumar said.

The board also approved six projects to the tune of Rs 347.16 crore. Once the minutes of the meeting are approved, administrative sanction will be given for the projects. Based on Smart City proposal grant from the centre and shares from state and city corporation, detailed project reports for projects worth Rs 1,122.05 crore have been completed. Administrative sanction has been given for projects worth Rs 937.84 crore and technical sanction accorded for projects worth Rs 584.97 crore. Works worth Rs 205.14 crore have been tendered and Rs 10.45 crore works have been awarded.

SCTL plans to tender all works by March.

It issued a tender for the Rs 83 crore redevelopment of Palayam market on Saturday. The project involves design, supply and installation of prefabricated structures for construction of a rehabilitation block for existing vendors, site clearance and construction of a new market building, design, supply and installation and maintenance of a electro-mechanical car parking system within the basement of the proposed market building.

Title: Five held with narcotics in separate raids in Rajasthan
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: The Special Operations Group (SOG) arrested two persons accused of smuggling narcotics across the state and recovered 1.5kg cannabis from them.

The accused Ankush Singh, 24, and Upesh Thagariya, 22 were nabbed with balls of the banned substance hidden in their jackets.

Anil Paliwal, ADG, SOG & ATS, said, “We received information that the accused were getting ‘charas’ from Himachal Pradesh and supplying it in various parts of Rajasthan. We tracked the accused and arrested them.”

According to officials, the recovered drug was of very high quality and would fetch a good price.

“The accused got high quality cannabis for around Rs 1 lakh and would sell it at ten times the price. In places where the availability is less, the cost would be even higher,” added the official. Both the accused were arrested in Jaipur. They are being questioned further.

Jaipur police also arrested three people from different parts of the city and seized approximately 5kg marijuana. The accused were arrested from Sanganer and Muhana police stations areas. Bunty Bairwa was arrested from Sanganer police station area with 2.5kg of marijuana who during questioning said he got the narcotics from Tonk and supplied it in Jaipur. In Muhana, Radheshyam and Satyanarayan were caught with the remaining quantity. Since October last year, city police has registered 238 cases and arrested 285 people for dealing in narcotics.

Title: Trump visit: 1.2 lakh guests to walk 1.5km to say namaste!
Content:
U.S President Donald Trump and first lady Melania Trump would visit India on 24-25 February. (AP)

AHMEDABAD: Except VIPs and VVIPs, everybody attending the Motera stadium event will have to walk 1.5km, city police officials said on Saturday. About 1.2 lakh persons will participate in the ‘Namaste President Trump’ event on February 24.Vijay Patel, DCP (control), told media on Saturday that 28 plots have been identified for parking buses and other vehicles. “These plots are in the radius of 1.5km of the stadium and thus the guests will not have to walk much,”he said. “We will conduct trials for vehicle routes coming from outside the city to prevent jams on February 24.”Patel said that five major teams have been formed to manage the security of the airport reception, the Sabarmati Ashram, the road show, the event at the Motera stadium, and overall traffic. “In all, more than 11,000 police officers and personnel will be deployed,” he said.City police officials reiterated that no person without a card bearing his/her name will be allowed inside the stadium. “In all, 120 entry points will be set up with doorframe metal detectors. Handheld metal detectors will also be used at these points,” said Patel. “Provisions have been made to admit the entire audience after frisking them in two-and-a-half to three hours.”Officials from the NSG and other elite agencies arrived in Ahmedabad on Saturday. State DGP and othe r senior officials conducted two presentations on the overall security plan and discussed coordination, said sources.

Title: Family overjoyed as Varanasi rickshaw-puller receives letter from PM Modi on daughter's wedding
Content:
PM’s letter was received by Kewat on Thursday

VARANASI: A letter from PM Narendra Modi congratulating and blessing Sakshi, daughter of a rikshaw puller Mangala Prasad Kewat hailing from PM’s adopted Domari village doubled the joy of marriage celebrations. The PM’s letter (dated February 3) was received by Kewat on Thursday.Being the resident of PM’s adopted village Kewat had sent his daughter’s wedding invite to Delhi and local office. “PM’s letter came as a great surprise as well as joy to the family,” said Kewat. Kewat is a big fan of Modi and active member of Swachh Bharat Campaign.

Title: Orthodox faction takes over church at Koothattukulam
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Jacobite faction members protest after Orthodox faction arrived with police to take over St Stephen’s Church o... Read More

KOCHI: St Stephen’s Church at Koothattukulam was taken over by the Orthodox faction on Saturday amid high drama as the Jacobite faction protested when the Orthodox faction arrived with police protection to ‘conduct holy mass’ in the morning.

Earlier, the high court had issued an order to provide police cover to the Orthodox faction to conduct prayers at the church. Police used force to control the unruly protesters and 23 of them were arrested and removed from the church’s premises.

The Jacobite faction condemned the police action. “The act of authorities and the police of evicting a Ramban (a senior priest), priests and devotees from their place of worship and cutting open the lock of the church is denial of justice. It is inhumane,” said the Jacobite faction in a statement.

“Most of the faithful, belonging to the church, are Jacobites and the church was taken over and given to the minority (around 10 families) belonging to the Orthodox faction,” said Jacobite faction members.

The Orthodox faction entered the church and conducted holy mass after police removed the protesters. “No devotee was forced out. Only those who were creating a ruckus and protested against the observance of prayers at the place of worship were removed by the police,” said Fr John Abraham Konnatt of Orthodox church.

“Maccabi (Malankara Action Council for Church Act bill implementation) and Kerala Christian Reformation Movement (KCRM) members also took part in the protest. Implementing the Church Act as it is only the long-term solution,” said Indulekha Joseph of KCRM.

It was on Tuesday that the high court ordered the government to provide police protection so that the Orthodox faction can conduct religious rituals as per the Supreme Court judgement issued in this regard. Earlier, Orthodox faction had returned after facing protest from Jacobite parishioners, when they arrived to implement the order at St Stephen’s Church. Yuhanon Ramban of Piramadam Dayara church, director of Maccabi was also arrested and removed from the spot.

Title: Commissioner set to take charge of BMC after council term ends on Feb 18
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Bhopal: The tenure of Bhopal Municipal Corporation (BMC) elected council ends on February 18. With elections to the civic body some time away, the state government would be required to appoint an administrator till such time the new council is in place.

The administrator will have his work cut out to manoeuvre the cash-strapped civic body in the next few months. Sources indicate that it could be a few months, before civic body polls are held.

As per municipal rules, divisional commissioner is expected to become the administrator, said top government officials.

Bhopal is also a part of smart cities mission and land monetisation for smart city development is expected to take place in the next few weeks. Government plans to raise over Rs 10,000 crore from private participation and lease of land along TT Nagar. The area based development (ADB) under smart city in the area is planned in 350 acre.

Action on Swachh Bharat mission, which includes completion of solid waste management and disposal at Adampur Chhwani along with construction of new abattoir facility, as per NGT orders would also be a priority. “We did our best. Some of the directives were to be met by urban development department,” said outing mayor, Alok Shamra.

“We are prepared to take the failures of the BJP-led BMC council to the public. There are numerous scams that have taken place while several public interest projects delayed. Handover of 350 colonies could not be accomplished, master plan roads could not be completed and the new master plan could not be implemented,” said local Congress leader, Girish Sharma.

In the current council, BJP enjoyed a two-third majority. Now, the ruling Congress government is expected to pace the development in the state capital ahead of local body elections in 85 wards. Another issue pending, which has been challenged in court is the division of BMC into two municipal councils, said political observers.

Over the last five years, while there has been a separate surcharge on waste collection, property tax was not increased. Over the past two weeks, senior state government officials have already sought a report on supply of piped water during summers. With bountiful monsoon last year, supply of uninterrupted water could prove to be a boon for the Congress government.

Development of metro rail in Bhopal along with proposed addition of new public transport buses are expected to gain momentum in the coming months.

Title: Fire erupts as shopkeeper ‘tests’ cracker
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Jaipur: Around seven shops located in the Indira Market of the Walled City were gutted in a devastating fire on Saturday afternoon.

The fire broke out in a cracker shop in the area and in no time engulfed the nearby structures. Around 21 fire tenders were pressed to douse the flames. The crew battled hard for four hours to control the fire.

Chief fire officer (CFO) Jagdish Phulwari, said, “The fire was controlled in time, otherwise it could have been bigger as shops are adjoined in the narrow market. No causalty was reported during the operation. Our team member Naveen Kumar was injured but is now stable. A total of 21 fire tenders made three rounds during the operation.”

The incident occurred around 12.30pm. There was widespread panic as soon as the inferno raged through the shutter with thousands of visitors, who thronged the market, running helter-skelter. Though, officials have not ascertained the cause of fire, eyewitnesses claimed it erupted due to the carelessness of the cracker shop owner. Rashid Khan, who works in a nearby shop, said, “The owner was testing a party cracker. The spark fell on other crackers which led to the incident.”

Cops cordoned off the area to keep spectators at bay. However, many a times the tenders struggled to reached on the spot as vehicles were parked haphazardly. A fire tender also hit an ambulance parked in the middle of the lane while rushing to the spot.

Shopkeepers alleged that there are more cracker shops in the area and administration has turned a blind eye towards them. A shopkeeper, on condition of anonymity, said, “Right next to my shop there is an influential cracker shop owner. This is a market for garments and not explosive items. Despite several complaints no action has been taken as officers claim he has licence to sell crackers.”

Phulwari, however, said, “The cracker shop owner where the fire occured did not take any NOC from JMC. We will take action against the remaining shopkeepers of the area.”

Title: First-time MP is new BJP chief in MP
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Bhopal: Madhya Pradesh BJP has got a new party president — first-time MP V D Sharma. Like Rakesh Singh before him, 49-year-old Sharma emerged as the dark horse as seniors like Shivraj Singh Chouhan, Rakesh Singh and Narottam Mishra were overlooked.

The announcement on Saturday took most of the party rank and file by surprise, say sources. One of the youngest leaders to be made state party president, Sharma is known to be a go-getter and joined BJP in 2013.

It’s believed Sharma was elevated over other big names being considered for the post during RSS chief Mohan Bhagwat’s weeklong trip to Bhopal earlier this month.

A former ABVP national general secretary, he has the full backing of RSS but doesn’t have a base yet in the state BJP. In fact, a section of BJP workers had burned his effigies when he was named party candidate from Khajuraho for the 2019 Lok Sabha polls, but he won.Despite initial opposition from within, he won by 5 lakh votes. The coming civic election is his first challenge. Sharma, who hails from Morena in MP, is an MSc in agriculture.He started with ABVP and has been in active politics for almost 32 years, recognized as a grass roots Brahmin leader in MP. He has studied pollution in Narmada and filed a case with NGT.

With Sharma being handed the party reins, the Madhya Pradesh BJP unit now has Brahmins in two key posts — the other being leader of opposition Gopal Bhargava.

Sharma thanked PM Narendra Modi, home minister Amit Shah and BJP president J P Nadda for giving “a normal party worker like him” responsibility of the party in the state. On the Kamal Nath government, he said: “Is sarkar ki eint se eint baja dange.”

Chief minister Kamal Nath congratulated Sharma and tweeted: “I hope to get his cooperation for development, progress and welfare of people of the state.”

Greetings poured in for Sharma. State BJP leaders, including Chouhan, congratulated Sharma. Party sources say Chouhan, a former state party chief, was considered a strong candidate for the post yet again, and that he wanted one of his trusted lieutenants, like Bhupendra Singh or Rajendra Shukla, to get the post. Rakesh Singh said he is happy that state party unit is getting a “young and dynamic leader”. “I was informed by the party in advance,” he added.

In Singh’s tenure, BJP lost power in 2018 after ruling MP for 15 years and bounced back with a stunning sweep of the Lok Sabha polls less than six months later, winning 28 of 29 seats in the state. By appointing a young state president, BJP seems to be moving ahead with its plan to prepare a new line of leadership. In the recent appointment of ‘mandal’ heads, the party stuck to leaders below 40 years of age and district presidents cannot be above 50.

Sources say Sharma will constitute his new team, unlike his predecessor who did not make any changes in the state organizational structure after his appointment in April 2018. Rakesh Singh, a trusted lieutenant of Amit Shah, was trying for a second term and had organised a grand pro-CAA rally in his Lok Sabha constituency, Jabalpur, last month which was attended by Amit Shah. However, sources in BJP say he lost out because it was perceived that he had not been able to corner the Congress government in MP, couldn’t create a wave in favour of CAA and NRC in the state, and neither could he stem the scores of resignations by minority community members from the party.

One of the biggest embarrassments for Singh was the voting of two BJP MLAs with Congress in assembly in July 2019, which took the party completely by surprise. Despite the setbacks, Singh was confident his tenure may continue till the civic polls in October. Party sources say he will now be accommodated in the Centre.

Title: Church issues norms on priests’ social media conduct
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Kottayam: The Malankara Orthodox Syrian Church has issued strict guidelines for its priests including their conduct on social media. The priests have been asked not to react on social media platforms against the interest of the Church.

Strict action awaits priests if they react against the interest of the Church on Facebook, WhatsApp or Twitter, according to the guidelines. The priests are also barred from posting photographs of themselves on social media wearing an attire other than that of a clergy.

Hereafter, the metropolitan will also keep a confidential report of every single priest. He will also keep the service book of all the priests. This will be implemented from April 1, 2020.

Only those priests who are assigned by the Church can speak on social media platforms about the stand of the Church on various issues. The priest are also not allowed to resort to any campaign on social media using followers for gaining personal fame. The priests are also barred from borrowing money from parish members for their personal needs. They will also have to file a monthly working report in time to the metropolitan of the diocese.

If any priest violates the guidelines, action will be taken against him and the metropolitan of the concerned diocese will have the right to impose pay cuts.

Title: Honour killing: Dad held for teen’s murder near Mandu
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Mhow: In a suspected honour killing, a 17-year-old girl was forced to drink pesticide and her throat was slit by a cousin, at the instance of her father, because she refused to end her relationship with a boy from another caste, police in MP’s Dhar said on Saturday.

The girl’s body was found beside Satghata Nullah near the tourist destination of Mandu, about 90km from Indore, on February 7. For the first five days, police struggled to identify the victim. Then, informers tipped them off that a schoolgirl was missing from missing from Patliyapura village, about 25km from where the body was found.

Police met the family, asked them why they hadn’t filed a missing person’s report, and took back a picture of the missing girl. It matched with the murder victim and she was identified as Roshni, a Class 12 student.

During investigation, police found that her family was furious with her for having a relationship with a boy from a different caste in the same village. The girl was a Bhil, and the boy is from Bhilala community. He, too, is a minor.

“Roshni’s father Ishwar Singh broke down during interrogation and confessed that he conspired to kill her. He asked Roshni’s cousin Mukesh and his friend Prithvi to murder her and dispose the body after she refused to break up with the boy,” said Dhar SP Aditya Pratap Singh.

On February 6, Mukesh and Prithvi took Roshni to Mandu in a car on the pretext of sightseeing. While returning, they force-fed her pesticides, rendering her unconscious, the SP said. “They stuffed her in the boot of the car and drove towards Satghata Nullah, where Mukesh slit her throat with a knife. The body was dumped on the roadside,” he added.

Police arrested all three on Friday. They were produced in court on Saturday and remanded in jail.

Title: AI-based tech for autistic kids lands startup Rs 50L grant
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Embright Infotech members who developed Auticare (extended reality)

Thiruvananthapuram: A crowded shopping mall could be an autistic kid’s worst nightmare. Imagine a therapist gently guiding the child through the mall where he/she doesn’t feel threatened or disturbed by fellow shoppers. This is one among the various scenarios Auticare , an extended reality (XR), artificial intelligence-based assistive technology developed by Technopark-based startup Embright Infotech , could provide to help children with autism-spectrum disorders manage life situations.

Auticare has helped the firm land the central department of science and technology’s highest innovation grant of Rs 50 lakh.

Embright, which specializes in virtual reality, augmented reality, internet of things and artificial intelligence (AI), is one of 15 companies to bag the Biotechnology Industry Research Assistance Council Biotechnology Ignition Grant (BIRAC BIG15).

This is the third governmental recognition for the firm, which had earlier cornered KSIDC’s entrepreneurial development fund and Nidhi Prayas grant. In 2019, Embright was one of 20 firms that reached the fourth round of BIRAC BIG14.

Founded in 2017 by A R Sathyanarayanan and Bobin Chandra, Embright has associated with the Kerala social security mission. “Auticare is being used in 12 therapy clinics under the social security mission. It helps with cognitive, social and self-care skills of autistic children through assistive technology based on XR and AI,” Sathyanarayanan, chief executive, told TOI.

He said Auticare was inspired by his mother, who has a PhD in clinical linguistics.

Title: Right to Health Bill may be tabled in assembly
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Jaipur: Much-awaited Right to Health Bill, which was announced by Raghu Sharma when he took over as health minister after winning the assembly elections, might be tabled in the ongoing budget session. The Bill was part of election manifesto of the Congress.

Though the health department has been preparing it for quite some time but the draft was yet to take the final shape. However, senior health department officials said that they are not sure that it will be tabled in the ongoing assembly session.

By bringing the Act, the state government is aiming to provide treatment to the most underprivileged person of the state.

The health department has taken help of the NGOs, working in health sector, for preparing the draft of the Bill. The NGOs have come out with their own draft framework for the Bill which was thoroughly discussed and submitted to the government. Chhaya Pachauli, a health rights activist, said that the draft essentially consists of three key sections which includes roles and obligations of the health department and the service providers, the rights of the users/patients and the implementation and monitoring mechanisms.

She said that the Act would ensure that the state is obligated to make sure that the right to access to quality health services and other underlying determinants of health, such as sanitation and food, is assured to everyone in the state and that the government takes adequate measures to ensure the same.

“While states like Assam and Kerala do have Public Health Acts in place, there’s no state which has yet introduced a Right to Health Act. Rajasthan, if it brings about this Act, would be the first one to do so and this would be a major step ahead towards meeting the goal of universal healthcare,” she said.

The NGOs have for long been advocating for a Right to Health Act to be brought about in the state.

Title: Maharashtra deputy CM Ajit Pawar wants two-tier flyovers on PMRDA’s Metro corridor
Content:
The University flyover in Shivajinagar

TimesView The proposal is shocking to say the least, and will lead to a massive wastage of public money. Pune city has already suffered due to a lack of long-term and scientific planning, not to mention misguided designs for flyovers. There is a complete lack of continuity, when it comes to traffic and transportation issues. The comprehensive mobility plan has become a mere showpiece and politicians rush in with new plans to show that they are doing some work. Citizens will have to join forces to foil such fancy ideas if they want to prevent further hardships and wastage of money through demolition and reconstruction of the flyovers.

New line’s report submitted

PUNE: Deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar has directed Pune Metropolitan Regional Development Authority (PMRDA) to explore the possibility of a two-tier flyovers — comprising a vehicular thoroughfare and a Metro viaduct — at three key junctions in the city.PMRDA is developing the Hinjewadi-Shivajinagar corridor of the Pune Metro rail project. If implemented, the proposal would entail the demolition of the existing flyovers at University Chowk , E-Square Chowk and RBI Chowk.The proposal calls for the flyover and the Metro viaduct to come up on the same pillars, along the lines of the double-decker flyover coming up at Nal Stop on Karve Road.So far, the authorities had considered the possibility of maintaining the existing University flyover and construct the elevated Metro line above it.Sources in the state government told TOI that with the 2022 deadline for all the Metro lines to become operational, Pawar’s fresh directive could cause a delay and also increase the project cost by over Rs600 crore. “These flyovers were constructed between 2007-10. Their demolition would put a huge burden on state exchequer,” a senior government official said.As per the agreement between the project executor and PMRDA signed last September, March-end was the date for the financial closure of the project, within three years of which the project must be completed. “Demolishing the flyover and re-constructing a two-tier structure would extend the operational period by two more years. This would be a violation of the agreement,” a source said.Meanwhile, transport experts from the city have opposed the construction of the Metro lines with flyovers. “Why give the option of taking out one’s private vehicle when there is a Metro line on the same route?” one expert said.The Delhi Metro Rail Corporation (DMRC) has submitted the initial project report for the proposed 18km elevated Shivajinagar-Shewalwadi Metro corridor. PMRDA officials said DMRC would soon ready the detailed project report (DPR).

Title: Rape survivor seeks court’s permission to terminate pregnancy, Rajasthan High Court issues notices

This story is from February 16, 2020

Title: Chargesheet soon in Pratap Nagar double murder case
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Jaipur: City police will file the chargesheet in the mother-son murder case in Pratap Nagar before the end of this month with the cops claiming that the investigation is nearly complete.

Shweta and her 18-month-old son were murdered on January 7. Three days later, her husband Rohit and his friend Saurabh Chaudhary were arrested. Both are currently in judicial custody.

“The investigation is nearly complete and it would not be long before we file the chargesheet in the case. We have enough evidence for a strong case against the two including scientific and digital proof,” a police officer said.

Though the FSL report is yet to come, officials claimed that its finding can be added in the chargesheet later.

Following the arrests, police had constituted a special team to frame the chargesheet in the double murder case which had sent shock waves across the city.

Rohit had paid Saurabh Rs 20,000 for the murders and had promised to pay more once the crime was executed.

During the investigation, cops also hinted at the possibility that the two actually had a pact to kill each other’s spouses due to marital discord.

While Shweta’s body was found in her house, the son’s body was found in the forest area just across the boundary wall of the residential complex where the family resided.

Saurabh had hit Shweta multiple times on the head with a blunt object before slitting her throat. He used the same weapon on the infant and strangled him to be doubly sure of the death.

Police caught up to him when he was seen leaving the house with the baby’s body in the neighbour’s CCTV camera. When the two accused were brought in front of each other, they confessed to the crime.

Title: Mah forest dept showcases tiger conservation at global convention
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Nagpur: The Maharashtra forest department will showcase its tiger conservation efforts at the 13th Conference of Parties (COP) to Convention on Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals (CMS COP-13) at Gandhinagar, Gujarat , between February 15 and 22, 2020.

The conference is being attended by representatives from 130 parties, including ministers from various countries, international inter-government and civil society organizations, experts, state governments among others.

As part of CMS-COP 13, side events, exhibitions, high level panel discussions have been organized for showcasing India’s diversity of ecosystems, landscapes and key conservation initiatives taken in the country for wildlife and habitat.

To conserve and protect migratory species, an international convention under the aegis of the United Nation’s Environment Programme — Convention on Migratory Species (CMS)’ is in force.

Presently, there are 130 parties to the CMS. It provides a global platform for conservation of migratory species, their habitats and migration routes. It brings together the states through which migratory animals pass the range states and lays the legal foundation for internationally coordinated conservation measures throughout a migratory range.

India became a party to the convention in November 1983. Over 176 species listed in appendices of CMS are found in India out of which 115 are found or migrate in Maharashtra, which includes green turtle, leatherback turtle, dugong, besides 135 bird species in Central Asian Flyway (CAF) etc

The Maharashtra forest department has taken various efforts in conservation of these species and restoration of their habitat. An Indian pavilion has been organized as part of CMS-COP 13 in Gujarat to exhibit India’s efforts in conservation of environment, wildlife, habitat restoration, climate change, mitigation of human wildlife conflict, wetland conservation etc

The state forest department is participating in collaboration with NTCA in the India pavilion to showcase department’s efforts in the field of tiger conservation. Besides, eight side events have also been organized based on various themes.

The department is also participating in these side events under the theme — Landscape conservation and management planning, marine animal conservations in collaboration with Salim Ali Centre for Ornithology and Natural History ( SACON ), Coimbatore, and Wildlife Institute of India (WII), Dehradun.

Title: Kem Chho Trump: Hotels houseful on February 23, 24
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

U.S President Donald Trump and first lady Melania Trump would visit India on 24-25 February. (AFP)

AHMEDABAD: With several delegates from the US and from across India visiting Ahmedabad for the ‘Namaste President Trump’ event, most 4-star and five-star hotels in Ahmedabad are operating at 100% occupancy on February 23 and 24. Apart from the Trump trip , the peak wedding season, and the movement of business travellers will boost hotel occupancy.

“Several rooms have been booked for the delegates arriving for the US president’s event,” said the spokesperson of Renaissance Ahmedabad Hotel. “Because of the wedding season, several rooms were booked in advance. Our hotel has been completely sold out on February 23 and 24.”

Subhrajit Bardhan, the general manager of DoubleTree By Hilton, Ahmedabad, said: “The US Embassy has blocked 80 rooms at our hotel and delegates will start arriving from February 22.” Corporate events and the wedding season have kept the hotel nearly full, Bardhan said. “We’re left with a handful of rooms for both days and it is expected that they will be sold out,” Bardhan said.

“Our hotel was fully booked even before the US president’s visit was confirmed, since this is the peak season for corporate events and weddings,” said Sonika Chaturvedi, the general manager of Courtyard by Marriott.

The presidential suite along with other rooms have been blocked for the US president and the first lady at Hyatt Regency on Ashram Road, sources said.

Title: Jaipur airport gets new swanky departure hall
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

AAI chairman Arvind Singh inaugurates the departure hall on Saturday

JAIPUR: In a move to de-congest the Jaipur airport during rush hour, the Airport Authority of India (AAI), Jaipur has started a new departure hall in an area of 2,700 square metre. The new hall has eight check-in counters, extra washrooms and other passenger’s amenities.

AAI chairman Arvind Singh inaugurated the departure hall on Saturday.

However, various airlines are yet to open their counters due to technical glitches. According to sources, 3.9 million passengers had travelled from Jaipur airport from January to December 2019.

While speaking reporters, Singh said, “On the instructions of the Union government, the AAI started the process of privatizing six airports in the country. For this a memorandum of Understanding (MOU) has also been signed on Friday for the privatization of Lucknow, Ahmedabad and Mangaluru airports.”

However, AAI is awaiting the final approval for the privatization of other three airports, including Jaipur, Guwahati and Trivandrum.

On the new departure hall, director (AAI), Jaipur, Jaideep Singh Balhara, said, “We have got eight new check-in counters and the passengers would be able to go for boarding through escalators. New facilities for drinking water and washrooms have been added for the passengers in the new hall. The new hall has also been connected to the existing departure hall. It has also been connected to the boarding gate number 2 and 3 on the second floor.”

With the boarding gate attached to the new hall, passengers will also have the option of going directly to the flight.

Apart from airport director, all heads of departments, CISF commandant Y P Singh and representatives of airlines were also present at the launch event.

New check-in counters have been installed in the new departure hall without any connection with SITA software needed to issue boarding pass. Currently, no airlines have started its operations in the new departure hall. “We will start this in next couple of days,” said Jaideep Singh Balhara, director (AAI), Jaipur.

Title: Agri body offers training to farmers to process cinnamon
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Panaji: In a bid to propagate cinnamon farming in the state, ICAR-Central Coastal Agricultural Research Institute (CCARI) will be providing specialised cinnamon processing training.

“There is good scope for cinnamon cultivation, especially since the condiment is very good for those with diabetes and blood pressure,” ICAR-CCARI director EB Chakurkar said.

He said the cinnamon available in the market – the thick-bark-type Acacia variety – is not always of good quality. The variety grown by ICAR meanwhile is a thin-bark variety which attracts anywhere between Rs 800 to 1000 per kg. “It is a pure form of cinnamon that can be grown easily as an intercrop. We can train farmers to grow and process it,” he said.

Chakurkar said farmers can directly sell the same to the Goa Bagayatdar, thus avoiding involvement of middlemen. “But farmers must come forward, themselves. Cinnamon is a slow growing crop. If farmers are interested, we can help,” he said.

ICAR itself has nearly 100 cinnamon plants growing on its Old Goa property.

Title: KC’s Jacob faction headed for a split?
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Kottayam: The Kerala Congress (Jacob) group is heading for a split as the two groups in the party have called separate meetings on the same day in Kottayam. Party leader Anoop Jacob called a meeting at the state committee office of the party here while party chairman Johny Nellore called a meeting at KPS Menon hall on February 21. The Johny Nellore group wants the party to merge with Joseph group in Kerala Congress (M) while Anoop Jacob group is against the merger.

Speaking to reporters on Saturday, Jacob said that his aim is to strengthen the party. At the meeting called by jacob on Saturday, 11 of the 16 state office-bearers of the party, and 10 of the 14 district presidents were present. District presidents of Ernakulam, Kannur and Kasaragod are supporting Nellore.

Palakkad district president took a leave, said Jacob. In the 70-member hi-power committee of the party, 42 took part in the meeting called by Jacob. The meeting decided against a merger with Joseph group and decided to strengthen the party. Working president Vakkanad Radhakrishnan presided over the event.

Title: Additional toll booths at lanes at Khed-Shivapur toll plaza
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Pune: The Pune collector Naval Kishore Ram has directed the National Highway Authority of India (NHAI) to build additional toll booths and lanes at the Khed-Shivapur toll plaza to ease congestion.

The first phase of the work at the Khed-Shivapur toll plaza would be completed by February 25 and the next phase would be completed by March 31.

New deadlines were set, post a meeting held on Friday evening, for the work on the Pune-Satara stretch to be completed. The road repairs and construction of the necessary bridges will be completed by the end of March. The concessionaire Reliance Infrastructure will complete the remaining work by the end of May.

In the meeting, the NHAI and the concessionaire assured to speed up the repair works.

The work of increasing the toll booths from Satara to Pune will be completed first by February 25. Internet services too would be strengthened in the area to enable FASTag services, the collector said.

The NHAI officials who attended the meeting told TOI that the necessary instructions were given to the concessionaire. “The contractor Reliance Infrastructure has assured us that all the road work will be completed as per the new deadlines,” Suhas Chitnis, the project director of NHAI, said.

Amit Bhatia, the regional head of the west region of Reliance Infrastucture said that five additional booths and lanes from Satara to Pune would be added to the existing 10 lanes to ease down the traffic congestion on weekends. The three additional booths to the existing 10 lanes towards Satara were expected to be operational by March 31.

He said additional manpower of 30 personnel would be deployed on weekends with hand held machines to issue tickets while waiting in the lane. The vehicles would be able to cross the toll plaza by showing the receipt.

The concessionaire also agreed to complete work for the bridge at Dhangewadi and Verve by March 31, while the balance work including street lights (proposed as per concession agreement) and service road (where land is free of encumbrances) would be completed by May 31.

While earlier there was a discussion about shifting the toll both, a government source said it was not feasible as the concession agreement with Reliance Infrastructure was done for a period of 24 years (2010-2034) and the toll booths were constructed accordingly. “If the toll booths are to be shifted, they have to adhere to the guidelines of 60km distance between two toll booths and the state government would have to bear all the shifting charges,” a senior government official said.

The Baramati MP Supriya Sule and MLA Sangram Thopte in the past led protests to close the toll plaza, which have become a major obstacle for commuters because of the traffic congestion. In December, the Pune collector had declared the route unsafe and even called for a halt on toll collection because of the large-scale protests.

Fresh target-completion dates were set. But, nothing concrete transpired. In the same month, the Union minister for road transport and highways Nitin Gadkari held a meeting with NHAI officials and yet no decision was taken on the cancellation of the toll.

Title: Pune: Builder, two others booked for cheating
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Following a court order, the Shivajinagar police have booked a city-based builder and two others for cheating a 32-year-old man from Wadgaon Budruk to the tune of Rs2.5 lakh.

The victim had booked a flat in a building, which was supposed to come up in Paud, in 2015.

The police on Friday registered the offence under charges of cheating and breach of criminal trust.

Assistant inspector Somnath Padsalkar, who is investigating the case, told TOI that Ananda Patil had approached the court, which directed police to take action.

In 2015, Padsalkar said, the builder claimed that he was starting a low-cost housing project in Paud, about 30km from here. He advertised a 1BHK flat for Rs16.5 lakh.

“After seeing the advertisement, Patil, who works in a small company, visited the builder’s office and paid Rs2.5 lakh via cheque and cash,” he said.

Recently, Patil visited the Paud to see the upcoming project. On reaching the spot, he realized that the builder has not undertaken any construction activity there. Patil then visited the builder’s office and demanded a refund of his booking amount, police said.

“The builder initially promised to return the amount, but then started evading Patil, who then approached the court,” Padsalkar said.

Title: Ahmedabad: Four cases filed over unverified tenants
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

Ahead of the visit of US president Donald Trump to the city, police has begun a drive to check if property owners have carried out police verification before renting out houses to tenants in Chandkheda, Motera and other areas. These areas are close to Motera stadium, which will be inaugurated by the US President on February 24.

DCP SOG Harshad Patel said they conduct such drives periodically, but because of Trump’s visit to the city, they have intensified these actions across the city. “In Chandkheda on Friday we booked four property owners for renting out houses without informing the nearest police station. We booked them under Section 188 of IPC for violation of a notification of the police commissioner, which had mandated that house owner inform the nearest police station before allowing tenants to move in,” added Patel.

Patel said they registered a case against Bhavik Parikh of Kalapinagar at Chandkheda police station who had rented his house in Divya Kunj Bungalows to Jignesh Parmar for a monthly rent of Rs 600 and had not informed police about it.

“Police also booked Mayur Patel of Hebatpur, for renting his house to Vipul Thakore without informing police. A case was also registered against Nimesh Patel of Vadodara, who rented his house to one Priya Patel for a monthly rent of Rs 5,000 and did not provide any identity proof of the tenant to police. The fourth case was against Amiben Shah of Shahpur who had rented her house to Bharatkumar Shah for Rs 5,000 and did not inform the nearest police station about. All four tenants were living in the same society,” added Patel. SOG sources said their drive will be more aggressive till Trump’s visit is over.

Title: Andhra Pradesh police department won five national awards
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Andhra Pradesh police department won a set of five national awards

VIJAYAWADA: The Andhra Pradesh police department won a set of five national awards for using innovation and technology to design efficient solutions at the Technology Sabha Awards held in Bhubaneswar, Odisha, on Saturday.

The awards were given for the state police department’s five initiatives which include, week-off process, investigation maintenance, Spandana online, best electoral practice, SC/ST PCR - Dashboard.

Previously on November 2019, the state police had bagged nine national-level SKOCH Order-of-Merit Award for outstanding work in various fields.

The most voted initiative among them all was the weekly-off for personnel. This is the first time in the country where official weekly off for police personnel was announced by the government and fully implemented.

Title: Coronavirus: Rajasthan government identifies hospital to deal with suspected cases
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose only

JAIPUR: Amid novel coronavirus (nCoV) scare, Infectious Disease Hospital (IDH) attached to Sawai Man Singh Medical College has been designated as Tertiary Care Centre for treatment and isolation of passengers referred with symptoms after screening from Jaipur airport.

At present one suspected nCoV patient is undergoing treatment at the IDH. The Health department has strengthened their surveillance at airport. Also, it has issued Helpline numbers 0141-2225624 and Toll-free number 108 and 104 for nCoV.

Officials said isolation wards have been demarcated in all medical colleges and district hospitals for isolation and treatment measures.

For spreading awareness on nCoV, the health department is distributing pamphlets at Sanganer International Airport, Jaipur. Health department is working in close coordination with police department for identification of passengers with travel history of China staying in hotels.

An advisory has also been issued for people by the health department to ward off the risk of the disease. The advisory says that people should follow the cough etiquette by covering the nose and mouth using handkerchief while sneezing and coughing and frequent hand washing with soap and water. Those who have travelled recently from the nCoV-affected countries must inform the national/state/district helpline number and remain under strict home isolation for 28 days from the date of arrival in India, irrespective of whether they are symptomatic or asymptomatic. Those who have travelled to or from Wuhan must get themselves tested for nCoV at the government-designated centres, the officials said.

So far, at anganer International Airport, screening of all passengers arriving from eight international flights daily has been continuing since January 28. For this purpose, five doctors and five paramedical staff have been deputed at the airport. Till Saturday, 13,539 passengers of 88 flights have been screened, of them 60 were suspected cases of nCoV. However, no confirmed case of nCoV has been reported from the state.

So far, 59 suspected patients have been admitted in isolation.

Title: Wagholi residents expect quick fix to garbage issue
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Pune: Wagholi residents are hopeful of a quick solution to the long-standing garbage problem after their recent meeting with district guardian minister Ajit Pawar who has asked the zilla parishad and local gram panchayat to draw up a detailed plan on garbage management for the area.

The gram panchayat swung into action after Pawar’s review meeting. It initiated steps to distribute garbage bins to every household in Wagholi to segregate wet and dry waste. There is a plan to deploy 15 vans for daily collection of garbage.

Until now, the residents, especially from housing societies in Wagholi, handed over the garbage to a contractor as the gram panchayat collected waste only from gaothan areas, leaving out housing societies which had no choice but to appoint private contractors to collect the garbage. The gram panchayat will collect waste henceforth.

An official from the gram panchayat said that there are 27,000 households registered with the administration. The distribution of two bins to every household---one each for dry and wet garbage—is about to start. The gram panchayat has 15 vans, which will operate on designated routes in six wards to collect garbage. The housing societies have been told to set up units to treat wet garbage within their premises. Many societies have already commissioned such units. The gram panchayat will primarily collect dry garbage, an official said.

The official added that Wagholi generates about 50 tonnes of garbage every day. The administration does not have a processing plant to treat all garbage. A contractor has been appointed to collect and transport the waste till the new processing plants become functional.

Three plants are expected to come up at Wagholi which will cater to the waste from six wards. The gram panchayat has already demanded spaces to commission the processing units.

Meanwhile, Pawar asked the Zilla Parishad and gram panchayat to prepare a detailed project report (DPR) on garbage management. The gram panchayat has said that the DPR is expected to be ready in the next few days.

Nitin Kumar Jain of Wagholi Housing Societies Association said that the residents are hoping for a concrete solution to the garbage issue after meeting the guardian minister. He said that the gram panchayat and zilla parishad need to be proactive in setting up garbage processing plants and keep a tab on open burning of garbage.

FESTERING ISSUES

Setting up of waste processing plants

Hastening road widening work

Resurfacing of internal and connecting roads

Installation of traffic signals at vulnerable spots

Setting up of STP plants

Daily garbage collection from houses

Steps planned:

Detailed report on daily garbage generation and processing requirement

Distribution of 54,000 bins to households for collection of wet, dry garbage

Daily collection of garbage from all six wards

Plots to be acquired for three processing plants

Title: Ramesh seeks comprehensive probe
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala on Saturday demanded a comprehensive inquiry into the findings of the report of Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) with regards to the police department. The opposition leader alleged that an organized loot is going on in the police department under state police chief Loknath Behera with the clear knowledge of chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan.

“A comprehensive inquiry should be conducted, which can also cover the period when UDF was in the power. Even during the time when UDF was in power, Behera was the ADGP in charge of funds for modernization of police force,” Chennithala said. Let there be a CBI probe, he suggested. Chennithala said that chief secretary Tom Jose using the vehicle purchased by the state police chief is unusual, and alleged that “the chief secretary has also connived with the state police chief in the loot”.

The opposition leader said that the Central Intrusion Monitoring System (CIMS) launched by the state police and Keltron is a high-level corruption in which a company named Galaxon, which has no previous experience in any similar initiatives anywhere in the country, is also a part. He demanded that a “probe should uncover the real people behind the company Galaxon, which has just a paid up capital of Rs 10 lakhs and has no previous experience in such projects”. He demanded that the government should give a clarification if the two directors of the company had earlier been blacklisted by the ministry of corporate affairs.

Chennithala said that despite the police explaining that the missing of 25 Insas rifles were only a clerical mistake, the CAG’s audit team had conducted inspection at the police chief store and examined the rifles before reaching at its final conclusion that the rifles are indeed missing. Regarding the diversion of funds meant for construction of subordinate police officers’ quarters, the opposition leader said that in 2015, when he was the home minister, the funds were sanctioned for Kerala Police Housing and Construction Corporation (KPHCC) for building the quarters, but in 2017, the funds were provided as supplementary grants, which cannot happen without the knowledge of the chief minister. The CAG had said in the audit report that the funds were then utilized to construct villas for the state police chief and ADGPs. Chennithala said that the vehicles for senior officers were being purchased using the funds for modernization, while the actual guidelines do not allow such a purchase. He added that during his tenure as home minister, the government had sanctioned Rs 40 crore from the Plan funds for vehicle purchase, so that the MoPF funds are not diverted for such purpose.

Title: Modi to flag off Mahakal Express, unveil 63ft-tall statue of DDU today
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Varanasi: Prime Minister Narendra Modi will inaugurate 36 projects and lay the foundation of 14 others besides unveiling the 63ft statue of RSS ideologue Pt Deen Dayal Upadhyay at Padao during his visit to Varanasi on Sunday.

Besides attending Veershaiva (Lingayat) Mahakumbh at historical Jangamwadi Mutt, the PM is also scheduled to flag off Mahakal Express, India’s third private train.

Talking to TOI on Saturday, district magistrate Kaushal Raj Sharma said after landing at LBS International Airport at 10.45am, the Prime Minister would reach Banaras Hindu University’s helipad to leave for Jangamwadi Mutt.

“He will leave for Sujabad by chopper to unveil the statue of Pt Deen Dayal Upadhyaya and inaugurate the initial phase of work at DDU memorial site ‘Antim Padao’ worth Rs 40 crore,” he said.

“Besides inaugurating 36 projects worth Rs 1057 crore and laying the foundation of 14 projects worth Rs 198 crore, the PM will also flag off Varanasi-Ujjain Mahakal Express train remotely at Padao,” he said.

Mahakal Express, which is the first overnight private train in the country, will connect three Jyotirlinga pilgrimage centres of Varanasi, Ujjain and Omkareshwar.

From Padao, Modi will go to DDU-TFC in Bada Lalpur area. According to officials, the PM is likely to interact with BJP leaders and workers at TFC.

Meanwhile, UP minister Sidharth Nath Singh on Saturday inspected DDU-TFC and said that 5,000 beneficiaries of ODOP (one district, one product) scheme would attend the event in which some of them would be given equipment under Vishwakarma and other schemes.

“An exhibition on ODOP, which has helped in ensuring 28% growth in export of handicraft and other products of UP, will also be organised by UP Institute of Design,” he said.

Title: Kerala: K Surendran appointed as BJP state president
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Union minister V Muraleedharan welcomes new BJP state chief K Surendran during an event in Pathanamthitta on S... Read More

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: K Surendran has been appointed as the new state president of BJP. Party national president J P Nadda announced the appointment of Surendran through a press statement in New Delhi on Saturday.

The post of party state president has been lying vacant ever since former president P S Sreedharan Pillai was appointed as Mizoram governor in October last year. The appointment of Surendran comes after much deliberations between the national leadership and senior party leaders in Kerala . The new president will choose his team soon.

Known as the trusted lieutenant of Union minister V Muraleedharan, Surendran was considered to the party chief post in 2018 too when Kummanam Rajasekharan demitted the office. But, he missed the same by a whisker then, mainly due to the resistance from RSS and former state president P K Krishnadas.

Surendran started his political career as a worker of ABVP and rose through the ranks. He had been serving the party as one of its state general secretaries since 2009. His active role in the Sabarimala agitation against the entry of women made him the face of BJP during Sabarimala agitation. He was jailed for 22 days during the stir.

In his first response, Surendran said: “The delay in the announcement of new party state president must be due to the time it took for completing the organisational election process. It doesn’t mean that the announcement got delayed due to any dispute. There is only one group in Kerala and that’s BJP core group. The party is not person centric. I would like to lead the party as a single unit, with the support and cooperation of all.”

Title: 15 minute stopover at Sabarmati Ashram
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Ahmedabad: US President Donald Trump, first lady Melania Trump, and Prime Minister Narendra Modi may not spend more than 15 minutes at the Sabarmati Gandhi Ashram on February 24. US consulate representatives, a team from India’s external affairs ministry, and officials of the Gujarat tourism department conducted a detailed review of the ashram premises on Saturday. A temporary stage has been set up at the ashram between Magan Niwas and the prayer ground on the stairs to the ghats leading to the riverfront. There, the two world leaders will stop for a brief photo call. The leaders will then proceed to the Motera stadium. A senior government official said, “President Trump will garland the picture of the Mahatma at Hriday Kunj. The garland will be made khadi yarn.” The official went on to say: “A 25-minute plan was suggested, but US officials wanted only 15 minutes keeping in mind Trump’s Agra visit.”

Title: Sunday clean-up date for Pashan residents
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Pune: Sunday morning is clean-up time for Pashan residents, especially those living in the vicinity of Shivalay Society.

For an hour starting 7:15 am, they clean the internal road and surrounding areas leading to Sai Chowk armed with masks, glows and trash bags.

What started as a one-day event by a housing society to mark the 71st Republic Day has now become a weekly affair for the neighbourhood.

It was last month when a message to residents to join a clean-up drive of rivers started doing the rounds on society Whatsapp groups. Rajesh Deshpande, a researcher, saw the message and thought of joining the initiative. “But then I thought about my own neighbourhood. In gated communities, the act of cleaning up takes place inside the compound, but nobody cares about the roads outside. Plastic and other waste lie strewn on roadside and these get washed down the river, polluting waterbodies.”

Deshpande floated the idea of a clean-up in the neighbourhood to mark the Republic Day celebration. Soon others from the Neha Apartments joined in. “On January 26, all of us cleaned the internal road area near our society till Sai Chowk on Sus Road. All of us toiled for an hour. When we saw how clean the area looked, we all felt very happy. Soon, we started thinking of doing this once a month and then decided to do it every Sunday,” he said.

However, there was a dip in enthusiasm the next Sunday and the numbers also came down. “I knew the momentum needed to be maintained for the programme to be a success and hence wrote a circular, urging people from other societies to join the movement. I went from society to society with this circular hoping that more people will turn up,” said Deshpande.

The next Sunday (February 9), three more people from other societies turned up. One of them was 66-year-old Umesh Gupta, a retired government official. “When I received the circular, being the secretary of a society, I circulated it to all members. We keep making noises about poor hygiene in our neighbourhood, but nobody takes any initiative to do anything. When I saw that someone was doing it, I wanted to help. I went on a clean-up drive along with members from other societies. I plan to do it every week,” said Gupta.

Title: Former state forest boss launches memoir about Melghat days
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Pune: Prakash Thosre, who had overseen the state’s forest department as the principal chief conservator of forests, recalled the forest range in Melghat in Amravati as one of its kind in terms of wildlife reserves and protected areas.

He was speaking at the launch ceremony of his memoir, “The Melghat Trail”, on Saturday. The event was attended by state home minister Anil Deshmukh.

“There are a few areas in Melghat which is covered by fog during the monsoon season. Patrolling during that time meant that my team and I had to be very alert for bear attacks,” Thosre said, while displaying a slideshow on about his years in the Melghat forest range.

Thosre said that several issues continue to plague Melghat, which is a protected tiger reserve. “Most notable of these is the land encroachment issue. The British started a logging industry in the forest range and encroachments have since been rife,” he said.

The guest for the evening, the state home minister Anil Deshmukh, echoed Thosre while recalling the origins of Project Tiger, the extensive tiger conservation initiative launched by the then-Prime Minister Indira Gandhi to arrest the huge decline in India’s tiger population. Deshmukh, whose home constituency is not too far from Melghat, used to accompany Thosre on many forest patrols and inspections, the latter recalled.

“Back in the day, hunting tigers was a big deal for many of the royal families in that area. Some kings ended up killing thousands of tigers because hunting was legal. But after Indira Gandhi launched Project Tiger, the number of tigers increased. In Vidarbha, there are now six tiger projects within a 200km radius,” Deshmukh added.

Title: Metro connectivity to Old City is citizens’ right: BJP
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

G Kishan Reddy and K Laxman take a Metro ride from JBS to MGBS post a review meeting

HYDERABAD: Blaming both ruling TRS and AIMIM for not completing Metro Rail connectivity, Telangana BJP leaders alleged that TRS government has been dancing to the tunes of AIMIM and as a result, people of Old City are being deprived of Metro.

The leaders demanded that government extend Metro connectivity to all corners of the city such as Alwal, ECIL and Kompally apart from completing MMTS phase II at the earliest.

Union minister of state for home affairs G Kishan Reddy held a review meeting with Hyderabad Metro Rail Ltd (HMRL) and L&T officials on Saturday. Later, he travelled from JBS to MGBS with BJP state president K Laxman and other leaders.

Kishan said had Metro connectivity been provided to Old City, the face of the Old City would have changed. He said people were complaining about high ticket rates and parking problems.

He took strong objection to inaugurating the Metro stretch from JBS to MGBS during Parliament session and not following protocols. The Union minister said though the project was taken up with help from Centre, the Prime Minister’s picture was not used at the inaugural.

Kishan said the government had sanctioned Rs 1,200 crore viability gap funding to Metro Rail project and the balance Rs 250 crore would be released soon.

On MMTS phase II, the Secunderabad MP said the Centre had released works for MMTS phase II to take it up to Yadadri, but state government has not released its share. Laxman said though Metro project was completed, footpaths, service roads and parking lots were not completed in several places.

Title: Trump visit: Flight delay uncertainty looms for Feb 24
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Ahmedabad: Travelling out of Ahmedabad from the city airport on February 24? It is likely that your journey may not be a smooth one. US president Donald Trump is coming here on the same day and there’s a strong buzz that passenger aircraft movements on Monday may be impacted. More than 250 flight movements are handled at Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International (SVPI) airport in Ahmedabad on a daily basis.

Travel agents are also concerned over bookings made by customers. “Several artists, who are coming from different parts of the country for the grand welcome for the US president, will arrive a day in advance on February 23,” said Manish Sharma, secretary, Travel Agents’ Federation of India, Gujarat chapter.

While there is no official confirmation about flight movements being affected, there is a buzz that the city may be declared a no-fly zone on February 24 with temporary flight restrictions put in place.

“No decision has been taken regarding rescheduling, diverting or cancellation of flight movements as yet,” said Manoj Gangal, director, SVPI airport.

Even airlines confirmed that they have not received any such information from the airport authorities. A well-placed source said that just like a notice to airmen (NOTAM) warning is issued to prevent landings and take-offs of aircraft on January 26 in Delhi for about two hours, similar measures may be put in place for the visit of the US president.

Title: UP bar council panel to probe court violence
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Allahabad: Bar Council of Uttar Pradesh (BCUP) on Friday set up a nine-member committee to probe the violent clash between lawyers at a district court of Lucknow.

The council directed the committee to submit a report by March 1.

On February 13, three lawyers were injured after a vrude bomb went off on the premises of a district court in Lucknow, following a clash between two rival groups of advocates. Chairman of BCUP Hari Shankar Singh said that appropriate action would be taken after the committee submits its report.

The members of the bar council who would be a part of the committee are Ajay Yadav, Arun Kumar Tripathi, Paresh Mishra, Abdul Razzak Khan, Akhilesh Awasthi, Prashant Singh Atal, Janki Sharan Pandey and Pradeep Kumar Singh.

The Bar Council of Uttar Pradesh is armed with the power to take appropriate action against lawyers in case of proved misconduct.

Title: Speeding truck runs over biker
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Pune: A 28-year-old motorcycle rider died in a hit-and-run accident involving a truck on Undri-Pisoli Road on Thursday night.

The Kondhwa police identified the deceased as Tejas Tukaram Raut, a resident of Uruli Devachi near. The truck driver fled the spot, and police are looking for him.

Police naik Arjun Pawar on Friday registered an FIR against the unidentified driver under the Indian Penal Code and Motor Vehicles Act.

Around 8.30pm, the truck was headed towards Undri-Pisoli, when Raut overtook it near Dagade Vasthi.

The truck driver lost control over the vehicle, which rammed the bike. Raut came under the front wheel of the truck, police said. Passers-by noted down the registration number of the truck and gave it to the police.

Sassoon General Hospital, in its advance post-mortem report, said the victim died of multiple injuries.

Title: ‘Science & culture hold equal value in Japan’
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Sculptor Kanayi Kunhiraman speaks at the Discover Japan event held at Ayyankali Hall In Thiruvananthapuram on ... Read More

Thiruvananthapuram: A panel discussion on Japanese culture , art , literature and cinema was held as part of the ‘ Discover Japan ’ event at Ayyankali Hall on Saturday. Organised by the district centre of the alumni society of AOTS (Association of Overseas Technical Cooperation for Sustainable Partnership) in collaboration with Japan’s ministry for foreign affairs, the three-day festival will conclude on Sunday.

Sculptor Kanayi Kunhiraman said people should learn from the Japanese, their culture and development.

“One can understand Asian culture through Japan. I had an opportunity to visit Japan in 1982. I found the Japanese people friendly and very helpful. Japan gives equal importance to culture and science. Despite all the resources, we are not developed as other countries. This is because we imitate other cultures. In Japan, people live in harmony with nature,” said Kunhiraman.

He went on to explain how artists such as Van Gogh were inspired by Japanese prints and their influence on art and world cinema.

K S Ravikumar, pro vice-chancellor of Sree Sankaracharya University of Sanskrit, Kalady, said the works of Malayalam writers and Japanese literature share many features.

“The short poems of Kunjunni Mash can be compared to haiku, a traditional form of Japanese poetry consisting of three lines. But, Kunjunni Mash had said that he was not aware of the Japanese form. More than art and culture, it is the industries and products of Japan that people here know more about. Japan created a model for enterprises and the country emerged as a phoenix after Hiroshima and Nagasaki were destroyed during World War II. During the war, left ideologues opposed Japan, considering it a fascist force,” said Ravikumar.

Pradeep Panangad, media advocacy coordinator at Institute for Sustainable Development and Governance, moderated the session.

Title: Early signs often ignored in paediatric cancer
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Visakhapatnam: In contrast to cancers that develop in adults, the treatment of children with cancer poses several challenges on account of lack of paediatric oncology specialists, difficulty in prevention due to the genetic origin of these cancers and low awareness of detecting early symptoms.

On International Childhood Cancer Day on February 15, oncologists said that while not common, around 1 per cent of all new cancer cases in a year are paediatric cancer.

In children, the most common incidences of cancer are acute lymphoblastic leukamia (ALL) or blood cancer, which accounts for about 40 per cent of cases, followed by brain tumour (30 per cent).

“Carcinoma of the bone, lymphoma or lymph nodes, Wilms tumour (kidney) and neuroblastoma (adrenal glands) are other types of cancer found in children mainly due to genetic mutation of idiopathy or unknown reasons,” said Dr Muralikrishna Voona, surgical oncologist and managing director of Mahatma Gandhi Cancer Hospital (MGCH).

“Since childhood cancer grows and spreads rapidly, it is essential that mothers and paediatricians or treating general physicians do not miss early symptoms. Complete cure rates of paediatric cancer are 70-80 per cent when diagnosed early and children respond well to chemotherapy. However, in our country, there is scarcity of specialties like paediatric oncologists. Training has to be given to haematologists and paediatricians in oncology,” said Dr Muralikrishna.

Dr Maruthi Prasad Upputuri, consultant paediatrician at Kims Icon Hospital said, “Since most general paediatricians rarely encounter children with cancer, they might miss the early symptoms. The symptoms differ with each type of childhood cancer and are generally non-specific. Nonetheless, persistent fever, fatigue, recent weight loss, night sweats, painless swellings, especially of the lymph nodes, early morning headache with vomiting, abdominal mass, unexplained pains, especially of the bone, should be taken note of and tested.”

Title: Vigilance grills Ebrahim Kunju
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The vigilance and anti-corruption bureau sleuths grilled former PWD minister V K Ebrahim Kunju for almost three hours on Saturday, in connection with the alleged corruption in the construction of Palarivattom flyover.

The former PWD minister appeared before the vigilance team at the special investigation unit-1, led by DSP Shyam Kumar for interrogation, after he was summoned by the agency. The government had sought the clearance from governor for prosecuting the former PWD minister who is currently an MLA, in connection with granting advance funds for the RDS projects, the contractor company for constructing the flyover.

It is reliably learnt that the vigilance sleuths also sought the reason from the former minister on why he gave clearance for providing funds in advance to the company, on the basis of which the funds were released. The vigilance sleuths also had confiscated the file in which he had given his clearance for releasing the funds. The files regarding the clearance of funds had shown that Kunju had given clearance for releasing Rs 8.5 crore to the company for the project.

Sources said that the former minister replied that there is nothing unusual on his part in giving clearance as all those who are involved in handling the concerned file from the secretariat assistant to the department secretary had made no objection towards the request for releasing the funds. tnn

Title: ‘Probe Goa Foundation, its sources of income’
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Ponda: The Goa Mining People’s Front (GMPF) has demanded that the state government initiate an inquiry into the members of Goa Foundation as well as its sources of income . The mining dependants’ front has blamed the legal suit filed by the NGO for the delay in resumption of mining activities in the state. Further, it has alleged that the NGO is delaying mining resumption simply because of greed.

Speaking at the press conference, GMPF’s Balaji Gawas said that members of Goa Foundation file suits in the apex court and travel by air to New Delhi and hence, chief minister Pramod Sawant should investigate their sources of income.

“There are several other sensitive issues in the state such as the Mhadei river water dispute, but Goa Foundation is only challenging mining-related issues”, Gawas said.
