Hailing the state government for its various initiative to get mining activities resumed, he said that just as this seemed likely, the NGO had created hurdles. If the NGO hadn’t filed the intervention petition, the mining resumption order could have been declared on February 10, Gawas said.

GMPF president Puti Gaonkar meanwhile demanded that before operations restart, the government must first ensure that mining companies reinstate staff who were let go after March 16, 2018 as well as absorb trucks and machinery that were stopped after closure of mining.

Title: Residents upset over slow pace of work on Arya Samaj Road
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Work in progress on Arya Samaj road in Mangaluru.

Mangaluru: Residents and business establishments on Arya Samaj Road are miffed over the work going on at a snail’s pace at Arya Samaj Road and Bridge Road .

Though the work on Arya Samaj Road was taken up about two years ago, this road which connects Balmatta with Kadri Road, still remains closed. Meanwhile, the situation is the same on Bridge Road that connects Bunts Hostel Road with Balmatta. This road remains closed for nearly a year for concreting.

Ashok Kumar, a resident staying near Arya Samaj Road, told TOI that people have been facing inconvenience due to the inordinate delay in the completion of work at Arya Samaj Road and Bridge Road. Initially, they closed the road two years ago, for the laying interlocking tiles. It was later dug up for the purpose of underground drainage (UGD) works. Now they have closed the road completely, to convert it into a concrete stretch. People are forced to park their vehicles on the road due to this,” he said.

Businessman Sharath Kumar said that both roads which link up to Balmatta, help in reducing traffic congestions on the Jyothi Circle to Balmatta road stretch and also from Jyothi Circle to Bunts Hostel Road. Since, both roads are closed, the area witnesses traffic snarls every day during peak hours, he added.

Mangaluru Smart City Limited managing director Mohammed Nazeer said the work is being expedited and initiatives will be taken to open both roads at the earliest. “Development work on Arya Samaj Road and Bridge Road are complicated, as it is a narrow stretch. We had to close the road to facilitate the work. The concrete work on Bridge Road is completed, but we need 20 more days for curing. Similarly, the work on Arya Samaj Road is also nearing completion,” he added.

Title: Road caves in at Bagikhana
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

The main road caved in due to water leakage on Saturday

Vadodara: The main road caved in near Bagikhana area of the city on Saturday owing to leakage in a water pipeline.

After the incident came to light on Saturday, the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) has put barricades to ensure that commuters stay safe from the large pit that appeared in the middle of the busy road. Work on identifying the leakage under the road and then closing the crater is yet to begin, said corporator Balasaheb Surve.

Surve said that the area was prone to such cave ins due to leakage in drainage or water pipelines. He said even this seems to have its roots in the laying of an underground cable. “There are booth sewage and water supply pipelines under crater. A cable can be seen in it. Which pipeline was damaged will become clear only when the crater is dug up further to access the pipelines,” he said.

Surve added that students of two schools and other institites located in the area were facing many difficulties.

Title: KGH waits for infra to treat leukaemia
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Visakhapatnam: While the state government has enhanced the scope of cashless cancer treatment by bringing certain treatments under the Aarogyasri scheme, the largest state-run tertiary healthcare centre in AP – the King George Hospital ( KGH ) — lacks infrastructure for treating leukaemia patients, which is the most common form of paediatric cancer and certain other childhood cancers requiring high-end equipment and expertise.

“Given the high expenditures involved in prolonged cancer treatment, which may extend from several months to years, the government has included most paediatric cancers under its insurance scheme. Patients covered under Aarogyasri can avail treatment in the network corporate hospitals. Though we treat free-of-cost, we have to refer most paediatric cancer patients to other private oncology centres as the required infrastructure is unavailable,” said Dr N Sujatha, head of the department of oncology at KGH. The department did not have a medical oncologist for the last three years.

Further, radiotherapy for children is not recommended as it impedes their growth. “In the absence of medical oncologists, we could not treat any paediatric cancer cases, even though they were mostly curable. Every month four to five such cases had to be sent back to other hospitals. But now we have a qualified medical oncologist on deputation and can at least treat certain types of carcinoma such as bone tumour, certain brain tumours and lymphoma,” said Dr Sujatha.

“We are still not equipped to treat leukaemia or blood cancer as it requires a costly, high-end set-up with trained staff, dedicated wards, a sterile environment, mechanism for storage of stem cells, advanced equipment for bone marrow transplant – altogether a separate unit to support the treatment which may last a year or two,” said Dr Sujatha.

Title: Probe against ex-VC: HRD panel to visit AU on Feb 24
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

looking for loopholes

Allahabad: The three-member inquiry committee, constituted by the human resources development ministry to probe allegations of irregularities against Allahabad University’s (AU) former VC RL Hangloo during his tenure would be visiting the campus again on February 24.

This would be the committee’s second visit in February.

While the team would be led by Indira Gandhi National Open University (IGNOU) vice-chancellor Nageshwar Rao, the committee’s other members would be vice-chancellors of Indira Gandhi National Tribal University Amarkantak and Gujarat Central University — Prakash Mani Tripathi and Rama Shankar Dubey respectively.

On its last visit to the campus on February 6, the team had met several university officials, including the officiating VC RR Tewari. The panel members had invited complaints about irregularities and said anyone could submit them along with valid supporting documents by February 16. By Saturday, AU received 30 complaints along with the supporting documents.

Sources said AU officials were preparing a summary of the complaints, which would scrutinised by the three-member committee on their next visit.

“The committee would look into the summary and decide if they would like to meet any of the complainants in person,” said a senior AU official.

The news about the committee’s visit comes days after a three-member team of National Commission of Women (NCW) members met AU hostel inmates on Thursday and Friday.

The committee, led by NCW chairperson Rekha Sharma, had recommended that AU registrar NK Shukla and finance officer Sunilkant Mishra be removed from their respective posts.

AU public relations officer Shailendra Mishra said, “The two inquiry committees have been doing their work independently and AU authorities would be cooperating in every possible way.”

Title: Change in AU statute: Varsity writes to govt
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Allahabad: Allahabad University ( AU ) sent a reminder to the ministry of human resources development (HRD) on Friday seeking amendments in a statute, which would allow it to expand its campus beyond the existing limit of 16-kilometre radius.

If the Centre approves the proposed changes to section 8 (1) of University of Allahabad Act, 2005, it would pave way for the construction of a satellite campus — a goal the varsity has been working towards since the past several years. University of Allahabad Act 2005 section 8 reads: “the powers conferred on the university shall be exercisable in respect of the area within a radius of 16 kilometres from the convocation hall of the university.”

On July 19, 2019, AU executive council wrote to HRD ministry requesting the government to remove the technicality pertaining to 16-kilometre limit and replacing it with ‘anywhere in the country’.

Officiating vice-chancellor of AU RR Tewari said, “It is the need of the hour that AU should expand and if the Act is amended suitably, it would help AU to open its satellite campus in Kaushambi or in any other district”.

Title: Vijayawada: Education body to intensify school and college inspection
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Inspections in 260 education institutions

VIJAYAWADA: Andhra Pradesh School Education Regulatory and Monitoring Commission (APSERMC) is preparing to intensify inspections across private and corporate schools and junior colleges, which are charging exorbitant fees. The committee is eyeing to complete the inspections by the first week of April to provide the grading so that fees can be fixed for the new academic year.

The committee, which had conducted inspections in 260 education institutions in two days last week, had found major discrepancies. They even found out that while schools in Kerala have introduced a water bell to increase hydration in kids, a few schools in Andhra Pradesh were not allowing the students to drink sufficient water to prevent them from visiting the toilet repeatedly.

“Schools were playing with the health of the students. Toilets in the schools were in poor condition. They are not allowing students to drink water to prevent them from visiting the toilet frequently. This is causing renal problems. Quality of food supplied in residential and semi-residential junior colleges is of poor quality and students will suffer gut disorders if they continue to consume this food,” said commission vice-chairperson Vijaya Sharada Reddy.

The APSERMC also noticed that several under-qualified teachers were playing a key role in private and corporate schools. Managements were recruiting under-qualified staff and paying them lesser wages. A few institutions were paying around Rs 7,000 to staff for 12 hour-work that is against the guidelines, the committee observed.

The APSERMC will initiate stringent action against corporate schools, which lacking proper infrastructure. The committee is in talks to suggest the education department to cancel accredition of schools found violating the rules. Meanwhile, private school managements are in limbo over the grading system proposed by APSERMC in fixing school fee.

Title: Civic body fines minister for illegal hoarding
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Hyderabad: The vigilance wing of Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation issued an e-challan to animal husbandry minister Talasani Srinivas Yadav on Saturday after an illegal cut-out surfaced at Necklace Road.

TRS leaders had raised an unauthorised hoarding at Necklace Road, ahead of chief minister K Chandrashekar Rao's birthday on February 17 to extend their wishes.

The minister was penalised with Rs 5,000 by the directorate of enforcement, vigilance and disaster management (EVDM), GHMC . “The penalty has been paid through cheque,” said Viswajit Kampati, EVDM director.

A netizen had posted a photo of the illegal hoarding on Twitter asking the EVDM director to taking necessary action against those responsible. The minister also took to Twitter and confirmed that the challan has been paid.

The EVDM wing was in the news recently after AIMIM and TRS corporators opposed fines imposed by EVDM. Political leaders opposing challans did not go well with citizens, who lashed out at them

Title: Nod for VACB probe against Sivakumar
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The government has given permission to the vigilance and anti-corruption bureau (VACB) to register a case and conduct a probe against Congress leader and former health and devaswom minister V S Sivakumar MLA.

Additional chief secretary (home and vigilance) Vishwas Mehta issued the order granting permission to the agency to register a case against him on the basis of the findings of a preliminary inquiry against the former minister, with regards to amassment of wealth beyond his known sources on income during his tenure as the health minister in the previous UDF government.

“The government has examined the findings of the preliminary inquiry in detail and on the basis of the findings of the inquiry, the government hereby accords sanction for the vigilance to register a case and conduct a probe against him,” the order issued by the government said.

Earlier, the sanction for conducting a probe against the former minister was obtained from the governor. The vigilance had initiated a preliminary inquiry against him in 2016 and had submitted a report to the government that he has acquired assets beyond his known sources of income and a detailed investigation has to be conducted by registering a case. There were complaints against Sivakumar that he has acquired several assets in the capital district when he was the minister.

Sivakumar responded that the case against him is a politically motivated one, and he welcomes any probe and would fully cooperate with it. He said that the clearance for vigilance probe is a ploy to divert the attention when the government is in the thick of corruption allegations. He said that the same complaint was earlier probed and found baseless.

Title: Tirupati: Kailasagiri reservoir likely to get storage capacity boost
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

TIRUPATI: In a bid to meet burgeoning demand for drinking water , the Tirupati municipal corporation is considering measures to increase the storage capacity of the Kailasagiri reservoir . A sum of nearly Rs 30 crore is being set aside for the purpose.

Speaking to reporters at the YSR Conference Hall, municipal commissioner PS Girisha said that the corporation and the irrigation department are jointly preparing a proposal to increase the storage capacity of Kailasagiri reservoir from 200 mc feet to 400 mc feet.

“We will send proposals to the state government for approval soon and are confident that works will be expedited to provide for the drinking water needs of denizens of the temple city,” said the municipal commissioner. Girisha further said, “We have been supplying drinking water to 10 wards within the civic body limits on a daily basis. Now, measures would be taken to provide drinking water to all wards in the city after the storage capacity is increase.”

Talking about development activities as part of the Tirupati smart city project, the municipal commissioner said that tenders will be invited soon for the construction of a new corporation office. “Measures have been taken to complete big projects including Garuda Varadhi and underground cabling on time,” he said while adding that the corporation is contemplating development of burial grounds within civic body limits. Around 22 schools are being developed under the Manabadi Nadu-Nedu programme, he informed further.

Earlier, the municipal commissioner and Tirupati MLA Bhumana Karunakar Reddy visited the burial ground near Railway Colony. Upon noticing the mess around the area, the commissioner directed officials to clear the bushes and maintain hygiene at the burial ground premises. He instructed officials to provide water and electricity to the burial ground.

Title: Court issues summons to Union min
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The chief judicial magistrate here on Saturday served a summons to Union minister of law and justice Ravi Shankar Prasad to appear before the court in a defamation petition filed by MP Shashi Tharoor. The summons is to appear before the court in person or through lawyer on May 2. CJM Prabhash Lal served the summons after taking cognizance of the defamation suit filed by Tharoor in 2018.

Tharoor’s petition was based on remarks made by Prasad in October 2018 during a news conference held in Delhi, where he addressed Tharoor “as an accused in a murder case”. He then went on to circulate the portion of the video of the press conference where he made the abovementioned remarks through his social media pages.

Tharoor initially served a legal notice to Prasad demanding an apology, which was rejected. Then, Tharoor filed a defamation suit before the CJM here.

Tharoor had personally appeared before the CJM court here twice as part of the case – first to file the defamation suit and then to give his statements when the case was taken up for petitioner’s hearing. tnn

Title: District & Nedumangad block panchayats make it 2 in a row
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram district panchayat rode on a slew of projects aimed at social welfare and ecological conser... Read More

Thiruvananthapuram: The district panchayat and Nedumangad block panchayat did the capital proud by bagging the Swaraj trophy for panchayats in the state for the second time in a row. The awards were announced by local self-government minister A C Moideen here on Saturday.

Thiruvananthapuram district panchayat rode on a slew of projects aimed at social welfare and ecological conservation to repeat the feat. Its ‘patheyam’ project for a hunger-free district entailed distribution of lunch packets. The Vidyajyothi scheme targeted weak students in class X to ensure better results in SSLC examinations.

“Following the success of green milk unit at Chettachal, we also introduced a modern hatchery unit which can produce 10,000 chicks a week. We were able to address transportation woes at 26 schools through our ‘sarathi’ project which involved purchasing vehicles for needy schools,” said V K Madhu, district panchayat president. Hi-tech girl-friendly amenity centres were also established in schools under another project.

The district panchayat also joined hands with the rural employment guarantee scheme cell to generate 2,000 farm ponds in various places. In addition, 1 lakh rainwater pits were also created.

Under ‘snehasparsham’, the panchayat launched a scholarship scheme for mentally ill students and an amount of Rs 28,000 is disbursed to eligible students annually. ‘Koothambalam’, which was conceived to give training in percussion instruments to students, was implemented in 15 schools and 10 libraries. The panchayat attained 99.9% plan expenditure during 2018-19. “It was a record among district panchayats,’’ said Madhu.

Nedumangad block panchayat’s ‘vallam nira’ scheme came in for special mention. It blends organic farming and floriculture and promotes it as an employment opportunity for households. On special occasions, four types of organic vegetables are made available to 25,000 houses. The project aims to realise organic villages through Kudumbashree and sale of additional vegetables and flowers from every house through stalls. The project will ensure that 50% of households in one village panchayat is covered under the scheme. Besides, the panchayat also conducted an social audit for all schemes in an exercise that lasted six months. ‘Jaivagramam’ scheme, plastic recycling and agri-incubation centres were also launched by Nedumangad block panchayat, said president B Biju.

Title: Phone bar on matric exam invigilators
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Bhubaneswar: No teacher will be allowed to carry mobile phones to examinations halls, nodal centres or evaluation centres during the Class X board exam to be conducted by the Board of Secondary Education (BSE) from February 19.

“If any teacher is seen with phone during the exam, he or she may be arrested,” said chief secretary Asit Tripathy. The chief secretary asked collectors, SPs and district education officers to ensure that the exams are held smoothly, to take all steps to check question paper leak and malpractice.

This year, 5,60,905 students will appear for the board examination in 2,888 examination centres. Forty-four special squads have been formed at the board level and 68 at the district level to monitor the exams, official sources said. tnn

Title: Government aiming to procure 50% of services from MSMEs: Goa CM
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

CM Pramod Sawant

PANAJI: The state government is aiming to procure 50% of products and services from medium, small and micro enterprises ( MSME ) to boost the sector, said chief minister Pramod Sawant .

He also said that land that was repossessed from special economic zone (SEZ) developers would be utilised for setting up industries.

Speaking at a function in Panaji on Saturday, Sawant said the government is taking numerous steps to facilitate the growth of MSMEs in Goa.

He also said as availability of land is a major challenge, this problem would be solved to a large extent following the move to repossess SEZ land.

Sawant also said the government has reconstituted investment promotion board to facilitate the setting up of industries in the state.

“We are committed to ensure that at least 50% of the total procurement for the government will be done from local MSMEs,” he said.

The chief minister further said that the state and union governments have geared up to promote the growth of the MSME sector.

At present, the MSME sector contributes 29% of the GDP and constitutes 48% of exports, as well as generates employment, Sawant said.

He said that the MSME sector is the real growth engine of India’s economy and holds the key to realise India’s aim to be a 5 trillion dollor economy, a goal set up by Prime Minister Narendra Modi .

“For this goal to be a reality by 2024, the MSME sector should be geared up to contribute 2 trillion dollars,” he said, adding that Union minister Nitin Gadkari has set a target of generating 5 crore additional jobs in this sector.

“I am sure the MSME sector will rise up to the challenge and meet both these objectives,” Sawant said.

He said that India has more than 50 million MSMEs which are facing liquidity crunch, for which the government is trying to find a solution.

Title: SCoR may become India’s most profitable zone
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Visakhapatnam: In what comes as good news for the city and the Visakhapatnam region, officials have projected that the new South Coast Railway ( SCoR ) will be Indian Railways’ highest revenue generator with projected annual earnings of around Rs 13,000 crore.

Till now, it is the Delhi-based Northern Railways that earns the highest revenue with the sector having earned Rs 8,925 crore as per the latest report. The Northern Railways covers 6,968km— the largest route in the country.

The SCoR, which is the 18th railway zone in the country will cover a route length of 3,496km, according to a senior railway official who added that the zone is projected to transport nearly 8.7 crore tonnes of freight and 20 crore passengers.

The reasons behind such high projected earnings include four major ports located nearby— Krishnapatnam, Kakinada, Gangavaram and Visakhapatnam and the four major railway stations— Visakhapatnam, Vijayawada, Tirupati and Rajahmundry.

Moreover, there are seven loco sheds— three electric and four diesel, seven coaching depots, the Rajahmundry-based MEMU car shed, wagon workshops, railway land for commercial operations, tourist spots, vast coastline and the Chennai-Howrah railway line.

“The four ports in Andhra Pradesh will be the backbone of SCoR which will contribute nearly 60-70% of revenue earnings by the zone,” the railway official told TOI.

Additionally, the Indian Railways has decided to build a second main railway station in Vizag city and another at Marripalem. These will be built at an estimated cost of Rs 76 crore. These stations are expected to provide advanced passenger amenities. “We are waiting for the date of commencement of SCoR. It will hopefully be done in the first quarter of the next fiscal,” the official said.

The SCoR zone was announced by the railway ministry in February 2019. A sum of Rs 170 crore was sanctioned for the development of the zone in the recent Budget. “Existing infrastructure in the city is enough to commence the zone,” added the official.

Title: Telangana: State cabinet to meet today
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

K Chandrasekhar Rao

HYDERABAD: The state cabinet will meet on Sunday afternoon to approve various administrative reforms and projects. Chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao is likely to apprise his cabinet colleagues about financial situation of the state, discuss the Pay Revision Commission and hike in retirement age for government employees. The cabinet is likely to finalise Assembly’s budget session dates too.

Official sources said the government might approve funds to urban local bodies, Pattana Pragati, approve certain posts like additional collectors and reorganise irrigation department into 11 circles.

Apart from these changes, government might announce farm loan waiver schedule. Few days ago, government had approved certain works under Kaleshwaram and other irrigation projects.

Title: Vijayawada: Jana Sena, BJP will fight for Amaravati, says Pawan Kalyan
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Jana Sena chief Pawan Kalyan

VIJAYAWADA: Jana Sena chief Pawan Kalyan visited capital region villages on Saturday and extended support to villagers who have been agitating in support of Amaravati as seed capital.

“Amaravati is the capital city of Andhra Pradesh and the decision happened long ago. The state government has the right to take a call on the location of the capital, but in this case Amaravati was already approved as the state’s new capital. The central government also recognized Amaravati in the map and granted funds for the development of infrastructure here. I am sure it will be the capital city forever. It’s shifting is just a temporary phase,” Pawan said.

He also blamed the YSRC government for the deaths of around 41 farmers. “They lost their lives for Amaravati. The state government should recognize their sacrifices,” he demanded.

He further said that chief minister Jaganmohan Reddy’s recent meeting with Prime Minister Narendra Modi should be taken in the right context. “Jagan met the PM in his capacity as CM of AP. There is no chance of BJP forging an alliance with the YSRC. Our cadres should understand this. We have decided to go for an alliance with the BJP for the welfare of AP and I am working in that direction,” Pawan added.

Explaining the reasons for the postponement of the Kavathu long march, Pawan said he took the decision on the request of BJP. “Both Jana Sena and BJP will fight in support of Amaravati. We had decided to stage the long march but postponed it as the top leadership of the BJP was busy with the elections in Delhi. We will soon announce the new date of the long march,” he said.

Title: BJP government always in denial mode: P Chidambaram
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Former Union finance minister P Chidambaram

TRICHY: Former Union finance minister P Chidambaram has accused the BJP government at the Centre of not accepting its mistakes and being in denial mode as rising unemployment and falling consumption are making India poorer.

Speaking on ‘Union Budget 2020’ at St Joseph's College here on Saturday, Chidambaram said finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman took 160 minutes to present the Budget, but did not convey anything.

“The finance minister should first speak about the present economic condition of the country. Then the minister should list out what all are the measures needed to streamline shortcomings in the previous year and future plans on existing projects which are successfully going on. However, she conveyed nothing in her 160-minute budget speech,” he said.

“No government would run without a single mistake. That can be rectified, but this government is not like that. The ruling BJP government has never accepted its mistakes. For example, demonetization and the way GST was implemented were great mistakes committed in independent India. But, they never accepted it because the ruling BJP government is always in denial mode,” he said.

“Electricity, industry, mines, refineries, coal and gas are important sectors which would determine the economic condition of any country. However, none of these sectors witnessed growth under the BJP regime. 60% of people rely on the agriculture sector. However, the growth rate of the sector was only 2%,” he added.

“When rising unemployment and falling consumption is making India poorer, the Union budget has no answer to address it. Former chief economic advisor of the Union government Arvind Subramanian had stated that the economy was in the ICU. However, my opinion is that the patient has been kept out of the ICU and incompetent doctors are looking after the patient,” he added.

Title: Leopard rescued in Goa's Bombade Sattari
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

The leopard was later shifted to Bondla Zoo for medical investigation

PANAJI: A male leopard that was found ensnared at a private property in Bombade , Sattari , was successfully rescued on Saturday.

The hour-long rescue operation was led by Valpoi range forest officer Valpoi Deepak Tandel along with the veterinary officer and tranquilising team of Bondla Zoo and a special protection squad of the North Goa forest division.

The leopard was later shifted to Bondla Zoo for medical investigation.

North Goa, deputy conservator of forests, Kuldeep Sharma told reporters that the leopard was trapped in a clutch wire snare set up by unidentified criminals to trap wild animals.

The rescued animal is currently under observation where it will be kept for a few days. Once found fit for release, will be released back in wild, Sharma said.

Title: Trichy: 69 get BTech degrees in IIIT’s first convocation
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

K Shanmugam,chief secretary of Tamil Nadu presenting degree

TRICHY: A total of 69 students received their degrees in the first convocation of Indian Institute of Information Technology (IIIT), Trichy , held here on Saturday.

The institute conferred B Tech degrees on 44 computer science engineers (CSE) and 25 electronics and communication engineers (ECE) who completed their degree in 2019. The toppers of CSE and ECE received the institute’s gold medal. The overall institute topper was awarded the President’s gold medal.

The toppers, who received the institute gold medal, are B Venkata Naga Sri Sai Vineetha (CSE) and Jhosna (ECE). Venkata Naga Sri Sai Vineetha (CSE), the recipient of the President’s gold medal, is the overall institute topper.

Among these graduates, 53 % of them have been placed with impressive salary packages ranging between 3.5 lakh and 20 lakh per annum in leading companies. Chief guest Ashok Jhunjhunwala, of Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Madras, addressed the students on the industry and institute collaboration.

He spoke on the challenges students face following the advent of electric power, robotics, 3D-manufacturing (i.e. additive manufacturing), nano materials, and artificial intelligence. K Shanmugam , chief secretary of Tamil Nadu, who is the ex-officio chairperson of IIIT, Apoorva, principal secretary, higher education department, K Vivekanandan, director, directorate of technical education, Mini Shaji Thomas, director, National Institute of Technology (NIT) Trichy attended.

Director of IIIT-Trichy NVSN Sharma gave a detailed speech on the establishment of the institute in Trichy as one of the 19 IIITs in India under the non-profit public private partnership (PPP) model in 2013-14.

Title: Meerut: Missing woman’s body found in field
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

MEERUT: Body of a 35-year-old woman who had gone missing on Friday evening was recovered from a field at Samaypur village under Mundali police station on Saturday morning.

The deceased was identified as Lakshmi, a resident of Jai Bheem Nagar in Bhawanpur area.

Police suspect that Lakshmi was strangled and later, her body was dumped in a desolate spot. Based on the complaint of her family, a case of murder has been registered against three named accused at Mundali police station.

According to Lakshmi’s family, she had left home on her scooter after she got call from one Umesh Gurjar, a resident of Parikshitgarh area. She had lent Rs 2 lakh to him. When she did not return home at night, her family lodged a missing complaint with Mundali police.

In the morning, her scooter was found abandoned on Garh road. The jewellery she was wearing was missing from her person while there were strangulation marks on her neck.

Meanwhile, police are yet to ascertain the reason for the murder. The investigating sleuths claim that the deceased woman was a money lender and the murder could be linked to one such deal gone wrong.

“We have registered a case against three named accused based on the complaint of the deceased’s husband. Efforts are on to arrest them. We are trying to look into all possible angles in the case,” said Avinash Pandey, SP (rural).

Title: Coronavirus scare: Moradabad brass firms stare at Rs 700-crore loss as handicraft fair in Frankfurt wears deserted look
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Meerut: A drastic dip in the footfall at coveted handicraft fair in Frankfurt, Germany due to the coronavirus scare has left the Moradabad brass exporters gasping for breath as they are now staring at a loss of around Rs 700-crore. As many as 150 representatives of the brass industry, who have put up stalls at the fair which will a five-day affair, stared at empty galleries for the second day running on Friday.

Adding to their woes, they have been allotted the stalls right next to exporters from China at the Ambiënte Fair Frankfurt 2020, one of the largest annual fares for handicraft held in Germany.

Rohit Dhal, director of H Lal Exports, who spoke to TOI from Frankfurt, said, “Scenario is bad, really bad. There are 150 exporters from Moradabad and most of them are sitting idle. The US and European buyers are in any case not coming here because of coronavirus scare.”

According to director of Export Promotion Council for Handicraft (EPCH), Neeraj Khanna, “According to an estimate, we expect a downfall of 70-80% in terms of footfalls. In usual circumstances, Moradabad-based brass industry used to conduct business worth Rs 800-crore in this fair. But, this year, we are staring at a loss of Rs 500 to 700 crores.”

“We are already getting feelers from the biggest importers in the US and in Europe. They are cancelling their visits due to advisory issued by the US to its citizens,” says Rakesh Kumar, director general of EPCH.

It’s not just export which has been affected drastically, but import as well.

“There are a lot of items we import from China to keep our export deliveries intact. Our current orders are also stuck in the customs department in China. Factories there are shut down and no production is taking place. All that is impacting us,” added Khanna.

However, there is a silver lining. China’s loss could be India’s gain. All hopes now rest on EPCH Fair in Greater Noida in April, the largest annual handicraft fair in India which is quite a draw for foreign buyers.

“Since it is a national affair and no foreign exhibitors are invited here, we have strong feeling that losses suffered in Frankfurt can be made up in April. Although, we usually have Chinese buyers also, this time things are not so easy for them because of undeclared visa restriction after coronavirus outbreak. So European and American buyers can always arrive here,” said Vishal Agarwal, an exporter from Moradabad.

Title: MGU: Prakash Kumar appointed as registrar
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Kottayam: B Prakash Kumar was appointed as the registrar of the MG University on Saturday. C M Sreejith was appointed as controller of examinations and Biju Mathew as finance officer in the syndicate meeting held at the MGU campus. Vice-chancellor Sabu Thomas presided over the meeting. The appointment is on a deputation basis for a period of four years. Kumar was the controller of examination as well as the director of the college development council. tnn

Title: Absence of PU college make kids in Hajabba’s school give up studies
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Hajabba along with schoolchildren at the Kannada Zilla Panchayat Higher Primary School at New Padpu in Harekal... Read More

MANGALURU: Most of those who complete their SSLC , especially girls in Dakshina Kannada Zilla Panchayat Higher Primary School at New Padpu in Harekala, which is the school built by Padma Shri awardee Harekala Hajabba, discontinue their studies as there is no PU college in the village.

Last academic year, only one girl student and a few boys out of 26 students,opted for PU after SSLC, but the rest have discontinued studies

Harekala Hajabba , 64, known as ‘Akshara Santha,’ says he can be at peace only when his school gets a PU college wing or the school is turned into a Karnataka Public School. The reason is that 80 to 85 per cent of students, especially girls, after completion of SSLC in Dakshina Kannada Zilla Panchayat Higher Primary and High School, New Padpu, discontinue studies as there is no government PU college nearby. The school, which is popularly known as Hajabba’s school, is situated about 25km away from the city.

“Last year, there were about 26 SSLC students who passed out from this institution, yet only one girl and few boys have continued their studies. Some boys dropped out after attending PU college for a few months. The rest have discontinued their studies or joined madrassa education, and one among them is a school and taluk topper, who scored 95 per cent. The reason is there is not a single government PU or any vocational training institution nearby. They have to travel to the city, which many parents do not prefer, and they cannot afford to send children to private PU colleges. Therefore, most of them discontinue their studies,” said school teacher Susheema. She added that some continue their PU after working for a year.

This year, 23 students including 10 girls will appear for the SSLC examination. Last academic year, the school received 92 per cent results in SSLC. The high school has 73 students and 91 students study in primary school. The primary school started in 2001 and high school in 2007. A majority of students come to school either by walking or by using public transport.

“Year by year, due to mushrooming of private English-medium schools and non-availability of PU college here, admissions are coming down at the school. It can be stopped when the government sanctions a PU college or a public school,” added a teacher.

Class X student Raksha, who quit an English-medium school at Konaje and joined Hajabba’s school, said that she prefers this school to her previous one. “There is a learning atmosphere at this educational institution. I wish to continue my PU on the same campus. It all depends on the government,” she said. Raksha’s sister Rashmi also studies in the same school.

“It is my dream to see a PU college on this campus,” said Harekala Hajabba.

Memorandum submitted to minister

During the visit of minister for primary and secondary education of S Suresh Kumar to the school on Saturday, Harekala Hajabba submitted a memorandum requesting additional facilities for the institution. In return, the minister responded and said that he will consider the memorandum.

He demanded to upgrade the Harekala school to a Karnataka Public School in order to provide education till the plus-two level, under one roof; compound wall across campus, bus facility as well as to carry out repairs of school building; school ground; laboratory, library and computer labs.

Title: Trial run of Alphonso cultivation in VZM and Chittoor dists yields poor fruit
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Even though India’s eastern coast is famous for the export of mango pulp, export of the fruit is negligible in these parts compared to the west coast. In a bid to close in on this gap, the horticulture department had farmers experiment with the Alphonso mango at a clinical scale in Vizianagaram and Chittoor . However, the experiment did not yield desired results.

Alphonso, one of the most popular varieties of mango is exported the most. Most of the Alphonso is grown in Ratnagiri and areas like Aurangabad in Maharashtra. While the export of the Alphonso has been a huge success there, it could not be replicated in north-coastal Andhra Pradesh.

Speaking to STOI, K Srinivasalu, director of planning at the horticulture department said, “The Alphonso experiment did not succeed here because the variety thrives in dry climatic conditions aided by black cotton soil. Both these conditions need to be met for flowering and pollination.”

Upon being asked about the clinical trials in Vizianagaram and Chittoor, Srinivasalu said, “It (the experiment) met with some success in Chittoor district where conditions are dry. However, farmers are not very keen on it because Chittoor is home to India’s mango pulp industry and only pulpy varieties are grown here. We have around 46 such units in Chittor district.”

Discussing the failure of the experiment in Vizianagaram, R Srinivasa Rao, AD horticulture said, “The excessive humidity in the coastal district proved too oppressive for the species to flower. This is why the farmers are simply not interested.”

On being asked if there is any other coastal district in the state where this variety could be grown, Srinivasulu pointed out that the extremely high moisture levels aided by high groundwater levels would make it impossible to introduce this variety in any of the coastal regions. In dry areas such as Rayalaseema, pulp varieties are highly suitable as they yield better results.

Title: 3 held for illegal bird sale in Nalgonda
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Forest department arrested three persons in Rahmathnagar, Nalgonda for selling Lesser Whistling Teals, Sandpipers and Painted Snipes, that are listed under schedule IV of Wildlife Act, 1972. The forest department seized 15 from Taviaaboina Saidulu. Singam Seenaiah and Singam Saidamma.

“The accused are fishermen who were not aware of the Wildlife Act. We have decided to impose a compounded fine of Rs 50,000 on the three,” said Shantha Rao, divisional forest officer of Nalgonda . TNN

Title: Allahabad: ‘Jilted’ youth shoots woman dead, kills self
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Local residents look on as police investigate the crime scene

ALLAHABAD: A 22-year-old jilted youth allegedly gunned down a woman using a countrymade pistol before killing himself with the same firearm in Jhunsi’s Havelia locality on Saturday.

The two died on the spot. SSP Allahabad Satyarth Aniruddha Pankaj said, “The girl was identified as Saumya (19) and was pursuing BCom from a local degree college.”

According to reports, the deceased youth Shanu, son of Rizwan Ahmed, reached Saumya’s home around 2.30pm and then shot her. She was on her way to attend coaching classes when she was attacked.

Police said the CCTV footage recovered from nearby homes showed Shanu and Saumya interacting often. The footage from the day of the attack shows that after killing Saumya, Shanu ran a few steps and then shot himself in the head.

“We have sent the two bodies for postmortem examination. Their call detail records show that the two knew each other well and had been in touch for quite some time,” said the SSP. Police said they are still probing what might have caused the deceased youth to kill the woman.

Title: Hundreds protest across delta condemning attack on protesters in Tamil Nadu
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Protesters in Trichy

TRICHY: Hundreds of people affiliated to various Muslim outfits staged protests in Trichy, Nagapattinam, Thanjavur, and Tiruvarur condemning the police action on people who were protesting against the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) at Washermenpet in Chennai on Friday. CPI state secretary R Mutharasan, Trichy MP S Thirunavukkarasar and Manithaneya Makkal Katchi leader M H Jawahirullah condemned the police action against protesters.

Around 1,000 people including women, and children gathered near Palakkarai Roundabout on Old Madurai Road at 11 am on Saturday. They raised slogans against police alleging that they unleashed violence against the protesters in Chennai. They also demanded action against the police officer who ordered the lathi charge. They also raised slogans against the ruling AIADMK government.

Following the protests, traffic was affected along the road for more than an hour. Buses and other vehicles were diverted via Beema Nagar, Heber Road, and Court to reach Chathiram bus stand. More than 200 police personnel were deployed in the area.

Hundreds of people also staged protests at Keelvelur, Nagore and Mayiladuthurai in Nagapattinam district. Earlier, they took out rallies before gathering at the protest spot. Similar protests were held in 11 places in Thanjavur. Police arrested 40 people as they tried to block traffic in Thanjavur city. More than 500 protesters participated in the stir.

Protests were staged at various places including Mathukur, Athirampattinam, Mallipattinam, Senthalai East Coast Road, Nadukkadai in Thiruvaiyaru, near Head Post Office in Kumbakonam, Thirubuvanam, and Natchiyar Koil in Thanjavur district.

Meanwhile police registered cases against around 1,000 protesters in Tiruvarur for staging agitation. People from Thiruvarur, Koothanallur, Thiruthuraipoondi, and Muthupettai gathered in large numbers and raised slogans against the police violence.

CPI state secretary R Mutharasan and Trichy Congress MP S Thirunavukkarasar, who were in Pudukottai to participate in various events on Saturday, said that police used force to disperse the peaceful protesters in Chennai. Police resorted to lathi charge unnecessarily, which has prompted people across the state to take it to the streets, they alleged.

Manithaneya Makkal Katchi leader M H Jawahirulla urged the state government to pass a resolution against CAA in the assembly.

Title: Trichy: Dacoity case slapped on 10 who snatched phones from students
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: The Cantonment police have registered a dacoity case against 10 unidentified people for snatching two mobile phones from a 22-year-old student and four of his friends at gun-point here on Friday. In his compliant, V K Ushama of Kozhikode district in Kerala said that he was studying first year MSc Chemistry in a private college in Trichy. He and three of his friends who were staying in the hostel, had gone to meet another friend Mohammed Abubacker Sadhik in Mannarpuram. They took Abubacker’s car and went to an indoor badminton club. After playing in the club, they went back to Abubacker’s place and then they all went to the Trichy International Airport for sight-seeing. While returning, when they were nearing the Government Circuit House, a multi-utility vehicle overtook and stopped in front of them. Another car locked their car from behind. Around 10 people got down from the car and one of them smashed the right mirror of the car using the gun. They threatened the students at gun-point demanding to part with their valuables. They also sprayed some liquid on their faces after which they snatched Abubacker and Ushama’s mobile phones and fled the scene. As the incident took place near the government circuit house, police intensified the inquiry with the students. Commissioner of police, Trichy city V Varadharaju also conducted the enquiry with them on Friday. While launching the investigation by sifting through the CCTV footage of the entry and exit points of the city to identify the accused, police also inquired with the students as to why they visited the airport in the late hours. Police said that the weapon could have been an air gun as they found some air gun pellets at the spot.

Title: Vijayawada: Red Cross society sets new record in Guinness Book of World Records
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

the state governor Biswabhusan Harichandan

VIJAYAWADA: The Andhra Pradesh Red Cross Society branch entered the Guinness Book of World Records for the most number of people signing up to donate blood on Saturday. Officials said that the previous record stood at 2,000 and the current new record achieved by the Red Cross stands at 10,200 signups in a span of eight hours, in Krishna district. The entire drive was flagged off by the state governor Biswabhusan Harichandan at 11 am and lasted till 7 pm.

Speaking on the occasion, the governor said, “This gesture of compassion by the youth of Andhra Pradesh will be recognised all over the world over, as Guinness Book registers this event as a World Record. This truly makes me proud.”

He added that blood banking stands as a core activity of the Indian Red Cross Society and Andhra Pradesh has 18 blood banks across the state. “It is the largest procurer and supplier of blood in the state. Last year alone, it collected 82,055 blood units in 1,125 camps all over the state,” he said. Krishna district collector Mohammed Imtiaz collected the award after Guinness officials recognised the achievement.

Title: After Delhi feat, AAP may contest civic polls
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Buoyed by Aam Aadmi Party’s Delhi sweep, the party is now likely to contest the upcoming municipal election in the city.

“In the past 48 hours or so people’s perception about the party has changed. There is a high chance that in the forthcoming GVMC election we might field a few candidates,” Sheetal Madan, AAP district convener in Visakhapatnam told STOI on Thursday.

AAP’s tryst with Visakhapatnam began on February 23, 2014. They inaugurated a party office at New Venkojipalem and within a few months 380 people registered as party volunteers.

But since then AAP’s journey in the City of Destiny has not been promising. In a year, their number of active volunteers plunged to 10. In the 2014 Lok Sabha polls the party contested from two Lok Sabha constituencies – Araku and Visakhapatnam – and from five assembly constituencies – Vizag East, Vizag South, Vizag West, Gajuwaka and Araku, and lost. At present the party has barely 180 volunteers and a majority of them are college students or recent graduates.

Speaking about the party’s journey, Madan, who is a physician by profession, told STOI, “We lost popularity in no time because of two factors. First, in Indian politics it takes time for a regional party to gain popularity outside its headquarters region. Second, whatever popularity we received in the city it vanished suddenly after Arvind Kejriwal decided to resign in 2015.”

At present, besides few supporters, AAP members face acute fund shortage. Members of the executive body hold meetings at their residences on a rotational basis.

In fact, the condition of AAP in Visakhapatnam is so critical that the party did not contest from any seat in the 2019 Lok Sabha and Andhra Pradesh assembly polls.

Title: Two men drown as bike falls into pond
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Allahabad: Two men, in their 30s, drowned after their bike ran into a signboard and fell into a pond near Birha village on Lediyari-Koraon road under Koraon police station in the small hours of Saturday .

Koraon SHO Rakesh Kumar said the two victims had been identified as Mangla Mali aka Sheru and Lali Kol, both residents of Azad Nagar locality of Koraon.

“The duo were returning home from Lediyari around 1:00 am when their bike hit a signboard installed on the side of the road. They fell into a nearby pond along with the bike, and drowned,” the SHO said.

“Hearing a loud sound, a few locals rushed to the spot. Both of them were fished out from the pond and rushed to a nearby community health centre (CHC) where the doctors declared them brought dead,” he added.

“The bodies were sent for post-mortem examination and later handed over to their families for cremation on Saturday afternoon,” said Kumar.

In another incident, a 72-year-old man died after he was attacked with an iron rod by his son in Dhanua village under Naini police station on Saturday. “Irked over being reprimanded by the man for hurling abuses, his son, a vegetable seller, battered him to death with an iron rod,” said police.

Title: Bengaluru News - Times of India
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

YOGI OF TABLA : Pt Suresh Talwalkar

Pandit Suresh Talwalkar is giving this interview from Dhaka, Bangladesh where he along with four other renowned musicians have been training interested students in aspects of Hindustani classical music. “I visit Dhaka every month and teach at the Bengal Parampara Sangeetalay, I have been doing it for the past five years,” says Pt Talwalkar who one of India’s foremost tabla players. Hailed as a Taalyogi, teaching the instrument, mostly used in Hindustani classical music concerts as an accompaniment, comes naturally to him. “I run a tabla school (Taalyogi Ashram) in Pune and I have everyone from Western music instrumentalists, percussionists, and even Kathak dancers coming to learn from me. I teach them the laya-taal aspect of music because I clearly can’t teach them movement,” he laughs. At 72, Talwalkar has been playing the instrument for over 60 years and is a prominent soloist. A constant feature of his concerts is how he uses vocal music as an accompaniment to the instrument while traditional format places the vocalist at the centre. “I started doing this because if people only heard the tabla going da-da-da-da, they’d get bored. Adding vocal music makes it a more pleasant listen,” he says. He may be a Padma Shri awardee but Talwalkar does riyaaz just like he did when he was a young student. “I end up playing the tabla for 7-8 hours every day and this includes when I sit down to teach my students.” “For musicians, music is our life and there’s little else we think about,” he says.

NEVER A SIDE MAN: Ranjit Barot

As a drummer, all music is fair play for Ranjit Barot. Whether it’s Carnatic classical, Hindustani classical, jazz or film music, Barot is comfortable lending his drums to all kinds of music. “At the heart of it, all music is the same. There is a sense of discipline and great mastery of skill underlying the art, and when you as a performer are thrown into different styles of music, you get with it. I don’t find it difficult to communicate with musicians at all,” says Barot. As a drummer, he is part of John McLaughlin’s band, McLaughlin and the 4th Dimension, and plays the drums, composes and sings for his band Uncommon. He is also the music director of live shows for long-time associate AR Rahman. As a constant collaborator, when it comes to sharing the stage with other performers, it must be a task to know when to take the lead and when to take the backseat. “But I have never been a part of an ensemble where I have been a side man,” he laughs. In John McLaughlin’s band, all four of us members are strongly featured. And about performing live with AR Rahman – his songs are popular and fantastically written, that if music is needed to be soft, I take a backseat,” says Barot who will be performing at the Udupa Festival with a whole ensemble of musicians including Ustad Taufiq Qureshi, singers Kaushiki Chakraborty and Vijayprakash, bassist Etienne Mbappe and keyboardist and violinist Christophe Cravero.

THREE GENERATIONS TOGETHER: Sukanya Ramgopal

I have performed with my guru many times before but every time I play with him, I am just as nervous as the first time I played with him,” says Sukanya Ramgopal about performing with her guru, the legendary ghatam player Vikku Vinayakram at the Udupa Festival on February 21. “It’s a mix of feelings I have. One part of me is nervous, one part of me looks at it as a learning experience, and a whole other part of me is looking to get a ‘sabhash’ from him for any musical experiments that I will present on stage,” Ramgopal says. Her relationship with the legendary Vinayakram goes back to over fifty years now, when as a barely 10-year-old she heard him play and knew she wanted to play ghatam for the rest of her life. The story of how she asked him to teach her the instrument – making her probably the first women to play the ghatam – is by now legendary. Vinayakram initially refused to teach her by telling her that the clay pot made for a difficult instrument for a girl to play. Ramgopal persisted. “Then, he went to his father and told him that I was troubling him! That’s when his father (TR Harihara Sharma) told him, ‘the ghatam doesn’t know who is playing it. I think we will be fine inducting Sukanya as a student,” she recalls, all these years later. A trailblazer, Ramgopal today is a guru herself, and next Saturday, what has her excited is that she will be sharing stage with her guru, and her student, Ghatam Giridhar Udupa. “It is for the first time that I will be playing with both of them together; that also makes it three generations on the same stage,” she says.

STUDENT OF MUSIC FOREVER: Pt Subhankar Banerjee

Tabla maestro Pandit Subhankar Banerjee has an impressive list of musicians he has accompanied in concerts. The most noteworthy among them would include Pt Ravi Shankar, Ustad Amjad Ali Khan, Pt Hariprasad Chaurasia, Pt Shivkumar Sharma, Balamurali Krishna and Ustad Rashid Khan. He has also like a handful of his peers been part of diverse collaborations including performing with a symphonic orchestra, jazz ensembles, and film music. Looking back fondly at having shared the stage with lofty names like these at a relatively young age, Banerjee says that what was noteworthy was the maestros never treated him any different. “They never made me feel like I was a kid. They always treated me as a peer and for me, these opportunities were about being at par with them in terms of my expertise. It was about making a mark of my own,” says Banerjee. That he got these opportunities makes him lucky. “Yes, it is true that I got these opportunities rather early but as a musician, you can’t merely rely on luck. You have to sustain your talent and mastery over your instrument, so that people trust you to deliver every single time,” he adds. Banerjee has been playing the tabla for over 49 years and every time he sits with it, “I see how it is this exhaustive subject with more to explore. It is a nice feeling to be a student of music, and one lifetime is not enough to know it completely.”

Title: Vijayawada: Drowsy driver rams lorry into truck, three dead
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: Three persons died on the spot after a truck rammed into a parked lorry near Manipal Hospital on Saturday morning.

The deceased were identified as Yenamaneni Prabhakar (46), Malla Reddy (50) and Manne Brahmaiah (56).

According to Tadepalli circle inspector Mallikarjuna Rao, at around 4.45 am, the mini-truck, driven by Shahi alias Tirumala Rao, was going towards Tadepalli from Vijayawada . As it approached Kanaka Durga Varadhi, Rao fell asleep behind the wheel and hit two men – Malla Reddy and Brahmaiah — who were standing behind a parked truck carrying construction materials and killed them on the spot. While Rao escaped, his companion Prabhakar who was sitting beside him died.

Locals managed to rescue the driver from the wreckage and took him to a nearby government hospital and called the police.

All the bodies were sent for post-mortem. Meanwhile, a case under section 304A of IPC (causing death due to negligence) was registered at Tadepalli police station against Rao.

Title: Two Telangana workers absolved of rape charges in Iraq
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

Title: Trichy: Irregularities in paddy procurement: 45 DPC workers dismissed
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Trichy: In the wake of the complaints of widespread irregularities in the direct procurement centres (DPC) in Thanjavur, Nagapattinam and Tiruvaur districts, 45 employees who were engaged in procurement centres in the districts have been dismissed by respective district collectors.

Tamil Nadu Civil Supplies Corporation (TNCSC) has been procuring samba paddy from farmers in the delta districts. So far 5.40 lakh tonnes of paddy have been procured through 1,655 DPCs including the 310 centres functioning in other districts.

From 443 DPCs in Thanjavur district alone, 1.90 lakh tonnes of paddy have been procured by TNCSC authorities till February 13, officials said.

Meanwhile, farmers raised complaints against officials and workers of DPCs as they demand bribe between Rs 30 to Rs 40 for a bag of paddy. The farmers also alleged that the staff gave priority to merchants rather than farmers.

Following the complaints, food minister R Kamaraj along with ADGP, Civil Supplies Corporation CID wing Prateep V Philip conducted inspections at various DPCs in Thanjavur a few days ago.

During the visit, the minister said that 12 committees have been formed to monitor the procurement process to curb any irregularities.

Based on the monitoring committee’s reports, the district collectors of Thanjavur, Nagapattinam and Tiruvarur dismissed 45 workers from various DPCs, officials from the respective districts said.

This includes 16 workers from Thanjavur. Authorities have slapped a fine of Rs 29,716 for clerical mistakes done by them in accounts.

Title: Goa University-Admission Ranking Test round 2 on March 7-8
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Goa University

PANAJI: The second round of Goa University-Admission Ranking Test (GU-ART) for masters programme at the university and its affiliated colleges will be held on March 7 and 8. The exam for the seats vacant after the first round will be conducted at the university campus.

Students selected for seats during the first round of GU-ART will have to pay the seat confirmation fees latest by February 19, the university said.

“As seats are still available, mainly under the reserved categories, the university has decided to invite applications and conduct the second round of GU-ART. Applications for admission to PG programmes will be accepted through the online mode only from February 18 to February 27. Candidates who have already answered Round I for a particular programme are not required to answer again,” the university said in a notification.

It also said that Goa University does not assume any responsibility for the candidates not being able to submit their application within the last date.

“Candidates are advised to apply online much before the closing dates and not to wait till the last date for applying/payment of application fee to avoid possibility of disconnection/inability/failure to log on to the website,” the varsity’s notification reads.

Students who have completed their graduation or are in their final year of graduation are eligible to apply to appear for GU-ART.

The results of GU-ART round II will be declared on the university website by March 13, the university said.

Title: Fog delays flights at Mangaluru airport
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

MANGALURU: Heavy fog disrupted several flights at Mangaluru International Airport on Saturday morning. According to MIA officials, five flights, including international flights, were delayed, and one domestic flight bound to Bengaluru was cancelled.

Minister for primary and secondary education S Suresh Kumar was at the Kempegowda International Airport, and he was made to wait for 90 minutes since his flight could not take off for Mangaluru. The minister tweeted that his Mangaluru programme got delayed because of the flight delay. A flight from Dubai to MIA, which was supposed to land at 8.40am, got delayed for nearly three hours. Two flights from Bengaluru landed after three hours from scheduled time.

Meanwhile, MIA officials said that two flights to Bengaluru, which were supposed to depart at 9.05am and 9.15am, left the airport at 12.07pm and 11.15am, respectively. SpiceJet flight SG 3427/SG 3428, Bengaluru-Mangaluru-Bengaluru, was cancelled.

Title: Jajmau tanneries to stop ops from Feb 19
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Kanpur: Around 248 tanneries in Jajmau area will stop their operation from February 19 following a notice issued by the Regional Pollution Control Board asking them to close the units again till its further orders without giving any reason.

The tanneries, which remained closed for a period of 13 months on the charge of polluting Ganga, were allowed to start production on December 20 for two months only. This time limit is expiring on February 19

SB Franklin, regional pollution control board officer, said the government had allowed running the units for two months only and this time will expire on February 19.

Uttar Pradesh Pollution Control Board in its order has simply stated that the tanneries in Jajmau would remain closed till further orders, he said.

Firoz Alam of Small Tanners' Association said that on December 20 last year, the government, while granting permission to run the units with half capacity, had also stated that the tanners would be allowed to run their units till next year if they followed the necessary norms and standards fixed by the pollution control board.

"During the last two months not a single notice was issued to any tannery by the regional pollution control board because the tanneries did not flout the norms set by it", Alam said.

The new closure order is beyond our comprehension. The office-bearers of the association will meet senior officers of the board to know the reason for closure, he added.

Firoz Zafar, an export-import advisor, said the closure order would not only damage the business image of tanneries but would affect leather export too.

He said the tanneries which have got orders from foreign companies would suffer a lot for failing to supply the goods in time.

The tanners would not only suffer pecuniary losses but also face problems in getting new orders, he added.

Title: Budget boost likely for state road projects
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Bhubaneswar: With an aim to strengthen connectivity, the state government is likely to make a substantial allocation for road projects in the annual budget for 2020-21 to be presented by finance minister Niranjan Pujari on Tuesday.

Officials said the state highway development project, the Biju Expressway project, the Capital Road Development Programme, road reconstruction in Left-wing extremism (LWE)-affected areas and Mukhya Mantri Sadak Yojana will get adequate allocation in the budget.

Announced in August 2014, the 639-km Biju Expressway has been conceived as an economic corridor project connecting Rourkela and Jagdalpur in Chhattisgarh. The project has been designed to pass through western Odisha and the Koraput-Balangir-Kalahandi (KBK) region.

While the Rourkela-Sambalpur stretch (163km) of the project has already been completed, around 182km stretch of the project is being developed by the National Highways Authority of India. The state works department has taken up the development of the remaining 293km.

“Work on different patches of the project is going on in full swing. We expect the project to be completed by December next year. We hope that the state government will allocate adequate funds for the project. A detailed project-wise allocation will only be known after the presentation of the budget,” a senior works department official said.

Under the state highways development project, the government has taken up the ambitious task of developing the state highways. By the end of December 2019, about 2,000 km of state highways have been widened since 2013-14. Adequate funds are also likely to be earmarked for the project during 2020-21 for the project.

Title: GHMC raises Rs 2,500 crore for SRDP works
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: GHMC has raised Rs 2,500 crore under the rupee term loan (RTL) scheme to execute Strategic Road Development Plan ( SRDP ) projects.

“We have already spent Rs 300 crore,” said a GHMC official. In all, works costing Rs 5,900 crore are being taken up under SRDP. Apart from the loan, Rs 495 crore has been raised in three tranches previously.

Bio-diversity flyover II, Shiekpet elevated corridor, Botanical Garden elevated corridor, Jubilee Hills Road No. 45 flyover, cable bridge at Durgam Cheruvu , four flyovers and one underpass in LB Nagar constituency and two flyovers in Old City near Bahadurpura and Owaisi Hospital are SRDP works under progress.

When GHMC raised bonds for the first time, the government of India had waived the interest rate. “Using bonds, we could raise less amount when compared to the loan we had availed. There is no guarantee that central government will waive interest charges for the second time,” said GHMC commissioner DS Lokesh Kumar.

Title: Karnataka and Telangana players win national under-18 tennis tournament
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

TRICHY: The under-18 national level tennis tournament for boys and girls concluded here on Saturday with Karnataka and Telangana players emerging as title winners in the boys and girls categories respectively. Players affiliated to the All India Tennis Association (AITA) participated in the event.

The event, organised for the first time in the city, was held at the tennis courts at the Union Club, Bharathidasan road, and Officers club, VOC road. As many as 112 players including 64 boys from various states including Tamil Nadu, Kerala, Andhra Pradesh and Gujarat participated in the tournament. While top seeded AITA players directly entered the main rounds, low-ranked AITA players entered through qualifiers. In the finals of boys category, Nithilan Eric of Karnataka beat Pragadesh Sivshankar of Tamil Nadu (6-3, 7-5). In the girls , Sanjana Srimalla of Telangana beat Lakshmi Prabha of Tamil Nadu (6-2, 6-4). In boys doubles, Krishang Raghuvanshi of Haryana and Pratush Mohanty of Odisha bagged the title. Sanjana Srimalla of Telangana and Pari Singh of Haryana bagged the title in the girls’ doubles . TNN

Title: Dehradun: Woman dies after termite-infested tree falls on her car
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Old woman died allegedly after a termite-infested tree fell on her car

DEHRADUN: A 36-year-old woman died allegedly after a termite-infested tree fell on her car near Indian Military Academy in the city late on Friday night. The victim was a resident of Vasant Vihar area near IMA. According to reports, the tree was found to be infested with termites and snapped and fell when the woman was passing by in her car. The woman’s family was also on board the car at around 11:30 pm on Friday when the accident took place. Woman’s husband and daughter sustained critical injuries. “The family of Nitin Gupta from Vasant Vihar was travelling in the car. The accident, in which a giant tree fell on the car left Priyanka Gupta dead. Meanwhile, Nitin and her daughter were admitted to a hospital with serious injuries,” added the cop who said that no FIR has been lodged in the case as this was a natural incident. Expressing concern over the accident, local environmentalists asked the government to put “tree doctors” in place so that they can identify such trees and avoid such accidents. They pointed out that there are several big and small trees along roads and highways in the city and thus, their health must be regularly monitored. Anoop Nautiyal, a city-based social activist, maintained that everything has a shelf life and trees are no different. “Cutting of trees is illegal but those which are in poor condition and can lead to such accidents shouldn’t be left like this along roadside. There must be a robust mechanism to identify such trees and then treat them or cut them down,” said Nautiyal who is planning to write to the state government to deploy forest department staff to track the health of trees. Reenu Paul, another activist and environmentalist, put forest department in the culprit box for the accident. “The trees, which are there on roadsides or on highways, are responsibility of forest department. In our area, there were old trees which were bent and falling down towards road. We had written to the forest department several times to get these trees removed or slashed but they kept on passing the bucks to Public Works Department (PWD). This accident could have been prevented if the forest department had done its job,” said Paul. He added that forest and power department are responsible for decay of trees in city as they put up posters, banners, and wires on them and all this increases the pace of their decay.

Title: Man killed over chiding for rash driving
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Rajkot: An issue as trivial as reprimanding a fellow two-wheeler rider for over speeding cost man his life in Mahuva of Bhavnagar district on Saturday.

Police said the accused, identified as Museb Qadar, had allegedly smashed the head of Hanif Kalawatar (40) with a cement block. Kalawatar was taken to Mahuva Civil Hospital where he succumbed to his injuries.

“Our investigation has revealed that Kalawatar had chided Qadar for over speeding his two-wheeler while driving. This incensed Qadar so much so that he picked up a concrete block and bludgeoned Kalawatar with it,” said an official from Mahuva police station, adding that a manhunt had been launched for Qadar.

Title: Akhilesh alleges threat to life after man chants ‘Jai Shri Ram’
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Kanpur: Samajwadi Party president Akhilesh Yadav on Saturday alleged threat to his life from a “BJP leader” after a man chanted ‘Jai Shri Ram’ during a women’s conference at the party office in Kannauj on Saturday.

Akhilesh was attacking the BJP government over unemployment and price rise during the programme when a man interrupted him and asked what he proposed to do if his government came to power.

The SP chief asked the man to come closer saying he could not listen to him. At this, the man chanted ‘Jai Shri Ram’.

Akhilesh asked a police officer to find out how the man managed to breach security ring. “Bring him to me and collect all details about him. Cops should check his belongings,” he said.

He further alleged that there was a threat to his life from a BJP leader.

“I have received a threat call and a message from a BJP leader. I have saved the message in my phone and will inform media persons about it in Lucknow soon,” Yadav said.

Inspector, Sadar Kotwali, Vinod Mishra said: “We will book the man, identified as Govind Shukla of Gugrapur village, for disrupting peace.”

Attacking the government over the issue of women’s safety, Akhilesh said incidents of sexual assault were being reported everyday.

He also hit out at the Centre for constructing wall to hide slum areas in Gujarat ahead of the visit of US President Donald Trump.

The SP chief also asked party workers to get ready for 2022 assembly polls.

Title: Exonerated duo allege cheating by T men
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Hyderabad: Sherla Raju and Kuntala Laxman who have been set free from the central jail in Erbil, Iraq have alleged that they were cheated of 3,000 dollars (Rs 2.14 lakh) by two workers from Telangana.

The two men took the money on the pretext of helping Raju and Laxman fight their case. The victims said the amount was given by friends to Murthy and Ramchander, who hail from Kadem Mandal in Telangana.

“When we asked for the money back, we were threatened,” Laxman said. They wanted the Consulate General of India (CGI), Erbil, to initiate action against them , as the accused were also allegedly using the name of the CGI to collect money from Telangana workers in distress.

Raju and Laxman had gone to Iraq four years ago after paying Rs 1.5 lakh each to an agent in Nizamabad. However, after being taken to Iraq they were left with no aqama (work permit). After being declared innocent, the two are seeking help from the state government and CGI to return home. TNN

Title: ‘Stand up and be the dissenters’
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Ahmedabad: Justice D Y Chandrachud, judge of the Supreme Court (SC) on Saturday advised students to have an optimistic outlook towards life, becoming part of the solution and standing up for the voiceless.

The SC judge was the chief guest at the 10th convocation of Gujarat National Law University (GNLU), where he is also the Visitor. The event was attended by Justice M R Shah, SC judge, Justice Vikram Nath, chief justice of Gujarat High Court, and Bhupendrasinh Chudasama, state law minister.

In his convocation speech, Justice Chandrachud said that courage is the hallmark of a lawyer. “By courage I don’t merely mean courage of standing up to government… That’s not the only courage I am referring to – people who stand up against the state may make headlines in the newspapers, but we want citizens to have courage to stand up at other milestones in the history of the nation,” he said. “Standing up for someone who cannot stand up for themselves requires courage.” He also asked the students to question. “Grow up in life, stand up and be the dissenters because it is only through your power of expressing views and courage of stating contrary position that you will make others to stop and think,” said the SC judge. A total of 218 students were conferred degrees at the convocation including 158 from the five-year integrated UG programme, 50 of PG programmes, nine of MBA programme and one doctoral student.

Title: Double murder case: Raigarh police detains Sai’s driver
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Jharsuguda: The Raigarh police on Friday night picked up the driver of arrested former Congress MLA Anup Sai for questioning in connection with the 2016 murder of Kalpana Das (35) and her 14-year-old daughter Pravati.

The driver, Bardhan Toppo, was picked up from his residence at Bagarachaka village, under Rajpur panchayat of Brajrajnagar, late on Friday night.

Addressing the media, Raigarh SP Santosh Singh said Sai had named his driver during interrogation. “We are suspecting the involvement of some more people in this case,” the SP had said on Friday.

However, in a video circulating in social media, Toppo is seen saying, “I came to know from various news outlet that my name has been taken by Anup Sai during interrogation in connection with a double murder case. But I am innocent and I am not at all involved in the crime. Some local people advised me to run away, but I didn’t flee. If I have not committed any crime, then why should I run away? I am not afraid and I want the district administration to help me.”

Meanwhile, BJP Mahila Morcha burnt the effigy of Sai in Gandhi Chowk and demanded capital punishment for the crime. “It’s a heinous crime committed by a former MLA for which we demand strict punishment,” said BJP leader Radharani Panda, a former legislator from Brajrajnagar.

Title: MBA student raped, allegedly kidnapped: Meerut police deny claim
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image
