MEERUT: A 20-year-old woman, pursuing MBA from Chaudhary Charan Singh university (CCSU) in Meerut , was returning home after her classes when she was allegedly kidnapped and taken to Bulandshahr’s Syana area where the youths allegedly raped and brutally assaulted her on Thursday evening.

Based on a complaint by her father, an FIR under relevant sections of gang-rape, abduction, illegal confinement and assault was registered at Garhmukteshwar police station.

Unable to trace her, the family in Hapur then approached police, which put the woman’s phone on surveillance and she was rescued on Friday from the house of one of the accused in neighbouring Bulandshahr district with serious injuries on her face and neck. She was rushed to a hospital in Meerut where she is said to be stable, police said.

Police, however, have denied the claims of rape .

“During investigation, it was found that the woman went with her friend on her own. Both of them are adults. She got injured after she fell from the bike. Rape has not been confirmed in the medical report. However, I have asked all the authorities concerned to look into every aspect of this case and carry out a thorough investigation based on the available forensic evidence,” Praveen Tripathi, inspector general, (Meerut range), said.

Local policemen in Hapur investigating the case claim to be in possession of evidence which corroborate the IG’s stand.

Meanwhile, alleging police inaction, hundreds of students of Chaudhary Charan Singh University (CCSU) in Meerut gathered in front of the office of IG police in Civil Lines area and staged a sit-in. The protest saw sloganeering by students despite repeated attempts by the senior police officials to pacify them.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Tamil Nadu: Memorial for Pulwama martyr unveiled in Ariyalur
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

The memorial was built near Sivachandran family’s agriculture land

TRICHY: A memorial built for C Sivachandran, one of the 40 CRPF soldiers killed in the terror attack in Pulwama last year, was unveiled in his village in Ariyalur on Saturday. Family members, villagers and elected representatives paid floral tributes at the memorial commemorating his sacrifice. The memorial was built near Sivachandran family’s agriculture land in his village Karkudi. The family said that the memorial was constructed with the help of the solatium offered by governments and other organisations. As part of unveiling, a booklet on the life of Sivachandran and a rural folk song commemorating him was released in the presence of chief government whip S Rajendran. “We have placed a demand with the district administration to erect a statue of my husband at a roundabout near Ariyalur district collectorate. His statue may serve as an inspiration for the youth to join the armed forces and serve the nation,” said S Gandhimathi, Sivachandran’s wife told TOI. Gandhimathi who was pregnant when Sivachandran was killed had delivered a baby girl recently. “We named her Sivamathi as per my husband’s wish,” Gandhimathi added. Sivachandran had joined the CRPF in 2010 and had been posted across Jammu and Kashmir since then. He was one of the two soldiers from Tamil Nadu among the 40 CRPF soldiers killed in the terror attack on February 14 last year. Sivachandran is survived by parents Chinnaiyan and Singaravalli, wife Gandhimathi and children Sivamuniyan and Sivamathi.

Title: Trichy: Ignorance of procedures complicating adoption says S P Mohan
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Commission member S P Mohan.

TRICHY: Lack of understanding of adoption procedures has been prompting prospective adoptive parents (PAP) to go for illegal means to adopt a child, according to the Tamil Nadu state commission for protection of child rights (TNSCPCR). The recent exposure of two babies being illegally given for adoption by their parents in Thiruverumbur and Kuvalakudi was a matter of serious concern, said commission member S P Mohan.

He was addressing a seminar on the legal procedures for adoption organized for the police and media personnel by the anti-child trafficking unit (ACTU) in Trichy at the district police office on Saturday. “The process of adopting a child legally takes ten months, but the concerning factor is that the number of children is less than that of the prospective adoptive parents now. Further, such parents are also misguided about the procedures and documents required,” said Mohan.

He said PAPs can apply online on the website www.cara.nic.in of the central adoption resource authority (CARA) by uploading 11 documents and paying the prescribed fee fixed by the government. Children being given care and protection at any one of the 21 specialized adoption agencies (SAA) will be given for adoption. “Most of the 11 documents, like Aadhaar, are readily available with everyone. They have to obtain only certificates for income, fitness and conduct. The fee for the procedure would run into a maximum of Rs 50,000. Unfortunately, those ignorant about these things go for illegal adoption by coughing up Rs 2 lakh to Rs 3 lakh and land in trouble,” said Mohan. Referring to the two recent incidents, Trichy superintendent of police Zia Ul Haq said had the parents waited for some time they could have adopted the children legally. Mohan also revealed the recent instruction from the government to ensure CCTV cameras in all private hospitals to check child theft. He said the administration of government hospitals should check if these CCTV cameras were functioning properly.

The TNSCPCR member also pointed out incidences of birth certificates of newborn babies being manipulated with names of ‘adoptive parents’ during illegal adoption to show as if the child was born to them. Member of child welfare committee (CWC) N Krishnamoorthy spoke about the legal procedures for adoption.

Title: Bareilly: 33 anti-CAA protesters booked for assaulting constable
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

Bareilly: Police in Pilibhit have registered a case against 33 named individuals and 90-100 unidentified others for allegedly assaulting a constable and illegally confining him during a protest against CAA and NRC on Thursday.

According to police, constable Dushyant Kumar, who was on duty at the site of protest, was allegedly assaulted when he tried to stop the protesters from cooking at the venue. A police officer said, “The protesters caught him and thrashed him. They even dragged him to an adjoining house and locked him up before threatening to kill him if he raised an alarm. However, he managed to escape from the house on Friday and reached the police station where he narrated his ordeal. After Kumar’s statement was recorded, he was sent for medical examination. He sustained seven injuries in the incident.”

Police said that though section 144 is in force in the district, the protest was organised without permission and the protesters had placed a loudspeaker and chairs at the venue.

Based on the complaint of SHO Shrikant Dwivedi, police have registered a case against the accused under IPC sections 147 (rioting), 188 (disobedience to order promogulated by public servant), 332 (voluntarily causing hurt to deter public servant from his duty), 333 (voluntarily causing grievous hurt to public servant), 353 (assault or criminal force to deter public servant from discharge of his duty), 342 (wrongful confinement), 506 (criminal intimidation) and section 7 of Criminal Law Amendment Act. Congress district president Harpreet Singh, Bhim Army district president Atul Valmiki, district in-charge of Rashtriya Kisan Majdoor Sangathan Yusuf Chaudhary and five women are among the 33 named persons.

Superintendent of police Abhishek Dixit said, “An FIR has been lodged for organising a protest without permission, physically assaulting a constable and keeping him in confinement. No arrest has been made so far.”

Title: Leopard attacks spur Bijnor BSA to order boundary walls around 800 government schools
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose only

BIJNOR: In the wake of repeated leopard attacks in Bijnor , the basic education adhikari has chalked out a plan to construct boundary walls around 800 government schools located near forests or agricultural fields. Of the 2,556 government primary schools in the district, 800 schools do not have boundary walls and are located in areas where leopards are known to prowl. These have been shortlisted for building a boundary wall.

The decision was taken as six people have lost their lives in leopard attacks in the district since November 27. Among the victims was 14-year-old Prahsant Kumar, who was killed near his school at Bhogpur village in Najibabad tehsil on January 6. Besides scores of people have been injured in attacks by the big cats.

After the boy’s death, BSA Mahesh Chandra suspended the head master of Bhogpur primary school for dereliction of duty. The BSA also issued an advisory to all teachers to keep a strict eye on their wards and ensure that none is allowed to leave school during study time. On their part, many teachers and parents’ associations raised the issue of the lack of boundary walls around schools.

When contacted, district coordinator of Sarv Shiksha Abhiyan Salim Beg said, “We have chalked out a proposal to construct boundary walls around the remaining schools. In at least 800 schools, the boundary wall is either broken or do not exist at all. I hope the boundary walls will be constructed in the next academic session.”

He added, “We have also sent a proposal to revamp over 70 primary schools whose buildings are dilapidated.”

There are 2,556 primary and upper primary schools in Bijnor district in which around two lakh students are enrolled. According to the data available with the basic education department, as many as 450 schools do not have a boundary wall while it is under construction in 350 schools. This poses a constant threat to both students and teachers alike. More than 24,000 children are at risk of an attack by the big cat. Many of these schools are near sugarcane fields, which have become home for the leopards.

According to forest department officials, some 100 leopards live amid the cane fields. With cane harvesting on, leopard sightings have increase and so have man-big cat confrontations.

Rameshwari, a senior teacher in Najibabad block, said, “Big cats have been attacking people for the past two months. Six people have been killed. Many schools are located on the outskirts of villages and the route to reach them are unsafe. Teachers themselves fear to take such routes to reach their schools.”

According to a resident of Raipuri village in the absence of a boundary wall, a leopard can enter a school, especially those on the outskirts of the village, near cane fields.

Title: Kolkata: Novelty factor keeps East-West trains packed on first weekend
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Rush of passengers at Karunamoyee station on Saturday

KOLKATA: The excitement over the newly opened East-West Metro line continued on the second day, which happened to be the first weekend for the truncated services, as thousands poured in at the stations to get a feel of the latest addition to the city’s public transport system.

Waiting to buy his return ticket from Salt Lake Stadium to Sector V station, Howrah resident Sandip Das said, “The new Metro is Kolkata’s pride. I hope we can keep it this way.” The bank employee made use of his weekend free time to take his first East-West Metro ride. “This is too good, easily comparable with the other Metros I have travelled on, be it in Turkey, China or Paris . I am waiting for the day I can ditch my car and take the Metro straight from my house to my Sector V office.”

At the Bengal Chemical station’s ticket counter, Saini Saha echoed Das: “Please, please make sure that the city’s pride is kept as shiny and efficient forever. The station looks like an airport and the rakes like bullet trains.”

Even as the weekend ridership dipped on Saturday compared to the first day of service on Friday, which was a weekday, the crowd meter spiked on and off. The hourly census compiled by Metro Railway for the six East-West Metro stations showed the passenger count rising to 1,593 between 4pm and 5pm on Saturday from 1,541 during the same time on Friday. Between 5pm and 6pm on Saturday, 1,905 commuters boarded the East-West Metro as against 1,779 the same time on Friday. According to data, Karunamoyee station is the biggest crowd-puller after terminal stations Sector V and Salt Lake Stadium. Even as people kept walking in and out of City Centre station all through the day, its numbers weren’t as high as expected.

But then, Atrija Dutta, a Class XI student from EC Block, was taking her fifth joyride from City Centre at 3pm. She intended travelling five more times with school pal Soumyabrata Samanta. “Staying opposite City Centre, I have seen the Metro project being pieced together over the last nine years. I remember the park that was sacrificed to make way for it. I have missed the green patch all my life, but now I am feeling a little better after riding the world-class Metro,” Adrija said, pausing to catch some breath. Her excitement was palpable.

The weekend riders included people like Kabir Chakraborty, who had deliberately skipped the first-day ride for that group photo he was busy clicking along with his 11-year-old son, Ayushman, and wife Nabamita at Sector V station on Saturday. On Friday, the TCS worker did long to cross over to the Metro station when he saw his colleagues rushing to catch Kolkata’s brand new rapid transit on the very first day. “But then, I thought of my son, who was in school writing his exams, and decided to defer the visit to the weekend so that we could take the first ride together,” Chakraborty said.

Title: Surprise checks reveal employee absenteeism at AU
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The dean (academics) and registrar in-charge of Andhra University ( AU ) Professor K Venkata Rao visited various departments of the varsity on Saturday. He inspected in the morning attendance registers and services offered by the examinations wing.

An inspection of the college development council, computer centre and transportation wing in the afternoon revealed that several non-teaching employees were absent from their duties without any prior authorisation. After identifying the absentees in the register, Prof Rao asked officials to initiate action against these employees.

Prof Rao said employees cannot leave office during working hours without informing the concerned officials. “Otherwise, they have to face the music. Negligence in delivery of duties cannot be tolerated. Employees should offer seamless services to those approaching the university. We should create a culture of speedy and efficient service delivery to meet growing expectations,” said Prof Rao.

Title: Mom, lover arrested for assaulting 3-yr-old boy
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Alappuzha: A three-year-old boy, who was brutally assaulted by his mother’s lover, is undergoing treatment in the children’s ICU of Alappuzha Medical College Hospital (MCH). Ambalappuzha police arrested the mother Monisha, (28, alias Vidhu) and her partner Vaishak (32), a fisherman by profession, from Neerkunnam for attacking the child.

CI T Manoj said Vaishak ’s first wife left him as she was unable to put up with him. “Monisha started to live with him three months ago after leaving her second husband, who is the boy’s father. The accused started assaulting the child a month ago. The accused considered the child as a burden and so he started attacking the child. He kicked the boy’s stomach and also injured the child’s penis. They were arrested on Saturday evening after residents took matters into their hands and tried to protect the child,” he said, adding that the child had told his relatives that his mother had also beaten him. The accused had tried to escape on knowing that police were after him and he jumped into the sea near his home to evade them. The police finally caught him.

They accused will be produced before Alappuzha JFCM court. Charges were filed against them under Section 77 of Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act 2015 (punishment for cruelty to child) and IPC sections 307(attempt to murder), 323 (punishment for voluntarily causing hurt), 324 (voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous weapons or means) and 34 (acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention).

District collector M Anjana said district child welfare committee will take care of the boy. “A Childline and a Kudumbashree member have been deployed to take care of the child at the hospital. After he is discharged, he will be shifted to the child protection centre. The condition of the child is stable,” said the collector.

Title: East-West Metro: 353 tokens lost on first day, 200 more on second
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

East-West Metro token stock has started depleting very fast

KOLKATA: On its first day of commercial service, East-West Metro lost 353 of the 11,860 tokens it sold and on Saturday, another 200 tokens went missing. Apparently, the passengers wanted to keep them as mementos of their first ride.

The missing tokens have set the new Metro back by Rs 20 (rounded up cost) for each token. Asked how commuters managed to leave the station without swiping out of the automatic fare collection system, officials said people simply walked away with the tokens because on the first day, the station staff were not all that vigilant and the side gates weren’t locked.

“Mediapersons were allowed into the station through these side gates, and they remained open,” an official said. He recalled that the occasion was so special that everyone was in a light mood. Officials believed that most tokens went missing between 8am and 10am.

On Saturday, a Salt Lake resident who had commuted on the first day showed his token and confessed, “This means a lot to me. It’s my first token of the East-West Metro, on its first day of service.”

Title: Bareilly: Health department to monitor seven who returned from Thailand for novel coronavirus
Content:
Representative image

Bareilly: The immigration department has sent a list to the health department for monitoring seven Bareilly residents who returned from Thailand, suspecting of contracting novel coronavirus (nCov-2019).Bangkok had last week declared 32 confirmed cases of novel coronavirus.District epidemiologist Meesam Abbas said, “We are daily taking health updates of seven Bareilly residents who went on a trip to Thailand. They have been quarantined at their homes. However, their condition is stable and none of them have shown any symptoms of the novel coronavirus. If any symptoms appear in future, we will take samples and send it to a laboratory in Lucknow.”Meanwhile, out of 47 people who returned from China since January, the incubation period of 28 days for 35 people is over and only 12 are currently under observation.According to health officials, the incubation period for the novel coronavirus is 14 days, but they are monitoring people for 28 days as a precautionary measure.The incubation period begins from the date of arrival to India and health team take daily health update to check if any symptom has appeared or not. Symptoms of the disease are fever, cough, difficulty in breathing, chest pain, pneumonia and rapid heartbeat.In Bareilly, health department had collected samples of four suspected cases for nCov-2019 and all of them had tested negative for virus.

Title: Agra: 3 killed in separate accidents
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

AGRA: At least three persons were killed and seven injured in three different road accidents on Yamuna expressway and state highway in Mathura and Agra districts on Saturday.

The first accident occurred on Yamuna expressway at around 6:20 am near milestone 80 of Surir police jurisdiction of Mathura district when a Greater Noida-based cab driver allegedly rammed into an unknown vehicle. Identified as Danendra Kumar (35), the victim was returning home after dropping a passenger.

According to police, “The victim’s car probably rammed into a vehicle. An FIR has been lodged against unknown persons for death caused due to negligence.”

Similarly, a mini-truck rammed into an auto-rickshaw ferrying six passengers on Fatehabad Road of Tajganj area. After the incident, the accused truck driver fled the spot.

“Two men identified as Laxman and Ram Singh travelling in the auto-rickshaw were killed, while five other passengers were injured. We have seized the mini-truck,” said police.

A CCTV footage of the accident revealed that the mini-truck was on the wrong side and hit the auto-rickshaw. At the time of filing this report, an FIR was yet to be registered.

Similarly at around 2:30 pm, a pedestrian couple was hit by a bike rider near Kundaul village of Dauki police jurisdiction in Agra. The couple was admitted to local private hospital in an unconscious state.

Title: Agra: 14-year-old booked for raping three-year-old neighbour
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

AGRA: Police have registered a case against a 14-year-old boy for allegedly raping a three-year-old girl in Firozabad district .

The accused is a neighbour of the survivor and is on the run after the crime. Based on a written complaint lodged by the girl’s parents, police registered a case against the boy, a class VII student, and are on the lookout for him.

Prabal Pratap Singh, superintendent of police (city), Firozabad, said, “We have registered a case against the boy. Once caught, we will present him before the juvenile justice board. The girl has been sent for medical examination.”

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: BJP MLAs clash over control of Haridwar college
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

HARIDWAR/DEHRADUN: A clash between rival factions owing allegiance to two BJP MLAs — Haridwar MLA Madan Kaushik on one side and Haridwar (rural) MLA Swami Yatishwaranand on the other — over the management of the Gurukul Mahavidyalaya, a more than a century-old educational institution in the city, has been going on since February 5, allegedly over control of the land belonging to the institution.

Both the factions are accusing each other of “trying to illegally capture control of the institution.”

Speaking to TOI, Hari Gopal Shastri, vice-chancellor, who is an associate of Yatishwaranand, alleged that the trouble arose on February 5 as supporters of cabinet minister Madan Kaushik tried forcibly to throw out the college officials from their offices in the campus. Reiterating the claims, Yatishwaranand said, “This is a blatant attempt by Madan Kaushik and his associates to take over the institution simply because they are eyeing the property of the college.”

Yatishwaranand alleged that when he along with other office bearers reached the premises on February 6, they were not allowed to enter. “All of us were forced to sit on a protest outside,” he claimed.

Reacting to the allegations, the college joint secretary Anil Goel, an associate of Kaushik, alleged that “Yatishwaranand is not even a primary member of the managing committee and has been expelled.” “His writ petition in the Nainital high court against his expulsion was dismissed by a single-judge bench in May last year and by a double-judge bench in October. Their group has illegally captured the college,” he added.

The college situated on the Delhi-Haridwar highway has about 300 bigha of prime land worth several hundred crores. Only a small part of it is being used to run Sanskrit courses and the strength of students is hardly a hundred. "The land mafia want to grab the remaining land lying unutilised and they are behind the power struggle in the institution," a local resident said.

Title: HMRL asked to raise median height
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Hyderabad: City police asked Hyderabad Metro Rail Limited to raise height of central median grills to regulate pedestrian movement. “Most accidents take place while people cross the road over central medians, particularly in Kukatpally & Serilingampally,” read a statement by GHMC. GHMC commissioner DS Lokesh Kumar also asked HMRL to take up development of medians from Jubilee Bus Station to Mahatma Gandhi Bus Station. TNN

Title: SSV School routs American School’s dreams by 60 runs
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Vadodara: Yug Shivle’s brilliant knock of 34 and Jenish Solanki’s 4 wicket haul helped SSV School to clinch an easy win over American School on the fourth day of the Maharani Shantadevi U-19 Inter School Tournament at the PTC ground here on Saturday.

After winning the toss, American School sent SSV School boys to bat first. But within one hour, seven of SSV’s batsmen were sent back to pavilion, with just 61 on the board in 20 overs.

Apart from Jenish Solanki’s fiery knock of 21 in just 25 balls, the eighth wicket partnership between Yug Shivle (34 in 73 balls) and Neel Patel (27 in 45 balls) helped the team get past 100 runs on the board. The duo troubled the American School bowlers and added 69 runs in 14 overs. Medium pacer, Bhavin Parmar, finally broke the record stand when the bowler clean bowled Patel.

Tailenders could not add much on the scoreline leaving SSV boys were all out for 144 in 38.1 overs as Parmar ran through the batting line-up of American School claiming 7 wickets.

American boys started the chase with a slow start on good batting pitch. The scoring rate was kept below three runs an over, however, the team kept losing wickets at frequent intervals. Bhavin Parmar again came to the rescue of the school, with a quick knock of 24 in 19 balls, but Jenish Solanki claimed his wicket in the 28th over to end all hopes of the American boys, who were all out for 84 in 32.2 overs.

Jenish was adjudged man of the match for his knock of 21 and a 4 wicket haul.

Title: Menstrual rigour: Gujarat state women commission meets traumatized girls
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Five-member state commission team at the institute on Saturday

RAJKOT: Members of the state commission for women visited the Shree Sahjanand Girls Institute campus in Bhuj on Saturday, while the National Commission for Women (NCW) will visit the premises on Sunday. The five-member team of the state commission recorded statements of the victims.

Talking to media persons in Bhuj, member of commission, Hansa Patel said, “We talked to nearly 60 girls in a separate room and also with the trustee and hostel management later. We have also asked the management to provide CCTV records of the day of the incident and to update us about the findings of their investigation.”

Members of the Kutch Mahila Vikas Sangathan (KMVS), working on women’s issue in Kutch, also accompanied the state commission members. A member of KMVS, Malshree Gadhvi said, “We are going to organize a programme in Bhuj on Sunday that will spread the message of abolishing these kinds of inhuman tradition followed by some of the sects. We will ask the girls of other institutes to report to us if they too are facing any similar kind of harassment.”

Meanwhile, the head of Swaminarayan temple in Bhuj, Dev Prakash Swami, reportedly visited the girl’s hostel on Saturday evening to resolve the issue. Generally, Swaminarayan priests are not even supposed to look at girls, but according to informed sources, the priest even went to the girls’ hostel. However, TOI could not independently verify the truth of his visit nor contact the Swami for his comments.

The Bhuj temple of Swaminarayan sect is managed by Nar Narayan Dev Gadi which runs the college and hostel too.

Title: In 2019, over 3k cyber frauds reported
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Hyderabad: In 2019, 3,838 cases of OLX fraud were reported in the three commissionerates – Hyderabad, Cyberabad and Rachakonda. One of the common ways to con people was by posting fake advertisements. If a customer showed interest, those posting ads said that they were army officials who got transferred recently, and so were selling the products at low prices. So, cyber teams have started awareness drives across the city. tnn

Title: Rs 1.65 lakh realised in KMC’s anti-encroachment campaign
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Kanpur: The enforcement wing of Zone-3 of Kanpur Municipal Corporation ( KMC ) on Saturday launched an anti-encroachment campaign and realised Rs 1,65,000 as fine from the encroachers.

The anti-encroachment squad demolished several illegal encroachments on the road between Sagarpuri and Jai Gurudev guest house. The team also took action against two units for storing dirty polythene and imposed a fine to the tune of Rs. 50,000 on each unit.

The team was led by Bhanu Pratap Singh, additional municipal commissioner and Radhey Shyam Patel, in charge of zone 3. In zone- 4, 1500 grams of polythene was seized. The officials removed encroachment from P Road and realised Rs 11,000 from illegal occupiers. They also realised Rs 3000 as fine for recovery of polythene, Shyam Patel said.

Title: Bihar: Teacher shot dead in Sheohar district
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: A 40-year-old woman teacher of a government school was shot dead by unidentified criminals in Sheohar district on Saturday.

Police said the incident took place around 9am when the deceased, Pallavi Kumari, was on way to a government middle school at Salempur under Tariyani block on a scooty. Three motorcycle-borne assailants intercepted Pallavi near Deokuli Dam and fired at her from close range.

The injured was rushed to a private hospital by locals. She, however, succumbed to her injuries during treatment. Pallavi was a resident of Sahiyari village under Riga block in Sitamarhi district.

Sheohar sub-divisional police officer (SDPO) said Pallavi was transferred to Salempur from Belahi Dullah about two months ago. “Efforts are on to identify the assailants and arrest them. The reason behind the murder is yet to be ascertained,” he added.

The daylight murder of the woman teacher has sent shockwaves among the local residents. “She used to go to her school on a two-wheeler from Sitamarhi, which the assailants were aware of. They were waiting for her near the Deokuli Dam. They fired at her soon after she reached the spot,” an investigating officer said quoting an eyewitness.

Title: Covid-19 scare: Steep duty hike push toy trade into deep trouble in Kolkata
Content:
The stock for battery-operated toys and soft toys is expected to last 30-40 days

KOLKATA: Partha Roy, a resident of Northern Avenue, went to Fariapukur last Sunday to buy a remote-controlled toy to gift his nephew on his birthday. He was looking for the same one he had earlier bought for one of his relative’s son. But to his surprise, Roy looked around but could not find it at 10-15 odd toy shops in the vicinity. He had no other option but to buy something else for his nephew.Roy is not the only one. Many buyers visiting markets at China Bazaar, Bagri Market or Fariapukur are having a tough time buying items for kids. A virtual stop in import from China in the wake of a massive hike on import duty on toys, and the coronavirus scare have hit the toy trade hard.Vikash Jain, the vice-president of West Bengal Exim Association, pointed out that the customs duty has been hiked from 20% to 60% in the Budget from immediate effect. Besides, only 10% of the total import from China are now coming to India. “The shortage has pushed up the prices of most toys by 25%-30%. The number of varieties available now has also gone down. We have stock of imported toys that will last 30-40 days,” he said. He added that the coronavirus scare has also taken a toll on import f Chinese toys.Currently, over 80% toys that are sold in city markets are imported from China, Malaysia, Hong Kong, the UK and Germany. Bengal is a Rs 1,000 crore market for toys while Kolkata alone account for Rs 700-750 crore. There are over 4,000 retail shops for toys in the city and the state figure is 10,000. The retailer and small vendors are now apprehensive that this steep hike would destroy the industry.Souvikk Ghosh, a toy retailer in Fariapukur felt the industry will cease to exist gradually. “The customs duty hike is from immediate effect, so even if some distributors have old stock, they will turn costly. Soon it will be difficult to get buyers,” he explained.Duty hike and coronavirus scare are killing the trade, Sumit Bhalotia of Venus Impex agreed, echoing Jain and Ghosh. “We are heavily dependent on import because there are hardly any indigenous manufacturing in India for sophisticated toys,” he said.

Title: Bareilly: Man booked for rape, murder of sister-in-law
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

BAREILLY: A man was booked for the alleged rape and murder of his sister-in-law following the directions of a judicial magistrate in Izzatnagar. The case was booked on Friday and the accused has not been arrested so far in want of “sufficient evidence”.

According to the police, a 25-year-old woman was found dead in her house in Izzatnagar on November 16, 2019, and her mother cremated the body without informing the police.

Later her mother came to know through her neighbour that her daughter was raped by her sister’s husband, who had also strangulated her to death, police said.

The court later gave directions to the police to record the statement of the neighbour. SHO Izzatnagar police station AK Verma said he would arrest the accused once he is able to gather sufficient evidence against the accused.

“The accused cannot be arrested unless we have strong evidence against him. In the absence of the autopsy report, we have to find some conclusive evidence. Self-confession is also an option, but we don’t think that the accused will accept his guilt. I wish the mother had informed police immediately after the death of her daughter and post-mortem report would have cleared the path for an investigation,” Verma told TOI.

Notably, an application was filed in the court under 156 (3) CrPC by victim’s mother after police had earlier refused to file an FIR in the absence of post-mortem report.

According to the complaint, the victim’s mother works as a labourer at a reputed institute in Bareilly and her elder daughter was married to the accused nearly 6 years ago. Accused often used to stay at her house but days before the incident her elder daughter had a quarrel with him because of his behaviour.

On October 16, when her mother went for work with her elder daughter, the accused allegedly came to her house and raped and killed her. When mother returned home, she thought that her daughter had committed suicide and cremated her body. Few days later, her neighbours gathered courage and told her that they had heard her daughter shouting for help but didn’t interfere as it was a family matter.

Title: Four ‘baraatis’ killed, 16 injured after bus hit stationed container
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

The joy of marriage soon turned out be a horror of tragedy for Zilpe family when four of its members, who were returning to Nagpur in a private bus, rammed into a stationary container from behind, were killed and 16 of them injured. The incident happened at around 5:15am on Saturday on NH53 near Singori village.

Around 35 ‘baraatis’, including men, women and children, were returning to the city after attending marriage of Amit Zilpe, a policeman posted at police headquarter in Nagpur, from Tiroda in Gondia district when the accident took place.

The deceased have been identified as Vithabai Zilpe, 72, Karuna Wankhede, 58, Anand Athawle, 28 and Satish Jambhulkar, 35. Vithabai was the grandmother of the groom. While Karuna and Anand were killed on the spot, the other two succumbed to injuries at a hospital in Bhandara which is just 15 to 20 kilometres away from the accident spot.

It is learnt that Karuna and Anand were stuck inside the damaged parts of the bus and had to be pulled out by police.

Mauda police have registered a case of rash driving and death due to negligence against drivers of the bus and the stationary container. Both the drivers are currently absconding. The driver of the container has been booked as he parked the vehicle without taking proper precautions.

Police sources said the bus driver was driving the vehicle at a high speed and might have fallen asleep following which it rammed into the container which was stationed on far left of the road, leaving the traffic on the national highway blocked for several hours. Such was the impact of the accident, that the bus split from middle till the third seat and the container’s head turned to 90% to the right.

Uncle of the groom, Arvind Zilpe, who was also travelling in the bus, told TOI, “We left the marriage hall in Tiroda at around 10pm on Friday. We were travelling to Nagpur when suddenly early in the morning our bus rammed into the container. It led to a chaos but we managed to calm people.”

Soon, a traveller informed police control room, and Mauda police, led by PI Madhukar Gite, rushed to the spot.

By the time help arrived, Vithabai and Satish who were seriously injured in the accident were sent to a hospital in Bhandara by their relatives but they died later, police said.

Police sent the injured to Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) in Nagpur where two persons were declared dead. Bodies of the deceased were later sent to Mayo Hospital where their postmortem were conducted.

“We used cranes to remove both the vehicle from the spot. We have also started search of both the drivers in the case,” said PI Gite.

Title: 8 mths on, chargesheet filed in Univ College assault case
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

The three main accused in the assault case are Sivarenjith, Naseem (in pix) and Pranav

Thiruvananthapuram: Almost eight months after third-year BA Politics student Akhil Chandran of University College here was stabbed on chest by his collegemates, police have submitted the chargesheet in the case before the court. Investigation officer of the case, inspector M Anilkumar of Cantonment police station here, submitted the chargesheet before judicial first class magistrate court – III on Saturday.

As many as 19 people are arraigned as accused in the case. All of them are students of University College and activists of SFI. The complainant, Akhil Chandran, is also an SFI activist. The three main accused in the case are Sivarenjith, Naseem and Pranav, who were all leaders of the SFI unit in the college.

According to sources, police have stated in the chargesheet that the attack on Chandran was the result of a continuing personal rivalry between him and the main accused in the case. Police found out in the investigation that the accused had difference of opinion with Chandran over the way the organisational activities were carried out inside the campus. This developed into a personal enmity. Around one year before the crime, the accused has allegedly vandalised the motorcycle of Chandran. The stabbing incident is considered to be a continuation of that rivalry.

The alleged crime took place on July 12. Following the incident, all the accused went absconding. Police identified the 19 accused from visuals shot by other students who were on the campus. The investigation continued from July to January this year during when police managed to track down and arrest all the suspects identified at different occasions. All of them are charged with section 307 of IPC pertaining to attempted murder.

Police have listed 70 people as witnesses in the chargesheet.

Title: One more phone found from jail
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Ahmedabad: Sabarmati Central Jail officials on Friday found one more cellphone on the jail premises. The phone was hidden in the washroom of Circle Yard 6 of barrack number 6/1. The officials have lodged a complaint with Ranip police in this connection. Police suspect that an undertrial Ketan alias Kishan Barot had been using the phone.

“Barot’s name was revealed by some inmates during the primary investigation,” said a jail official. Further probe will be done by the special operation group (SOG) after getting the case from the Ranip police.

The police had launched Operation Clean-Up last month to scan jails for illegal items. The jail authorities woke up after city crime branch registered a case under GujCTOC against gangster Vishal Goswami and his associates for running an extortion racket from jail. Besides 500 regular staff, 100 additional constables were posted in Sabarmati jail after the incident. tnn

Title: NHAI launches underpass work on Trichy-Chennai National highway
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

The Trichy-Chennai National Highway 38

TRICHY: As a part of eliminating the accident black spot on the Trichy-Chennai National Highway 38, National Highways Authority of India ( NHAI ) has launched civil work on a vehicular underpass on the highway at Srirangam. The proposed four-lane underpass will link Kondayampettai in Srirangam with Thiruvalarsolai and adjoining agrarian hamlets on Kallanai Road bordering the neighbouring Thanjavur district.

According to NHAI Trichy Project Implementation Unit (PIU), the underpass was sanctioned by the ministry of road transport and highways (MoRTH) based on suggestions by the NHAI to eliminate accidents on the stretch. Hundreds of vehicles from Kondayampettai and Srirangam cross the busy Trichy-Chennai NH every day amidst the heavy volume of speeding vehicles to reach Thiruvalarsolai on Kallanai Road and Grand Anicut dam, a major tourist attraction.

As accidents are frequent on the stretch, the underpass on the lines of the one at Samayapuram on the Trichy-Chennai NH was suggested on the NH near Iraniyamman temple. NHAI through the concessionaire of Samayapuram toll plaza has taken up the civil work on the underpass at an estimated cost of Rs 15 crore after getting permission from the MoRTH.

Ahead of installing the underpass, NHAI has launched the civil work on service roads. Vehicles using the Trichy-Chennai NH can use the 400-metre two-lane service roads until the completion of the work. “Once the work on the service roads is completed, the portion of the Trichy-Chennai NH will be closed,” an official source with NHAI said. The seven-metre wide service roads are being relaid by the concessionaire of Samayapuram toll plaza. NHAI said work will take 8-9 months to complete. “Kondayampettai-Thiruvalarcholai road intersection is a major black spots on Trichy-Chennai NH,” G Kanaga Rajan, member, Trichy Intra-City Development Endeavours, said.

Title: Nagpur: Potpourri of lit fests giving littérateurs a high
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: Reading a favourite book with a beverage to boot is a high in itself, but engaging in a lively and engaging conversation with the stars who put their pens to paper is a high of a different kind, a culture which is slowly gaining momentum due to the rise in the number of literature festivals being held in the city in the last three months.

Right from the Orange City Literature Festival which was held in December to the Vidarbha Literary Festival and the ongoing Nagpur Literary Festival, engrossing and enthralling sessions have taken the theme ‘celebrating literature’ to an altogether new level.

To get to know their side of the story, TOI spoke to a few citizens and authors .

Mrunal Naik, project head of the Orange City Literature Festival believes that such festivals satisfy the literature needs of avid readers. “It’s really nice that the city is witnessing such initiatives. Readers are getting the opportunity to interact with renowned authors and personalities in Nagpur. I hope this trend continues for years to come. One gets to attend multiple sessions and there are a variety of topics to choose from,” said Naik.

People from all age groups can be found at these festivals. They are either soaking in the knowledge or lending their ears to celebrity speakers. “Literature festivals are attracting more and more authors to Nagpur, irrespective of the genre. This will help Nagpur to shine on the world literary map,” said Hemant Lodha, chairman of the Vidarbha Literary Festival.

For Swati Sani, literature festivals have opened new doors for budding authors to make a big impression by talking about their creative work and interacting with their readers or future readers.

“Interacting with authors helps readers to understand the art of writing and interpreting. Local authors are also getting a stage to showcase their literary work which is truly appreciable,” said Sani.

Dr Naznin Chimthanawala, an author and psychologist, spoke about the gains from literature festivals. “In today’s fast-paced world, where people are busy on their mobile phones, literature festivals offer a much-needed positive escape. People not only meet authors, they also meet other literature lovers which is a very healthy sign.” she said.

Right from science to romance, history to sexuality, there is something for every book lover because of the multiple sessions that are conducted. “People are coming in good numbers to enjoy the lit fests. I think it’s a great opportunity to bond over books and interact with your favourite authors,” said, Mandar Pandhare, an active participant in city’s social events.

Rashmi Priya, another literature lover, said, “We get to learn a lot from authors and their writing journeys. Lit fests are very motivating for youngsters as their minds are filled with curiosity and creativity.”

Suresh Akotkar is not only an avid reader but also an author. He is all praise for the literature wave that has swept the city. “People always appreciate good books but with such kind of events, they even get to celebrate the authors in person. People come enthusiastically to attend and engage in mindful conversation with the authors.”

Title: Bihar minister flies into rage as cop tries to frisk him
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Bihar health minister Mangal Pandey

PATNA: Fame can sometimes be a burden, but going unrecognised can be much more problematic. State health minister Mangal Pandey discovered it the hard way when a police officer stopped him from entering the venue for a foundation stone laying ceremony of a hospital in Siwan district on Friday.

A video went viral on Saturday in which Pandey, who is also a native of Siwan district, can be heard rebuking an assistant sub-inspector of police (ASI), Ganesh Chauhan, for preventing him from entering the venue of the function. “Pagal ho gaye ho kya? Mantri ko nahi pahchanta hai (Have you lost your senses? You don’t recognize the minister),” he said.

The minister didn’t stop there. Going a step further, he asked sub-divisional police officer (SDPO) Jitendra Pandey to place the cop in question under suspension. “Isko turant suspend karo. Isko kaun yahan duty lagaya hai (Suspend him immediately. Who has deployed him here on duty?” the minister can be heard telling the SDPO, who was assigned to take care of the VIPs.

Apart from governor Phagu Chauhan, a number of ministers and BJP functionaries were present at the function. State art, culture and youth affairs minister Pramod Kumar, who was watching the scene from close distance, however, preferred not to intervene with a lower rung police officer.

In a bid to pacify the minister, who was angry over the cop’s (mis) behaviour, the SDPO assured the former of looking into the matter on a priority basis. “I will apprise my seniors about his (Ganesh Chauhan’s) misconduct. He should not have behaved even with common people so rudely,” the SDPO told the minister before he left for the venue.

A BJP functionary, who was just behind the health minister, said on condition of anonymity, “It was more humiliating for him (minister) as he was surrounded by many supporters, who later introduced him to the police officer on duty. Pandey, a native of Siwan district, was earlier the state president of the BJP.”

The ASI Chauhan, however, had no regrets for the incident. “I was doing my job. Frisking was being conducted at the entrance gate of the venue for the function. I signalled him to stop for frisking because I didn’t recognise him. The rest depends on my seniors,” he told this newspaper.

Last year, the minister had hogged the limelight when a video surfaced in which he could be heard asking about the India-Pakistan match score amid a press briefing held by Union health minister Dr Harsh Vardhan to discuss the ways to cope with the AES deaths in Muzaffarpur and other parts of the state.

Meanwhile, leader of opposition in state assembly Tejashwi Prasad Yadav slammed the health minister for seeking suspension of the police officer. “Shocked to see how Bihar’s health minister is bragging about his entitlement. Assuming the Cop on duty couldn’t recognize the minister & requested for identification, does it behove of a minister to publicly threaten & humiliate him? Power drunk minister shd be suspended instead (sic),” Tejashwi tweeted on Saturday.

Title: Uttarkashi: Four killed, as many hurt after car falls into gorge
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Car they fell into a 250-metre-deep gorge from Yamunotri national.

UTTARKASHI: At least four people were killed and as many sustained severe injuries after the car they were travelling in fell into a 250-metre-deep gorge from Yamunotri national highway near Barkot village area of Naugaun block in Uttarkashi district on Saturday evening.

Soon after the accident, a State Disaster Response Force team and local police personnel launched a rescue operation and fished out bodies. Meanwhile, the injured were rushed to a local health centre, from where they were referred to a hospital in Dehradun after being given primary treatment.

According to sources, all eight passengers were residents of Naugaun block and they were returning after visiting a fair organised in Gangnani region on Saturday.

Devendra Patwal, district disaster management officer, told TOI, “The deceased have been identified as Seema (36), Naveen Chauhan (32), Arpita (2), and car driver Deshraj (27). We are trying to find out how the accident took place. The exact cause of the accident can be ascertained only after a probe is carried out.”

Title: Plans afoot to replace coal–based furnaces with PNG in Moradabad brass units
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

The coal furnaces are used to smelt copper and zinc for manufacturing brass and molding it into shapes.

BAREILLY: In an attempt to curb air pollution due to emissions of toxic fumes from brass furnaces in UP’s Moradabad, the Pollution Control Board in collaboration with Moradabad’s district administration and civic authorities is chalking out a plan to replace use of coal to fire furnaces with piped natural gas ( PNG ).

According to officials at the Pollution Control Board in Moradabad, there are approximately 5,000 big and small metal manufacturing units operating in the city and some are running in residential areas. They coal furnaces are used to smelt copper and zinc for manufacturing brass and molding it into shapes. Aluminum and silver are also smelted. Most of the units flout pollution norms. Despite frequent crackdowns on erring operators, not much has been achieved. This time around, efforts are being made to replace the pollution emitting units with gas furnace to reduce air pollution. A private gas agency has been roped in for the purpose, said officials.

Uttar Pradesh Pollution Control Board, regional officer, Moradabad, Ajay Kumar Sharma told TOI, “The pollution board, district administration and Moradabad Municipal Corporation are jointly working on a plan to completely eliminate the coal furnaces from the city and replace them with gas-based furnaces. The PNG-based furnaces are expected to reduce level of air pollution as compared to coal furnaces that emit a huge amount of carbon dioxide.”

Speaking with TOI, deputy commissioner (industries) Anuj Kumar said, “Around 5,000 big and small metal units are currently operational in Moradabad and all of them use coal-based furnaces for smelting metals. According to the Central Pollution Control Board (CBCB), the city was among the 10 most polluted cities (persistently recording ‘severe’ AQI levels) in the country in 2019. It is a matter of concern and, therefore, a plan is underway to control the air pollution. The work will be taken up in phases. Initially, all coal-based furnaces will be converted into PNG-based furnaces.”

Kumar added, “The gas supplying agency will soon be applying for an NOC from the nagar nigam to undertake digging work in parts of city in order to lay the gas pipelines for supply of PNG to these units. All the areas where the coal-based furnaces are being used will be covered under the project. By doing so, the livelihood of those working in the brass units will not suffer as these will not be shut down. The use of green fuel will also help in environment conservation.”

Recently, residents of Rehmat Nagar under Katghar police station limits had lodged a complaint with district administration regarding air pollution from metal furnaces in residential areas and had demanded closure of such units. So far, around 80 metal manufacturing units flouting pollution board norms have been shut down by Moradabad Pollution Control Board.

Title: Agra: AMU resident doctors demand Dr. Kafeel Khan release
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Dr Kafeel Khan, who was booked under National Security Act

AGRA: Resident Doctors Association (RDA) of AMU ’s medical college on Saturday demanded release of Gorakhpur pediatrician, Dr Kafeel Khan , who was booked under National Security Act (NSA) by Aligarh police a day before.

Taking out a protest march on medical college campus, the resident doctors demanded revocation of NSA charges against Khan. The medicos said raising one’s voice against injustice is not a crime and Khan should be released immediately.

Shouting slogans against UP police and the state government, the medicos also demanded withdrawal of Citizenship (Amendment) Act.

Talking with mediapersons, president of RDA, Dr Hamza Malik, wondered how can a doctor, who has organised several free health camps to save people from encephalitis and floods, be a threat to the nation.

Dr Shahnawaz Iqubali, vice-president of RDA, said the government’s move of slapping NSA on Khan was nothing more than a blatant attempt to suppress his voice.

Title: All 61 anti-CAA protesters skip hearing on damages in Bijnor
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Anti- protesters of CAA

BIJNOR: All the 61 alleged protesters who were served notices by the local administration to recover damages for their alleged activities during the anti-Citizenship Amendment Act protest last year failed to turn up at the hearing of the case at the ADM court here on Saturday. Additional district magistrate Avadesh Mishra has now advanced the final date of hearing by two days. Now, it is scheduled to take place on February 17.

Speaking with TOI, ADM Mishra said, “We have given one more opportunity to the protesters who were served notice. The hearing was to be completed on Saturday but none of the 61 accused attended the proceedings. We have now fixed February 17 as the final date. If anyone skips the next hearing, procedure for attaching their property will be initiated. Any further pleas will not be accepted.”

According to officials, a massive protest took place against the CAA in Bijnor district on December 20. Protests turned violent in eight towns of the district, including Bijnor, Nahtaur, Jalalabad, Nagina, Chandpur, Najibabad and Sherkot. The protesters allegedly burnt vehicles and vandalized shops.

The worst-affected towns were Bijnor and Nahtaur. In Nahtaur, two persons were killed in firing. More than 40 police personnel across district were injured. More than 3,900 protesters were booked under various IPC sections, including sections 147 (punishment for rioting), 148 (rioting, armed with deadly weapon), 149 (every member of unlawful assembly guilty of offence committed in prosecution of common object), 323 (voluntarily causing hurt), 353 (assault or criminal force to deter public servant from discharge of his duty), 336 (act endangering life or personal safety of others), 427 (mischief causing damage), 436 (mischief by fire or explosive substance with intent to destroy house, etc), 307 (attempt to murder), 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant), and 120-B (criminal conspiracy).

More than 150 protesters were arrested from various parts of the district. So far, more than 70% of those arrested have come out of jail on bail.

The administration had assessed damage to public properties at Rs 21.70 lakh and served notices on 61 protesters. ADM Mishra awarded 30 days to them for their explanation. All the accused submitted their explanation, asserting that they were not involved in damaging properties. The date was scheduled for hearing the matter on February 15. Government counsel appeared in the court but none of the protesters served notices showed up to attend the proceedings. Now, next date has been fixed on February 17.

Mishra said, “We kept on waiting for them but they did not reach y court. That is why, I think it is justifiable to give one more opportunity to the accused. If they do not come on February 17, I will have to initiate legal proceedings against them. Later, their pleas will not be conceded.”

Title: Ahmedabad: Woman’s kin attack her live-in partner
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A 20-year-old youth who has been in a live-in relationship with a young woman since February 10, was beaten up by the woman’s relatives and warned not to contact her. The youth, Rahul Parmar, was admitted to Shardaben Hospital on Friday night from where he filed an FIR.

Anandnagar police have registered the case under sections 323, 294 (b), 506 (2) and 114 IPC against four accused, Daksha Chavda, Rajesh Chavda, Hitesh Chavda and Kiran Chavda. Inspector S J Baloch of Anandnagar police station said they are searching for the accused. According to the FIR the complainant has been living with the woman in Nikol.

On Friday, Parmar went with the woman to meet his mother in Anandnagar at about 12.30pm. While they were returning in the evening, an Eeco car arrived. “The woman’s mother came out of the car and pulled her daughter inside. Then the woman’s maternal uncle Hitesh Rathod and his wife Kiran began beating Parmar. “The FIR states when Parmar fell on the ground, Kiran threatened they will kill him if he tried to live with the woman again,” said a cop.

Title: Man held for cheating people
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Hyderabad: Detective department officials nabbed a person for cheating people to the tune of Rs 46 lakh in both Telugu states by collecting deposits with the promise of giving bonus and returns. Alluri Purnachander Rao started a firm and collected deposits from 102 investors. Later, he failed to pay the money to the depositors and went absconding since 2019. Rao was also involved in a Negotiable Instruments Act case in Hyderabad in 2006. tnn

Title: Water bottling firm’s godown gutted
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Short-circuit sparked the fire on Saturday morning

Vadodara: A godown of a water bottling company at Makarpura GIDC was gutted as short-circuit sparked fire on Saturday early morning.

According to fire department sources, short-circuit in electrical wires in the company’s godown led to fire which engulfed the entire facility within a short time.

The company’s workers smelt the smoke when they were asleep in the area. Thankfully they evacuated the area in nick of time thus managing to save their lives.

Meanwhile, firemen from Makarpura GIDC fire station reached the spot immediately and saw the plastic bottles burning furiously.

A fire official said that the water jugs caught fire quickly as these were all made of plastic material. “We showered water but as these were made of plastic fire spread quickly. Our men could save some of the jugs, but the company claims to have suffered losses in lakhs of rupees,” the fire official said.

The company provides drinking water in these jugs to several commercial establishments in the city.

Title: Raniga ‘slapped’ a teacher who protested ‘strip’ diktat
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Rajkot: A day after four women staffers including the principal of Bhuj-based Shree Sahajanand Girls Institute were booked for outraging the modesty of 68 girls, the victims now fear a different kind of backlash for their mutiny.

The girls now are mortally frightened that principal Rita Raniga, who is dominating by nature and the main culprit who orchestrated the shameful exercise, may heap serious reprisal on the girls. Monday’s strip test opened a Pandora’s box of other issues with the institute.

Talking to TOI, the victim said: “It’s not that all the teachers were in favour of Raniga’s exercise. There were many teachers who objected and of them one was even thrashed by Raniga for trying to physically protect the girls. Raniga often insulted teachers in the assembly hall in front of all the students.”

Raniga “asked her (the teacher) not to interfere in the matter” and also gave a deaf ear to many other teachers who pleaded her not to go ahead with the test, said one of the victims.

The girl further said that the teachers who started to voice their objections verbally after a few students began to cry, “were told by Rita Ma’am to keep quiet if they wanted to continue in the job”.

Such is their fear for her, that students have nicknamed Raniga as “terror”.

The girls also said that the claim that they are informed of all these rules prior to admission is false. “When we joined the college we were not informed about the rules regarding periods at that time. Only after joining we came to know about these strict rules. We are also not allowed to wear western outfits in college and have to wear traditional clothes only. If a legging is slightly above the ankle, the student is punished for wearing such a short garment,” another student said, insisting repeatedly not to be quoted for fear of being tormented again.

The girls also complained that they are made to clean the entire hostel area owing to a shortage of staff inside the hostel. They are also ordered to help the kitchen staff in cooking and cleaning.

Title: History-sheeter held for role in 20 thefts
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Ahmedabad: Crime branch on Friday caught a history-sheeter, Mehboob Saiyed alias Johnson, 48, from near Teen Khuniya Garden, for his alleged involvement in more than 20 thefts of vehicles, mobile phones and purses.

Inspector R S Suvera of crime branch said Johnson was caught earlier for thefts in the jurisdictions of Shahpur, Khadia, Gomtipur, Ellisbrige, Madhavpura, Maninagar, Isanpur and Kalupur police stations.

“He has been detained under the Prevention of Anti-Social Activities Act (PASA) five times and was sent to Junagadh, Surat and Rajkot jails,” added Suvera.

Crime branch sources said during his interrogation it emerged that he was wanted in eight cases for vehicle thefts, purse snatchings and mobile theft. The sites of the offences were Laldarwaja, Civil Hospital, Kalupur railway station, Satellite and Relief Road.

Title: SIT formed to probe the incident
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Rajkot: The Kutch Superintendent of police (west) Saurabh Tolumbia on Saturday formed a Special Investigation Team (SIT) to investigate incident at Shree Shajanand Girls Institute of Bhuj. Mahila police inspector P H Lagdhirka, police inspector of B Division R N Khant, circle police inspector S B Vasava and Mahila police sub-inspector Archna Raval are part of the SIT.

The police on Saturday surveyed the place of offence with forensic team and collected the footages of CCTV from hostel. The police also recovered the notes from the victims in which principal Rita Raniga made students write that “We will not take any legal step in the alleged incident”.

This notes have been taken on the record as an evidence, said police. The police also called a female doctor of G K General hospital in the hostel for medical check up. However, the girls refused to undergo any medical check-up. The police on Saturday recorded statements of 45 girls, where all confirmed the incident. The police has also initiated the process to record the statements of the victims under CrPC section 164 before a magistrate.

Title: Nagpur: CBSE enters the world of memes to calm anxious nerves
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Nagpur: On Saturday afternoon, the CBSE entered a previously uncharted territory on social media as it created its first ever set of memes .

The central board pleasantly surprised the internet when its official handle on Facebook displayed two memes related to board exams, which kicked off on Saturday with optional subjects. The posts were soon racing around in WhatsApp groups comprising mostly academicians and were also shared on unofficial school/class groups.

Senior PRO of CBSE Rama Sharma said the idea was to connect with young kids. “To engage with students in a meaningful and interesting way, we have developed memes for the first time and posted them on social media handles.” The board has been smartly using social media to not only propagate messages but to also counter fake news on the platform.

Ad guru Sanjay Arora said this is a welcome move by CBSE since the board is communicating with teenagers. “I am really happy that the CBSE has done such a thing because you have to speak the language of your target audience. It’s a brilliant move by the board,” said Arora.

Students too are loving the social media-friendly board and its antics. Manav Wadhwani, a Std X student, said “Memes are often the only way these days that youngsters like us are getting updated with the current affairs. This form of adaptation by CBSE was unexpected, but I am pretty sure it will be fun to go through. I am in full support of CBSE using memes to guide us children, especially those appearing for boards.”

Abhishek Gallewale, also a Std X student, said “I think this a great initiative to distress students from the pressure of exams. They should do it more often to keep the students charged up and increase the humour quotient a bit more next time.”

For the current memes, CBSE is pushing the hashtags #examtime #beontime #dontbelate #discipline #youcandoit #the unstoppableyou #preparewell #bestofluck. It is on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram and a simple search for “CBSE HQ” will guide students and parents online to these social media handles.

The board exams kicked off on Saturday for optional /vocational subjects with 55,364 students appearing for them across the country.

Title: Yasmin Shaikh: How a bar girl became Mumbai's crime queen
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Yasmin Shaikh

MUMBAI: Her rap sheet shows 53 cases of theft. Meet Yasmin Shaikh , the crime queen on Mumbai railways who has been allegedly stealing from female commuters for more than a decade. Her crimes are said to have financed a flat in Govandi and a boarding school for her oldest daughter. Shaikh (37) is currently in the custody of Wadala GRP.

Shaikh started her career as a bar girl . She lived at Antop Hill at the time. Following the state ban on bars, she took to crime. Initially, she partnered with other women snatchers. One of the snatchers advised her to don a burkha to avoid getting identified and she followed the advice even after she went solo. Twice married, Shaikh has three children. Her oldest, a 15-year-old girl, studied in a boarding school at Panchgani and chose not to live with her mother afterwards.

“On January 26, a teacher approached Wadala GRP chowky and said she had been looted on the Harbour line at Kurla the previous evening. She said a woman in a burkha was standing close to her as she boarded a packed train. Later, she couldn’t find her mangalsutra,” said an officer. When the police checked the CCTV footage from the station, they guessed who the thief was. “We identified Shaikh from the footage on the basis of gait and picked her up near her current home at Govandi. Around 5.5 tolas of gold was found on her,” said senior inspector Rajendra Pal.

But the police were convinced Shaikh had amassed more stolen valuables and had hidden them. Subsequently, a GRP team reached her residence and searched it thoroughly. “We found gold ornaments and cash stashed in empty tiffin boxes,” said Pal. Stolen cellphones were also found. Combined with the previous day’s recovery, the value of all stolen valuables came to nearly Rs 8 lakh. Police also learnt that Shaikh had paid Rs 16 lakh for the Govandi house, though the property is yet to be officially transferred in her name.

One of Shaikh’s modi operandi was to enter women’s coaches carrying an infant. She would stand close to her target and on the pretext of pacifying the crying infant, slip her fingers through her target’s handbag. In some cases, she was found covering her face with a bag to avoid getting captured on camera. Whenever her case is scheduled to be heard in court, she instructs her family to bring an infant to court to gain sympathy, said cops. Outside railway premises, she has also been involved in thefts at Dharavi and Kurla.

Title: Nagpur: Now, 24/7 cops’ presence at board exam custody centres
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

NAGPUR: Taking a cue from last year’s board exam evaluation scam in Nagpur, officials from the divisional board office have revamped security measures at custody centres where answer sheets are stored post the exam.

The biggest change in the new system is that cops will be present round the clock at these sensitive custody centres where answer sheets are brought straight from the examination hall after the exam is over. The other changes include increase in the custody centres and number of personnel deployed there.

In 2019, Nagpur cops busted a racket in which the solved answer sheets were being replaced in the original bundles in connivance with people at custody centres, evaluators and touts. Though the board has a very secretive and almost foolproof system in place meant to ensure that the paper evaluator’s identity is never revealed to the student and vice versa, some people were able to find a weak link at the custody centre. The replacement of answer sheets too never got caught till 2019 as they were using original booklets and hologram stickers. Till last year, extra unused answer sheets and holograms were not properly accounted for by the board which led to their misuse by unscrupulous characters.

Ravikant Deshpande, chairman of the Nagpur divisional board, said, “Every custody centre will now have 24/7 police presence. We have also changed many custody centres and also increased their numbers to spread out the answer sheet bundles.”

Starting this year, the board has also eliminated the problem of unused sensitive material through efficient monitoring. Now a proper count of total answer sheets and holograms given to every exam centre is noted and this will be matched against the number of students who actually appeared. The exam material will be accounted for properly when the excess is being returned to the board.

A senior principal told TOI that earlier, everyone was very lax. “Teachers would just go and return the bundle and say that all unused 50 sheets are here. But in reality, that bundle contained 45 sheets or maybe 47. Nobody knew and that’s how the pilferage started,” said the principal.

The increase in personnel at the custody centre has, however, not gone down well with the people being called to report for duty. Sharad Bhandarkar, a zilla parishad employee and office bearer of one faction of the union, said, “ZP schools’ primary teachers have been assigned duty at custody centres from February 17 till March 16. Now what is the role of primary teachers for an exam that is related to high school and junior college? And who will teach ZP school kids when these teachers are away on duty. We will be meeting officials and requesting them to reconsider their decision.”

Title: Bareilly: Man killed by bull, second case in Kheri in Febuary
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Man killed by bull

BAREILLY: A 72-year-old man was killed in a bull attack in Pareli village in Hyderabad area of Lakhimpur Kheri district.

The farmer, identified as Victim Ramnaresh Shukla, was sitting near a bonfire with other villagers on Friday when a raging bull charged towards him and tossed him in the air. Thereafter, the bull gored him repeatedly until few locals came to his rescue.

The elderly man was later rushed to the hospital, but he died during treatment.

This is the second death that has taken place this month in Kheri due to bull attack. On February 9, a farmer was gored to death in Shahjahanpur district. Last year, 10 people were killed in stray cattle attacks in Kheri district.

The villagers have demanded the capture of stray bulls roaming in the area as they are posing a threat to the children and elderly people. Sub-divisional magistrate (SDM) Akhilesh Yadav on Saturday assured locals that the stray cattle would be sent to shelter house.

“It was an unfortunate incident. A team of revenue department has been sent for gathering information about the victim for sanctioning compensation in this case. I have also asked the chief veterinary officer to send a team for capturing the stray cattle in the area,” Yadav told TOI.

Title: Daughter connives with lover to pull off a Rs 38 lakh heist in her own house in Uttar Pradesh
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

AMROHA: A woman connived with lover to pull off heist in her own house in Amroha, revealed police investigation.

On February 6, a milk trader of Amroha had filed an FIR of theft of Rs 38 lakh, which he had kept in the house after selling off a property.

According to a police officer, the investigation revealed that the trader’s own daughter was involved in the heist and wanted to marry her lover against the wishes of her parents.

The matter pertains to a milk trader at Tarauli village under Adampur police station area of Amroha district . Police has arrested four accused on Saturday including daughter of complainant.

Police have recovered Rs 25.5 lakh from their possession. Apart from this, a Scorpio car used in the crime, three mobiles, a knife, photos and a mark sheet were also seized.

According to police, milk trader had filed a complaint against unidentified thieves on February 6. Police had registered a case under section 380 of IPC. Amroha superintendent of police formed several teams to crack down the case.

Addressing a press conference, Amroha superintendent of police Vipin Tada said, “Police have arrested four persons, including daughter of the complainant, her lover Kuldeep Giri, his aides- Daulat of Bamanpur village and Mustakeem under Aahar police station of Bulandshahar.”

“The woman had met Kuldeep Giri in a religious programme at Tarauli village around eight months ago. Kuldeep is a ‘bhajan’ singer. He had came to Tarauli from Bulandshshar. She fell in love with Kuldeep in single meeting. Kuldeep had provided her a mobile and a SIM also. They often chatted over phone. Kuldeep frequented her village clandestinely and met her. She became obsessed in his love and wanted to settle with him.” He said.

Giving more details, SP said, “Some days ago, milk trader had sold off his property located at Saidnangali area at Rs 38 lakh. After selling the property, trader had handed the money to his daughter. She kept it in the house. She had told her lover about money in her possession. Kuldeep came under allurement. She held a meeting on February 4 with Kuldeep, his brother-in law-Dinesh Kumar, his friends-Mustakeem and Daulat. They hatched a plan to siphon off this amount.”

Stating about their plan, SP said, “As per plan Kuldeep along with his friends reached girl’s house at Tarauli village on February 5 where she handed Rs 38 lakh to her lover. Kuldeep took away the cash. Next day, they tried to give a look to the incident as heist on February 6’s night. Kuldeep along with his friends barged into the house of the girl where she was waiting for them. They scattered and shattered all things kept in the house. When girl’s mother wake up and spotted some unidentified persons in their house, she shouted for help. One of them, attacked wife of the trader and escaped from the scene. Soon after, Kuldeep and his accomplices fled, girl told her parents that thieves committed theft and took away all money kept in the house.”

Title: After Harish Rawat's facebook jibe on BJP, Uttarakhand's CM Trivendra Singh Rawat hits back
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Harish Rawat

DEHRADUN: A verbal tussle has resumed between ex-chief minister Harish Rawat and his successor Trivendra Singh Rawat . While Harish Rawat accused BJP of making Uttarakhand into a “state of instability”, CM Trivendra Singh hit back saying that the statement of the former CM might have been made in wake of the “poor condition of Congress party”.

Hinting at a possible change of CM by the BJP, Harish Rawat in his post said that judging by the results of Delhi polls and the activities in BJP, it looked as if the “state was heading towards another political instability”. He further wrote that BJP was responsible for pushing Uttarakhand into instability right from the time the state was created. “I stand by what I have written. Any change hampers the development work and pushes the state backwards,” Harish Rawat said on Saturday.

Meanwhile, the post on social media by the former CM has further set tongues wagging about the speculations on change of CM in the state.

On the sidelines of an event, CM Trivendra Singh Rawat said, “[Harish] Rawat ji is a senior leader of opposition party and is performing his duty.” He did not fail to take a swipe at the senior Congress leader quipping that if the post was linked to the recent Delhi polls, then, “he needs to give it a serious thought as Congress has performed worst there”.

The CM also said that the BJP has increased its vote share as well as the number of seats in Delhi and “if anyone has lost everything, it was the Congress party”.

Title: Organic garden at school is the centre of attraction
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Healthy: Organic garden developed by students of DK ZP Govt Higher Primary School, Bokkapatna

MANGALURU: Though every government school in Dakshina Kannada has a kitchen garden, the organic garden developed by students of DK Zilla Panchyat Government Higher Primary School, Bokkapatna-3, is the quite the centre of attraction.

Many, including the department of public instruction, government schools and private companies and outreach groups from Chennai and Bengaluru, have studied it.
