“It’s completely organic and no chemicals are used. The schoolchildren take up the responsibility of caring for it through the year, including vacations. Those who study it look for ways to implement it on their campuses,” said headmistress Magdalene D’Souza.

The garden grows three varieties of eggplants , tomatoes , chillies , ridge gourd , spinach , lady’s finger (local variety), spinach, long beans, beans and plantains. “Only cow dung, manure prepared out of wet waste and organic manure donated by NGOs and outreach programmes are used in the garden. Apart from students, volunteers from outreach programmes of corporates also help in the upkeep,” she said.

Magdalene’s son, who works in the US, and daughter, who works for an IT company in Mangaluru, have donated a lot of equipment for the garden and the institution. The yield is exclusively used for preparation of midday meals. Magdalene said if there’s any excess, it’ sold locally and the revenue is used for school development work.

“Currently, there is a water supply issue on campus. Students, who don’t want their garden to go dry, collect water from all possible sources, including waste water used for cleaning vessels and plates,” she said. The school, built in 1945, has 43 students in classes one to seven with four teachers and two honorary teachers. Most students are children of migrants from other parts of Karnataka who are daily wage labourers and have no formal education.

Title: Embassy in Japan trying to get Indians off cruise ship early
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

TOKYO/ DELHI: The Indian embassy in Japan on Saturday said it is making efforts to disembark all the Indians on board the cruise ship moored off the Japanese coast after the end of the quarantine period as authorities confirmed that 218 people, including three Indians, have been infected with the deadly disease on the ship.

Official sources said Indian officials were in touch with Japanese authorities and were making all efforts possible to ensure the well being of the three Indians who tested positive.

A total of 138 Indians, including 132 crew and six passengers, were among the 3,711 people on board the quarantined ship that arrived at the Japanese coast earlier this month. It was quarantined after a passenger who de-boarded last month in Hong Kong was found to be the carrier of the COVID-19 on the ship.

The Indian embassy is in contact with Japanese authorities, the ship management company and Indian nationals on board the ship. “We have continued our efforts for early disembarkation of our nationals after the end of the quarantine period and subject to favourable results of their tests,” an embassy official told PTI on Saturday.

A third Indian crew on board a cruise ship off the Japanese coast tested positive for the virus, taking the total number of infected Indians to three. The embassy has contacted all three Indians who are currently receiving treatment at medical facilities.

Title: Bareilly: Two Army jawans among 7 held for abducting retired Army man
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

The accused had abducted Dalchandra because his son says Sher Singh

BAREILLY: Seven people were sent to jail on Saturday for allegedly abducting and thrashing a retired Army man in Bahedi area of Bareilly district . Among the arrested include two serving Army jawans who were spending their holidays here. The accused had abducted Dalchandra because his son, Sher Singh, had insulted the two jawans during a wedding ceremony in Aliganj a few days ago, police said. All the seven accused were booked under sections 364 (abduction with intent to kill) and 323 (voluntarily causing hurt) of the Indian Penal Code . According to the police, Dalchandra, a resident of Pindari village, was sleeping in his house when three people knocked on his door at 1 am on Friday to ask for an address. When Dalchandra opened the door, the accused forced him into their SUV car and fled the spot. Dalchandra’s son immediately informed the police, following which a team was formed to trace the kidnappers. The abductors were finally arrested in Devarnia area where the police had put a barricade and was checking all the vehicles there. Dalchandra told TOI, “Two persons knocked on my door and asked for an address. When I came out of my house, few more jumped from the SUV and dragged me inside the vehicle. Hearing my cries for help, my son came out of the house and identified the SUV. He immediately informed the police and I was rescued. The accused were planning to take me to Aliganj.” The two Army jawans were identified as Bhagwandas and Netrapal, who have been serving in for the past eight years. Their aides have been identified as Rajesh Singh, Dharmendra Singh, Brijendra Singh, Amit Kumar Singh and driver Vinay Kumar. “We have caught all the accused. They have confessed to their crime after which we booked an FIR against them for abduction and beating the retired Army man. The victim was sent to the hospital for treatment and medical examination,” SHO Bahedi police station told TOI.

Title: Bareilly: Three people killed after car rams into tree
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Three people were killed after the driver lost control of the car.

Title: Over 500 run for lake revival
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Hyderabad: Over 500 students and residents participated in a 5k Run for the revival of Meedikunta lake in Miyapur on Saturday. The run was organised by Fountainhead The Global School in collaboration with group SWAN-Save Water and Nature. Meghana Musunuri, founder and chairperson - Fountainhead The Global School said, “This is the start of Meedikunta lake revival. We will also develop a walking track around the lake.” tnn

Title: Gambling losses turn rickshaw driver into drug peddler
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Rajkot: Huge losses in gambling made an autorickshaw driver to take up even more serious criminal activities to earn quick money. Police arrested Dilawar Lingadia (48) with 1.739 kg ganja (marijuana) worth Rs 10,380 from Harihar Chowk in Sadar Bazaar locality of Rajkot on Saturday.

“Lingadia who was an autorickshaw driver, said that he had incurred a heavy debt after losing in gambling, and that in order to tide over his financial crises he had resorted to drug peddling,” said R Y Rawal, inspector with special operation group of Rajkot police.

The police have booked Lingadia under various sections of the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances (NDPS) Act.

During his interrogation, Lingadia told the cops that he had brought the contraband from Ashwini Kumar locality of Surat.

“We will be producing Lingadia before a court here to seek his remand to find out since how many times he has sold drugs in Rajkot and the places where he had gone to purchase narcotics,” added Rawal.

Title: Surgeons’ body trains doctors on human touch, critical care
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Hyderabad: The Association of Surgeons of India (SAI) has started training future surgeons (PG students of general surgery) in critical care , breaking bad news to patients, communicating with patients and relatives etc to improve human touch, patient interaction and overall quality of surgeons. In the first batch, 50 trainee surgeons from Telangana have undergone the training. Meanwhile, the association will make a representation to the union health ministry to include these courses as mandatory courses in medical curriculum.

Courses such as basic surgical skills course, surgical skills training, critical care course and communication skills course are areas which are currently untouched in MBBS curriculum.

“These subjects are largely untouched and need to be focussed upon. In the three years of the MS (general surgery) programme, even though trainees work in a ward, see and operate on patients, important elements like how to make an incision, how to hold each instrument, how to break bad news is not formally taught,” said Dr P Raghuram, President, Association of Surgeons of India.

The trainees undergoing these courses will also be presenting papers overseas at conferences overseas, so they can learn and collaborate with counterparts from across the world.

“At any given time in India, there are over 3,000 surgical trainees in the system, who are indeed the future of ASI . Therefore enhancing their knowledge base and improving their skills is of paramount importance for the future of surgery,” added the official.

Title: Gandhiji’s complex personality remains uninterpreted: Parekh
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Lord Bhikhu Parekh (centre) at Navrachana University

Vadodara: “Mahatma Gandhi was a complex personality which many have failed to understand till date,” — said Lord Bhikhu Parekh, member of UK’s House of Lords, at an event in the city on Saturday.

Parekh, former vice-chancellor of M S University and an eminent political theorist, was delivering a lecture on ‘Mahatma Gandhi’s legacy: A critical assessment’ at the city-based Navrachana University (NU) as part of NU’s ‘Samvaad’, a celebrity lecture series.

The Padma Bhushan awardee said that no biography of Gandhi so far has been able either fully capture or illuminate the complexity, tensions and apparent contradictions of Mahatma’s personality. He said nobody has been able to elucidate the sources of his powerful emotional hold over so many of his associates as well as his countrymen in general.

It was his (Bapu’s) conviction that India should not be partitioned, but he was not prepared to impose this view on others, said Parekh, who himself has penned several books on Gandhi. Parekh added that at times even he believes that they could have been better.

He said that even the then Congress leaders could not understand Gandhi. “It is very obvious because of the complexity of his personality,” said Parekh.

Responding to query whether political leaders of the country are using Gandhi’s name to serve their own purpose, Parekh said that world over, names of eminent political leaders are used by the political leadership. India is no exception to the general rule, he said.

Opining that today’s youth are moving fast towards consumerism, he said that it is totally different from what Gandhi used to believe.

Title: Ahmedabad: ‘Will sell your wife for the money’
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: The owner of a chocolate shop in Manekchowk, Pankaj Vaghela, lodged a complaint at Vadaj police station on Friday, alleging that one Pradeepsinh alias Bapu, a moneylender, threatened him saying that he would recover his debt by selling Vaghela’s wife. The moneylender also allegedly threatened to kill him.

Vaghela had borrowed Rs 1.5 lakh from Bapu for his business. According to the complaint, he was to pay Rs 1,500 a day for 100 days.

After he had repaid Rs 50,000 with interest, he failed pay the instalments for a month. Bapu then told him that he would have pay Rs 1 lakh more at daily instalment of Rs 1,000 for 100 days, along with the remaining Rs 1 lakh from the loan.

“According to the FIR lodged by Vaghela, he had repaid Rs 17,000 he failed to pay the instalments for a few days. Bapu then demanded Rs 2 lakh from him and told him he had a month to repay the sum in full or he would recover the money by selling Vaghela’s wife. He said if that didn’t work he would kill him,” said Inspector J A Rathwa of Vadaj police station.

Title: Ahmedabad: Man booked for ex-girlfriend’s suicide
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Distressed after her boyfriend left her and married someone else, a 17-year-old girl, an FYBCom student, killed herself suicide by jumping into the Narmada Canal near Zundal on February 2. Adalaj police registered a case of abetment of suicide against Hardik Chaudhary of Gunja village in Mehsana.

According to the FIR, the daughter of a bank employee, the girl and her mother went for a walk outside their housing colony on February 2. “When her mother returned, the girl’s father asked her about the girl. The mother told him that the girl had, halfway into the walk, told her that she was not feeling well and was going home. The father then checked and saw that her scooter was missing,” said a police official.

Her parents, brother and neighbours looked for her and found her scooter and dupatta near the canal. “On February 4, her body was found in the Narmada minor canal passing through Nadoliya and Agol villages,” said an Adalaj police official. A case of accidental death was registered by Adalaj police.

During the investigation, after questioning her friends, police learned that she had been in a relationship with Hardik, who had left her and married another woman. “This had made her upset and she committed suicide,” a police official said.

Title: With flights yet to take off from Bareilly, locals gift dummy aircraft to administration
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

They handed over a dummy aircraft to express their dissatisfaction over the long wait for a civilian air servi... Read More

BAREILLY: A group of residents under the aegis of Rashtriya Ekta Vyapar Mandal on Saturday gathered at the collectorate here and submitted a memorandum to city magistrate Madan Kumar addressed to President Ram Nath Kovind . They also handed over a dummy aircraft to express their dissatisfaction over the long wait for a civilian air service from the city.

Haider Ali, president of the organization, said they gifted an “aircraft” to the administration as it has been 11 months since the civil airport was inaugurated in Bareilly but flights are yet to take off from it.

The agitators gathered at Chaudhary Charan Singh Park from where they reached the DM’s office. They carried placards saying, “Tumse na ho payega (You can’t do it)”, and raised slogans against the BJP government at the collectorate gate. They also raised the matter of the hike in LPG rates.

“BJP wants to recover money that it spent on Delhi elections from the public. We oppose the Rs 144 hike on LPG cylinder. This government has nothing to deliver to the public other than ‘jumalebaji (false promises)’. They had promised to start flights from Bareilly almost a year ago but nothing has happened so far,” said Ali, who was earlier an office-bearer of the Samajwadi Party..

Title: Now, Ibrahimpur model in all states
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Hyderabad: The Association of Surgeons of India (ASI) has vowed to replicate the Ibrahimpur model across 29 states by adopting villages.

The Ibrahimpur village was adopted by breast cancer specialist Dr P Raghuram . The remote village in Medak now has a digital classroom and an electric crematorium.

Every chapter of ASI will adopt a village and undertake initiatives that are ‘village specific’ . “ It is important to have several rounds of discussions with residents of the adopted village to identify projects that would benefit them. After zeroing down on identified projects, funds must be raised locally and time-bound execution can be achieved by working closely with the village Sarpanch,” said Dr P Raghuram. TNN

Title: Accident deaths dipped by 11% in southern dists in 2019: Police
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Madurai: The overall road fatalities in southern districts have come down by 11.18% in 2019 compared to its previous year, according to data available with the Tamil Nadu police. In 2018, there were 2,746 road deaths in nine southern districts, while in 2019, the number came down to 2,439. However, while many districts succeeded in bringing down the road deaths in 2019, a few have seen a rise in the number.

Various departments like police, transport and district administrations are working together more enthusiastically to bring down road accidents and deaths for the past four years. A team comprising officials led by transport commissioner T S Jawahar recently reviewed road accident prevention in Madurai and Virudhunagar districts and took stock of the situation. The year 2018 witnessed 12,200 deaths, and it came down to 10,500 in 2019.

Ramanathapuram and Virudhunagar districts stood out among the nine southern districts as they managed to bring down the accident deaths respectively by 22.56% and 22.27% respectively. However, Tirunelveli and Tuticorin fared badly, as they witnessed an increase by 3.64% and 1.73% respectively.

Virudhunagar superintendent of police P Perumal told TOI that various efforts like introducing zig zag barricades at important junctions and road studs, used as reflectors and increase in traffic violation cases like helmet, drunk and drive and overspeeding have helped the police bring down the accident rate. “Last year, we had a target of 20% reduction in road fatality, which we achieved. This year, 15% reduction has been fixed and we are working to achieve it as well,” he said.

Police officials said that identification of places, where accidents take place frequently and improving safety in such places has helped bring down accidents. Apart from doing some modification in road engineering to improve safety, locals in such areas have been sensitized to use roads cautiously.

Title: Mystery shrouds death of 65-yr-old ‘poisoned’ man
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

cap

Rajkot: Mystery shrouds the death of a 65-year-old man , who claimed that he was poisoned before his demise on Saturday in Rajkot.

According to police, the victim Dhanji Kasiyani was brought to Rajkot Civil Hospital by his live-in partner Jignasa Vasiyani and his son Balkrushna. At the hospital, Kasiyani was declared brought dead.

Kasiyani had arrived in Rajkot from his native Jayava village of Dhrol taluka in Jamnagar district on Saturday afternoon, after which he made a call to his uncle.

“His uncle made us listen to the audio clip of his telephonic conversation with Kasiyani in which Kasiyani was heard saying that he was victim to blackmailing and that four men had siphoned off Rs 25 lakh to Rs 30 lakh from him. He also talked about his live-in relationship with Vasiyani,” said an official from University police station, while refusing to divulge the name of Kasiyani’s uncle, citing secrecy of the investigation.

Police said that Kasiyani made his last call to his uncle, saying that he had been poisoned. His uncle called up Kasiyani’s son Balkrushna, who rushed to Rajkot. Balkrushna knew about Kasiyani’s relationship with Vasiyani. So he went straight to her home in Ratnam Pride Residency near Ghanteshwer SRP Camp and found Kasiyani lying unconscious. Then both Vasiyani and Balkrushna rushed Kasiyani to the civil hospital where the doctors declared him dead on arrival.

As Kasiyani was at Vasiyani’s house, the needle of suspicion pointed towards her. However, in her statement to the police, Vasiyani claimed, “When he came to my house, he said he had been thrown out of his house. Then he started spitting blood, following which I called up Balkrushna. He was poisoned much before he came to my house.”

Meanwhile, the police have launched an investigation into the case. “As of now, we have little evidence to draw any conclusion in this case. We are investigating as to who had made Kasiyani consume poison,” added the official.

Title: Duo falls in ditch, keeps sitting there in protest with bike
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

The two men slipped into the ditch on Ajwa Road on Saturday

Vadodara: Two men residing on the Ajwa Road area in the city created quite a scene on the road to embarrass the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) after their motorcycle slipped and fell into a ditch filled with water on Saturday. The duo sat in the ditch with their motorcycle and said they would not move till the issue is resolved.

The incident took place on Saturday morning when the duo was travelling together on the same motorcycle. They tried to avoid the ditch filled with water, but somehow ended up falling in it. Since they had been seeing he ditch since quite some time now, they decided to sit at the site itself in protest.

Opposition Congress councillor from the area Anil Parmar said that the two men Ghanshyam Parmar and Vijay Patil were known to him.

“They called me after the incident and said that they would sit there itself in protest. There is a leakage in a water supply pipeline at the spot since 15-20 days. It was repaired twice, but the problem recurred,” said Parmar.

Parmar pointed out that VMC officials swung into action soon after the protest and the pipeline was repaired. “I requested the duo to leave the place to which they agreed,” he said.

Title: Bareilly: Congress leader Pratapgarhi issued Rs 1.04 crore notice for ‘violating section 144’at anti-CAA stir-in
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Congress leader Imran Pratapgarhi

BAREILLY: Congress leader Imran Pratapgarhi , who had contested 2019 Lok Sabha polls from Moradabad constituency, has been issued Rs 1.04 crore show cause notice for “violating section 144” by addressing anti-CAA protesters at a sit-in in Moradabad. People, including a large number of women, have been protesting at the city Eidgah since January 29, and such notices, according to an official, are “only precautionary measure to avert violent protests”.

In the notice issued by additional city magistrate (first) Rajesh Kumar, Pratapgarhi has been asked to explain why Rs 1.04 crore “spent on deploying force to maintain law and order in and around the Eidgah should not be recovered from him”. Pratapgarhi, who has termed the notice as “pressure tactics by the BJP government to silence opposition’s voice”, has been accused by the administration of allegedly provoking people of a particular community and fuelling enmity between two communities. According to him, the notice was issued on February 6.

Also, he has been asked to explain why he should not submit a personal bond of Rs 10 lakh with two sureties. Administrative sources stated that Rs 13.42 lakh is spent per day on the police and paramilitary forces, including one platoon of Rapid Action Force, half section of Provincial Armed Constabulary and police force deployed at the Eidgah. So, the eight-day expense adds up to Rs 1.04 crore.

Reacting to the notice, Pratapgarhi told TOI on Saturday, “I reached Moradabad on February 7. But, the notice was issued on February 6. Besides, I had informed the SP (city) as well as the administration of my visit so that they could provide me security. I reached the Eidgah directly. During my address, I also appreciated the police and administration for their support.”

“I have been participating in similar protests and sit-ins across the country, but not received any such notice. Lately, I was in Lucknow. And I addressed the people there. Local administration says that section 144 is in force. But, it is actually for those who are opposing the government. Deputy CM Keshav Prasad Maurya recently reached Moradabad and addressed a large gathering in support of CAA but for him section 144 is not effective,” he said, claiming that he was yet to receive a copy of the notice and will challenge the matter in court.

ACM Kumar, however, explained, “The sit-in organisers and Congress leader Imran Pratapgarhi have been issued notices. Since, section 144 is in force in the district any such assembly is unlawful. Police had informed us on February 6 about his arrival the next day. So, we had to issue the notice on the same date. Such notices are issued as precautionary measures to warn those people who may pose a threat to law and order. No further action will be taken until any untoward situation erupts at the protest site. We mentioned an amount of Rs 1.04 crore in the notice. Imran has been instructed to submit a personal bond of Rs 10 lakh with two sureties.”

Notably, the administration in Moradabad has issued notices to at least 12 individuals, which include Imran Pratapgarhi. The official further said that 11 of them had already submitted a personal bond of Rs 5 lakh each. Pratapgarhi was given seven days to respond which has now expired.

Title: Donald Trump likely to visit Taj Mahal on Febuary 24
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Security personnel patrol the premises of Taj mahal on saturday

AGRA: As part of his two-day visit to India later this month, US President Donald Trump is likely to visit the Taj Mahal on February 24.

Senior officials said that though no official programme has been announced by the White House so far, they have received a tentative date of his visit. According to the tentative schedule, Trump is likely to reach Taj city from Ahmedabad at 4.30pm on February 24 and spend over two hours there. The Ahmedabad-Agra route details are being worked out, sources claimed. They added that besides Air Force One, there could be VH 3D sea planes and White Hawks flying from Ahmedabad to Agra. President Trump and First Lady Melania Trump are likely to visit the world heritage monument in the evening and then depart for New Delhi, where Prime Minister Narendra Modi would host a magnificent dinner reception for the couple.

Officials said that a high-level team from the US embassy is scheduled to visit Agra on Monday to discuss the modalities of Trump’s visit. The delegation would also comprise security experts who are likely to review the arrangements at Taj too.

On Saturday, a preparatory meeting, chaired by divisional commissioner Anil Kumar and attended by police and district administration officials, was held in connection with the proposed visit of the US President.

Earlier this month, the White House had announced that the US President and First Lady would visit India on February 24 and 25. Prime Minister Narendra Modi would host the couple in Ahmedabad and New Delhi. This will be Trump’s first visit to India as US President and will also be a state visit .

Late US President Dwight Eisenhower was the first Potus to visit the Taj Mahal over five decades ago. It was an open Cadillac ride accompanied by Jawaharlal Nehru in December 1959. Bill Clinton had also visited the monument of love in 2000.

Title: Maharashtra: 40 surya namaskars a day keep ‘101-year-old’ granny fit
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Laxmi Damle recently taught 10,000 schoolchildren surya namaskar

MUMBAI: Laxmibai Damle says she believes in keeping fit. For this the woman from Ratnagiri , who her family members claim is a 101 years old, does at least 40 surya namaskar every morning .

Days after she taught 10,000-plus Kalyan school kids surya namaskar, TOI met her at a relative’s home in Borivli. The petite woman was attired in a nine-yard blue saree and red blouse, her silver-grey hair was rolled into a neat bun. She has no teeth but her wrinkled skin glows. As Laxmibai is hard of hearing, her niece, Sulakshana Bodas, and husband Sarvottam, whose residence Laxmibai was visiting, played interpreter.

The day TOI met her this past week, she had already done 40 surya namaskar for the day earlier in the morning.

Asked if she would do a few more, Laxmibai readily agreed. Sitting ramrod straight on the floor, she crossed her legs and stretched her palms upwards. Adjusting the folds of her nine-yard saree, she tucked the loose end of her pallu around the midriff, bent forward to touch her feet, her red glass bangles cling-clanging. And then, in one fell swoop, she lunged forward and the next moment her body was in the plank position—parallel to the floor. All along, Laxmibai kept chanting ‘Om Surya Namaha’.

“Whenever we look at her, she’s doing the surya namaskar, especially when she feels a bit uneasy,” says Sarvottam Bodas. Days earlier, when he woke up in the middle of the night, he found her busy at her fitness mantra at that unearthly hour.

Laxmibai, who hails from Kolamabe village, says she learnt to do the surya namaskar when she was in school. “It was a Christian teacher at Agashe Kanya Shala in Ratnagiri who taught me the namaskar,” she says, admitting that she is not too educated.

Married at the age 13, her husband and his family never objected to her penchant for exercise. A light eater, Laxmibai has a weakenss for sweets. “But I have no ailments at all. Till today, I haven’t popped pills for any sickness. The surya namaskar is my medicine,” she says.

Even today, she helps with household chores, including shredding vegetables and preparing buttermilk with churner. “Just for timepass,” she says. Earlier, when she could hear properly, she loved watching Marathi serials on television, says Sulakshana.

“But she hates watching movies in cinema halls as she does not like to sit in the AC. She is not too fond of Hindi serials on TV either as she does not know the language,” Sulakshana adds.

Overall, Laxmibai is content with her life. “My family members take good care of me,” she says, still sitting ramrod straight. “At my age, there’s nothing I need, nothing I long for.”

Title: One held for Rs 1.3 cr jewellery heist
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Ahmedabad: Nikol police on Friday arrested a 31-year-old man, Nikhil Rathod, for robbing a jeweller’s employee of goods worth Rs 1.3 crore. Police say they have recovered jewellery worth Rs 87 lakh from Rathod, a resident of Chharanagar. Investigators say three others who were involved in the planning of the January 30 robbery — Manish Sevani and Uttam Tamanche of Kubernagar, and Vishal Tamanche of Sardarnagar — are still at large. DCP Zone 5 Ravi Teja said based on CCTV footage and human intelligence, they got a tip-off on Friday that Rathod was near Sardar Mall in Nikol. “We immediately sent a team which identified and nabbed Rathod. We have also recovered gold jewellery worth Rs 87 lakh from his possession,” added Teja.

Title: Lack of publicity hits TNSTC’s city tour service
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Madurai: The city tour service started by the Tamil Nadu State Transport Corporation (TNSTC), Madurai division, has failed to get many takers due to lack of publicity. Although the service is much needed, with many domestic and foreign tourists, thronging the city, not many are aware of the availability of such service.

TNSTC launched the service in the second week of January by utilising the buses connecting Ellis Nagar parking lot and Meenakshi Amman Temple. During Sabarimala and Pongal seasons, 20 TNSTC buses were operated connecting the temple and the parking lot. Now, around six buses are operated.

The service will take tourists to five spots such as Thiruparankundram, Thirumalai Nayak Mahal, Mariamman Teppakulam, Gandhi Museum and World Tamil Sangam at a minimum cost of Rs 125 per passenger. The launch of the city tour itself happened without informing the stakeholders or the tourism department officials.

“We get passengers enough to operate only two to four services in a day, that too because of canvassing taken up by the transport staff at the parking lot. Visitors are not informed about the availability of service, which could be a boon to them,” said a transport official.

J Sakthivel, a visitor from Salem said, “We spent Rs 1,500 on a taxi to visit a few places in the city. We were not aware of the city tour and nobody informed us about it when he inquired with the auto drivers. We could have utilized it, had we known it.”

When contacted, an official from the TNSTC said that they had erected a banner informing the facility at Ellis Nagar parking lot, but it was damaged by vandals. They are planning to erect the banner again. They are also planning to keep an advertisement board on buses to reach out to the visitors, he said.

Title: 65-year-old falls in storm water drain, dies
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

The drain on Sun Pharma Road, where the man fell

Vadodara: A 65-year-old resident of Gotri was found dead in an open storm water drain on Sun Pharma Road on Friday afternoon. Satish Patel accidentally fell in the drain when he had gone out for a walk, said JP Road police.

A local saw Patel’s body floating in the water at around 8 am on Saturday. but his body remained unidentified till Patel’s family members approached Gotri police station on Saturday evening with a missing person complaint. The family got a rude shock upon learning about the death and identified the body.

Police said that Patel had been suffering from age-related ailments due to which his family had restricted his movement outside the house. On Friday too, when he was leaving for his walk, they warned him not to go far and return early.

“The family members told us that due to old age Patel was suffering from memory loss, and also suffered problems with vision and hearing. In the past too, he lost his way home a couple of times and had to helped home by complete strangers,” said a police official.

According to police, Patel may have lost his way on Friday as it was getting dark and may have slipped into the storm water drain. The police official said that there was an injury mark on his head and as the drain is several feet below ground level, the deceased may not have been able to come out.

A case of accidental death was registered at JP Road police station after the post-mortem was conducted at SSG Hospital.

Title: Encroachments in Nainital’s markets: locals blame admin
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Bara Bazaar in Nainital

NAINITAL: As the peak tourist season approaches, local residents of Nainital have asked the administration to clear the encroachments that have cropped up in and around the lake town’s markets. Residents said that vendors have been squatting on the pavements of Mall Road, as well as other prominent places like Tallital Market, Mallital and Bara Bazaar .

“Not only do they take up the space meant for pedestrians, they dispose of their waste right on the road,” said Neelam Kumar, the owner of Modern Book Depot in Nainital. Locals alleged that complaining repeatedly to the municipal council had yielded no results. “We keep making rounds of the municipality and the administration. However, the encroachment across town hasn’t changed,” Kumar added.

“The markets are less crowded these days but once the tourist season is here, the streets will be heavily crammed. Markets like Tallital and Bara Bazaar, where the lanes are not very wide, will get choked if the squatters are not removed,” added Aman Thapliyal, a trader.

The officials of municipal council when queried by TOI claimed that encroachments in the hill town will be cleared before the tourist season.

“We keep surveying the entire town from time to time to keep encroachments in check. If there are places that need to be cleared, we will do it soon,” said municipal council chairman Sachin Negi.

Title: Death toll in Kappalur fire accident rises to four
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: The death toll in the Kappalur fire accident which took place on Monday has risen to four after one more person who was undergoing treatment in government Rajaji hospital, succumbed to burn injuries on Saturday.

Police sources said that A Karthick, 24, the fourth victim, could not be saved by doctors despite the best possible treatment. The fire accident took place in a temporary shed where petrol and diesel pilfered from trucks were kept.

It caught fire from a stove used for cooking. Six persons were present in the shed, playing carrom board when the incident happened.

While P Ganesan, 40, died on the spot, five people were admitted to the hospital. The shed owner identified as M Asaithambi , 50, and R Vijayakumar, 35, succumbed to injuries on Tuesday and Thursday respectively. V Arumugam, 66, is being treated in the hospital.

A case was registered against Asaithambi under IPC section 304 (II) - culpable homicide not amounting to murder.

Title: Death in observation home: Three booked
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Palanpur: Three persons including the in-charge of the Zonal Observation Home in Mehsana were booked on Friday late evening for allegedly torturing a 17-year-old boy resulting his death on Thursday.

The Mehsana district Collector H K Patel also ordered a judicial inquiry into death of Chirag Chauhan, who was nabbed from Ahmedabad on Wednesday after he had escaped from the observation home, along with eight others, on February 3.

Patel said that they have will be giving Rs 4 lakh compensation to the parents of the deceased juvenile.

Those charged with murder of Chirag include in-charge superintendent of the observation home Vishnu Prajapati and two guards Akshay Chaudhary and Kanu Chaudhary.

Father of the deceased Mukesh Chauhan had alleged that his son was assaulted at a juvenile remand home during wee hours on Thursday which resulted in his death.

Title: Cong ups ante on4% Muslim quota
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Hyderabad: Congress on Saturday sought to reassure the Muslim community that it will put up a strong fight in the Supreme Court to ensure that 4% reservations for Muslims in Telangana is continued.

Telangana Congress president N Uttam Kumar Reddy praised the role played by former minister Mohammed Ali Shabbir and the then chief minister YS Rajashekhara Reddy in giving 4% quota to backward groups among Muslims in 2004. tnn

Title: Chhattisgarhi Mahotsav: Facilities come up even before commissioner gives go ahead
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

the start of the 3-day Chhattisgarhi Mahotsav on Saturday

NAGPUR: Six and half hours before the start of the 3-day Chhattisgarhi Mahotsav on Saturday, the Nagpur Municipal Corporation issued work orders for the setting up of the stage and other facilities for the event at RTO Ground at Dipti Signal.

Even though the stage work was almost complete, there were doubts over the event being held after municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe raised several queries over the Rs 36lakh event. With the concerned departments fulfilling most of the riders, Mundhe gave the event the go-ahead.

Standing committee chairman Pradip Pohane, who had proposed the fest, had already ensured that there would be no hiccups by asking the sports and cultural department to construct the stage even before work orders were issued.

Pohane told TOI that Mundhe cleared the work order on Saturday. Much of the facilities had been set up at the RTO Ground by Friday. Not just the stage, even the backdrop highlighting tradition of Chattisgarh was ready. Chairs, sofas, high posts to erect high-mast lights etc too were in place.

Pohane said work orders for some were issued earlier. “Stage work was done before the issuance of work order as it had post facto approval from the civic chief. The general body had approved the fest. Proposals were submitted to NMC three months ago but its departments delayed the process,” he said.

On Saturday, Pohane told TOI that Mundhe had stopped work orders for the event. Mayor Sandip Joshi said that administrative approval to works were approved by Mundhe’s predecessor Abhijit Bangar so the former “should not create hurdles”.

Like it was for the Akhil Bharatiya Natya Parishad and other events, it has become a practice for the civic body to get works done from private agencies, especially for cultural programmes, even before work orders are issued.

The NMC has continued to spend on various types of fests even after the Nagpur bench of Bombay High Court passed strictures on it for spending funds on Nagpur Mahotsav. Then, the NMC had organized the Mahotsav by raising funds for two years only to abandon the event.

Union minister Nitin Gadkari inaugurated the event on Saturday evening. The performance of Padma Vibhushan awardee Teejan Bai, a renowned Pandwani exponent, on Sunday will be the highlight of the fest.

Title: No Ganga water supply in 27 wards in Agra
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Ganga water has not been provided despite making several rounds to the Agra municipal corporation

AGRA: Despite repeated complaints to the civic body administration, residents of over 27 municipal wards in the city are yet to get Ganga water supply due to the absence of necessary infrastructure.

According to locals, the requisite infrastructure to supply Ganga water has not been provided despite making several rounds to the Agra municipal corporation. Paschimpuri resident Suresh Kumar said, “We have made several requests to the civic body administration seeking Ganga water supply. However, no action has been taken yet.” Shamshabad Road resident Vimal Mohan said, “The supply of Ganga water in the city was started around a year ago. However, a large part of the city is still not connected to the pipelines. The required infrastructure should be developed in a time-bound manner.”

Under the Gangajal project, Agra receives water supply from Palra headworks in Bulandshahr’s upper Ganga canal. Around 130 km of pipeline has been laid for the purpose. At present, Sikandra and Jeevan Mandi waterworks stations receive 140 cusecs of Ganga water on a daily basis.

According to data available with the civic body, only 18 municipal wards in the city have complete infrastructure for Ganga water supply. Mayor Naveen Jain said, “We receive a number of complaints from various parts of the city over Ganga water supply. We have directed officials to ensure that pipelines are laid and required infrastructure set up to provide adequate water supply to each and every household.”

Talking to TOI, Jal Sansthan officials said that a proposal has been sent to the state government for laying water supply pipelines in the said wards.

Meanwhile, residents claimed that leakage on water supply pipelines maintained by Jal Sansthan cause much wastage on a daily basis. Estimates suggest that at least 50 million litres daily (MLD) water is wasted in the city due to pipeline leakage.

Title: 168 kg ganja smuggled from Andhra Pradesh seized, 3 held
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Sleuths from Narcotics Intelligence Bureau CID seized ganja weighing 168 kgs, smuggled in a sedan from Andhra Pradesh , in Madurai city police limits on Saturday and arrested three people.

Based on suspicion the team stopped the car near Bamurugan temple in the extension area of Thabal Thandhi Nagar under the Koodal Pudur police limit. But the car driver did not stop the vehicle and the team chased them down. However, one of the occupants managed to escape.

It was found that ganja stuffed in small packets was hidden inside the vehicle. Three people identified as A Vinoth, 28, from Kalanpatti near Peraiyur, M Udayakumar, 30, from Keelakailasapuram near Sellur and T Anandakumar, 30, from Pattimedu in Madurai city were arrested. The person on the run was identified as Udayavan from Kalappanpatti.

Police sources said that the ganja procured from a mountain range in Andhra Pradesh was on its way towards Usilampatti.

Title: MSU faculty to take ‘on the spot’ action on copycats
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Vadodara: In a policy decision, M S University will give instant justice to ‘copy cats’ from now.

Deciding to decentralize the current system where the ‘cheaters’ or students who are caught copying in exams are punished on case to case basis by the university level unfair means committee, the university’s syndicate members have decided that cases of small-time offenders should be dealt by the faculty itself.

In the earlier system, many students had to wait for months together as the appointed committee handles all such cases in bulk and submits its recommendations for approval from the university’s syndicate body.

“The university has taken this decision on a trial basis so that students who are caught in small time offences don’t end up waiting for months till the time university-level committee arrives at a conclusion,” said MSU vice-chancellor professor Parimal Vyas.

The faculties will be asked to appoint their own observers and senior teachers to act upon such cases. “The idea is to take on the spot decisions.

Once, exams of students get over, the faculty level panel itself will decide on the type of punishment that the student who is caught cheating will undergo,” said Vyas.

While the role of the unfair means committee will decrease, the committee will still exist. “If the faculties come across any severe case of exam-related offence, such cases based on their severity will be reported to the committee,” said Vyas.

Title: Nagpur: As city’s potholes grow in size, their repair cost too goes up
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

representative image

NAGPUR: A study by Visvesvaraya National Institute of Technology (VNIT) has revealed that neglected potholes have cost the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) dear with the expenditure for repairs increasing manifold.

After the VNIT’s civil engineering department adopted a stretch of Hingna road for a year, a small pothole appeared in December 2016. If the NMC had repaired the pothole right away then the expenditure per sqm would have been in the region of Rs500-Rs700.

While the NMC failed to wake up from its deep slumber, the size of the pothole increased by February 2017.

However, three months later, in June 2017, the pothole became bigger and deeper and needed immediate repairs. The cost of repairs increased to Rs1,200—1,750 per sqm.

As the civic body continued to turn a blind eye, the small pothole turned into a huge crater by July 2017. This lackadaisical attitude proved costly for the civic body as now, it needs to relay the entire stretch at a cost of Rs50 lakh per km, the VNIT study revealed.

“It’s just the tip of the iceberg. With the city’s road network approximately 2,700km, the NMC needs to come up with a comprehensive road asset management system which can save wasteful expenditure worth crores of rupees,” said V Landge, head of VNIT’s civil engineering department.

The Central India’s premier institute has also submitted its study — carried out by Landge, Parag Deshpande, Udit Jain, Vivek Hokam and Abhay Tawlare — to the civic body.

“We have submitted a proposal to the NMC to launch the Nagpur road asset management system (N-RAMS) which will be a smart step for a smart city. Our service charges per annum would be Rs2 crore,” said Landge.

According to VNIT’s proposal, data collection will be done by traffic volunteers. They will use a mobile app to record details of faulty roads. VNIT has offered to develop the road severity index to help prioritize rehabilitation and also to strategize repair work within the limited budget.

The NMC has insufficient manpower to handle the city’s road network. The other concern is the limited budget for repairs and maintenance of roads.

Road maintenance is not based on measurable objective criteria but on ad hoc demands of elected representatives, stated the study.

Many a time, a bad road (especially in fringe areas) remains neglected while maintenance is carried out at locations where it is not required and the result is wasteful expenditure and deterioration of serviceability level of the overall road network, the study found.

The only solution is developing a comprehensive Road Asset Management System which will encompass the NMC assets, including roads, drains and related infrastructure, their condition (based on measurable technical criteria), its resources (budget, manpower, machinery) and contractor (quality of the work, history, reputation).

The NMC will not require permanent staff and hence, no need for additional investment as it can be done within the domain of the Smart City project.

About the implementation of the system, the study suggested geotagging of all roads, converting all roads into manageable road pieces of uniform sizes, assigning unique ID to each road, quantitative measurement to judge the quality of road in terms of defects and defect parameters, design algorithm to estimate repair cost based on defects and multidimensional analysis based on location, time, defect and contractor.

VNIT has offered to develop the road severity index to help prioritize restoration and simultaneously help to strategize repair work within limited budget.

Mayor Sandip Joshi appreciated VNIT’s study and said if NMC implements it then taxpayers’ money will be saved. “Next week a meeting between the premier institute and NMC’s chief engineer Ulhas Debadwar will be convened,” he said.

Title: Banned paan masala, tobacco worth Rs27 lakh seized near Kalamb
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Yavatmal: In a joint operation, local crime branch of the police and food and drugs administration (FDA) have seized a consignment of banned paan masala and scented tobacco along with truck and arrested two persons from a village under Kalamb police station jurisdiction on Thursday night.

According to LCB chief PI Pradeep Siraskar, in-charge superintendent of police Noorul Hassan received a tip-off that a truck (HR 38-Z/ 6282) was transporting banned pan masala and scented tobacco products between Kalamb and Nagpur. Hassan summoned FDA officials and set up a special squad of LCB under API Vinod Chavan to track down the truck. The team found the truck parked at a dhaba ahead of Kalamb.

The team inspected the vehicle and found 80 bags of Raj Niwas sugandhi paan masala and scented tobacco, banned by the state government. The value of the consignment has been estimated at Rs26.92 lakh and the truck Rs25 lakh.

Kalamb police have registered an FIR against occupants of the truck Padamsingh Tomar (42) and Mohansingh Adivasi (37), both residents of Bhavangad village in Madhya Pradesh , and arrested them. FDA officer Gopal Mahure and his team participated in the operation.

Title: Trekking banned on Kurangani hills as mercury rises
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Madurai: The forest department in Theni district has announced a ban on trekking at Kurangani till further orders. The instruction came into effect from February 15 due to high possibility of forest fires as summer has begun. Trekking on the authorised and guided 11km stretch from Kurangani to Top Station through Central Station will resume after the climatic conditions turn conducive.

After the fatal fire that claimed the lives of 23 trekkers during an unapproved trek at Kurangani in March 2018, the forest department started authorised trekking from November 30, 2018. The department announced that as per the rules, trekking will be suspended annually for two months – from February 15 to April 15 – as the grass and bushes that are dried up during summer could catch fire. However, in 2019 it was suspended in the third week of January well ahead of the scheduled ban period due to non-conducive climatic conditions. A total of 69 people sought permission from the department for the trek in the less than two-month period. It is learnt that there were a few fires in and around Kurangani of which a couple of ones were on the approved trekking track.

District forest officer (DFO) S Gowtham said that it was reopened in August, after nearly seven months, as the climatic conditions were not favourable till then. This time trekking was permitted till February 15 due to conducive climatic conditions, unlike the previous year. Only around 200 people had sought permission for trekking at Kurangani from August till date.

Forest department sources said that they have drawn fire lines for about 150km in the forest under various schemes, created awareness among the locals and stakeholders and also restricted grazing in the forest to prevent fires. The department warned stringent action against those who try to trek during the ban period and those who set the grass on fire in the forest. They also asked people to report forest fires to the office of the DFO at 04546- 252552 or district disaster management unit at 1077.

Title: Health check-up, organ pledge at pre-wedding bash
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Wedding guests undergo tests at the venue

Rajkot: It was pre-wedding function of a different kind in Rajkot on Saturday. Relatives of the groom Mitesh Kakkad and bride Henny Pujara underwent health check-up and pledged their organs for donation, besides being given a lesson on conserving environment.

Usually, any pre-wedding function would have loud music, dance and elaborate dinner for the relatives. But Mitesh and Henny wanted to give a social message an just taste of good food.

Mitesh will marry Henny at a mass marriage function on on Sunday.

On Sunday, guests arriving for Mitesh’s pre-wedding function were welcomed with a sparrow nest and a book with a message to save the environment. They underwent health check-ups which was followed by a video message on importance of organ donation. Mitesh had organsied the function with help of his brother-in-law Mittal Khetani, a social activist. “We explained to our guests that one person can save the life of five people by donating the organ. There were guests who took a pledge to donate their organs. At the de-addiction camp and some of the guests also promised to get rid of their addiction.”

Pratik Sanghani one of the guests said “I have attended so many marriages but this is the first where my knowledge about health was enhanced. Health check-up and awareness on other diseases is a unique message by the to-be wed couple.

According to Khetani nearly 300 guests participated in the event. There was a separate seminar for kidney disease during which guests were made aware about protecting kidneys from ailments.

Title: Agra: Missing pictures of examinees from attendance sheet will pose verification problems
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

The Secondary Education Council had decided to place a fix a photograph of the candidate on the attendance sh... Read More

AGRA: Preparation for UP Board examination for Class X and XII, scheduled to commence from February 18 are in full swing. State authorities are monitoring the preparations on a daily basis to ensure fair conduct of the exams. As part of the exercise, a photograph on the examinee’s admit card must match the one on the attendance sheet. However, the attendance sheets of several examination centres do not have any photo of the examinee.

To prevent any impersonation during the board exam, the Secondary Education Council had decided to place a fix a photograph of the candidate on the attendance sheet so that it can be matched with the admit card available with the student. But, so far, more than a dozen exam centres have found the photos of the candidates missing from the attendance sheet.

The exam centre officials have contacted the office of the district inspector of schools (DIOS), alerting it about the missing photos and the consequent problem that will arise during verification of examinees on the exam day.

Ravindra Kumar, DIOS, said, “Several cases of photographs of candidates missing from the attendance sheet have surfaced. The board authorities have been informed in this regard. Soon updated attendance sheet will be made available”.

Meanwhile, several other irregularities have also been detected in the admit card of the students. Some have errors in spellings of name of candidate and that of schools. Besides, all the subjects of the exam are not mentioned. Several teachers are complaining that they have been assigned duties at two exam centres on the same day. The DIOS office is addressing such complains every day.

Title: Developer gets show-cause notice for levelling land at Jadhavwadi
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Kolhapur: Civic chief Mallinath Kalshetti on Saturday issued a show-cause notice to a developer for levelling of the land in the flood-prone locality of Jadhavwadi.

Kalshetti, along with the officials of town planning department, visited the site and found that huge amount of murrum and gravels have been spread over the site. The town planning authorities said that height of the land has been increased to 3 ft which, according to them, is violation of the clause 53 (1) of the Maharashtra Regional Town Planning Act 1966.

“The construction activities in the locality may lead to flooding in the nearby residential areas. I have asked the junior engineers to carry out the survey of the locality and check for more such activities. Also, the officials ignoring such activities will also be acted upon,” Kalshetti said.

Construction activities along the banks of Jayakwadi river are one of the reasons to aggravate the flooding situation in the low-lying areas.

Title: TNPSC scam: Major changes in Group IV, Group II-A exams
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

CHENNAI: The Tamil Nadu Public Service Commission (TNPSC) on Saturday announced major changes in Group IV and Group II-A exams and candidates aspiring for posts of junior assistant, typist and assistant need to clear both preliminary and main exam. Till now, the commission selected candidates based on one exam for these posts.

After unearthing major scams in Group IV, Group II-A exams, the TNPSC in its meeting on Friday decided to bring major changes in the examination pattern and improve the security of answer sheets while being transported. “In the future, Group IV, Group II-A exams will have two stages — preliminary and main. To prevent impersonation, candidates need to be present at the exam centres an hour in advance,” a release from TNPSC said.

Candidates need to give their thumb impressions instead of signature on answer sheets. Details of candidates and answer sheets will be separated in the exam hall itself and sealed, and candidates need to sign on the seal. Changes have been introduced to avoid fudging of OMR sheets. “Candidates who do not know answers for multiple choice questions will have to shade a specific box provided for each question. They also need to mention the number of questions for which they used the additional box option at the end of the exam. If a candidate does not shade any of the boxes for a question, the answer sheet will become invalid,” TNPSC said. The commission has decided to allot an additional 15 minutes for filling the details.

“Transportation of answer sheets from exam centres to TNPSC office also will be strengthened. The vehicles will be GPS-tagged and CCTV cameras will be installed to monitor the answer sheets 24X7,” TNPSC added.

Following the complaints from candidates, TNPSC has unearthed major scams in Group IV and Group II-A exams. It also banned 99 candidates who wrote exams from Rameswaram and Keelakarai exam centres in Ramanathapuram district for involving in malpractices. According to the CBCID, the answer sheets of Group IV candidates were tampered with on a moving vehicle by middlemen, who shaded the correct responses for candidates from whom they had taken money. The CBCID has arrested more than 40 persons in connection with the scam so far.

TNPSC also plans to improve communication with candidates and will launch a special page on its website. “It will be helpful to receive feedbacks on new changes and help the commission know about malpractices,” the release said.

Title: Tankers supplying Aavin milk to Chennai go on strike
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: Milk tankers in contract with state-run dairy brand Aavin to supply milk to the city went into strike on Friday midnight as the management failed to float new tenders and continued to operate them at old rates for the past one year. More than 303 tankers have stopped bringing in not less than 12 lakh litres milk into Chennai. The management, however, assured that milk supply to city consumers will not be disrupted.

“We have roped in private tankers to bring in milk from various districts. There won’t be any disturbance in milk supply as all the tankers have started to come into Chennai,” said a senior Aavin official.

“Fresh tenders must have been floated a year back but were were not able to do it due to the local body elections. We will convene a meeting with the tanker operators on Sunday or Monday and try to get them to withdraw their strike,” said the official.

For Aavin, Chennai is the biggest market as the maximum amount of milk is sold in the city. Apart from retail sale of milk in Chennai and other big cities, Aavin has started selling milk in bulk as well. “Untill last year, we were converting excess milk into milk powder and that was not very profitable as the market for milk powder was not big. Recently, we started selling the excess milk in bulk to milk dairies in Tamil Nadu and other states. This has increased revenue,” said the official.

Title: Meet on managing groundwater
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Hyderabad: A one-day seminar on groundwater management law was held at Symbiosis Law School (SLS) on Saturday.

Experts addressed issues related to groundwater and focused on the need to prepare a comprehensive road map to avert water crisis. “Water availability and its usage is uneven and requires legal regulation in India,” said MK Ramesh, professor, National Law School of India University in Bengaluru. tnn

Title: New bus services flagged off
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Madurai: Four new bus services were flagged off by revenue and disaster management minister R B Udayakumar on Saturday. The services will be operated from Thirumangalam to Arapalayam, MGR Bus Terminal, Anna Nagar and Park Town.

The buses worth Rs 1.14 crore were flagged off in the presence of Madurai district collector T G Vinay and higher officials from Tamil Nadu State Transport Corporation. More new buses connecting mofussil areas of Madurai are in the pipeline. The officials said that 85 new buses have been allotted to TNSTC’s Madurai division recently. Out of which, 50 are city buses and 35 are mofussil buses.

Tamil Nadu Transport Corporation is serving around 1.75 crore people through its eight divisions, officials said.tnn

Title: 3 SL fishers detained for entering Indian waters
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Madurai: Three Sri Lankan fishermen who entered the Indian territorial waters off Dhanushkodi in Ramanathapuram district were detained by the Ramanathapuram district marine police on Saturday. The trio was identified as Anthony Suganth, 26, Santhiya Thomas Luvis, 32, and Thavasin Dominic Sahaya Vinistro, 24, from Talaimannar, a coastal area in the north western part of Mannar district in Sri Lanka. The trio set off from Talaimannar in their fishing boat at around 4am on Saturday.

“They were found fishing about one nautical mile (1.85km) within the IMBL in Indian waters off Arichal Munai near Dhanushkodi,” marine police inspector for Ramanathapuram district S Kanagaraj told TOI. He said the IMBL is only 6 nautical miles (11km) from Arichal Munai.

The inspector said that the Sri Lankan fishermen were fishing about 5 nautical miles (9km) from Arichal Munai and crossed the IMBL around 5.45am. Trouble began when a Indian Navy chopper spotted them and asked them to head to Arichal Munai, but the fishermen started speeding towards the IMBL. However, they were stopped by the chopper. Left with no other option, the Sri Lankan boat reached Arichal Munai and the trio was detained by the Mandapam marine police and picked up for questioning. Marine police sources said that inquiries are underway by the intelligence agencies and that a case was not registered till Saturday evening. Their boat and fishing gear were stationed at Arichal Munai beach.

Title: CM Edappadi K Palaniswami urges NGO to take free breakfast to all Tamil Nadu schools
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Edappadi K Palaniswami

CHENNAI: The state government is keen that the Kaalai Unavu Thittam — a breakfast scheme provided by The Akshaya Patra Foundation — be extended beyond Chennai corporation schools. Chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami, while laying the foundation of the new centralised kitchen of Akshaya Patra at Mackey’s garden, Greams Road, on Saturday, urged the trust to extend the scheme to all schools across the state, so all students can eat nutritious and clean breakfast.

The 20,000sqft kitchen on Greams Road will process breakfast for around 12,000 children in corporation schools. Raj Bhavan had sanctioned Rs 5 crore for the facility and on Wednesday, governor Banwarilal Purohit donated Rs 2 crore to the foundation as the first installment from governor’s discretionary grants.

Apart from the Greams Road land, Palaniswami added that the corporation had leased a plot, measuring 35,000sqft, on Perambur Barracks Road to the foundation to set up another centralised kitchen. The kitchen will be able to prepare food for 25,000 children.

Deputy chief minister O Panneerselvam said, “Akshaya Patra Foundation has been providing food for students in 16,856 schools across 12 states and two Union territories. More than 18 lakh children benefit from the scheme.”

The free breakfast scheme was launched last year by the governor when the foundation, working with the city corporation, set up its first centralised kitchen in Thiruvanmiyur. It serves nutritious breakfast to 5,785 students studying in 24 corporation schools.

“When I was told about the idea to start the breakfast scheme, I was elated and took no time to agree to inaugurate the scheme because in order to feed the mind, you must first feed the body. The success of this programme has convinced me to extend it to more than 12,000 corporation school students,” said Purohit.
