Title: Tamil Nadu: Mob lynches youth in Villupuram village, 7 held
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

VILLUPURAM: Police on Friday arrested seven people, including three women, on charges of lynching a 24-year-old youth in Villupuram district. They were produced before a Tindivanam court which sent them to jail. The victim was identified as R Sakthivel, a resident of Karai who worked in a fuel outlet.

Police said R Theivanai, 26, of Karai lodged a complaint with the Periyathatchur police station on Wednesday saying she had received a call from her brother Sakthivel saying a mob had tied him up and was assaulting him near Boothurmalai in the district.

She said she reached the spot with her relatives and found that a mob led by K Raja and his wife R Gowri of Nagar was assaulting her brother. People in the crowd were abusing and kicking Sakthivel on the head and chest; and some were hurling stones at him, she said in the complaint. Some in the mob claimed Sakthivel, a dalit, had sought sexual favours from a woman, while Sakthivel had said he reached a water body to attend to a call of nature when the woman spotted him half-naked and raised an alarm.Theivanai further said police teams from the Periyathatchur and Kanjanur stations reached the spot and rescued her brother from the mob. They directed her to take him to a hospital for treatment. Claiming that she did not have enough money to admit him to a hospital she took him to their house on a two-wheeler. Once there, Sakthivel lost consciousness and she called the ‘108’ ambulance service. A medical tema, which arrived in an ambulance, which reached the spot, declared that Sakthivel had died.

The Periyathatchur police registered a case against Raja and Gowri and five others, including two women, under Sections 147 (punishment for rioting), 148 (rioting, armed with deadly weapon), 294 (B) (obscene acts and songs), 302 (punishment for murder) of the Indian Penal Code and Section 3 (2) (v) of the SC/ST (POA) and arrested seven people.

Meanwhile, Social Awareness Society for Youth urged the government to initiate action against Periyathatchur sub-inspector K Vinothraj for failing to admit Sakthivel to a hospital after rescuing him with severe injuries sustained in the mob attack.

The forum also demanded that the government provide adequate compensation to the victim’s family. It said neither the superintendent of police nor the collector visited the crime scene or the villages of the victim or the accused people to initiate a probe into the incident leading to the death.

Title: Uttarakhand: Water sports conclude in Udham Singh Nagar
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Trivendra Singh Rawat inaugurated the final game of the Kayaking and Canoeing Championships

RUDRAPUR: Chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat inaugurated the final game of the Kayaking and Canoeing Championships conducted under Udham Singh Nagar Carnival 2020 on Saturday. The three-day-long water sports competition, held at Haripura Baur reservoir in Udham Singh Nagar, saw participation of athletes from all across the country. CM Rawat said that the government is working to develop Udham Singh Nagar as a hub of water sport activities. He promised that the district would be made an important national centre for canoeing and kayaking championships in the coming days.

The 1000-metre men's kayaking championship was won by Narendra Kathayat of Madhya Pradesh (MP) and Uttarakhand’s Shubham Kumar bagged the silver medal. In kayaking men's doubles championship, state's Shubham and Rohit clinched the gold medal and MP's Aakash and Anuj managed to secure silver.

In canoeing competition, Badal Kumar of Uttar Pradesh (UP) won gold and Vishal Kumar, also from Uttar Pradesh, bagged silver medal. In canoeing men’s doubles, UP's team of Badal Kumar and Vikrant bagged the top spot and Uttarakhand stood second with Vishal and Surya Kumar winning the silver medal.

Title: Maharashtra: Spurred by governor visit, police clear road for a smooth ride
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

PUNE: Driving on Katraj-Dehu Road bypass between Wakad bridge and Indira institute on any given day, one is struck by the sheer chaos caused by illegally parked vehicles and unauthorized vendors.

On Friday morning, however, the same road posed a contrasting picture, having suddenly become free of all such encumbrances on Friday. The reason? Governor B S Koshyari was in town. Buses and cabs were not in the way, trucks were dutifully parked on the service road and vendors were told to steer clear. “We have been told to shut shop for the day as some important person was in the area,” a fruit vendor said as she packed up her stall.

“The governor is attending an event in the area and we have been told to remove encroachments and make sure the road is not blocked,” a constable on badobast duty said.

This zeal to cater to a VIP’s movement left regular commuters less than impressed. “Daily inconvenience caused to thousands is ignored by the authorities. However, once a VIP is around, the situation turns around 180 degrees,” Vishal Pawar, a frequent commuter, said.

Yash Jain, another regular, too was struck by the sudden change. “I rarely see so many police personnel on this stretch. The carriageway was completely clear, making for an easy drive. Police must take routine action here and not only when a VIP comes,” Jain said.

However, Hinjewadi traffic police inspector Sunil Dahiphale said they don’t always have the necessary manpower.

Title: CCRI’s North-East centre starts farm training, evaluation of commercial varieties
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

bearing fruit

NAGPUR: The city-headquartered Central Citrus Research Institute’s (CCRI) model Regional Research Centre for Citrus (RRCC) set up at Biswanath Chairali in Assam has started farm training and evaluation of commercial varieties for development of the fruit in the Northeast region.

Authorities are calling its first big activity in the Northeast as a landmark during the CCRI’s 35th anniversary year in 2020.

The regional centre has started evaluation of commercial varieties with fertigation (injecting fertilizers). Apart from this, 51 citrus germplasms have also been planted for evaluation. RRCC has started training of farmers in the region. Demonstrations of citrus varieties in the fields of farmers have also started.

The RRCC has been set up to address all the issues regarding the crop in the North-Eastern region.

This centre will operate as a model centre of citrus technology dissemination in North-East region.

AKSingh, deputy director general (horticulture and science) ICAR, laid the foundation stone of the RRCC and its farm house building recently.

A 3–day “National Citrus Meet -2020” was organized at Biswanath Chariali, Assam from January 10-12 in collaboration with Assam Agricultural University (AAU), Assam, Central Agricultural University (CAU), Imphal and ICAR — Research Complex for North-Eastern Hill Region, Umiam.

Around 150 delegates, including citrus experts, horticulturists, state agriculture department officials, KVK specialists and programme coordinators, development agencies, university faculties, scientists, students and farmers participated.

CCRI director MS Ladaniya said the institute will provide first hand information and all details about cultivation, marketing and post-harvest management of citrus fruits in North-East region. “The central government is spending huge funds for growth and development of North-East region for creation of job opportunities to youth thereby improving the livelihood status of citrus growers and overall development of the region. The three-day meet included seven different technical sessions comprising various aspects from nursery management to post harvest management and socio economic aspects along with concurrent poster displays,” he said.

The meet’s chief guest, Dr KV Prabhu, said there was need to properly register the citrus varieties. He said that the North Eastern region being centre of origin for citrus, germ plasm collection and cataloguing should be the priority.

AK Singh said that the focus should be on productivity enhancement and value added products from citrus. He emphasized on green but low cost technologies for doubling farmers’ income.

Ladaniya said “The regional centre has started evaluation of commercial varieties with fertigation. Apart from this, 51 citrus germplasms are also planted for evaluation. RRCC has started trainings of farmers in the region. Demonstrations of citrus varieties in fields of farmers have also started.”

Title: ‘Gully Boy’ Owns The Night, Proves Its Time Has Come
Content: Turns out both the pen and the sword are equally mighty weapons in Ranveer Singh’s ammo. Every time the actor wields either onscreen—be it in CGI wars or rap battles—his off-screen rivals don’t seem to have much choice but to concede defeat.That’s what happened at the 65th Amazon Filmfare Awards 2020 @Awesome Assam on Saturday when Singh—whose last two Black Lady trophies came from playing the smitten Peshwa Bajirao in ‘Bajirao Mastani’ and the savage Alauddin Khilji in ‘Padmaavat’—took home the best actor award for playing a slum-dwelling rapper prone to brandishing dagger-like Hindi rhymes in ‘Gully Boy’.In a clean sweep that could be labelled “poetic justice”, the film set in Dharavi’s unglamorous squalor colonized the glamorous evening by bagging several top honours, including best film, best music and best lyrics. Besides Zoya Akhtar who won best director and Alia Bhatt who won the best actor in a leading role (female) for her pitch-perfect rendition of a girlfriend with anger issues, the film’s promising supporting actors Siddhant Chaturvedi and Amruta Subhash, too, went home with a Black Lady each.Besides the gritty film, what eased the glitzy event’s first-time journey from Mumbai—its natural habitat of 64 years—to the North-East was a yellow autorickshaw that puttered onstage bearing co-hosts Vicky Kaushal and Karan Johar.“Nomoskar Assam, ki khobor?” asked its dapper, bow-tie-sporting autowallah, Kaushal, with his trademark “josh”. And the audience, kitted out in vibrant silk mekhela chadors to witness Hindi cinema’s biggest night at the sprawling Indira Gandhi Athletic Stadium, Guwahati, cheered heartily in response.Assam chief minister Sarbananda Sonowal presented the Lifetime Achievement Award to filmmaker Ramesh Sippy who has such classics as ‘Sholay’, ‘Saagar’ and ‘Shaan’ to his credit.Assam chief minister Sarbananda Sonowal presents the Lifetime Achievement Award to Ramesh Sippy at the 65th Amazon Filmfare Awards 2020 at the Indira Gandhi Athletic Stadium in Guwahati on Saturday.Buzz about the ceremony had seen a crowd of local residents camp outside the city’s Lokapriya Gopinath Bordoloi International Airport and the famous Kamakhya temple for a prized selfie with the likes of Karan Johar and Madhuri Dixit.While college student Ankita Baruah’s wait at the airport was rewarded with a fleeting glimpse of idol Akshay Kumar at 1.30am on Saturday, 52-year-old cyclist Bhupen Likson made headlines by pedalling 600km over six days from his native town in Assam's Tinsukia to the venue to meet Salman Khan. The enthusiasm was high even though state board exams for classes X and XII are on.Times Group managing director Vineet Jain presents a cheque to CM Sarbananda Sonowal for the Chief Minister's Relief FundIn the leadup to the awards, the air was thick with the whispers of drivers, shopkeepers and young cafe-goers, all of whom seemed to be swapping lists of local attendees from the Assamese film industry. Assamese star Amy Baruah formed the radiant cultural centrepiece of a Bihu folk dance performance—a showcase that especially pleased the front row full of government dignitaries, including tourism minister Chandan Brahma. On Friday, Ranveer Singh had joined his fans outside the airport in a Bihu dance.The front few rows temporarily turned into a sea of emotion as Ayushmann Khurrana began his performance with an ode to Raj Kapoor's 'Mera Naam Joker'.Another tender moment played out onstage when Abhimanyu Dassani received the trophy for best debut actor for the quirky ‘Mard Ko Dard Nahi Hota’ from his mother, actor Bhagyashree.Tradition and modernity intersected backstage as local dancers watched Shiamak dancers go about their high-energy rehearsals.Co-hosts Karan Johar and Vicky KaushalFactors that added to the onstage charge were Akshay Kumar’s pelvic thrusts, Madhuri Dixit's gyrations, Ranveer Singh's beret-sporting tribute to R D Burman hits and a joint pant-less cameo by Varun Dhawan and Vicky Kaushal. When actor Akshay Kumar threatened to take off their towels, an unexpected reference to Assam’s famous national park arrived. “Sir, it’s Kaziranga, not Kazi-nanga,” pleaded one of them.Madhuri Dixit sets the stage afire with her legendary dance stepsTitle sponsor for event is Amazon.in, destination partner Awesome Assam, the event is powered by partners Joy beautiful by nature, Shyam Steel, Vimal Elaichi, Bikaji and Gaurs Group. The exclusive television partners are Colors and Colors Cineplex, global digital partners Facebook and Instagram, outdoor partner Bright Outdoor Advertising, cinema advertising partner Khushi Advertising, radio partner Radio Mirchi, music partner T-Series, trophy partner The Award Gallery, invitation partner Ravish Kapoor, technical direction and stage management On Cue Productions, acts remixed, choreographed and designed by Shiamak Davar, dancers by Shiamak Davar Institute of Performing Arts. The event is designed, scripted, directed and managed by Fountainhead Entertainment and the show director is V G Jairam.(With inputs by Prabin Kalita)

Title: Anti-CAA protesters hit streets across state condemning police excesses
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Madurai: A large number of people from the Muslim community gathered at Mahaboobalayam in Madurai city, where people have been staging protests since early Saturday morning against the Citizen Amendment Act (CAA) and National Register of Citizens (NRC). Women outnumbered men in the protest. They condemned the police lathi charge on anti-CAA protesters in Chennai on Friday.

As soon as the news of the Chennai lathi charge spread, people staged protests at Goripalayam, Villapuram, Nelpettai and Mahaboobpalayam. In Villapuram, the protest continued till early on Saturday morning. Soon after it was called off, protesters shifted to Mahaboobpalayam and continued the agitation till night.

Police personnel in large numbers were present at the protest venue. Deputy commissioner of police (law and order) E Karthick took stock of situation.

People, who led the protest, collected money among themselves for water and food for the protestors. They had erected a shamiana for shade.

A police officer said that revenue officials and police officers held talks with the protestors, but they were not ready to withdraw the stir. “We did not disturb them, as they did not block traffic movement and was peacefully protesting. We just wanted to make sure that the protest did not expand to the main road,” he said.

Meanwhile, a group of people staged a protest at K Pudur bus stand against CAA on Saturday evening. The protest lasted for an hour. Similar, protests were staged by various political and non-political outfits in southern districts. A large number of people took part in the protest staged in front of Tuticorin South police station organized by the Thowheed Jama-ath.

Meanwhile, executive director of People’s Watch, Henri Tiphagne has written to state chief secretary K Shanmugam and director general of police J K Tripathy urging them to allow people to stage protests peacefully to express their dissent with the government and its policies as permission for peaceful protests is being rejected across the state. He also condemned the violence by the Chennai police and detention of protestors for hours.

Title: Nagpur: Harmony singers take audience down memory lane
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Dipali Sapre and Shirish Suryavanshi.

NAGPUR: To mark Valentine’s Day, Harmony Events organized a musical event titled ‘Romantic Black and White’ for the elderly audience at Bhat Hall in Reshimbagh, on Friday.

Amateur and professional singers presented 25 soulful songs. The journey down memory lane started with song ‘Aha rim jhim ke ye’ presented by Gauri Shinde and Akshay Gupta. Maximum number of songs were presented in duets.

Next was ‘Jane kahan mera jigar gaya ji’ by Dipali Sapre and Shirish Suryavanshi. ‘Jahan mein jati hun’ presented by Purva Salpekar and B Shrikant upped the pep quotient while ‘Chhod do anchal’ by Pallavi Damle and Panjak Pawar left the audience humming for more.

Thereafter, Swapna Pande and Swapnil Titare sang ‘Tasveer teri dil mein’ while Ashwini Salunkhe and Asfaq Sheikh presented ‘Tujhe jeevan ke dor se’ — both songs were liked by one and all.

Audience also enjoyed the song ‘Ye raatein ye mausam’ sang by Indapawar couple Milonee and Yatindra, followed by a presentation by siblings Akshay and Swati Gupta who sang ‘Dil ki nazar se’. Next was ‘Dil ki girah khol do’ presented by Shinde and B Shrikant, followed by a very beautiful song ‘Jhoomta mausam mast mahina’ by Salpekar and Suryavanshi.

Thereafter, several other songs and duets were presented much to the liking of the gathering.

The event was conceptualized by Rajesh Samarth while Shweta Shelgaonkar anchored it.

Title: Man who flashed at woman in Delhi Metro held
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: A man, who had allegedly flashed his private parts at a woman travelling inside a metro train going towards Gurgaon on Thursday, has been nabbed. The man was taken into custody by the Metro Unit of Delhi Police on Saturday and further investigation was under way.

The accused, who has been arrested on charges of sexual harassment, making obscene gestures and outraging the modesty of a woman, has been identified as Abhilash Kumar, a resident of Gurgaon. He is a civil engineer and works at a private company in Gurgaon. He is unmarried, and a native of Karnal.

“The case was cracked by Delhi Metro Rail Corporation (DMRC)’s security cell in coordination with the Metro Unit of Delhi Police,” Anuj Dayal, executive director (corporate communication), DMRC said.

The suspect’s face was not clearly visiblein the tweet posted by the woman.

“He had recharged his travel card online and this helped us identify him,” he added.

Around 1 pm on February 12, the victim had tweeted saying a man with a backpack and wearing a grey jacket flashed his penis at her inside the metro around 6 pm while she was returning from work.

“A complaint regarding obscene behaviour by a male passenger was received on DMRC’s official Twitter handle. DMRC intimated the Ghitorni Police station and also contacted the complainant assuring her of all cooperation possible,” Dayal said, adding that an FIR was subsequently filed.

“We request the public to use the passenger emergency alarm button if they notice any such incident and inform the Train Operator immediately. Also, please give the coach number that you are travelling in so that the person can be apprehended at the earliest,” Dayal said. “DMRC takes complaints regarding the safety of its women passengers with great seriousness,” he added.

Title: Two assault bus driver, conductor in Pune
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A PMPML bus brushing against a motorcycle on SB Road earned the driver and the conductor a beating from the motorcyclist and the pillion rider on Friday afternoon.

The Chatushrungi police have booked the two men for barging inside the bus and assaulting the two men. The duo also attempted to rob the conductor of his bag of cash.

The conductor, Kailash Randive (56), lodged a complaint with the police on Friday.

The bus was en route to Shanipar chowk from Niljyoti, via SB Road. Sub-inspector MA Jadhav said, “After the bus grazed the motorcycle, the two started chasing the bus and managed to overtake it before it reached SB Road.”

The FIR states the duo stopped the motorcycle in front of the bus, prompting the driver, Mahadev Shinde, to halt. “After an altercation the duo climbed into the bus and grabbed Shinde,” the FIR states.

When Randive rushed to the driver’s cabin area to rescue him, the duo assaulted them both, police said. “They tried to snatch Randive’s bag of cash but he resisted them. The duo then jumped off the bus and one of them threw a tile at the window of the bus and damaged it,” a police officer said.

Title: Anti-CAA protests: Thousands raise voice against police excess, refuse to be cowed down
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Following Friday's violence, thousands gathered across TN to condemn the high-handedness of police against ant... Read More

CHENNAI: Many parts of the state witnessed anti-CAA protests on Saturday as people came to the streets condemning police lathicharge on a section of protesters, including women, at Washermenpet in Chennai on Friday evening. However, no violence was reported on Saturday. Police claim that they resorted to lathicharge after protesters threw stones and footwear at the force, injuring four uniformed personnel including a woman joint commissioner of police.

People staged agitations in many places in Trichy, Nagapattinam, Thanjavur, Tiruvarur, Coimbatore, Theni, Periyakulam and Madurai, condemning the police excesses. The protesters circulated a video to claim that police action was unprovoked. Social media was flooded with messages urging people to hit the streets to condemn police excesses. Flash protests were reported from more than 200 places across the state on Friday and Saturday, said police.

In Chennai, about 1,000 people who gathered at Mint to gherao Washermenpet police station dispersed after senior police officials held talks with elders and promised a fair probe into Friday’s incident. However, later, they tried regrouping at Mannadi and Esplanade in North Chennai.

Meanwhile, protesters continued their agitation at Kannan roundabout, the epicentre of Friday’s clash. By evening, crowd swelled to a few thousand people.

On Saturday morning, Chennai city police commissioner A K Viswanathan met chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswamy to explain the law and order situation. Cops have released another video of over five minutes, showing agitators pushing barricades and attacking policemen.

State president of a Muslim outfit, Vellore Ibrahim, on Saturday met senior police officers and demanded detailed probe into the Kannan roundabout violence and claimed that several extremist groups had spread false news to instigate violence.

In Trichy, around 1,000 people including women and children gathered near Palakkarai Roundabout at 11 in the morning. Several hundred people staged protests at Keezhvelur, Nagore and Mayiladuthurai in Nagapattinam district. Similar protests were held in 11 places in Thanjavur district.

In Madurai, the agitators gathered at places like Goripalayam, Villapuram, Nelpettai and Mahaboobpalayam. Similar, protests were carried out by various political and non-political outfits in the southern districts. Thowheed Jamath organised a protest in front of Tuticorin South police station.

Meanwhile, executive director of People’s Watch, Henri Tiphagne has written a letter to chief secretary K Shanmugam and DGP J K Tripathy urging them to allow people to stage protests peacefully.

In Coimbatore, More than 2000 members of Tamil Nadu Thowheed Jamaath (TNTJ) conducted a protest in front of South Taluk office.

Title: Volunteers read out to visually-challenged students
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Madurai: Around 150 first-time volunteers sat a one-on-one reading session with 150 visually-challenged school students at Read Fest 2020 on Saturday at the Indian Association for the Blind, Madurai.

Organized by Lit the Light Trust, a Chennai-based voluntary service group, the exclusive reading session held for the first time in Madurai saw volunteers of different age groups enthusiastically read out to school students and discuss various subjects.

“The event is to create better awareness among people who are not exposed to the struggles of the visually-challenged. Despite the availability of technology like audio recordings and braille, visually-challenged students need support from volunteers as they grow up,” said S N Barath, one of the founders of Lit the Light. He is also hoping to organize more activities in Madurai.

The event was inaugurated by V Senthilnathan, district employment officer, Madurai, who himself also read to a student. “With the right support and hard work, differently-abled people can achieve anything. Opportunities are always open. However, it requires tremendous effort and patience. Such sessions with volunteers supporting definitely boosts their confidence,” said the officer. Many of the volunteers were students from colleges in Madurai and nearby areas and most of the visually-challenged school students who took part were from Classes IX to XII.

A Class X visually-challenged student, Ajay T felt that such reading sessions helped them understand subjects much better. “I struggle with braille especially when covering large portions. I always feel I can learn better listening and when it is a person reading to you, you tend to connect with what they say and can ask questions,” he said.

His reader, Pandiselvi N, a college student is simply happy to help. “I was overwhelmed as I read. Such volunteering also helps feel a sense of fulfilment, especially during difficult times personally,” she said.

Title: Hyderabad puts on its game face
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

HYDERABAD: When it hit the market in August 2019, Hitwicket SuperStars achieved more than just 1,30,000 downloads in 48 hours. It shattered gender stereotypes by featuring women players in a cricket game for the first time and sealed Hyderabad’s place as a rising gaming destination of the world. Back home in India, it joined the league of Bengaluru and Pune – the crème de la crème of this Rs 350 crore-worth industry.

“The game caught massive international attention with 30% of our current users being based in the UK, the US, Australia, Pakistan, Bangladesh and Sri Lanka,” said Keerti Singh, co-founder and VP (operations) of the city-based startup, Hitwicket. Launched in 2015, along with her friend Kashyap Reddy, this artificial intelligence and machine learning-driven gaming firm is among 150 companies, VFX studios, and academies that have compelled gamers globally to sit up and take note of Hyderabad.

US-based industry leader in games and interactive media solutions, Pole to Win International (PTW) recently announced that it will expand its base in the city, where it first set foot in 2016. It’s also planning to increase its workforce here, over the next four years. “We trained a team of gamers in Hyderabad last year who represented India on the international circuit at our first PUBG tournament in Milan. This was under our new esports team name – Orange Rock Esports,” said a company official from the city.

Today, Hyderabad has about 300 big and small successful games under its belt, with 100 (approx) more in the pipeline. Official data indicates that close to Rs 200 crore-worth of gaming content for India and outside is being developed in Hyderabad. Industry pundits say that the city will draw over Rs 700 crore in the next three years with a string of international players eyeing local market. The resource pool, too, may increase with a lot of local talent joining the industry that offers annual salaries between Rs 4 lakh and Rs 40 lakh.

“A lot of independent studios are also coming up in Hyderabad. The surge has been evident in the last few years. And this because Hyderabad is a big game consumer market,” said Chaitanya G, founder and CEO of Chennai based-Playtonia that conducts leagues across the world for popular e-sports like Counter-Strike: Global Offensive , FIFA 2019 and PUBG Mobile.

Apart from new-age computers, mobiles, and high-speed internet that are propelling the growth of the gaming industry everywhere, what’s working for Hyderabad is the number of engineering institutes training students in coding, thereby attracting students towards the development of apps, say experts.

“The number of game developers in the state is expected to rise 10-fold in the next five years. There is huge demand for vernacular content in gaming, animation and VFX and games are being developed keeping the local audience and themes specific to our country in mind,” said Rajiv Chilaka, president Cricket, TVAGA (Telangana VFX, Animation and Gaming Association).

“Cricket, games with mythological backdrops, those revolving around mental health and puzzles to stimulate the mind are some of the popular themes developed in Hyderabad,” he added. TVAGA is a non-profit association of the media & entertainment industry in Telangana, working in collaboration with the state government.

Title: Woman dies after giving birth in Pithoragarh
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

PITHORAGARH: A 28-year-old woman died after giving birth to a baby girl at Har Gobind Pant Mahila Hospital in Pithoragarh on Saturday.

This is the second such maternity death in the past fortnight and fourth in two months.

Deceased Ridhima Gunjiyal, a resident of Gothi village of Dharchula Tehsil, was admitted to the hospital on Friday and on Saturday morning she gave birth to a baby girl, according to Bhagirathi Garvyal, chief medical superintendent (CMS) of the hospital. “But, after a while, Ridhima started having respiratory issues and she passed away after two hours,” Garvyal said, adding that Ridhima was eight-month pregnant and had only five grams of haemoglobin, which is very low. The baby girl’s condition is said to be stable.

“She also had high blood pressure. Such patients are of high risk category,” Garvyal said. The CMS also said that the hospital lacks adequate health facilities. “There are no modern facilities available here. The hospital is also old. Ayurvedic and Homeopathy department runs from here too. So, enough rooms are not available for women,” Garvyal added. Earlier on February 3, Neelam Bora, a 26-year-old resident of Didihat, died after giving birth in the same hospital. There were two more maternity deaths in the hospital in December.

Title: 60 man-eaters killed in over 19 years in Uttarkhand
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

This year, two leopards one in Haridwar and the other in Narendra Nagar have already been killed after they we... Read More

DEHRADUN: Uttarkhand lost 60 leopards and tigers , who were declared man-eaters, in over 19 years, according to forest department data. This year, two leopards — one in Haridwar and the other in Narendra Nagar — have already been killed after they were declared man-eaters. All these big cats, including 56 leopards and four tigers, were eliminated by shooters as they posed threat to human lives.

According to the data, in 2009, as many as 13 man-eater leopards were knocked down, the maximum in any year so far. This is followed by eight leopard killings in 2007, seven killings in 2016, and four killings each in 2019, 2014 and 2011. The data further reveals that all four man-eater tigers were killed in 2012.

Lakhpat Singh Rawat, a contractual shooter of forest department, claims that he alone has shot down 53 man eater big cats — 51 leopards and 2 tigers — in the state in between 2002 and 2019. “I had shot down a tiger in Sunderkhal, Ramnagar in Corbett Tiger Reserve in 2011 and my second tiger kill was on October 20, 2016. However, killing isn’t the only solution. Villagers should be educated about big cat movements and other things,” said Rawat. Notably, forest department data doesn’t verify his claim.

“Once a big cat is declared man-eater by any competent authority, it must either be tranquilized and captured or terminated,” says YV Jhala, senior scientist at Wildlife Institute of India (WII).

It is worth mentioning that the state lost 58 lives to man-wildlife conflict incidents last year. Among these deaths, five died due to leopard attacks in Pauri Garhwal forest division. Senior officials cite human negligence as the major reason behind man-wildlife conflict deaths.

Meanwhile, Rajiv Bhartari, chief wildlife warden of Uttarakhand forest department, told TOI, “Deaths due to leopard attacks are avoidable and we are initiating awareness camps and voluntary protection force for sensitive villages.”

Koko Rose, DFO, Tehri Forest Division, said, “We are urging villagers to use torches during evening and night time. We also ask them to move in groups and construct toilets in their house.”

These measures assume significance as Uttarakhand boasts of a considerable big cat population in Corbett and Rajaji tiger reserves.

Though family members of brave young girl Rakhi (11) who rescued her 4-year-old brother on October 4 from deadly leopard attack feels that more patrolling by forest department will only solve the problem, “In the hills, economy is totally based on agriculture and livestock we cannot avoid our routine duties. Forest department is grappling with severe staff crunch, it should first fill those vacant posts and also various announcements made by them to have volunteer village protection force etc. should see daylight at the earliest. Its own three people were killed in Corbett Tiger Reserve, what they have to say for it?” asked mother of Rakhi.

After National Tiger Conservation Authority (NTCA) latest decision to disallow an outsider to shoot an animal and take permission from authority before radio collaring the wild cat, environmentalist feel justice is being done to the tigers and similar move should be taken for leopards too, “It is a nice move to seek adequate permissions from experts before taking life of any animal. We strongly believe that it is time now that India make stringent norms around leopards too rather knocking them down just because villagers’ have momentary anger after losing their loved ones.” said SS Badoni wildlifer from Haridwar.

Title: Will pay up, but only SC relief can save us: Voda Idea
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

NEW DELHI: Embattled telecom provider Vodafone Idea is ready to pay the government dues related to the Supreme Court’s AGR (Adjusted Gross Revenues) judgment, but said that its ability to remain a going concern hinges on a leniency in the payment schedule for the telecom department’s demand of over Rs 53,000 crore.

The company, which has a debt of over Rs 1.1 lakh crore and appears to be the worst hit from the top court’s AGR judgment, said it is “currently assessing the amount that it will be able to pay” to the government.

“The company proposes to pay the amount so assessed in the next few days,” it said in a statement amid concerns on whether it will make the payment or not. However, it made clear that it needs relief as far as the payment schedule is concerned.

The SC order of October 24 last year had asked companies to deposit the amount in three months (by January 23), and the temporary relaxation handed by the telecom department received a reprimand by the top court on Friday.

The Department of Telecom said on Friday that it wanted the payments by the close of the day, though companies are now planning to pay it before March 17, the next date of hearing in the Supreme Court.

“As disclosed in the company’s financial statements for quarter ending December 31, 2019, the company’s ability to continue as a going concern is essentially dependent on a positive outcome of the application for modification of the supplementary order,” it said.

Vodafone Idea and its promoters — Vodafone group of the UK and India’s Aditya Birla group — have already said that the survival of the company hinges on a relief from the government, and the top court.

And while Vodafone mulls the amount that it will be paying, Sunil Mitta’s Airtel has already made clear its intentions to pay, as well as the schedule. Airtel, which faces payment dues of over Rs 35,000 crore on the AGR order, said it will pay Rs 10,000 crore by February 20, and the rest by the next hearing in the top court on March 17.

Tatas, which have sold their telecom business to Airtel, are also likely to deposit their dues of around Rs 14,000 before the Supreme Court’s next hearing.

And while the financially-stretched telcos find out ways and means to make the payments, the order has come as a bolt from the blue for many public-sector undertakings who have also been caught in the DoT-industry standoff on AGR. These non-telcos — which include Gail, Oil India , Powergrid and Delhi Metro — have also been asked to pay the government heavy dues on their overall revenues.

Title: Open two key trekking routes for foreigners too: Tour operators
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

The Harsil-Lamkhaga Pass-Chitkul and Nelang-Badrinath trek

UTTARKASHI: Months ahead of the trekking and mountaineering season in Uttarkashi , local trek operators have demanded that two key routes in the region - Harsil-Lamkhaga Pass-Chitkul and Nelang-Badrinath - be opened to foreigners. The administration has restricted access to foreigners on these routes, which fall on the inner line of Indo-China border and are of strategic importance to the defence forces. Locals said that foreigners are instrumental in the trekking business, and the ban on them is affecting their income.

“The Gangotri valley region of Uttarkashi district is a hotspot of trekking and mountaineering activities, which attracts adventure lovers from all over the world. However, the administration has banned foreigners from going on two major routes, the Harsil-Lamkhaga Pass-Chitkul and Nelang-Badrinath trek. The restriction has deprived both foreign tourists and local tour operators,” said Jayendra Rana, president of Garhwal Himalayan Trekking and Mountaineering Association.

Tour operators said that the Harsil-Lamkhaga Pass-Chitkul route connects Himachal Pradesh and Uttarkashi and the administration of Himachal allows foreigners to access it. “Foreigners easily get access to this trek route (Harsil-Lamkhaga Pass-Chitkul) from the authorities in Himachal Pradesh. The ban on Nelang-Badrinath trek is understandable, as it is closer to the Indo-China border and has a heavy deployment of armed forces, but the restriction on the other route is unreasonable. The Harsil-Lamkhaga Pass-Chitkul trek attracts a lot of tourists, including foreigners, due to its enchanting beauty,” added Rana.

Bhagwat Semwal, another tour operator, agreed. “It is due to such restrictions that we are losing business to other hill states. Foreigners play a major role in the economy of trekking and mountaineering based activities in the district, but tourists would rather visit Himachal Pradesh or Ladakh. Instead of imposing restrictions, the administration should conduct intense security checks on tourists entering the inner-line areas.”

Sub divisional magistrate Bhatwari Devendra Singh Negi said, “The entry of foreign tourists in Harsil-Lamkhaga Pass-Chitkul trek and Nelang-Badrinath trek routes are restricted, as both the trek routes falls in inner line area of Indo-China border and have strategic importance. The issue is under the authority of the Central government and we are not allowed to take any decision on the issue. However, we have forwarded the demand of local trekking agencies to senior officials.”

Title: Nainital: BD Pandey Hospital receives funding after 2 years
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

NAINITAL: Nainital town’s only hospital, BD Pandey Hospital , has received government funds after two years, as the funding to the 125-year-old hospital was blocked by the government because the hospital could not use Rs 55 lakh which was credited to it in 2012.

The hospital administration failed to disclose the head under which this fund was to be used. Therefore, the government stopped its funding for the last two years. “The hospital administration could not disclose where the money had come from or for what purpose it was to be used. Therefore, the money kept lying in its account since 2012,” read a document prepared by the district administration.

The BD Pandey Hospital is the only government hospital in Nainital and has recently completed its 125th anniversary. However, locals have raised complaints of lack of vaccines at the hospital and deteriorating infrastructure. “The pharmacy at the hospital is always lacking even the basic medicines. The walls are damaged and the pathology lab would be closed by noon. This all happened at the only government hospital in the town,” said Ramesh Bhatt, a local.

The officials of the district administration told TOI that the shoddy work done in maintaining the funds at the hospital were the reason for the shortage of medicines and the poor infrastructure. “Till a few months ago, the hospital didn’t even have the anti-rabies vaccines or antivenom used during snakebites. The condition at the hospital was so bad that the sewer line was flowing below the operation theatres and the work had to be stopped during monsoons,” said Nainital DM, Savin Bansal .

Bansal added that it was only after a fresh audit was conducted of the hospital’s accounts that the Rs 55 lakh was used along with additional Rs 50 lakh that the administration received from the government. “We conducted the audit of the hospital’s accounts and used that money. We also received Rs 50 lakh from the government and now the hospital has enough medicine and we have decided that the pathology lab at the hospital will remain open till 8 pm,” he said.

Title: First non-bailable arrest in GST case in Nagpur
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

The first arrest under a non-bailable offence in a case involving GST evasion

NAGPUR: The first arrest under a non-bailable offence in a case involving GST evasion was made in Nagpur recently. This was in extension to an earlier action in which the directorate general of GST intelligence (DGGSTI) had arrested three persons who were allegedly running shell companies.

The firms were formed with the purpose of issuing fake invoices for availing fraudulent input tax credit (ITC) worth Rs10.44 crore.

The three arrested earlier were basically daily wagers who are supposed to be acting as front for running the dummy firms, which ultimately benefited the mastermind who was held on Thursday. The trail finally led to the arrest of Raja Agrawal, the proprietor of M/s Raja Cement House, an iron and steel company in the city, which was availing ITC on the basis of fake invoices issued by such firms.

Apart from the three shell firms in Nagpur, Raja Cement was also getting purchase invoices from business concerns as far as Ludhiana to avail ITC.

The case holds importance because for the first time, an arrest has been made under a non-bailable offence, which is applicable for alleged evasion of over Rs5 crore. This means that the bail has to be secured form the court. Here, Agrawal has been remanded in judicial custody till February 27. This is the first such arrest in the entire Nagpur zone which extends till Khandesh and Marathwada, apart from Vidarbha.

Sources said DGGSTI units in the country are estimated to have made nearly 100 such arrests in different cases. It has been found that there has been a rampant practice of availing ITC through invoices from fictitious firms, leading to a major impact on the actual revenue collections. The modus operandi is simple. The firms’ addresses are traced to the least expected locations, said a source.

According to a press release issued by the DGGSTI Nagpur unit, the agency had conducted searches in different parts of the country. It was found that M/s Raja Cement had recorded supplies from firms located in Nagpur and Ludhiana.

However, it was found that these firms were fictitious and no actual supply was made. Preliminary search has found that fake invoices worth more than Rs100 crore were generated to get the ITC.

Chartered accountant Amit Agrawal said the act has been amended to cover the mastermind in such cases. Earlier, such persons could get away making poor people like their employees the scapegoat.

Title: Teachers to be trained to help disabled kids perform better
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: A special training programme will be held next week for government high school and higher secondary school teachers in Madurai district , to train them to better take care of disabled students , district education officials said on Friday.

As part of the Inclusive Education of the Disabled at Secondary Stage (IEDSS) scheme under Samagra Shiksha Abhiyan (SSA), the teachers will be prepared and sensitised to handle children with special needs in classrooms. “Differently-abled students, especially from class IX to XII, are prone to get discriminated against as schools tend to fret about the results. This training will guide teachers to help such students to perform well, instead of segregating and discouraging them because they are slow-learners,” said a district SSA official.

He further added that the training programme, which is being implemented across the state, is aimed at helping children with special needs feel normal and welcome in regular classrooms.

“The teachers will be sensitized about how to take care and teach children with special needs. Often teachers grow impatient without understanding what the child’s needs are and what he/she is going through. There are also different kinds of disabilities, with each requiring a unique approach by the teachers,” said the official. Some types of disabilities under IEDSS include, blindness, low vision, hearing impairment, locomotor disabilities, mental retardation, cerebral palsy and autism.

In Madurai district, a total of 604 children with special needs are undergoing formal education at government high school and higher secondary schools under the IEDSS scheme.

The special training program will be held for government high school and higher secondary school teachers from all four educational districts in Madurai-Madurai, Melur, Usilampatti and Thirumangalam. The venue, dates, number of teachers and trainers taking part are expected to be finalised soon.

Title: Opposition leaders lash out at police for using force against protesters
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Chennai: Opposition parties led by the DMK on Saturday lashed out at the police action against anti-CAA protesters in Chennai and sought action against the police personnel who used force against the agitators. On Friday, an anti-CAA protest had turned violent when a group of protesters clashed with police here, leaving four police personnel and several agitators injured.

The incident led to sporadic protests across Tamil Nadu, including at Washermanpet in the city, where the violence erupted, but protesters subsequently called off the agitation, following talks with city police commissioner A K Viswanathan. Agitators alleged that police used force against them without any provocation. Across the state, cases have been filed against several thousand protesters.

The police action also echoed in New Delhi where a group of people, including students of Jamia Millia Islamia, held a protest near the Tamil Nadu House on Saturday, condemning Chennai city police action against anti-CAA demonstrators.

In a statement, DMK president M K Stalin said the protests were being held in a peaceful manner and sought to know why police used force to disperse them.

“Lathi charge was done unnecessarily on the peaceful protesters for no reason and this prompted people across the state to take to the streets,” Stalin said and demanded that all cases registered in this connection should be withdrawn. He wanted action to be initiated against police personnel responsible for the untoward incident.

DMK Rajya Sabha MP Kanimozhi, in a tweet, blamed North Chennai police joint commissioner Kapil Kumar Saratkar for the incident. “A sensitive and sensible handling of yesterday’s agitation in North Chennai would have saved bloodshed and violence against protesters. Saratkar mishandled the situation, which led to violence. Kapil Kumar was the DIG when Tuticorin firing took place,” said Kanimozhi.

CPM state secretary K Balakrishnan accused the state government of stifling anti-CAA protests. He urged the government to permit protests as long as they remain peaceful. Amma Makkal Munnetra Kazhagam leader T T V Dhinakaran and MDMK leader Vaiko said using force against peaceful protesters was condemnable.

BJP national secretary H Raja, however, condemned anti-CAA protests and slammed the attack on police personnel.

Title: Haridwar: WHO nominates Chinmaya Pandya as its Yoga specialist
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

HARIDWAR: Haridwar-based Dev Sanskriti Vishwa Vidyalaya (DSVV) pro-vice chancellor Chinmay Pandya has been nominated as its Yoga expert by the World Health Organisation (WHO). Pandya will consult the body on Yoga and provide guidance on a mobile health application being developed by WHO .

Shanti Kunj media in-charge Hemant told TOI, “The application will be of great help in treating non-communicable diseases. Pandya will also work as a Yoga specialist at Morarji Desai National Institute of Yoga, New Delhi, which will develop a mobile Yoga application. Pandya holds important position in a number of religious, social and academic bodies in India and abroad.”

According to the details provided by Shanti Kunj media division, Pandya has delivered lectures at Cambridge, Latavia, and Chicago Universities besides addressing conferences at a number of prestigious academic institutions including IITs, IIMs, Indian Medical Association, Indian Military Academy, Bhabha Atomic Research Centre, and Defence Research and Development Organisation.

Pandya is the first Indian ever to be nominated as a member of the jury for an international honour — the Templeton Award.

Title: Health officials probe death of woman, foetus
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Health officials on Saturday conducted an inquiry into the death of a 25-year-old woman and her foetus at the Usilampatti government hospital on Friday and submitted a report to higher officials after her relatives protested claiming medical negligence.

P Sangeetha from Reddiyapatti, a private school teacher, was taken to the Vikramangalam primary health centre (PHC) on Thursday morning after she went into labour. However, an hour later, the woman suffered complications and had to be taken to Usilampatti GH on a 108 ambulance. At the hospital, she underwent a C-section, but the foetus died while inside the womb. Sangeetha too died later not responding to treatment. Angry relatives blamed the delay in referral by the PHC staff for Sangeetha’s death and demanded action against those responsible. According to a senior health official, so far no lapses have been found on the part of the doctor and nurses at Vikramangalam PHC. “At the PHC by 12 noon on Thursday, when Sangeetha started showing signs of complications, she was immediately asked to go to Usilampatti GH. However, it has come to our notice that it took at least 1 hour for the 108 ambulance to reach the PHC for transportation. The victim and her relatives had also continuously tried reaching ambulance staff but were neither informed of the delay nor instructed to look for an alternative vehicle,” said the official.

Meanwhile, an official source at the 108 ambulance office claimed that the ambulance reached the patient as fast as possible. “When the woman was referred by the Vikramangalam PHC, we got information that the condition of the patient and foetus was stable. There was no issue in transportation. Even on reaching the Usilampatti GH, both the mother and foetus were fine. We did our best,” said the source. So far, no action has been taken against anyone in this regard.

Title: Former murder accused killed in ‘road rage’ case in Nagpur
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative imageRepresentative image

NAGPUR: A former murder accused was killed in a road rage case after his bike was dashed by a speeding truck on Friday on Nagpur-Jabalpur road. The deceased, Arif Ansari Rehman, 40, was signalling the truck driver to stop, after the duo had got into a quarrel at a dhaba few minutes earlier.

Sources said, Rehman was an accused in a murder case in 2008 but was acquitted.

According to police, Rehman, who has a past criminal record, had gone to a dhaba on Nagpur-Jabalpur highway where he got into a quarrel with the truck driver. The driver later left the dhaba and Rehman along with a worker of the dhaba, Pranay, started following it.

Rehman signalled the truck driver to stop as he was overtaking it, but the accused driver raised the speed and rammed his bike. Rehman and Pranay both fell on ground.

Rehman’s legs were severed as the truck ran over him. He was rushed to Mayo hospital where he was declared brought dead.

The driver of the killer truck has been booked by Old Kamptee police for rash driving and culpable homicide not amounting to murder. Police have also launched a search operation to nab the driver of the killer truck.

Title: Beed residents protest against Citizenship Act after HC order
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

A large number of women from different communities congregated at the Idgah Maidan in Majalgaon on Saturday.

AURANGABAD: The residents of Majalgaon turned up in large numbers at the Idgah maidan on Saturday to join the peaceful agitation against the Citizenship Amendment Act and National Register of Citizens, after the Aurangabad bench of Bombay high court quashed and set aside two orders passed by the additional district magistrate of Beed district and Majalgaon police station.

An activist had moved the HC against the Majalgaon police and Beed additional district magistrate orders denying permission to hold agitation against CAA at the Idgah maidan. The HC in its order stated that people wanting to agitate in a peaceful way “ cannot be called traitors, anti-nationals only because they want to oppose one law.”

After the HC order, due permission has been granted for carrying out peaceful agitation in Majalgaon. Agitators belonging to different communities distributed sweets at the venue. The organisers read out the Preamble to the Constitution and pledged to legally contest against the implementation of CAA along with NRC and NPR.

Sources in the administration maintained that the issue cropped up after the additional district magistrate issued an order under section 37 (1) of Maharashtra police act that restrained the gathering of more than five people at a public place. While the Majalgaon police station, following the standard operating procedure, had issued a notice under section 149 of CrPC, which empowers police to take action to prevent a crime.

Agitated over being denied ‘written’ permission for holding a peaceful protest every evening for four hours at Idgah ground, Ifteqhar Zakee Shaikh, an activist, moved the HC.

Beed superintendent of police Harssh Poddar told TOI, “The Beed police was never against any kind of peaceful agitation and protests. In fact, the protests that are being held at private places in about half a dozen talukas in the district, they do not even require police permission.”

When contacted, Shaikh said the four-hours a day of agitation has been going on for about a month, while the matter was in court. “We are glad that permission has not only been granted, but also the HC order has cleared the air about peaceful protests.”

Title: Only two NDMC staff filed fraud complaints: Delhi Police
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

A Delhi Police barricade

NEW DELHI: A day after bank accounts of hundreds of New Delhi Municipal Council ( NDMC ) employees were allegedly hacked and money siphoned off, Delhi Police and the civic agency have swung into action.

The official statement issued by the civic agency on Saturday said, “NDMC came to know about the incident after the money went missing from several bank accounts. It appears to be a case of ATM fraud . The matter has been reported to Delhi Police.”

Police, meanwhile, claimed to have received only two complaints of online fraud from the employees, while the civic agency employees’ union claimed over 200 employees lost their money.

“We have received two complaints and forwarded it for necessary action. Prima facie they seem to be cases of forgery done by cloning of ATM cards,” said a senior police officer.

On Friday, the employees’ union wrote to the NDMC chairman raising the issue about its members losing money amounting to lakhs, which was withdrawn from ATMs at different locations, most of them from SBI accounts. “Fearing losing money, many people have surrendered their cards,” the letter mentioned.

The first incident came to light on February 9 when Amir Yadav registered an FIR at the Parliament Street police station saying Rs 15,000 was withdrawn from his salary account from an ATM at Munirka, while he was at home. Likewise, Ashok Batra, a resident of Gyan Khand (Indirapuram) claimed Rs 40,000 was withdrawn from his account on February 12. “I received an SMS alert about the transaction in the evening, while the ATM card was with me,” he said.

Title: Uttrakhand: Right wing members booked for rioting on Valentine’s Day
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

ROORKEE: Over 50 members of a right wing outfit were booked by city police for allegedly rioting and taking out a procession against Valentine ’s Day celebration on February 14. Among these, seven offenders have been named and 50 others have been put as unidentified in the FIR.

It is reported that swords and other weapons were brandished during the procession. A confrontation of right wing members with people of other community was also reported.

All the accused were booked under sections 147 (rioting), 148 (rioting with deadly weapons), 149 (unlawful assembly of people), 283 (any person who causes danger to public way), 336 (negligent or rash act which endangers human life) of Indian Penal Code along with section 7 (false rumour) of Criminal Law Amendment Act.

"We have registered cases against right wing workers at two separate police stations of Roorkee . Most of the wrongdoers are still underground but we have pressed many teams to arrest them," said SP (rural) Swapn Kishore Singh.

Title: Media students hone scientific temper at national workshop
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Madurai: Around 40 college students took part in a two-day national workshop on Saturday at the India-based Neutrino Observatory (INO), Madurai, to develop scientific temper when reporting and communicating societal issues. “Science does not mean just the research done in laboratories. Perception of societal issues changes when viewed with a scientific temper. This workshop will help train students to look at problems in society with a scientific outlook,” said Dr S Nagarathinam, professor and head, department of communication, Madurai Kamaraj University, who delivered the keynote address.

The workshop on, ‘Redefining science communication for masses in the age of convergence’ was organized by Media Research Forum, Madurai supported by Vigyan Prasar, Government of India. The event kicked off with Dr TV Venkateswaran, scientist F, Vigyan Prasar, delivering the inaugural address. The students from at least five districts, Madurai, Dindigul, Ramanathapuram, Karaikudi, and Trichy participated in the programme addressed by expert speakers from across India.

The organisers said that the workshop is for students, especially media students to develop their ability to present science in a nuanced manner on media platforms in the age of convergence. “Even in Sangam literature, there are many examples of how science was always conveyed in a simple yet clear manner to masses. In this era, there is a need to present science in the most-understandable form on media platforms,” said Dr Nagarathinam.

One of the key speakers of the workshop Dr B Satyanarayana, scientific officer H, Tata Institute of Fundamental Research (TIFR)/ INO will be addressing the students on Sunday.

Title: Uttarakhand's Ranji season ends with defeat against Maharashtra
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Maharashtra pacer Ashay Palkar

DEHRADUN: Uttarakhand ended their dismal Ranji Trophy 2019-20 campaign with a defeat against Maharashtra by 67 runs in Baramati on Saturday.

Uttarakhand were 103/2 at stumps on Day 3 of the game and the team had to chase a target of 270 runs set by Maharashtra on the last day. However, Uttarakhand kept losing wickets on regular intervals and the match gradually became one-sided in favour of Maharashtra. Uttarakhand got bundled out at a total of 202 runs. For Maharashtra, Satyajeet Bacchav and Ashay Palkar took three wickets each

With this loss, Uttarakhand is now at the bottom of the table of Elite Group C. The side lost seven out of the nine games it played managing only two points in the entire Ranji Trophy 2019-20 season.

Uttarakhand would now be relegated to the Plate Group where it featured in its inaugural Ranji Trophy season.
