Title: Nainital’s British-era library remains shut for over three years
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

The library was set up by a resident of Nainital named Mohan Lal Sah in 1933 after he provided a grant of Rs 5... Read More

NAINITAL: For years, the lake town’s only and the oldest library, Durga Sah Municipal Public Library, had been the centre for literary debates, meetings and discussions. However, a financial dispute between the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and its contractor has led to the 87-year-old library remaining shut for over three years.

The library was set up by a resident of Nainital named Mohan Lal Sah in 1933 after he provided a grant of Rs 5000 and was named after his father Durga Sah.

City historians stated that Nainital’s only library was the hub for scholars and students. “We would go to the library every day. It had the best collection of books on almost every subject. Whether you were looking for books on Indian literature, Western literature, Philosophy or Science, you could find anything here,” said Ajay Singh Rawat, an environmentalist and former professor of the Kumaon University.

In 2015, the ADB was given the task of renovating the library along with almost a dozen other heritage properties which included several historical churches in the town. “The project was given in 2015 and the work on the library started in June 2016 when the library was closed for public use. However, in January 2019, a financial dispute between the contractor and the ADB led to the abandonment of the project and it has remained in this condition ever since,” said an official of the tourism department.

For Rawat and many others who have spent their lives in the town, the condition of the library and the response from officials has been disconcerting. “We remember how all of us would gather near it to listen to news bulletin by the All India Radio (AIR) every morning and evening. People from across the town would come to read newspapers, magazines, literature and even gazette articles which couldn’t be found in any other library,” Rawat said, while also crediting the town’s only library for giving the maximum number of forest officers from Nainital. “There was a time when most of the officials in the UP Forest Services were from Nainital. This was only because the library facilitates it,” he added.

When asked about the project’s progress, the ADB officials said that the older contractor has already been removed and new tenders have been floated. “We have floated the tenders and a new contractor will soon be chosen for the projects across the town. The overall facade of the library has already been repaired but some works like flooring and polishing are yet to be completed. We aim to finish the project within six months,” said HC Sharma, support engineer, ADB.

Title: Kumbh area in Haridwar to spread across 1,454 hectare
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

The entire Kumbh area is spread across 150 sq km covering four districts of Uttarakhand

DEHRADUN: For the Kumbh Mela set to take place next year, the state government authorities have hit the top gear. Officials said that the entire Kumbh area would be spread across 1,454 hectare - out of which 583 hectare has been reserved for parking and 874 hectare for camps. The entire Kumbh area would be divided into 41 sectors - nine sectors more than the previous Kumbh.

The entire Kumbh area is spread across 150 sq km covering four districts of Uttarakhand . Melaadhikari Deepak Rawat, who convened a meeting of the preparations at Haridwar on Saturday, said that in the previous Kumbh a total area of 650 hectare was used and keeping in mind the high number of devotee turnout, it has been increased to 1,454 hectare.

“The total area of the Kumbh is 150 sq km but effectively the area used would be over 1,400 hectare, which is nearly double the area used earlier. The number of sectors has also been increased. Many more such meeting on preparations would be held in the future,” Rawat told reporters on Saturday.

For the extensive exercise, the media centre, police line, traffic line, radio line, cultural tents, homeguard line, entertainment park, helipad, Ayush and Wellness centre would be made in the Kumbh area.

For physically-challenged persons, eco-friendly low-floor buses would be arranged and there would be a separate ghat for them. For the women devotees, the state would start pink seva e-rickshaw and auto, which would be driven by the women.

The dates for ‘Shahi’ snan (key bathing days) were announced earlier. They are: March 11, 2021 (Mahashivratri), April 12 (Somwati Amawasya), April 14 (Baisakhi Kumbh) and April 27 (Chaitra Poornima). The six ‘Parv’ snan days during Kumbh are January 14, 2021 (Makar Sankranti), February 11 (Mauni Amawasya), February 16 (Basant Panchami), February 27 (Magh Poornima), April 13 (Nav Samvratsar) and April 21, 2021 (Ramnavmi).

Title: Cheque cloning racket busted: Maharashtra’s first offence registered at Aurangabad
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: The Aurangabad city police registered an offence and arrested one accused on Saturday after busting an inter-state cheque-cloning racket that is suspected to have cheated many banks and account holders of several crores.

This is also the first cheque-cloning offence registered in the state. All the previous offences were reported from northern India, especially the National Capital Region.

The arrested suspect has been identified as Bhagwan Bhausaheb Muley, a sarpanch. He has been accused of withdrawing Rs 16 lakh from the account of one Bablu Laxman Hari, a resident of Bhagalpur in Bihar, using a forged cheque.

Authorities concerned said the suspects were found using a forging technology so superior that the forged cheques could get past all physical or technological scanning measures and even the Cheque Truncation System (CTS) machines available with private and public banks.

Rahul Khade, the deputy commissioner of police (zone-II), told TOI: “We have arrested Bhagwan Bhausaheb Muley, a sarpanch. Our investigation indicates that he is the first person involved in the racket to have been arrested by us.”

The preliminary investigation has revealed that a Pune-based individual, who has an account in a public-sector bank, has also been cheated of Rs 97 lakh using the same technology. The police have already launched a manhunt for other suspects and have rushed teams to different places.

Talking about how the scam was perpetrated, investigation officer and assistant inspector Ghanshyam Sonawne said the suspected members of the gang would first identify the bank accounts that are either connected to outdated phone numbers, or do not have any phone number on record at all.

“The preliminary probe has revealed that the accused were aware of the amount available in their target’s bank account, the victim’s signature, cheque number and other relevant details. We are checking the source from where all these crucial, sensitive and secret details were acquired by the accused,” said API Sonawne.

An officer privy to the case said the accused would forge cheques from the very sequence available with the target, forge his/her signature and submit the cheque in the bank to get an account transfer done of the cash. When banks do not have the contact number of an account holder, they check the authenticity of cheques using CTS machines. And on confirming the authenticity of the cheque, they clear the cheque.

Using a similar modus operandi, On February 5, Muley submitted a forged cheque of a man from Bihar in the Karmad-based branch of a nationalised bank. As the bank did not have the contact number of the real account holder, it scanned the cheque in the CTS machine, and subsequently transferred Rs 16 lakh to Muley’s bank account. The amount was soon transferred to another bank account using RTGS and NEFT.

The incident came to light on February 11 after the Bhagalpur-based victim checked the balance in his account and discovered the transaction. The bank authorities alerted the branch in Karmad, following which records were scanned. It was then found that in addition to the Rs 16 lakh stolen in this case, an amount of Rs 97,000 was withdrawn in a similar manner on February 4. Another similar cheque of Rs 78.56 lakh was pending with the bank for clearance.

Sources in the bank said after the Karmad police refused to register an offence, the matter was referred to higher-ups in the bank, who approached API Sonawne. He carried out a preliminary probe, before bringing it to the notice of his seniors. They immediately issued directives for filing of an offence.

Based on the complaint lodged by 40-year-old Deepak Shreevas, the district coordinator of the nationalised bank, Jinsi police have registered cases of criminal conspiracy, cheating, forgery, fraudulent execution of signature, against the accused members of the gang.

Title: Nagpur is known for unity in diversity: Nitin Gadkari
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Nitin Gadkari inaugurated the three-day Chhattisgarhi Mahotsav

NAGPUR: City MP and Union minister Nitin Gadkari stated that Nagpur is known for unity in diversity. He announced that one of the events of Khasdar Sanskrutik Mahotsav and Khasdar Udyog Mahotsav will be held at Dipti Signal in East Nagpur.

Gadkari inaugurated the three-day Chhattisgarhi Mahotsav organized by the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) at RTO Ground, Dipti Signal, on Saturday evening. East Nagpur MLA Krishna Khopde, standing committee chairman Pradip Pohane, who conceptualized the event, leader of the opposition Tanaji Wanve, chairman of city transport committee Balya Borkar, Lakadganj Zone chairman Rajkumar Selokar, former deputy mayor Deepraj Pardikar, other office bearers, officials and corporators were present.

Appreciating the event, Gadkari said, “Nagpur is probably the only city which organizes the Chhattisgarhi cultural programme during Marathi-based events. Even programmes related to other languages and traditions are organized. It is because the city is known for unity in diversity,” he said.

The minister added that, “Culture, arts and sports help in grooming children. It is the need of the hour to showcase the importance of each and every tradition and culture to our children for their all-round growth. If not done, our children will be lost in the world of mobile phones,” he said.

Lauding the efforts of Pohane and others for hosting such a colourful event on an abandoned open space, Gadkari said, “I will ensure hosting one of the events of Khasdar Krida Mahotsav at this place. One of the programmes of the recently-announced Khasdar Udyog Mahotsav will be organized here. Nearly 5,000 youths from this area can learn ways to become self-employed from the programme related to the Khasdar Udyog Mahotsav,” he said.

Khopde said that in the past, Dipti Signal was infamous for being backward, but all that has changed because the area is now known for its vast development. “Developmental projects executed here have increased the value of property in Dipti Signal to a great extent. Chhattisgarhi Mahotsav is the first big event being organized here,” he said.

In his introductory remarks, Pohane informed the dignitaries about the programmes planned during the fest.

Sadique Khureshi conducted the proceedings of the programme while corporator Chetna Tank proposed a vote of thanks.

Immediately after the inauguration, a drama titled ‘Shirdi Ke Saibaba’ and based on the life of Sai Baba was performed. The performance of Padma Vibhushan awardee Teejan Bai, a renowned Pandwani exponent, will be the highlight of the fest on Sunday.

Title: Fire in Delhi Today: Fire breaks out at Connaught Place hotel, three in hospital
Content:
Hotel authorities used their staffers to evacuate the guests from all the floors

NEW DELHI: A major tragedy was averted at Park Hotel in Connaught Place on Saturday after a fire broke out in the basement around 9am. Though the blaze was doused by the hotel staffers, the smoke reached the above floors through the air-conditioning ducts. Guests panicked and tried to break open windows, and at least a couple of them sustained injuries. Some of them tried to jump out as well.Instead of informing the fire department and the police about the incident, the hotel authorities used their staffers to evacuate the guests from all the floors. As many as 12 people, including two staffers, who complained about breathlessness were taken to the hospitals nearby. Out of these, nine people were discharged after treatment. Three, including two foreign nationals, had to be admitted to Ganga Ram hospital.Both the Parliament Street police station and the fire headquarters are within a few hundred metres. But it was only around 12.30pm that the police were informed about the incident by the hospital authorities.Additional DCP, New Delhi, Deepak Yadav said that the hospital had informed the Rajinder Nagar police station after which an inquiry was initiated by Parliament Street station. The fire department was also informed. “Those admitted to the hospital for treatment include Abdi Bashir and Joshim Kvan from Norway and Kundan Rai from Gurgaon,” added Yadav.A spokesperson from Ganga Ram hospital said that around 11am, 9 patients were brought to casualty out of which seven patients were discharged after giving the first aid. “Two male patients from Norway have been admitted for breathing difficulty due to suspected inhalation injury,” said a senior official.An FIR has been registered in this regard and the cops are conducting an inquiry to establish the culpability.DFS chief, Atul Garg, said that five fire tenders were immediately pressed into service but by that time the fire was doused. “We issued a show-cause notice as several lapses were found in the fire safety mechanism of the hotel. A team will send a detailed report to the department concerned at NDMC after an inspection,” added Garg. It was later found that the fire had broken out due to a short circuit in one of the cables of the generator.In a statement, the hotel spokesperson said, “We are deeply concerned about the incident that took place at the basement. There was a short circuit that led to a minor fire. However, the situation was quickly normalised by our in-house crisis management team. Some of our guests were exposed to the smoke, and as a precautionary measure, they were sent to the hospital for a thorough check-up. Safety has always been our top priority and we assure that all our guests and employees are safe. An investigation has been launched to get to the bottom of the incident so that we can take measures to avoid a similar situation in future.”

Title: SCB plans rallies to fight plastic menace
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Students at a rally in Cantt area to curb use of single-use plastic

SECUNDERABAD: In order to strengthen the implementation of the ban on single-use plastic, the Secunderabad Cantonment Board ( SCB ) will now circulate a special brochure, listing plastic and thermocol goods that have been banned for sale and use. The brochures will be supplied to shopkeepers as well as consumers.

Officials said the SCB could be the first Cantonment in the country to come up with a proposal to educate the public on these lines. The aim is to reach out to all shopkeepers in the area who use plastic extensively and frequently.

The SCB’s health and sanitation wing had already taken up awareness campaigns in noted shrines in the Cantonment area and on Saturday, the campaign was extended to schools in the area. Students took out a rally to raise awareness on the issue and pledged to do their bit.

SCB officials on Saturday kicked off the drive from a private school in Bowenpally in the form of a rally.

“The brochures are printed in two languages, Telugu and English, and will be distributed in over 15,000 small, medium and major commercial units in Secunderabad Cantonment. It is a six-page brochure which contains a list of banned plastic and thermocol items, penalties to be imposed against the violators and list of officials handling the plastic ban orders and along with contact numbers,” SCB solid waste management superintendent, M Devender told TOI.

Residents who find shopkeepers using plastic, despite the ban, can call on the specified mobile numbers to lodge a complaint. We keep the informant’ credentials completely confidential, he said.

Officials said that they would continue conducting raids by deploying special teams. “If banned plastic materials are found, heavy penalties will be imposed,” said the SCB official. “We have been conducting raids for over six months at various commercial units and sealed many of them. Once penalties were paid, we allowed them to resume operations,” a senior SCB official said.

Title: Haryana: Government staffers to get benefit of tenure in aided schools
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

CHANDIGARH: The services rendered by the staff in government-aided private schools of Haryana would be computed for assured career progression (ACP) and other pensionary benefits on their joining the regular government service. These benefits will be provided to the eligible employees in lieu of a verdict passed by a single-judge bench of HC in 2015 in Uma Devi’s case. The judgement has now been upheld by a division bench of the HC.

Division bench comprising Chief Justice Ravi Shankar Jha and Justice Arun Palli has upheld the order while dismissing the appeal filed by Haryana government challenging the order passed in Uma Devi’s case. The bench has dismissed the appeal after the state failed to justify the 1,434 days’ delay in filing the appeal against the single bench order.

“Having examined the averments set out in the application we are of the considered view that explanation tendered to justify the delay that occurred in filing the appeal does not constitute a sufficient cause. Rather, upon an advice sought from the office of the advocate general as also the legal remembrance, it was opined that matter was not fit for appeal,” the division bench has observed in its order released this week.

With this order, the issue has attained finality and the period spent by employees in government-aided private schools will be counted for the purpose of ACP and other benefits, if such employees join regular government service subsequently.

In this matter, around 51 petitioners, including Uma Devi, had knocked the door of the court in 2013 through their counsel advocate Vikas Chatrath seeking directions to Haryana government to treat the services rendered by them in government aided schools countable towards the pension, pensionary benefits and as well as other consequential benefits.

The Haryana government, however, had opposed the plea on the grounds that their services cannot be counted because such employees have not made contribution towards the central provident fund (CPF) while rendering the service in government-aided schools and, therefore, the record cannot be verified.

Hearing all parties, the single bench headed by Justice Amit Rawal of the HC in its order dated July 24, 2015, had allowed the petition. To resolve the problem of non-availability of record of such staff, the HC had directed the employees to furnish the record of their service rendered in the aided schools and state was told to verify such record with the schools concerned. Court had asked the state to complete the entire exercise within a year. The state, however, had challenged these orders.

Talking about the ramification of the dismissal of state’s appeal, advocate Vikas Chatrath said although the state had in some cases implemented the 2015 orders, in some cases the petitioners had filed contempt plea in which the state was not implementing the orders, citing pendency of appeal before the bench.

Now, things are clear and the government staff who worked in private-aided schools prior to joining regular services would be benefited, Chatrath added.

Title: Hoping for better rank, Cantt board sends fresh Swachh report to Centre
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Secunderabad: Following a poor rank in the previous Swachh Sarvekshan survey results, Secunderabad Cantonment Board (SCB) officials have now prepared and sent a fresh report to the central government. Officials hope that the new report will help them procure a better rank.

SCB was placed at the last position in the Swachh survey that was announced this January. The new detailed detailed report (for January and February 2020) focuses on the implementation of sanitation system and the underground drainage system.

Ministry of Urban Development officials had visited Secunderabad Cantonment to review the work. “We have uploaded every report on various issues, on the Swachh portal. We now expect Secunderabad Cantonment to feature in the top 10 slot,” sources at SCB said. TNN

Title: Indian style ‘Chai Tapri’ to dot Dubai streets; Tea Post plans overseas foray
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Rajkot: The next year you visit Dubai, don’t be surprised to encounter an Indian style ‘Chai Tapri’, albeit an air-conditioned one! Rajkot-based tea retailing startup, Tea Post, is planning to enter Gulf countries in the coming fiscal. The objective is mainly to cater to the Indian diaspora.

“We are planning to open five outlets in countries like Dubai, Sharjah and Abu Dhabi in the next financial year. The first outlet will be opened on our own in Dubai and thereafter we will look to set up a franchise model there,” said Darshan Dashani, promoter, Tea Post, which started in a small scale in 2013 and now has 170 outlets in India with 10 of them being air-conditioned. The company currently has 400 employees.

The Dubai outlet will be known as ‘Tea post-Apni Chai ki Dukan’ and the promoters have already applied for forming a company according to the legal requirements in Dubai.

“We did our research and found that many Indians in Dubai would like our tea if it tastes exactly like the tea sold in India. There are many local people there who are tea lovers and we expect them to come to our outlet,” added Dashani.

Tea Post initially plans to invest Rs 2.5 crore in the Dubai venture. The startup is planning to explore the Australian market after establishing itself in Dubai.

The first outlet of Tea Post started in Rajkot’s Kalavad Road in 2013. It was launched with the aim to give good ambience to tea lovers with the same feeling of a Tapri and with the same price. The aim of the company was to create spaces for people to hang out with friends and family and offer tea at an affordable price. Teas of various flavours and hot snacks with reasonable price attracted tea lovers, and the company hasn’t looked back.

Title: M Devendra Singh to be new collector of Yavatmal
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Yavatmal: M Devendra Singh has been appointed as the collector of Yavatmal while Ajay Gulhane has been transferred from Yavatmal without any indication of his new assignment.

The incoming IAS officer was the Municipality Corporation Commissioner of Latur. It is his maiden posting as the collector of a district.

Ajay Gulhane has assumed the office of the district Collector of Yavatmal a year ago and he has successfully conducted both the Lok Sabha and State Assembly elections. He has in his credit a spectacular work of constriction of over 5,000 check dams across the district. He is eagerly waiting for his new assignment.

Title: Maharashtra: Tiger kills farmer in Tadoba Andhari Tiger Reserve buffer
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

CHANDRAPUR: A tiger made yet another kill, this time in the buffer zone of Tadoba Andhari Tiger Reserve (TATR) on Friday evening. Victim Balaji Wagmare was heading for overnight vigil in the farm in the fringe of forest when the tiger attacked and killed him.

Wagmare was attacked and dragged to the thick shrubs by the animal. The incident came to light on Saturday morning when villagers looked for him and found his mutilated remains in the shrubs. Deputy director of TATR (buffer) Guru Prasad Prasad said they have given a cheque for Rs5 lakh to the kin of victim as ex-gratia, while the remaining part of the compensation will be paid as per procedure.

Sources said that a tigress with two cubs was seen frequenting close to the FDCM resort near Kolara gate of Tadoba since the last few days. While many tourists are learnt to have watched the tigress and its cubs, foresters were keeping a watch over them as they made forays close to the resort.

Prasad claimed that the villagers were quite aware of the presence of tigress and its cubs in the area. Despite being warned, the victim went alone to his farm in the evening.

However, Prasad said so far they have no confirmation whether the same tigress is responsible for the attack. He added that they would install camera traps to get further information about the tigress.

This is fourth human kill in Chandrapur this year. A tiger had killed one Sarita Pal from Morwahi in Saoli range on Friday while she was working in the farm. The predators had killed 23 people in Chandrapur district last year.

Title: Blaze at Rohini jhuggi, none hurt but 1,000 homeless
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

The shacks were mostly made of wood and plastic due to which the fire spread rapidly

NEW DELHI: Around 1,000 people were left homeless after a major fire broke out at a JJ colony in Rohini Sector-16 on Saturday evening. Officials said that 13 fire tenders were pressed into service and no casualties were reported so far.

However, the firemen would conduct a search operation after the area cools down to see if anyone was trapped inside.

The incident took place around 7pm when fire broke out at one of the shacks of Bangali Colony and spread rapidly. Firemen said that the slums were scattered in an area of around 1,500 sq yard. The shacks were mostly made of wood and plastic due to which the fire spread rapidly. The firemen managed to control the flames within an hour and were conducting cooling operations.

Officers said that initially it was difficult for the fire tenders to reach the site since the camp was located in an area that remained crowded with e-rickshaws and three-wheelers.

Residents said they heard loud explosions as the fire spread with cooking gas cylinders in other shanties exploding. Fire officials said they had to undertake a cautious approach since most shanties had cylinders which could explode. The officials also had a tough time getting into the narrow lanes of the JJ colony. People tried to salvage their possessions and suffered burns in the process.

Residents claimed that some children who were sleeping in the shacks were missing. However, police said that no one had approached them saying that their child was missing.

The area district magistrate and senior police officers who had reached the spot ordered that a medical team and a disaster management team be present at the spot to take care of injured persons and arrangements for food and tents be made. Water tankers and toilet facilities were provided by Delhi Jal Board. A case under Section 436 of IPC (mischief by fire or explosive substance) was registered.

Title: Edu officers stay in village to address parents’ concerns
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Koppal: Iliganoor , a remote village in Karatagi taluk of Koppal district, witnessed a unique education awareness campaign by senior officials of the education department.

A team of officials and teachers, led by Gangavathi block education officer (BEO) Somashekhargouda Police Patil, launched the 24-hour village stay from Friday morning to strengthen the bond between people and government schools. As block-level officials voluntarily stayed at the village, the move is said to be first of its kind in the state.

Villagers were thrilled to attend the grievances meeting, where parents had the privilege to sit on the dais, while the officials sat in the audience to listen to what parents want.

Police Patil told TOI that his village-stay programme was inspired by government school stay by education minister S Suresh Kumar. “We had scheduled different programmes from 7am. This event is aimed at knowing expectations of both teachers and parents. Normally, parents and teachers would blame one another in case of poor academic performance of students. If this gap is filled with mutual participation, then quality of learning will automatically be improved,” he added.

Villager Devendrappa Siddapur, also a former APMC chairman, said that village witnessed festive atmosphere as officials spent the entire day in the village. “The initiative guided both parents and teachers. Parent-teacher meeting cleared many confusions that normally prevail. Officials and teachers participated in prayer, jatha and meetings,” he said. Some cultural events were held in the evening.

Police Patil said that a team of 25 youths, who are pursuing PU or above courses, are made to teach basic concepts to schoolchildren. “Our teachers have trained those youths in teaching basic concepts of all subjects. They spend an hour a day teaching their juniors. Each youth has been assigned around 15 students so micro-teaching is ensured,” he stated.

Anjanappa Hanchi, a BA student, said it’s a joyous experience to teach his juniors. “As our village is backward, such initiatives will help school students improve their learning. Meanwhile it’s an opportunity for us to improve our communication skills and knowledge,” he asserted.

K Sharanappa, chairman of School Development and Monitoring Committee, said that around 50 teachers of Ulenur cluster participated in the programme.

Block resource person V V Gondabal, Primary School Teachers’ Association taluk president Amaresh Mailapur, Headmasters’ Association president Dayanand Babu and other officebearers of teachers’ associations, cluster resource persons and other officials also joined in this initiative and stayed in the government school overnight. A play on education presented by teachers enthralled villagers and children.

Title: Concrete investment plans lined up for next 5 yrs: Portugal prez
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Panaji: Portugal President Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa said here on Saturday that he was extremely satisfied with his meeting with Prime Minister Narendra Modi and the two countries deliberated and outlined concrete investment plans, which will be taken forward over the next five years.

“My long meeting with Prime Minister Narendra Modi was very fruitful—bilaterally and multi-laterally. We discussed concrete projects for investment—Portuguese investment in India and Indian investment in Portugal. This is for economic cooperation, scientific cooperation, technical cooperation and university and cultural cooperation for the next five years,” he said.

The Portuguese President said Goa, which shares a cultural link with Portugal, acts as a bridge between India and Portugal.

Sousa arrived on Saturday for a two-day visit to Goa, which was a Portuguese colony for over 450 years, and presided over the inking of several agreements between Goan entities and Portuguese bodies.

He has come with a 38-member strong delegation and is accompanied by a team from the Union ministry of external affairs.

Sousa, who is on a four-day visit to the nation, reiterated his country’s support to India’s long-standing ambitions to become a permanent member of the United Nation’s Security Council.

“You know that India has the full support of Portugal to become permanent member of the Security Council of the UN. We shall help India at the highest level in our next meeting of the Ocean conference in Portugal,” he said.

Regarding the ongoing debate over Goans applying for Portuguese citizenship and whether the issue was brought up during his meeting with the Indian officials, Souza said: “Everything that is good for mutual relations in any field is always a subject of attention of both Indian and Portuguese authorities.”

Sousa delivered the opening remarks at a conference on urban design where he stressed on the need to improve the lives of citizens. For this, said Sousa, nations had to design for the future without the baggage of the past.

“When we meet the future, we do not meet the past. We cannot have nostalgic vision of anything at any place,” said Sousa.

He also said that there were no first class and second class cultures.

“There are no first class cultures or second class cultures or first class civilizations. All cultures are first class cultures. That is what we have learned with our history and your history too. It is the dialogue between these culture and civilizations, armed with intelligent tools, that we can get improved synergies,” Sousa said.

Title: Hope for Parkinson’s patients? Delhi University team develops drug molecule
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: There is a ray of hope for over 10 million people affected by Parkinson’s disease across the world. A Delhi University professor and his team have found an effective drug molecule for the treatment of Parkinson’s disease. So far, there is no cure for the disease.The molecule developed by DU professor has undergone pre-clinical trial, and now been taken by an American pharma industry for further studies. Professor D S Rawat of the chemistry department and his team of seven other people were working on this project for the past eight years.Earlier, the team had developed a molecule for malaria treatment. The results of their experiment were published in ACS Medicinal Chemistry Letters in 2012.“During the same time, I came across a paper published by Sanders in 1987 in ‘Nature’ journal wherein he concluded that chloroquine, a drug for malaria treatment, can retard Parkinson progression. But no one carried forward that work. Since our compounds were better than chloroquine for malaria and had structural similarity with chloroquine, we thought of taking it forward,” DS Rawat told TOI.The team then got in touch with professor Kim at Mc Lean hospital at Boston in the USA. “We started collaboration with him and in 2014, MJ Fox Foundation funded this project. We got exciting results, and our molecule cleared pre-clinical trials, meaning it has an excellent chance to be developed as a drug,” said Rawat.“Out of 10,000 compounds, only one compound comes to market as a drug,” Rawat added while explaining the importance of the compound reaching the trial stage.The molecule developed by the team is based on a hybrid technology. “In this, a medicinal chemist joins two or more drugs for better efficiency than giving drugs in combination,” said Rawat.

Title: Talasani orders probe into dip in Vijaya Dairy milk procurement
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Milk procurement by state-run Vijaya Dairy has dropped from five lakh litres per day two years ago to less than three lakh litres per day now. There has been a 40% decrease in milk procurement by Telangana State Dairy Development Cooperative Federation (TSDDCF) which sells packaged milk and milk products.The reason behind this dip can be attributed to procurement strategies by private players, lower production of milk, among others. Taking a serious note of this, animal husbandry minister Talasani Srinivas Yadav has ordered an inquiry. “Despite the government extending support to the TSDDCF, procurement has dropped by 40% which is unacceptable,” the minister told officials. On the instructions of the minister, special teams have been formed to conduct an inquiry at state, district and village level. The teams will also speak to the dairy farmers at the village level and submit its report by the end of this month.Yadav said the government has distributed 65,000 buffaloes. “Instead of the milk production increasing facilitating a rise in procurement by Vijaya Dairy, the procurement has gone down. Also, probe the involvement of officials and if there is any role in helping the private dairies,” the minister directed the top officials of animal husbandry department.When contacted, TSDDCF managing director G Srinivasa Rao confirmed to STOI that the milk procurement has come down by 40 per cent due to various factors including aggressive marketing by private dairies and production coming down to climatic factors. “The production is low and also the milk powder stocks have exhausted. The private dairies were quick to offer a better price to the farmers to raise their procurement targets,” he said.

Title: As tourists cancel Goa plans, CM says no terror alert, all are welcome
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Panaji: A day after tourism stakeholders raised a red flag about tourists cancelling plans to come to Goa after Section 144 was imposed in North Goa, chief minister Pramod Sawant on Saturday tried to allay the fears of visitors and said there was no “terror alert for the state”.

“People should not panic. It is just an administrative order. I welcome all tourists—international and domestic—to visit Goa,” he said.

Sawant also said the state government was considering withdrawing the notification imposing section 144 as there was “unnecessary panic due to media highlighting the notification”.

“This type of notification is issued regularly,” he said.

He also said tourists shouldn’t worry about visiting the state for the week-long carnival festivities, which begins on February 22, or who have made plans to come for holidays.

The state’s tourism sector, which has already taken a hit due to reduction in tourist footfalls, found itself dealing with cancellation of bookings due to the notification.

Hoteliers and agents have been receiving calls from Thursday asking if Goa has been placed under lockdown due to threat perception.

District magistrate (North Goa) R Menaka also came out with a detailed clarification of her February 10 order. She said though section 144 has been imposed, it doesn’t prevent assembly of four or more persons.

“The order is a precautionary measure only to step up the alertness, essentially to impose tenant verification on all the owners of residential accommodations, private guest houses, paying guest accommodations, etc, so that there is proper verification of antecedents before premises are let out on lease, rent or on hire basis,” she said.

“All tenants are required to be verified through their identity proof such as voter ID, driving licence, Aadhaar, passport, etc, and the verification form should be submitted to the nearest police station for record,” she said.

Menaka also tried to underplay the effect on tourism due to her order.

“The order doesn’t impact tourists, carnival, shigmo or other celebrations. The public should not panic as these orders have been routinely issued as part of general preparedness in the past too for the entire state by both the district magistrates,” Menaka said.

Incidentally, only North Goa district had put out a terror alert and imposed section 144, while South Goa has not issued any warning.

Title: Forest dept lens on Mancherial tiger
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Hyderabad: Following a tiger attack on a cattle-grazer in Neelwai range of Mancherial ’s Chennur forest division on Friday, the forest department is closely monitoring the movement of the big cat. They are currently keeping a close eye on villages in the tiger corridor. Forest officials said that they had identified the big cat within hours after the attack, however, have decided not to reveal its identity.

“The tiger has been identified and we are taking all necessary steps to prevent such incidents in future. It was a random attack and it does not look like the tiger attacked this man intentionally. There is no chance that he could have survived otherwise,” said Mancherial district forest officer Shivani Dogra adding that K4, the tigress with a wire snare around its abdomen is not responsible for the attack.

“We do not want to reveal the identity of the tiger because that might have consequences and prove to be dangerous for the big cats surviving in these forests. The attack was not made by K4. There are quite a few tigers moving in this area and we are constantly monitoring their movement,” Dogra said.

Villagers have been asked not to venture out of the villages alone, especially during early morning or in the evening as that would be the time when these big cats are mostly active.

Title: TRS victorious in 900 out of 904 PACS
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Hyderabad: After winning the local bodies and urban local bodies elections held recently, the TRS on Saturday went on to sweep the primary agriculture cooperative societies (PACS) elections held across the state. Of the 904 PACS and 11,650 director posts, election in 157 societies was unanimous.

The polling was held for the rest of the societies. Farmers exercise franchise in PACS polls. According to the results till late in the night, candidates supported by TRS won in 900 societies and likely to secure chairperson posts. Of the 11,650 director posts, around 11,000 directors belong to the ruling party. In places like Huzurabad and Sircilla, all the director posts were secured by TRS. TNN

Title: ‘Completed PhD to club photography with aesthetics’
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Passion led Mangesh Raut, 39, to pursue photography

Passion led Mangesh Raut , 39, to pursue photography , a field contrary to his family business, which is tailoring. His late father, Krishnarao, was a popular tailor and had a big shop at Yashwant Stadium. Raut calls his dad an artist who designs garments.

Mangesh too does the same, albeit with a camera. The world of lenses has not been a bed of roses for Raut, but what saw him through was his utter grit and determination to learn and to succeed, which he did by earning a PhD in photography at Nagpur University’s 2020 convocation. Raut shared his thoughts with TOI on the road ahead and the challenges as well.

Excerpts from an interview .

Q. What was the topic of your PhD and why?

A. My subject was ‘Photographic beauty and the beauty of photography analysis and appreciation’. My research was not for the common man and neither was it for a professional photographer. It was purely for the artiste who sees the beauty in his surroundings and clicks pictures.

Q. How would you define photography?

A. Photography can be divided into three parts — technical, artistic and aesthetic. While the technical part includes camera lenses and computers, the artistic part resides in every individual, primarily in the form of creative ideas. The aesthetic aspect pertains to beauty, the beauty of nature and all things and creatures that come along with it. The first step is aesthetic followed by artistic and then technical. For example, when we see with your eyes, the first thing that strikes you with its beauty is called aesthetic. After that, you start visualizing various angles to capture that beauty. It’s called artistic sense. The last part is technical which comes basically from knowledge. Behind every picture there are two important people — the one who produces it and the one who likes or dislikes it.

Q. What kind of hardships did you face along the way?

A. After completing my bachelors (BA in fine arts) from Government Chitrakala Mahavidyalaya (GCM) in 2004, I was very clear about pursuing a career in photography. My specialization was photography. I took my first step by going to Mumbai to work as an assistant. I was always fascinated by computers and the camera. In Mumbai, I struggled a lot, but the end result was very satisfying. My favourite teacher and mentor, Raja Mankar, who is now the dean of GCM, helped me immensely. It is only because of him that I met many established photographers in Mumbai and even got to assist them for two years in projects pertaining to jewellery and wedding photography.

Q. You achieved mastery in animation. You even combined it with photography. How did you manage to do that?

A. I got technical knowledge in college, but practical knowledge came my way while assisting established photographers. Photography is a costly affair. You need to invest a lot of money to buy good equipment like camera, lenses and lights backdrops. Actually, the list is endless. At that point in time, I wasn’t financially sound and, hence, I decided to focus on animation courses as computers were my second love. The other reason for pursuing animation was to get a job as most of my college mates were in Hyderabad. They were doing courses in animation and were also earning well. In 2006, I moved to Hyderabad from Mumbai and learnt animation and VFX. But my conscience didn’t allow me to take up a job in the field of animation as my first love was photography. I came back to Nagpur in 2007 and started my own institute. My childhood experience of doing jobs in an STD booth, a stationery shop, DTP, a photo copy centre and later photography in standard 10 to make ends meet gave me a lot of confidence. I did wedding photography and whatever money I earned, I used it to start my institute. A job wouldn’t have given me the freedom to do both animation and photography at the same time. I had a lot of time on hand and hence, decided to use it constructively by doing my masters in fine arts (2008-2010).

Q. When did you think of doing your PhD?

A. During my MFA days I was quite impressed by Dr Vinod Indurkar’s lectures on aesthetics. I took special permission from him to attend his lectures even after completing my masters. I wanted to club photography and aesthetics. Indurkar Sir went a step further by suggesting that I could do a research on the subject. We worked on it for quite some time and in 2013, I registered for my research under his guidance with my topic being ‘Photographic beauty and the beauty of photography analysis and appreciations.’ I did my research in Hindi.

Q. You even took up a job. Why did you quit?

A. After registering for my PhD in 2013, I joined as a lecturer in J J Institute of Applied Arts in Mumbai. I was there for two years with my wife Yogita. She is also an artist and like me, she too has done her masters in fine arts and even registered for PhD. Both of us got transferred to the Government Arts College of Design in Nagpur and I continued with the job till 2017. After that, I quit and started focusing on my PhD and my institute as I always felt that students from rural backgrounds need additional support.

Q. Are you happy with what you have achieved?

A. Today’s world is dominated by social media and with the advent of new technology, photographers are now feeling the need to enhance their skills to compete with the world. This realization has dawned on students. Many of them, especially from rural backgrounds, are approaching me to learn photography professionally. Even though my batchmates are holding high positions, I’m happy to guide youngsters.

Q. Are you not worried about the changing technology?

A. My father was a famous tailor and owned a shop at Yashwant Stadium. Twelve persons were working under him. With the changing trends in ready-made garments, his profession was short lived. But I’m sure that it won’t happen with photography as the world is depending a lot on visuals. Plus, the knowledge that I have acquired keeps me updated with the changing trend.

Q. To who would you attribute your success in photography?

A. My elder brother Nilesh, who is serving the country through the Border Security Force (BSF) on the Jammu & Kashmir border, has been a father figure after the demise of my father. I was also lucky to get a very helpful personality like Mayank Mishra, a neighbour and a businessman who himself is a very good photographer. He had a lot of faith in my abilities and gave me all his equipment to pursue my career in photography. He was the one who guided me and told me to work hard and honestly.

Title: Telangana: Rejuvenation work on Godavari and Krishna rivers set to begin in April
Content:
Godavari river (File photo)

HYDERABAD: Over 70 lakh acres of the land on either side of major rivers Godavari and Krishna would be rejuvenated in the state soon if the efforts of the government are materialized. While the detailed project reports (DPR) are being prepared, which would be submitted to the Centre next month, the works are expected to begin in April.“The idea of the project is to improve the water quality and water flow and reduce sedimentation five km on either side of the both the rivers Godavari and Krishna. Various state government departments such as forest, agriculture, horticulture, rural development and urban development departments are being roped in the project. They have been asked to submit their proposals by March 10 including financials,” GRS Reddy , state coordinator for Telangana and senior scientist at Institute of Forest Biodiversity told STOI.After successfully taking up Ganga rejuvenation project, the Centre has decided to rejuvenate thirteen rivers falling under nine river basins for development. The Indian Council of Forest Research and Education has been tasked with the work, Godavari river rejuvenation was entrusted to Institute of Biodiversity (IRB) in the Telangana. The Centre wants to complete the project within five years (2020-2025). “Godavari river basin in the state covers about 60,270 sq kms spread, Krishna covers 7,420 square kms including tributaries. Main Godavari itself covers 509 km in the state,” the coordinator said.The state irrigation officials said the entire riverscape (five kms on either side of the rivers) would be divided into three layers — natural landscape, agroforestry landscape and urban landscape. The first one would be taken up by the forest department and include work such as protection, habitat management by taking up soil and water conservation, weed control and bio-mediation. The second, agroforestry, is mostly to promote agriculture and horticulture production. “The farmers would be guided with soil and moisture conservation works and planting of economic and fruit trees. The urban landscapes (will be) to develop eco-parks, riverfront development, avenue plantation and institutional plantation,” GRS Reddy said.While development activity would be taken up by government departments, the private land owners have liberty to seek the government help. If the farmers come forward, the government would help them by giving some incentives, officials said. The Telangana forest department is the nodal implementing agency and will coordinate with other department such as revenue, panchayat raj, rural development, irrigation, agriculture department.

Title: Longowal van tragedy: Punjab CM Amarinder Singh orders statewide check on school vehicles
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Police personnel check the charred remains of a vehicle in which four children were burnt alive. (PTI)

PATIALA: In the wake of Longowal school van fire, chief minister Amarinder Singh on Saturday ordered the state transport department to immediately launch a statewide check on all school vehicles to avoid recurrence of such tragic mishaps.

Captain Amarinder directed the district child protection officers of the social security department to keep a vigil on school vehicles violating the provisions of Motor Vehicles Act and on school managements using worn out vehicles for transportation of students. He told the transport department to take strict action against any erring school managements, found violating guidelines for school vehicles. In a tweet, Amarinder said, “Very sad to learn of news from Sangrur, where we lost 4 children because their school van caught fire. Injured have been rushed to the hospital. DC and SSP Sangrur are on the spot & I have ordered a magisterial inquiry. Guilty will be strictly punished.” The tragedy occurred when the van was dropping kids of nursery wing of the private school.

Punjab minister Vijay Inder Singla reached the spot. He said it was unfortunate a teacher bought a 20-year-old van and started plying it. AAP state chief Bhagwat Mann also reached the spot and sought a murder case against school management.

Title: 61% toll fee in Punjab, Haryana now collected through FASTag
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

The toll fee collection through FASTag has increased from 37% in December 2019, to 61% in the first week of Fe... Read More

CHANDIGARH: A total of 40 toll plazas in Punjab and Haryana under the National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) have achieved over 61% target of the collection of toll fee through FASTag.

The toll fee collection through FASTag has increased from 37% in December 2019, to 61% in the first week of February. The NHAI had started the Electronic Toll Collection (ETC) through FASTag on December 15, 2019, at all toll plazas across the country. There are 20 toll plazas each in Punjab and Haryana under the Chandigarh regional office of the NHAI.

The Union ministry of road transport and highways has also taken a decision to waive off cost of Rs 100 for FASTag between February 15 and 29, with an aim to increase digital collection of user fee via FASTag. ETC aims to remove bottlenecks at toll plazas, to ensure seamless movement of vehicles and collection of user fee using Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) technology.

Highest collection of toll fee through FASTag in the first week of February was recorded at Bhavdeen toll plaza under in Hisar at 81.42 %, followed by Makrauli toll plaza in Rohtak at 80.50%, and Saini Majra toll plaza in Ambala at 79.43%. Whereas the lowest collection of toll fee through FASTag was recorded at Chollang toll plaza at 38.38%, followed by Usma toll plaza at 41.38%, and Chak Bamniya toll plaza at 42.52%, all three in Jalandhar area.

NHAI regional project director K L Sachdeva told TOI that on an average 250 FASTags were being sold daily from each toll plaza in Punjab under his jurisdiction. He said that around 40,000 vehicles pass through Dappar toll plaza everyday and around 72% of them now have FASTag affixed on their windscreens.

Taking note of the high cash transaction at four toll plazas each in Punjab and Haryana, the Union ministry had last month granted 30 days exemption to these toll plazas to convert a maximum of 25% FASTag lanes into hybrid lanes to collect cash from vehicles. The extended period came to an end on Saturday (February 15). Toll plazas exempted in Haryana included: Chandimandir, Gharonda, Panipat and Shambhu. Those in Punjab included were at Dapar, Ladowal, Berhampur and Dhareri Jattan.

Now single lane on each side of all toll plazas would continue to be cash lane. The NHAI officials did say that considering the rush of vehicles in the single cash lane, they can take decision to divide such vehicles in two lanes to avoid more inconvenience to commuters. Any vehicle user without a FASTag entering a dedicated FASTag lane at any national highway toll plaza will have to pay double the applicable fee.

Title: First for Punjab: Biometric attendance for students at Mansa government school
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

The school is in the district’s Bhikhi village

MANSA: Government Senior Secondary School at Bhikhi village of Mansa not only became the first school in Punjab to install a biometric system for attendance, but it has also started a mobile message service to keep parents and guardians informed about the attendance of their wards.

When the students mark attendance on reaching, the parents will automatically receive a SMS about the same. This is first of its kind in any government school, claim the school authorities.

The idea of informing the parents about the whereabouts of their daughters came up when the school authorities were brainstorming after finding out that at least in two cases the girls had lied to their parents about being in school when they were not.

Soon after biometric system was established, mobile numbers of parents were fed into the school system, which now sends the message twice to the registered mobile numbers — when the students log in upon entering or leaving the school. If the student is absent for the day, this will also be sent after 9.10am.

This is being done on a trial basis at the moment. “We have asked the parents to provide only mobile number that they use regularly so that messages could be seen well in time,” newly joined school principal Preetinder Ghai told TOI.

Principal Ghai said the school was inspired by the upgraded government schools in Delhi. And in three months, it managed to spruce up its infrastructure to the point that now the school authorities feel that they are ready to compete with upscale private schools.

“The school has a science park with 16 working models. We have put CCTV cameras in every classroom. The school has wifi and seven projectors for students’ use,” said Ghai. The school library is also being stocked with books that would encourage students to look beyond school curriculum. School managing committee chairman Malkit Singh said, “We want our students to feel as if they are in private schools.”

Title: Beauties of yesteryears vroom on Delhi’s streets
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

More than 140 vintage cars are participating in the event

NEW DELHI: More than 140 vintage cars , including eight from abroad, and 35 heritage bikes on Saturday took to the streets of Delhi as part of the ninth edition of the two-day 21 Gun Salute International Vintage Car Rally & Concours d’Elegance.

Owners of some of these well-preserved cars, from Cadillac, Rolls Royce, Bentley and Volkswagen and other manufacturers, took a ride from India Gate — where the event was flagged off — to Karma Lake Lands in Gurgaon.

At the Gurgaon venue, other rare beauties on display included a Bikaner horse cart, wedding palanquin and erstwhile Maharaja Of Gwalior’s howdah.

The eight international vintage cars taking part in the event included 1930 Cadillac V-16 Roadster and 1939 Buick Roadmaster Convertible Sedan, Model 81C from the US; 1936 Rolls Royce 25/30 from Canada; 1951 Bentley MK VI Freestone and Webb from Germany; and 1959 Jaguar XK 150S, 1959 Alfa 2000, 1966 Ford Mustang, Maserati 3500 GT SpyderVignale from Belgium, organisers said.

The oldest car in the rally was showcased by industrialist Gautam Singhania, who brought his 1903 Cadillac and 1936 Rolls Royce. Vintage cars owned by various erstwhile royal families, including Mysore, Rajkaot, and Talcher were also on display.

Madan Mohan, chairman and trustee of the 21 Gun Salute Heritage and Cultural Trust, emphasised on inculcating the value and importance of heritage motoring.

“Seeking to promote India as a global heritage motoring tourism destination, some of these iconic vintage cars will kick off on a 23-day ‘Incredible India Rally’ on February 17. They would traverse through 17 historic cities and cover nearly 4,000 km,” he said. The rally will culminate in Udaipur on March 10.

This story is from February 16, 2020

Taking note of the high cash transaction at four toll plazas each in Punjab and Haryana, the Union ministry had last month granted 30 days exemption to these toll plazas to convert a maximum of 25% FASTag lanes into hybrid lanes to collect cash from vehicles. The extended period came to an end on Saturday (February 15). Toll plazas exempted in Haryana included: Chandimandir, Gharonda, Panipat and Shambhu. Those in Punjab included were at Dapar, Ladowal, Berhampur and Dhareri Jattan.

Now single lane on each side of all toll plazas would continue to be cash lane. The NHAI officials did say that considering the rush of vehicles in the single cash lane, they can take decision to divide such vehicles in two lanes to avoid more inconvenience to commuters. Any vehicle user without a FASTag entering a dedicated FASTag lane at any national highway toll plaza will have to pay double the applicable fee.

Title: Nagpur: Over 33,000 employed in Mihan, says Nitin Gadkari
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Nitin gandhari

NAGPUR: Union minister Nitin Gadkari on Saturday junked the criticism made by the MVA government on Mihan failing to generate jobs and said he will soon come out with a list of persons employed at Mihan and various other companies in the region.

Speaking to the media during announcement of three-day Khasdar Audyogik Mahotsav, which is scheduled to start on March 14, the city MP said Mihan has been growing at a rapid pace and many big companies have already started their operations. “I had assured to provide jobs to 50,000 persons of which 33 ,000 are working there. A majority of them hail from the areas like Umred, Kamptee and others,” he said.

Accompanied by Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSME) director P M Parlewar, MLA Mohan Mate and others, Gadkari said the Centre is planning to launch a portal titled, ‘Bharatcraft’, on the lines of Amazon, Flipkart and Alibaba for selling products made in India. “We’re in talks with the post offices, which are now converted into Indian Payments Bank , to use its manpower for delivering goods at home and also use its offices for storing them like online giants. We’re also in process of launching a website where ideas for innovation and research will be invited.”

Explaining about Mihan, Gadkari said that AIIMS had already started its operations from the new campus and its world class infrastructure was out of imagination. “The Dassault Company has already started making its nine-seater Falcon aircraft which will be out by 2022. The company will also be making parts of Rafale fighter jets. Tata group’s Tal Manufacturing Solutions is making parts for Boeing and Airbus. I’ve spoken to Patanjali directors and they told me that work is in final stage.”

Speaking on promotion of Khadi, the minister displayed a wrist watch made entirely from Khadi and being sold at Rs5,000 per piece. “Except the machine of the watch, every other things have been developed by Khadi. We’ve tremendous potential in Khadi industry with innovative products. There are many success stories on Khadi industry in the region. The government has also launched various schemes to promote these products,” the minister said.

Elucidating on use of other products like honey and milk, Gadkari said both have big potential in the region if marketed properly and can provide huge employment opportunities, particularly in the tribal-dominated areas like Gadchiroli, Melghat, Gondia and Bhandara. “Now, SpiceJet is offering honey pouches with tea in their flights. Mother Dairy’s operations in the region have helped the milk producers to sell their products.”

Khasdar Audyogik Mahotsav from March 14-16

After a grand success of Khasdar Krida and Khel Mahotsav, now Gadkari has come out with another innovative concept of Khasdar Audyogik Mahotsav. “The mega event would be organized at SCZCC, MLA Hostel and Deshpande Hall where exhibitions on industrial products and discussions of experts on various topics will be held simultaneously,” MSME director Parlewar said, adding that it would be a regular feature in the city’s calendar every year.

Gadkari informed that industries minister Subhash Desai was invited for the event along with all MLAs from the region. “I would soon be conducting a meeting of all MPs and MLAs and request them to send youths from their respective constituencies for visiting the event,” he said, adding that youths will get employment opportunities through the event.

A mega national industrial expo will be the highlight of event where big industries and public sector units will be showcasing their products and technologies along with startups and MSMEs. Even IT/ITES industry along with research and educational institutions will be part of the expo.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Fear in air as new master plan takes wings
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

TAMIL NADU: Now that the state government has requested the civil aviation ministry to stick to the old master plan for the airport expansion project, for which 627.89 acres was notified, landowners are a worried lot as they fear the impasse would further delay their compensation. Most of them said the issue, as the state government fears, would lead to more litigations, stay on land acquisition and delay in settlement.

Earlier this year, the Airports Authority of India (AAI) had conveyed to the state government that as per the new master plan, only 606 acres was required for the project, of which 6 acres fall outside the notified area. However, the state government had on Thursday shot off a letter to the civil aviation ministry, requesting it to stick to the original plan.

Narayani, a resident of Madurai , said his nine cents in block four was marked for acquisition in 2010-11 and that he was stuck in the (acquisition) process for the past nine years. “When the notification was issued in 2010-11, we were upset. But we agreed to hand over our land in March 2018, when we realized that we had no other option. While the new master plan won’t affect the acquisition of my land, I hope the state government won’t further delay our compensation, citing this as a reason.” He said he had called up the officer incharge of land acquisition last month to know the status of payment. “The officer said money is coming.”

Other landowners, especially the ones who have leased out their land, said the AAI was being unfair to them. P R Jagannathan, who owns a plot of land in block two, said, “They stuck to a single master plan for the past 10 years. How can they suddenly change the plan when the land acquisition process is on?”

Murugesan, a landowner in block four, said he was taken aback by the recent developments. “We can’t use the notified land to get a bank loan. Banks treat the land like it has no value. We pray that the recent developments don’t delay our compensation in anyway. I am pinning my hope on that amount to find a shelter for my family.”

Another landowner, who didn’t want to be named, said the AAI didn’t seem to understand the seriousness of the issue and how they were affected.

Many residents in the notified area who have already taken loans to buy alternate apartments and land in the vicinity, are also nervous about the changes in the master plan. They were betting on the compensation to pay off the loans. Ajay D, son of a landowner in block eight said, “The government is yet to specify the 28 acres to be denotified. If owners of that land have already taken loans, they have to now look for buyers. It will, however, difficult for them to find buyers given the uncertainty over land acquisition in future.”

Title: Tamil Nadu: Government in a dilenmma
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Airports Authority of India (AAI) now says it requires only 600 acres

TAMIL NADU: While 628 acres of land had already been notified for the much-awaited airport expansion project, the Airports Authority of India ( AAI ) now says it requires only 600 acres of it. That’s not all. It requires another 6 acres outside the notified area for the project as per the revised master plan. This calls for acquisition of land adjoining block 9 and 10.

The move hasn’t gone down well with the state government and local administration minister S P Velumani, has taken up the issue with Union civil aviation minister Hardeep Singh Puri. He wants the AAI to reconsider its decision as the state government has already initiated the land acquisition process for the notified 628 acres.

“We have begun compensating landowners in blocks 1,7 and 11 and allotted Rs264.47 crore for the same so far. The state-level committee has already approved land acquisition in another 13 blocks,” Velumani said.

The state government also fear that a change in plan would offer landowners an opportunity to seek compensation under the New Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in Land Acquisition, Rehabilitation and Settlement Act of 2013.

“This would fetch an additional burden of 100% solatium on the exchequer, while the market value of land would go up by another 12%. The case would be same be it the owners of 6 acres additional land to be acquired, or the ones who have already consented to part with their land under the industrial purposes act. The huge burden on the exchequer will halt the entire process of land acquisition,” the minister said.

The government also fear more criticism from the landowners, who he thinks would stop cooperating with the district administration.

Title: 61% toll fee in Punjab, Haryana now collected through FASTag
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

The toll fee collection through FASTag has increased from 37% in December 2019, to 61% in the first week of Fe... Read More

CHANDIGARH: A total of 40 toll plazas in Punjab and Haryana under the National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) have achieved over 61% target of the collection of toll fee through FASTag.

The toll fee collection through FASTag has increased from 37% in December 2019, to 61% in the first week of February. The NHAI had started the Electronic Toll Collection (ETC) through FASTag on December 15, 2019, at all toll plazas across the country. There are 20 toll plazas each in Punjab and Haryana under the Chandigarh regional office of the NHAI.

The Union ministry of road transport and highways has also taken a decision to waive off cost of Rs 100 for FASTag between February 15 and 29, with an aim to increase digital collection of user fee via FASTag. ETC aims to remove bottlenecks at toll plazas, to ensure seamless movement of vehicles and collection of user fee using Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) technology.

Highest collection of toll fee through FASTag in the first week of February was recorded at Bhavdeen toll plaza under in Hisar at 81.42 %, followed by Makrauli toll plaza in Rohtak at 80.50%, and Saini Majra toll plaza in Ambala at 79.43%. Whereas the lowest collection of toll fee through FASTag was recorded at Chollang toll plaza at 38.38%, followed by Usma toll plaza at 41.38%, and Chak Bamniya toll plaza at 42.52%, all three in Jalandhar area.

NHAI regional project director K L Sachdeva told TOI that on an average 250 FASTags were being sold daily from each toll plaza in Punjab under his jurisdiction. He said that around 40,000 vehicles pass through Dappar toll plaza everyday and around 72% of them now have FASTag affixed on their windscreens.

Taking note of the high cash transaction at four toll plazas each in Punjab and Haryana, the Union ministry had last month granted 30 days exemption to these toll plazas to convert a maximum of 25% FASTag lanes into hybrid lanes to collect cash from vehicles. The extended period came to an end on Saturday (February 15). Toll plazas exempted in Haryana included: Chandimandir, Gharonda, Panipat and Shambhu. Those in Punjab included were at Dapar, Ladowal, Berhampur and Dhareri Jattan.

Now single lane on each side of all toll plazas would continue to be cash lane. The NHAI officials did say that considering the rush of vehicles in the single cash lane, they can take decision to divide such vehicles in two lanes to avoid more inconvenience to commuters. Any vehicle user without a FASTag entering a dedicated FASTag lane at any national highway toll plaza will have to pay double the applicable fee.

Title: Punjab: Lukewarm response to hiring retired doctors plan
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

CHANDIGARH: The Punjab government’s plan to overcome shortage of specialist doctors at its facilities by offering re-employment after retirement has got a lukewarm response.

Grappling with a shortage of surgeons, gynaecologists, physicians and paediatricians, the government had decided to offer them re-employment up to 65 years of age, after attaining superannuation at the age of 60.

The department has got 27 applications, but it doubts if any of the applicants would join back as they will not be given a post of their choice or any administrative responsibilities. Rehired doctors will perform only clinical duties with no additional financial benefits. They will get remuneration equal to the last drawn salary minus pension.

Also, for a retired specialist, setting up one’s own facility or working with a private hospital is more lucrative.

Punjab health minister Balbir Singh Sidhu said retired doctors were being offered jobs at places where there was a shortage of specialists and this might be the key reason for not many showing interest. “We will again invite applications and will make necessary changes in conditions if required,” said Sidhu.

Rural health statistics released by the Union health and family welfare ministry in January had pointed out shortage of specialist doctors. According to the report, Punjab was among three states in the country which recorded a decrease in the number of specialists. Against the sanctioned posts of 496 specialists doctors (surgeons, gynaecologists, physicians and paediatricians), only about 93 are occupied.

Only 32 of the 111 sanctioned posts of surgeon are occupied at community health centres (CHCs) in rural areas. Also, 98 posts of obstetricians and gynaecologists are lying vacant. Similarly, there is a shortage of 72 physicians and 70 paediatricians in rural CHCs .

Punjab Civil Medical Services Association (PCMSA) fears the situation could get worse as doctors who have completed 20 years of service, which made them eligible for post-retirement benefits, have started to resign.

PCMSA president Dr Gagandeep Singh said not many doctors were willing to take up jobs in government hospitals due to lack of benefits. “Recently, two specialists doctors – skin and orthopedics – resigned on completion of 20 years. More will follow,” he said.

Dr Singh said the government should make efforts for creating specialists within the existing workforce by giving incentives. “A delegation of the association last week met principal health secretary and took up issue pertaining to shortage of specialist doctors,” he said. The association submitted suggestions for resolving the problem.

Title: North Karnataka’s potential showcased
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Hubballi: Who said hi-tech companies cannot survive in North Karnataka? Companies like Aequs, Sankalp Semiconductors and Navya Biologicals, which are no less than any European company, have been functioning here successfully, said Ashok Shettar, vice-chancellor, KEL Technological University, while presenting the aspirations of the region to the government and investors at Invest Karnataka 2020 here on Friday.

The first session showcased the potential of the region as industrialists presented their perception.

PB Anand Padmanabhan, president, Shahi Exports, said he has seen three governments in the past five years but industrial policies have been stable. He appreciated the state government, saying elected representatives, irrespective of political affiliation, and officials have been very responsive about handling grievances. “I haven’t seen such a responsive attitude in any other state,” he added.

He said his company had 23 factories in Bengaluru eight years ago. “Now, we have 24 factories in other districts of the state. We have invested Rs 200 crore in North Karnataka in the past two years and now plan to set up five factories in Dharwad, Belagavi, Gadag and Ballari districts. We’ll also set up power plants in the region,” he added.

Aravind Melligeri, chairman and CEO, Aequs, Belagavi, said he set up the company in Belagavi to challenge China. “Everyone who had doubts about our future are now wonderstruck to know that every aircraft in the world is equipped with parts manufactured in Belagavi. Many talk about lack of logistics support in North Karnataka, but we deliver our product to Paris in 48 hours. Our clients, who thought we were in Belgium, today pronounce Belagavi with ease,” he said.

Gunjan Krishna, commissioner for industrial development, said five industrial estates and eight industrial areas have 5,000 units and employ 28,000 people in Hubballi-Dharwad.

Deshpande Foundation CEO Vivek Pawar and other entrepreneurs as well as officials were also present at the event.

Title: S Goa hotel sends packing Chinese man with booking
Content: Panaji: A starred hotel in South Goa recently asked a Chinese national who had a booking with it to leave. The man — who arrived in Goa by a Maharashtra-registered vehicle, came to India from the UK, and hasn’t been to China in over two months — then left the state.The Travel and Tourism Association of Goa (TTAG) said that the hotel informed health authorities about the Chinese guest on Wednesday. It couldn’t be confirmed if the man stayed in any other hotel.The TTAG, however, didn’t approve of the guest being asked to leave on account of his nationality.TTAG said that health authorities ought to have been prompter in visiting the hotel as soon as they were informed.“They need not have waited till the next day to visit the hotel and check on the guest,” TTAG president Savio Messias told TOI. “As per my information, nobody visited the hotel till Thursday afternoon.”State epidemiologist Dr Utkarsh Betodkar said that a health official from Chinchinim primary health centre — under whose jurisdiction the hotel falls — visited the hotel. “But he (the Chinese guest) had already left the hotel. He could not be contacted,” Betodkar said.He also said that he has been interacting with hotel personnel during the past several days to create awareness about coronavirus . He said that targetted programmes were held for hotels.Betodkar also said that authorities need help from people to deal with the problem. “Help us help you, I would say,” he said.Meanwhile, Betodkar said that the state quarantined four persons at Goa Medical College (GMC) only after they cooperated and agreed to be isolated till their coronavirus test results were out. After they all tested negative, they were discharged.

Title: Install 11 water quality monitors: NGT
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

National Green Tribunal

CHANDIGARH: The National Green Tribunal (NGT) monitoring committee on Saturday directed the Punjab Pollution Control Board (PPCB) to install 11 real-time water quality monitoring stations (RTWQMS) at the earliest. Of these, four would be installed at the Satluj, one at Beas , four at Ghaggar and two at Buddha Nallah by March 31.

Chairperson of the monitoring committee, Justice Jasbir Singh (retd) asked all the line departments to ensure 100% treatment of sewage by March 31 across the Punjab. The chairperson, during a meeting on Saturday, also emphasised on the setting up of sewerage treatment plants (STPs) by March 31, 2021 in accordance with NGT orders.

The committee also reviewed the progress of implementation of action plans for clean rivers in the state.

The progress of improving water quality of polluted river stretches, functioning of various STPs, common effluent treatment plants, effluent treatment plants installed in industries was also discussed.

Title: Survey paints grim picture of health service in rural Punjab
Content:
Representative image
