CHANDIGARH: From non-compliance of rules to shortage of medicines, the survey for implementation of programmes of National Rural Health Mission 2019-20 has painted a grim picture of district hospitals in Punjab .To ensure timely execution of key components of National Health Mission by the state, Union health ministry got a survey conducted in four districts — Sangrur, Mohali , Moga and Patiala —through population research centres of Centre for Research in Rural and Industrial Development (Crrid) and Panjab University, for which field survey was carried out in November last year.In Sangrur district, monitoring was done in district hospital, community health centre, Bhawanigarh; primary health centre, Chajjli; and sub-centre in Bhattiwal Kalan . The report pointed out that against norms of NHM, a number of women were discharged early in cases of both normal or C-section deliveries due to shortage of beds in the district hospital. Also, women were made to share beds in the gynaecological ward.Part of the building of district hospital was found to be dilapidated. Shortage of essential drugs was found in all health facilities in Sangrur where sampling was done. Vitamin-A, antibiotics, painkillers and antacid injections were found to be in short supply in the district hospital. The CHC lacked Vitamin-A, Amoxyclav, Ranitidine injection and Ondansetron injection.The PHC did not have antibiotics. Highlighting poor quality, the report pointed out that the gynaecologist, orthopedician, eye surgeon and surgeon were utilising the same operation theatre for different operations, compromising norms of quality. The sub-centre was found lagging in segregation of bio-medical waste at source.Due to absence of security guard, the fear of being threatened by the patients and their kin, especially at night time, was affecting the smooth functioning of health facilities. Non-availability of guard at night led to chaos on many occasions, forcing the health authorities to call police for help.The public health centre in Landran , Mohali, was found to be operating from a shared building with veterinary hospital. With no partition, entry was common for patients and animals, thus exposing patients to infection. The community health centre in Mohali lacked proper cleanliness. The condition of the public health centre’s building was not good.A number of posts of medical specialists, like paediatrician, surgeon, gynaecologist, ophthalmologist, radiologist and physician, were lying vacant in all sampled districts.In the district hospital of Sangrur, only 3 paediatricians against 16 sanctioned posts were worker. While 13 posts of surgeon had been sanctioned, only 7 were filled. Dr Pyara Lal Garg, health expert and former registrar of Baba Farid University of Health Sciences, demanded an audit of National Health Mission programme in Punjab. He said the government should fix accountability for irregularities.

Title: Maharashtra government seeks legal opinion on forming SIT for Elgar case
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Anil Deshmukh said the home ministry had also opposed the transfer of the Elgar Parishad case to the NIA befor... Read More

PUNE: State home minister Anil Deshmukh on Saturday said the government had sought legal opinion from the advocate-general if a Special Investigation Team could still be formed to look into the Pune police action in the Elgar Parishad case despite its further probe being transferred to the National Investigation Agency.

He said, “We have sent a note to the advocate-general, asking him to give legal opinion on whether the state government form an SIT (Special Investigation Team) after the central government had transferred the Elgar case to the NIA. If the advocate-general’s opinion is ‘yes’, then the government will constitute an SIT.”

Deshmukh’s statement came in the wake of chief minister Uddhav Thackeray’s consent to a probe by the NIA despite alliance partner NCP’s opposition. NCP chief Sharad Pawar on Friday had expressed his disapproval of Thackeray’s consent to hand over the investigation into the case to the NIA.

Deshmukh made the statement in the presence of city police commissioner K Venkatesham and other senior officers while interacting with reporters during his maiden visit to the Pune police commissionerate.

“NCP chief Sharad Pawar had given a letter to constitute an SIT headed by a retired judge to inquire into the Pune police action because he had received several complaints and the nine activists arrested in the case were respectable citizens. We had reviewed the investigation conducted by the Pune police on January 23. On the next day, the central government issued a notification transferring the Elgar case to the NIA. We had opposed the decision of handing over the case to the NIA because the state government was not consulted before taking such an important decision,” he said.

Deshmukh said, “We had also opposed the transfer of the case to the NIA before the special UAPA court in Pune. The chief minister later overruled the decision taken by me. The NIA has now taken over the case from the state police and we now expect them to conduct a fair and proper investigation.”

On the 36 rioting cases related to Koregaon Bhima clashes registered with the Pune rural police, he said some of the cases were still being probed by the police and the chargesheets would be filed on completion of investigations.

It is the police’s case that the Maoists supported and funded the Elgar Parishad in Pune on December 31, 2017 as a part of a larger conspiracy to create social unrest and overthrow the government. Alleged provocative speeches and inflammatory statements at the Parishad contributed to the caste clashes at Koregaon Bhima near Pune on January 1, 2018.

Title: At 100, Osmansagar’s tide hits an ebb
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

HYDERABAD: The picturesque Osmansagar , an engineering and architectural marvel, has turned 100. While it should have been an event for Hyderabadis to rejoice, ironically the reservoir across the river Musi has fallen on bad days in its centennial year.

Osmansagar was built in 1920 by the Nizam VII, Mir Osman Ali Khan, as part of the two-pronged strategy of engineer-genius Sir Mokshagundam Visvesvaraya to tame floods in Musi and provide drinking water to a million people in Hyderabad.

The foundation stone was laid by the Nizam on March 23, 1913, and the lake was ready, brimming with water in 1920. The Nizam VI, Mir Mahbub Ali Khan, had conceived the project soon after the devastating deluge in 1908 that had killed about 50,000 people (reported by Los Angeles Herald in its October 2, 1908, issue). The flood had affected over 4 lakh people and caused financial loss of Rs 20 crore, which, if compared to present-day price of gold, would be Rs 6.05 lakh crore. The devastation was huge and human bodies lay strewn all over.

The deluge was the result of unprecedented rainfall over a catchment of 860 square miles of Musi and its tributary Esi on September 28, 1908. The quantum of rainfall recorded at Shamshabad, where a rain gauge was available, was 12.8 inches in 24 hours and 18.90 inches in 48 hours. The flood discharge was 4.25 lakh cusecs and the narrow Musi could not withstand the flash flood, resulting in unprecedented death and destruction in Hyderabad.

The construction of Osmansagar had prevented flash floods in Hyderabad in the last 100 years. The occasional flooding in the city is not due to overflowing of the Musi, but encroachments on channels that drain the rainwater into the numerous lakes dotting the city and ultimately into Musi.

INTACH Hyderabad convener P Anuradha Reddy says Osmansagar is not a mere water body, it is part of the engineering and architectural heritage of the princely Hyderabad state. The survival of Osmansagar is essential for Hyderabad for many reasons. Apart from its environmental charm and benefits, Osmansagar is part of Hyderabad’s hydrological cycle. It was one of the biggest structures built in the British India. “Osmansagar is an engineering marvel. It speaks volumes of the genius of the father of Indian engineering, Sir Visvesvaraya , who took care of every detail of the dam. We presented the lake with INTACH award not only for its engineering superiority but also for the unique hydrological equipment it possesses,” she says.

Unprecedented planning went into the lake design and construction. Material was sourced from a special railway line laid for the project.

Title: Going green with herb-infused water in glass bottles
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Ahmedabad: When the Who’s Who of environment activists and political leaders from across the globe congregate at the 13th Meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals (CMS-COP13) at Mahatma Mandir in Gandhinagar beginning February 15 their thirst will be slaked by HerbalH20, a herb-infused water in glass bottles. The brainchild of Vadodara-based entrepreneur, Prateek Patel, 30, the herbal water is giving a spirited fight to packaged water in plastic bottles and creating its own space among those concerned about health and environment. And to reach the tables at CMS-COP 13 is no mean achievement for a product that’s just six months old.

Patel launched his startup, Shrishti Lifescience, and his product, HerbalH2O, with a strategy to go green, after spending four years in management consultancy for pharmaceuticals and auto industries.

In recent seminars held by government agencies, Dholera Special Investment Development Authority (DSIRDA) and the Delhi-Mumbai Industrial Corridor Development Corporation , Patel’s company served water in returnable glass bottles rather than using plastic bottles that are discarded after use. At these seminars, HerbalH20 used natural botanical extract of basil to flavour the water.

With the health and environmental appeal of HerbalH2O, Patel’s franchise-based business model and concept of circular economy is making quick inroads in the bottled water segment, a top sector of FMCG products. His herbal water in glass bottles has become a regular feature at government, NGO and corporate events.

“Our herb-enhanced water in glass bottles is a better alternative to water packaged in plastic. We have set up plants across the country with each plant having 1 lakh per day bottling capacity. Nine more plants are in the pipeline for Delhi, Indore, Nagpur, Raipur, Somnath and Udaipur among other cities,” Patel said.

“Drinking water can be used as a medium to deliver the compounds of essential herbs, which we generally do not consume due to lack of habit or ready availability. HerbalH2O gives you the option of drinking the goodness of herbs without additional efforts. The glass bottles reduce micro-plastic contamination of water and help mitigate plastic waste generation,” said Patel, adding that this thought was the primary driver behind his startup venture.

“Each 200ml plastic packaged water bottle generates approximately 11 grams of plastic waste. The glass bottle is the safest and most eco-friendly form of packaging as it doesn’t react with the product and can be reused. We follow the concept of circular economy of packaging. In the circular economy, nothing goes to dustbins. We buy back all used bottles for 30% to 50% of MRP. This makes the product safe from packaging contamination and prevents waste generation and reduces the packaging cost in the long run as packaging comes back instead of going to the dumping yard,’’ Patel added.

Patel claims that in the last six months, approximately 300 tonnes of plastic waste generation has been prevented with his venture of providing herbal-infused drinking water in glass bottles.

“We add extracts of herbs grown in-house in the drinking water. We have four variants for three seasons — Tulsi for monsoon, mint and fennel for summer, and ginger for winter,” Patel said.

“Previously one litre of water in India sold at the MRP of at least Rs 200 but his pricing is Rs 80 and if consumer return the bottle they get a cashback of Rs 30, that cost Rs 50 for glass bottled Enhanced Drinking. This cost will soon be reduced as volume will increase and it has a potential to compete with single use plastic bottled water in prices as well and I am working on it,’’ entrepreneur claims.

Patel claims that in the last six months, approximately 300 tonnes of plastic waste generation has been prevented with his venture of providing herbal-infused drinking water in glass bottles.

“Drinking water can be used as a medium to deliver the compounds of essential herbs, which we generally do not consume due to lack of habit or ready availability. HerbalH2O gives you the option of drinking the goodness of herbs without additional efforts. The glass bottles reduce micro-plastic contamination of water and help mitigate plastic waste generation.” Prateek Patel, founder, Shrishti Lifescience

Title: Coronavirus: Poorly equipped medical teams man Punjab borders
Content:
Representative image

AMRITSAR: Digital thermometers are the only equipment Indian medical teams are equipped with for screening passengers showing symptoms of suspected novel coronaviruses arriving at Attari international border from Lahore. Worse still, at Dera Baba Nanak, the medical team depends on its abilities to screen the pilgrims arriving back from Kartarpur Sahib through their physical symptoms alone.While talking to TOI on Saturday, Amritsar civil surgeon Prabhdeep Kaur Johal said they had provided digital thermometers to their team posted at Attari international border. She added that the medical team at Amritsar’s international airport had the thermal scanner for screening passengers.Sources said district health authorities didn’t have any thermal scanner, which costs around Rs 9 lakh. The one being used at Amritsar airport has been provided by the Airport Authority of India.According to Pakistan media reports, no confirm coronavirus case has been reported there but as many as four persons with symptoms of coronavirus were admitted in hospitals.Gurdaspur senior medical officer Vijay Sharma said they had posted a medical team at Dera Baba Nanak international border to monitor the pilgrims arriving from Pakistan after day-long pilgrimage. The medical team screen the passengers with any physical symptoms at the border.Meanwhile, in wake of coronavirus alarm, prices of the face masks, both surgical and N 95, have shot up. The masks are flying off the shelves.Nanak Surgical Enterprises’ Vishal Gupta said surgical masks, which were earlier sold from Rs 3 to Rs 5 per piece were now available between Rs 5 to Rs 8.Civil surgeon Johal said they were using triple layer masks and medical staff which gives medicines to the coronavirus suspects wore N95 masks. She added the report of the sole patient in the isolation ward had also come negative.

Title: Three income tax cases against Amarinder Singh, son adjourned
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Amarinder Singh

LUDHIANA: A local court on Saturday adjourned the alleged tax evasion cases registered by the income tax (I-T) department against chief minister Amarinder Singh and his son Raninder Singh. The court of chief judicial magistrate (CJM) P S Kaleka set the next date of hearing at February 29.

The I-T department had filed one case of alleged tax evasion against Capt Amarinder and two other cases against his son Raninder. Counsel for the department, Rakesh Gupta, said the government had to send senior standing counsel of the Central Board of Direct Taxes (CBDT) Zoheb Hossain from Delhi to argue in the case.

However, he didn’t turn up on Saturday and as a result the case against the chief minister was adjourned till February 29 and cases against Raninder were adjourned till March 21.

Title: Toy prices in Pune face a surge as coronavirus outbreak disrupts imports from China
Content:
Pune is facing a 50% shortage of supply of toys from China

PUNE: The global coronavirus outbreak is playing havoc with the prices of plastic and electronic toys in the city.These toys are imported from China, the epicentre of the global health emergency, and the consequent supply disruption has resulted in a 40% spike prices, sources from the Toy Traders Association of Pune said.“There is a 50% shortage of these toys in Pune, and the prices have been on an upward spiral since December 1, 2019, ever since the market in China was shut in the wake of the outbreak,” a source said.India’s toy markets are dominated to the tune of nearly 70% by Chinese imports, including electronic cars, musical toys, dolls, kitchen sets, toys for toddlers and remote-controlled toys, among others.Sachin Kulkarni, who owns a toy store on Laxmi Road, said the cost of battery-operated stuffed toys has gone up from Rs790-800 to Rs1,000 in the past month. “The sudden surge in prices could also be attributed to the stringent changes in Union government’s Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS) certification and the recent announcement of a hike in import duty on toys from 20% to 60%,” he said.As per the recent notification issued by the Centre, imported toys will now need to be tested locally and must comply with BIS standards. “Non-compliant toys would have to be destroyed. Given the uncertainty regarding quality, many toy dealers have started to refrain from importing,” Kulkarni said.He added the local market was in a panic. “We expect a further 20-30% hike in toy prices,” he added. “No new consignment has arrived from China since the outbreak,” Rahul Chheda, owner of Ambika Toys on Laxmi Road, said.Bad news is in store for the furniture sector too. “Almost 35-40 % of the furniture is imported from China. Now supplies have stopped and rates are likely to increase by 30-40%. At present, dealers are just selling old stock,” Sachin Nivangune, president of Pune District Retail Traders’ Association, said.

Title: Money siphoned off from two bank accounts
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Ahmedabad: Cyber cell investigators were puzzled on encountering the case in which Jagdish Parmar, 56, and Manilal Maheriya, 64, residents of Saijpur Bogha with savings accounts in the same bank, lost money to cyber criminals.

Both complainants say they did not share bank accounts details or one-time passwords (OTPs) with anyone and yet cyber criminals managed to siphon off Rs 2.80 lakh from their accounts. Some of the money was withdrawn at ATMs in Delhi and some through online transfers.

Deputy commissioner of police, cyber cell, Rajdeepsinh Jhala said there has to be an insider involved for the thieves to have got the bank account and debit card details. “We have some clues and will soon crack both cases,” he added.

In a complaint registered on February 14, Manilal Maheriya, stated that on April 10, 2019 at about 11.35am he received a message from his bank informing him that Rs 20,000 had been withdrawn from his account from a ATM and another Rs 80,000 were transferred online to a certain account.

“Maheriya said he had never shared his bank details or an OTP with anyone but the money was still siphoned off from his account,” said an investigator.

In another complaint, lodged on February 15, Jagdish Parmar, 56, a wireman, stated that on the morning of January 19, he saw a message from his bank informing him that Rs 20,000 had been withdrawn twice from an ATM in Delhi.

Rs 40,000 had been transferred online to the account of one Rahul Kumar and another Rs 40,000 had been transferred to the account of one Rakeshkumar,” a cyber cell official said.

Cyber cell officials said Parmar also said that he had not shared his banking details or OTPs with anyone. “We have details of the ATM centre from which the money was withdrawn and the account numbers the money was transferred to,” an investigator said.

Title: Coimbatore: Three men arrested for attacking cop
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

Coimbatore: The city police have arrested three men for attacking a head constable attached to the Singanallur (law&order) police station while he was on night patrol on Friday night. In his complaint, head constable Johnson said that he had found M Shanmugam, 26, of Kaveripattinam in Krishnagiri, S Chinnathambi, 29, of Harur in Dharmapuri district and S Ramamurthy, 30, of Namakkal on the IrugurOndipudur Road under suspicious circumstances on Friday night. When he asked them to leave, the trio attacked him. Residents of the area caught the trio, who were in an inebriated condition and handed them over to the Singanallur police. Johnson, who suffered ear injuries, was given first aid at the Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital (CMCH). He later lodged a complaint with the Singanallur police. The trio was remanded in judicial custody and was lodged in the Coimbatore Central Prison.

Title: CCTV cover to be a must in all buildings
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Pune: State home minister Anil Deshmukh said on Saturday that the Maha Vikas Aghadi government would amend the building bylaws to make it mandatory for builders to install CCTV cameras in new and old buildings.

“The buildings need to have cameras installed at vantage points on their premises, including entry and exit points. The building authorities should monitor the cameras and help police in gathering evidence, if needed,” Deshmukh said.

“We have proposed the installation of certain software, embedded with artificial intelligence, in CCTV control rooms so that they can detect the face of any criminal on record from images captured by the cameras. In such a situation, the concerned police stations would be alerted,” he said.

“Soon, a team would visit Telangana to study the legal aspects of women’s safety so as to expedite judicial processes against suspects involved in cases of crime against women. This is to avoid incidents like the one at Hinganghat in Wardha, where a woman was torched by a man,” Deshmukh said.

On shortage of manpower in the state police force, he said there had been a freeze on recruitment for the past five years, but now they have plans to recruit 8,000 policemen. He also reiterated that a two-member committee was investigating phone-tapping complaints put forth by politicians from different parties.

Title: Bengaluru: SUV rams 2 bike-borne students; friends track down car in 2 hours
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

The victims’ friends said police were reluctant to file a case even after they showed the registration plat of... Read More

BENGALURU: A sports utility vehicle driver allegedly hit two bike-borne students and escaped on Friday night. While police were initially reluctant to register an FIR, friends of the students played Sherlock Holmes by tracking down the car within two hours of the accident .

The car has been seized by police but the driver is yet to be identified. The drama unfolded in front of Central Mall in Jayanagar around 11.30pm on Friday when the victims, Mohammed Murtaza Jamal and Naveen Kumar — both engineering students and residents of Kumaraswamy Layout — were headed back home after visiting a friend’s house.

A speeding SUV knocked down their two-wheeler and the driver fled with the car. Murtaza and Naveen, who suffered serious head injuries, were shifted to a nearby hospital by passersby and fellow motorists.

Murtaza’s brother Mujtaba Jamal told TOI he learnt about the accident within 10 minutes. “By the time I reached the spot, my brother and his friend were shifted to hospital. We looked around the accident spot and found a numberplate, which must have fallen off after the collision. We approached police to take up the case but they were reluctant. By then, Murtaza’s friends and classmates reached the hospital and the numberplate’s photo was shared with them. One of them claimed he had spotted a vehicle with a similar numberplate in his locality, near Banashankari BDA complex,” Mujtaba said. After searching for some time, the friends managed to identify the place where the SUV was parked.

They returned to Jayanagar traffic police and informed cops about the car’s location. Around 2am, police visited the house and seized the car. However, there was no information about who was driving the vehicle at the time of the accident.

Mujtaba, who made many rounds of the police station, eventually got the case registered at 2pm on Saturday. Meanwhile, Naveen and Murtaza underwent surgeries on Saturday. Deputy commissioner of police (traffic west) SK Soumyalatha said they have registered a case and probe is under way.

Title: Pune: Cyber fraudsters use remote-access app, KYC bait to ‘phish’ for money
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A city-based professional fell for a novel cyber trick and lost Rs 45,000, once again highlighting the need for heightened awareness among users.The professional received a message and a call from a person, who claimed to be a Paytm customer care representative. The caller informed him that his Paytm KYC was suspended and that his account would be blocked in 24 hours.The SMS read, “Dear Pytm customer your Pytm KYC has been suspended. Call Pytm office ... immediately. Your account will block within 24 hr. Thank you Pytm team”.The caller then fooled the professional into downloading a remote-access app, which gave the fraudster virtual control over his smartphone, including a real-time view of whatever happened on the smartphone. The caller told him to send himself a text with details of his card, including the CVV. Not long after, the man got a message that Rs45,000 was debited from his bank account.“The fraudster by then had access to my phone, so he could even see the one-time password (OTP) sent by the bank, which he used to make the transaction using my card details,” the professional said on condition of anonymity.This was just one among many similar cases of cyberfraud that have cropped up in the city. In the 46 days of this year, the cybercrime police have received 110 such complaints.“We are encountering this new phishing fraud all of a sudden, with almost 110 complaints from January 2020. Such frauds are increasing across India, including Pune. Such complaints started pouring in last December,” inspector Jayram Paigude of the cybercrime cell of the Pune police said.The cybercrime police suspect the involvement of gangs in Jamtara in Jharkhand and from West Bengal. Jamtara is notorious as the hub of phishing attacks in the country. “The fraudsters’ bank accounts are usually traced to northeastern locations,” Paigude added, advising, “People should be aware that no matter who claims to be calling them, they must not respond to such unknown calls that solicit confidential information. Our investigations are on and we plan to block the fraudsters’ bank accounts and mobile numbers connected with these cases.”Shweta Chawla, a digital forensic investigator and head of Pune-based SC Cyber Solutions, said this was a widespread trick. “People get calls claiming that their mobile wallet KYC is suspended. The fraudsters say that they would help the user update KYC information and take the user through a series of steps,” Chawla explained.“One of the things that they tell the victim to do is click on a remote-access software link sent by them, which helps them gain control of the victim’s cellphone. Then, while keeping the victim on the call, they start financial transactions through the victim’s mobile wallet or credit card associated with the wallet. The victim, being on call, may not pay attention to the OTPs sent by the bank. Since the fraudsters have access to the victim’s phone, they directly copy those OTP’s,” she added.Chawla further said most victims are not aware that the link could be dangerous and instead, misinterpret it as a patch or update from the mobile wallet company. “I have come across four or five such cases recently,” she said. “Such frauds seem to be ‘upgraded phishing attacks’, with one victim having lost Rs1 lakh, while another lost Rs50,000,” she added.Paytm Payments Bank, which has one of India’s most popular e-wallet, said it never calls or contacts any user for sensitive information. A spokesperson said, “We are at the forefront of building digital safety for online payments. Paytm doesn’t call nor message anything related to KYC.”The spokesperson further said the company constantly educates and informs customers to not fall prey to such messages and calls. “Our app alerts users to uninstall suspicious apps that give remote access to the user’s smartphone. Similarly, we have been working with telecom companies to block such spam messages and calls,” the spokesperson said, adding that the company recently filed an FIR against such fraudsters. “Our cyber cell is connected to police crime branches to effectively tackle fraud as and when it is reported,” the Paytm spokesperson said.

Title: Udhagamandalam: Tiger escapes from metal snare
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Gave Threat

Udhagamandalam: A tiger , which was trapped in a metal snare in a private land at Uyilatti near Kotagiri, managed to escape from the trap, forest department officials said on Saturday.

Villagers, who saw the trapped animal, had informed the officials. However, before the officials could reach the spot, the big cat escaped. assistant conservator of forests Saravana Kumar said. “Though it managed to break the snare, the animal has suffered injuries. It is hiding in a nearby bush. A team has been deputed to monitor it.”

In the meantime, an inquiry is under way in this connection, the official told TOI. “It is a farming land, where the owner had cultivated potatoes. We have warned the owner for placing the snare. An inquiry is under way.”

The department plans to treat the injured animal after it is captured, the official added.

Title: Reservoir quenched thirst for 90 years
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Hyderabad: Except for a few years when the inflows were meagre, Osmansagar had provided drinking water to lakhs of people for almost 90 years. The last 10 years have, however, been problematic, as concretisation picked pace. In fact, it was the only mega source of drinking water in Hyderabad for seven years (1920-27) before another reservoir, Himayatsagar, was built across the Esi, a tributary of the Musi, in 1927.

When the foundation stone was laid for the dam in 1913, AT Mackenzie, then superintending engineer, irrigation branch of public works department (PWD), had announced that Osmansagar would be known for its purity, copiousness and permanence.

“It can challenge comparison with any town in the East. This is no light undertaking. In no part of the world would it be a small matter to dam up a river draining nearly 300 sq miles of country and subject to violent floods, with a wall 125 feet high, to transform it into a placid lake three or four times the area of the Hussainsagar, and capable of containing 10 times the quantity of water, to construct a covered conduit 12 miles long, and a pipe system for nearly a million people,” Mackenzie had said, adding that there have been big engineering works carried out in India, but Osmansagar in its boldness and width of view is as big as any.

The dam has a storage capacity of 3.9 tmc feet. The length of the dam is 6,300 feet with the masonry part extending to 3,400 ft. It has a flood discharge capacity of 92,100 cusecs.

Title: Auction of six cars of DSK generates Rs 39.45 lakh
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Pune: The city police and revenue authorities on Saturday auctioned six four-wheelers of the developer, DS Kulkarni, who is in prison with other family members for a cheating case.

The auction generated a total of Rs39.45 lakh. It was conducted on the premises of the Shivajinagar police station on FC Road.

Tehsildar Sandesh Shirke, assistant commissioner of police Shivaji Pawar (crime) and inspectors Manisha Zende and Sunil Gawali overlooked the auction process. The

The Pune police had seized the 13 vehicles — including a high-end Porsche, two BMW cars an MV Agusta motorcycle — from DS Kulkarni in 2018 during the course of the investigation of the alleged Rs2,091 crore economic fraud of the developer and his firm. The vehicles were worth around Rs5 crore.

A special MPID court had cleared the auction of nine of the seized vehicles.

On Saturday morning, seven out of the nine vehicles were taken out for auction. But, there were no takers for the MV Agusta motorcycle. The six vehicles, all cars, were sold within three hours, a police officer said.

The Regional Transport Office (RTO) had estimated the cost of these vehicles to the tune of Rs33.15 lakh, Shirke said.

The highest bid of Rs9.3 lakh for a car was announced by Sampat Patil, a farmer from Kolhapur. The cheapest car was sold at Rs3.05 lakh, the police said.

A police officer told TOI that the motorcyle’s bid started from Rs26 lakh. But, none of the bidders were interested.

Around 60 bidders from across the city participated in the auction procedure. Majority of them were involved in the business of second hand cars.

Title: Rapping the truth
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Even to have a conversation with AR Rahman would be enough”. Sri Lankan- origin Canadian rapper Shan Vincent de Paul is on his first multi-city concert tour to India, called Oh Gawd, and he has a wish list, sort of. There’s the Indian food that he is looking forward to as he travels to Pune, Mumbai, Delhi and Chennai, apart from Bengaluru. But the one thing he hopes comes true is meeting music composer AR Rahman: A huge inspiration for Paul, so much so that his latest single, Best Friend, samples Rahman's iconic song, Mustafa Mustafa (from the 1996 movie, Kadhal Desam. More on this song later, first let’s get talking about Paul and his Mrithangam Rap series that has made him and co-collaborator Yanchan , familiar and much-loved faces in India, the Tamil community in particular.

Marrying mridangam and rap

Mrithangam Rap has Yanchan play the traditionally classical instrument, the mridangam, to Paul’s incessant rapping - mostly in English with a few Tamil words interspersed, one of the rap songs in fact has a popular Rajinikanth dialogue thrown in. The idea - of pairing mridangam with rap is, to quote a fan’s response on their YouTube page, “Brilliant, who would have thunk!” “The fusion is what makes it interesting. I grew up on American rap, Yanchan on Carnatic music, and Mrithangam Rap is about bringing these two worlds together,” says Paul about the collaboration which started as a simple jamming experiment. “We only rehearsed once before the camera started rolling, and then we just went with the flow,” he recalls about what transpired when they sat down to shoot the first video. Today, Paul is credited as the creator of Carnatic rap – ‘an entirely new fusion of classical Eastern instruments with Westerninfluenced rap’. Did he expect Mrithangam Rap to succeed? Yes and No.

“I expected it to do well. I remember telling Yanchan to wait till episode 10 by when it would blow up. The first one went viral and by the third, it had exploded. I was surprised by how quickly it took off,” he says. The series currently has six episodes, and Paul reveals that he and Yanchan will be playing a few of those songs in their concerts here. After all, the virality of the series was a major factor in them getting the gig at the VH1 Supersonic music festival in Pune.

Rap and racism

Paul’s songs talk about topical issues like racism, toxic masculinity, and immigration. Growing up in Brampton, Canada as son of Sri Lankan immigrants - they had migrated from Jaffna to Montreal as refugees, Paul was the only brown kid in his elementary school and so racism was something he’d had close encounters with. In fact, he admits to seeing systemic racism in Toronto even today. “Toronto is one of the most multi-cultural cities in the world but there is systemic racism and that had affected how I viewed myself for the longest time. It was only when I began to see myself as an artiste that I realised that my skin colour didn’t matter anymore.”

A song to celebrate male friendships

Now, back to the song, Best Friend, and Paul explains that the idea for the song came from a need to break stereotypes about male friendships. “When we talk about toxic masculinity, a lot of it starts with how men treat other men. When you read about rapes or sexual abuse, those things start with how men treat themselves. Boys are told not to cry, not to express themselves physically; there’s so much insecurity about holding hands among men! So the song, which is also a tribute of ours to AR Rahman, is about challenging society’s ideas of masculinity and loving your friend,” Paul explains.

Title: 66-year-old patient dies as car rams ambulance in Salem
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

SALEM: A 66-year-old patient died near Ayothiyapattinam in Salem district on Friday night after a car rammed the ambulance in which she was being carried to a hospital. Another six people suffered injuries in the incident.

Police identified the deceased as P Selvi, a resident of Puthiragoundampalayam near Vazhapadi.

“She was running a high temperature and her family members took her to a private hospital in Vazhapadi. Doctors there reffered her to another private hospital in Salem. When the ambulance carrying her reached Masinaickenpatty near Ayothiyapattinam on Salem-Chennai national highway, an SUV heading towards Chennai hit it,” a police officer attached to the Ammapet police station said. “The ambulance was crossing the road to reach a service road when the accident happened.”

Selvi succumbed to her injuries on the spot, while her husband Paramasivam, 70, and daughter P Parameswari, 45, ambulance driver V Murthy, 38, and three others in the SUV suffered injuries.

The Ammapet police took the injured to the Salem government hospital, where the body of the deceased was taken for postmortem.

A case has been registered and further inquiry is on.

Title: Osmansagar can meet water needs of 47 crore people for a year
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Osmansagar

HYDERABAD: How much groundwater is recharged by Osmansagar lake a year? It is sufficient to meet the drinking water needs of one-third of India’s population for a full one year. Sounds strange? Here are the calculations.

Estimates reveal that the quantum of water Osmansagar helps in the groundwater recharge is whopping 17,395 kilo lakh litres a year. This is sufficient to meet the drinking water needs of 47.34 crore people for a year or 52.60 lakh people for 90 years.

According to rainwater harvesting and conservation manual of the Government of India, 100 square metres of a porous ground will yield 80,000 litres of water per year if the annual rainfall is 800 mm. If this calculation is considered, Osmansagar, which is spread over 22 sq km, will yield 17,395 kilo lakh litres a year as the annual rainfall in Hyderabad is 800 mm.

The World Health Organisation (WHO) has fixed drinking water standards at 10 litres per person per day. This translates to 3.65 kilo litres per year. Based on this WHO standard, the groundwater recharge done by Osmansagar (17,395 kilo lakh litres) is sufficient for 47.65 crore population (one-third of India) for 365 days.

Osmansagar is not a mere lake across the Musi. It controls the flood flow into the Musi downstream in Hyderabad, apart from recharging the groundwater table in the otherwise rocky terrain with a little porosity. The lake feeds the aquifers that replenish the groundwater table in the IT corridor, financial district and emerging residential and commercial quarters in western parts of Hyderabad.

It also supports vast biodiversity in the form of aquatic, terrestrial and avian fauna. If the lake dries up, the parts of Hyderabad that form the financial and IT capital of Hyderabad will lose the water table. The city will also lose its “reserve” drinking water body that would be helpful in times of emergency when Krishna and Godavari supplies are hit.

Title: Salem: 20 injured, three critical, in Thammampatti
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

SALEM: More than 600 bulls and 287 tamers participated in the jallikattu held at Thammampatti on Saturday.

Twenty people, including eight spectators, were injured in the event, event coordinator P Suresh said. “Ten people were treated immediately while the rest were sent to the Attur Government Hospital,” Suresh said.

“The condition of K Ramachandran of Trichy , Sellakannu of Salem and Shankar of Madurai is said to be critical. Sellakannu and Shankar were referred to the Salem Government Hospital ,” he added.

The event began at 9.30am. Thammampatti temple bull was released first from the vadivasal, followed by the other bulls.

Salem collector S A Raman, chairman of the Tamil Nadu state apex co-operative bank R Elangovan and district SP Deepa Ganiger inaugurated the event.

Bulls were brought from Trichy, Perambalur, Namakkal and Madurai apart from Salem, Suresh said. “Veterinary doctors of the animal husbandry department inspected all the animals and issued fitness certificates before the event,” he said.

As many as 287 men qualified to tame the bulls after medical examination. The event concluded at 5pm.

Prizes including motorcycles, gold coins and jewellery were given to the tamer and owners of the bulls.

Title: Coimbatore: Two men held for impregnating two minor girls
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: Police have arrested two Pollachi residents who impregnated two minor girls .

S Yasin, 20, an auto driver, had raped a Class XI girl whom he had befriended, five months ago. “He told the girl that his aunt wanted to meet her and took her to a place in Pollachi in his vehicle, where he repeatedly raped her. The girl became pregnant and told her parents about the incident. When her parents approached Yasin, he threatened the minor with dire consequences. He was remanded in judicial custody and lodged in the Coimbatore Central Prison ,” a police officer said.

Police on Wednesday arrested N Ganapathy, 23, of Thoppampatti near Pollachi, who was working as a labourer, for impregnating a 16-year-old girl.

The victim had undergone a medical checkup at the Pollachi Government Hospital, where doctors found that she was five months pregnant. The doctors informed police, who conducted inquiry with the girl. The investigation revealed that Ganapathy had ‘married’ the minor a few months ago.

Ganapathy was remanded in judicial custody and lodged in the Coimbatore prison.

Title: Coimbatore: Residents in a fix as bus plies only once
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

As many as 60 children, who study at the Kinathukadavu Government Higher Secondary School, have been denied tr... Read More

COIMBATORE: Residents of Immidipalayam village near Kinathukadavu are facing inconvenience as bus number 42, which used to ply four times a day, is now operating only once.

Due to this, 60 children, who study at the Kinathukadavu Government Higher Secondary School, have been denied transportation, the villagers said.

The bus, which operates from Pollachi till Devaradipalayam via Immidipalayam, used to conducts four trips to the village — at 8am, 2pm, 6pm and 8pm. “But now it comes only at 8am. This is causing severe inconvenience to the public. While adults who go to work come back in autorickshaws, children who go to school, have no other option but to walk back,” said A K Periyar Mani, an activist and a resident.

The issue has been persisting for over a month, said T Manikandan, a Class XII student. “In between, the officials let some buses to our area. But now, even that has stopped,” he said. “The school gets over at 5pm. We used to board the bus and reach our homes within half-an-hour. But now, we have to get another bus till Vadasithur and then walk from there for around 3km. It now takes about two hours to reach home from school.”

When they asked why the trips have stopped, Tamil Nadu state transport corporation (TNSTC) authorities told them that there was not much revenue from the trips, Mani said.

TNSTC officials have promised to look into the issue.

Title: Coimbatore: Bharathiar varsity plans research centre on Subramania Bharathi
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

COIMBATORE: Bharathiar University plans to document and archive all possible materials and sources on its namesake, the nationalist Tamil poet Subramania Bharathi .

The university will set up a world-class research centre, ‘Kaani Nilam’, which will act as a one-stop destination for all possible information, research requirements and queries about Bharathi, professors of the university’s Tamil department said.

“The university has taken up the project to mark the centenary death anniversary of the poet, which falls in September 2021,” said S Chitra, professor, department of Tamil, who is also organising the project.

“We will collect documents, manuscripts, research and archival materials and make it available for all so that anyone can use it for their research projects on Subramania Bharathi. Also, any Bharathi lover can visit the centre to experience his works and life,” she said.

In an attempt to recreate Bharathi’s life and personality, the centre will have models of the houses he resided at various points of his life. Besides having visualisations from his masterworks such as Kannan Paattu and Panchali Sabatham, the centre would also have a model of ‘kuyil thoppu’ or ‘koel orchard’, which features in one of his masterpieces ‘Kuyil Paattu’ (The Song of Koel).

To gather original materials related to the poet, the university authorities have been speaking to his descendants, Chitra said. “We have spoken to his sister’s son who lives in Varanasi. He is 96 now. He has the poet’s harmonium, a pen and other things used by Bharathi. Some other relatives have approached us saying they have rare documents related to him. We are trying to source them. If not, we will try to bring models of them for the centre,” she said. The centre will also house a collection of published secondary literature and pop culture references the poet, she added.

On Saturday, the university officials, headed by vice-chancellor P Kaliraj, held a discussion with writers, scholars and prominent people from the city and presented the idea to them.

Title: PWD, Portugal ink ‘final’ pact for water project
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Panaji: Two years after Goa and Portugal inked a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) for technical cooperation for water supply and waste water management, Aguas de Portugal (AdP) and public works department ( PWD ) signed a formal “Work Contract” to improve the Selaulim and Opa water treatment plants.

In September 2018, Goa’s public works department (PWD) entered into an understanding with the Portuguese government agency in Lisbon to upgrade the Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) system at Selaulim water supply project and implement it for the Opa project. The project was to be implemented in a two-year period but instead suffered a two-year delay.

The arrival of Portugal president Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa for a two-day visit offered the state government an opportunity to finalise the work contract, which was signed in the presence of chief minister Pramod Sawant and PWD minister Deepak Pauskar.

Aside from this, MoUs were signed between V M Salgaoncar Institute of International Hospitality Education and Turismo de Portugal, Govind Ramnath Kare College and University of Coimbra and IIT-Madras and INESC-TEC in the area of ports and waterways management.

“We in Goa can interact with the professionals from Portugal, on how to undertake urban development. The Portuguese have heritage cities that have been modernised while retaining their character,” said chief minister Pramod Sawant while speaking about the various MoUs inked.

Several additional MoUs were signed in the field of academics and scientific research. An agreement to establish academic, scientific and cultural cooperation in the framework of language and culture was also arrived at.

MoUs and letters of intent between the Portuguese Institute for Systems and Computer Engineering, Technology and Science (INESC-TEC), under CEMENT (Cooperation for Excellence in Marine Exploration and Navigation Technologies) were also inked.

IIT-Goa, National Institute of Oceanography, National Centre for Polar and Oceanic Research (NCPOR), TERI - The Energy & Resources Institute and Goa Shipyard Ltd are part of the CEMENT initiative.

Goa Shipyard Ltd signed an agreement with Estaleiros Navais De Peniche (ENP) Portugal for collaboration and cooperation in the field of design, construction and supply of ships to African and Latin American countries.

Title: Cops takes bribe from auto driver, suspended in Salem
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

SALEM: A special sub inspector (SSI) and a constable, both attached to Kannankurichi police station , have been placed under suspension for taking a bribe of Rs 1,000 from an autorickshaw driver to release his vehicle that was seized for violations of motor vehicles act.

It is to be noted that the SSI was caught for the same offence in 2018 and had served jail term for more than a month.

According to a police source, city police commissioner T Senthil Kumar placed SSI Subramani and police constable Ganesan under suspension after the auto driver submitted a video evidence of the duo accepting bribe from him.

The source said the incident took place on January 30 when the two were on a vehicle check in Periyakollapatty area on Hasthampatty-Yercaud stretch.

“They seized the auto as driver S Prakash, 28, didn’t wear uniform and failed to produce registration certificate of the vehicle and driving licence. The SSI asked Prakash to get the autorickshaw back after paying the fine before the court,” the source said.

Prakash subsequently paid the fine and approached the officers to claim his autorickshaw back. “However, they demanded Rs 1,000 to release the vehicle. Prakash paid them the bribe and videographed the same.” the source said.

He later forwarded the video to city police commissioner, seeking action against the SSI and the constable. Senthil Kumar ordered a departmental inquiry, which the deputy police commissioner (crime and traffic) S Senthil carried out. The inquiry revealed that the officers were at fault.

Title: Coimbatore: Indoor badminton court on reserved site pulled down
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

The court was built by the resident welfare association of GKD Nagar on the park site a year ago. The associat... Read More

COIMBATORE: The city corporation on Saturday removed an indoor badminton court constructed on an open space reservation (OSR) land at GKD Nagar .

The space was reserved for a park and a shop, corporation officials said. The facility was also charging the users.

Corporation town planning officer Ravichandran told TOI that they removed 50% of the structure housing the court. “We will remove the entire structure in another day,” he said. “We faced no resistance from the residents, who were informed of the decision two to three days ago.”

The court was built by the resident welfare association of GKD Nagar on the park site a year ago. The association collected money from the people, who used it, on a monthly basis. That was when petitioner C K Varadarajan appealed to the Coimbatore corporation that the 36,272 sqft land marked for a park and 3,720 sqft marked for a shop, should only be used for that purpose.

The civic body issued the residents a notice on June 1, but no action was taken. It prompted Varadarajan to write to the Prime Minister’s cell, which in turn, directed the petition to the state chief secretary. That seems to have prompted the corporation to take the decision to demolish the structure.

Though the association defended building the structure, stating that it was built for public use, the petitioner said a park that has green cover would make it more useful for senior citizens and children.

Title: A chance to watch horse racing near city
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Nashik: Citizens will get to watch horse racing near Grape County on Trimbakeshwar Road on Sunday morning.

This is for the first time such race is being organised as per international standards and norms. The race has been organised by Indigenous Horse Owners Association (IHOA).

Usually such horse races are held regularly in Mumbai, Pune and Lonavala. But, for the first time, a horse racing event is being held near Nashik city. The objective is to provide a unqiue experience of to city residents, said Ranjit Nagarkar, secretary of IHOA.

The race will be held in three categories — 20 km, 40 km and 60km. A special track with length of 20 km hase been developed for the race. In addition, medical check up of horses will be done after every 20 km.

Around 40 horses from across the country will participate in the race that is slated to begin at 7.30 am.

Three horses will participate in the 60 km race, 16 will participate in 40 km race while 19 horses will take part in the 20 km race.

Title: Textile school students seek affiliation with central university of Tamil Nadu.
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Textile school students seek affiliation with central university

Coimbatore: Students of the Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International School of Textiles and Management (SVPITM) on Avinashi Road in the city staged a sit-in protest on the campus for the second day on Saturday, demanding that the institute to be affiliated to the Central University of Tamil Nadu.

The institute, which functions under the ministry of textiles, is functioning like a private institution and there are no proper facilities, the protesters said. “There is no proper hostel facility for boys. Those who are from places afar such as West Bengal, Odisha and Jammu and Kashmir, are forced to stay outside. In the girls’ hostel, 10 students are made to stay in one room,” said a protester. “There are no qualified faculty members with expertise in textile technology. There are also no proper laboratories on the campus,” he said.

There were talks that SVPITM would be made an incubation centre of the National Institute of Fashion Technology (NIFT), the protesters said. “We feel that things are moving in that direction. If that happens, we fear that our degrees would lose value,” said another protester. “The fee is much higher than that of any state or central university. Only if the institution is affiliated with the central university, it would get funds.”

The college offers three-year BSc course in textiles and two-year MBA courses in textiles, apparels and retail. It has 300 students and 12 teaching faculty members.

Repeated attempts to reach the director of the institution, M K Gandhi, went in vain.

Title: ‘Modi government benefited telecom giants not users’
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Randeep Surjewala

CHANDIGARH: A day after the Supreme Court (SC) direction to telecom companies to clear the dues, All India Congress Committee communication head Randeep Surjewala on Saturday said the Modi government was only keen on lining the pockets of telecom giants while fleecing 112 crore Indian subscribers.

“Is the increase in mobile phone tariffs by 40% a means to recover AGR?” asked Surjewala. Surjwala also asked Prime Minister Narendra Modi to step down and take the moral responsibility of the scam which will directly hit 112 crore prepaid mobile phone users.

“He must step down, if he has any morality left. These allegations are not coming from us but are proved through statements made by government as well as Telephone Regulatory Authority of India (TRAI). In fact, all this has been done to benefit major telecom giants, who are now facing the ire of the apex court and are bound to clear the dues,’’ he said.

Surjewala substantiated the allegations by elaborating on the chronology of events since October last year, when the apex court had directed telecom companies to pay Rs 1,02,000 crore towards the adjusted gross revenue under the Telecom Policy 1999.

“In November last year, the Union cabinet headed by Modi approved deferring Rs 42,000 crore spectrum auction instalment.

Following this, in December, the telecom companies had raised the tariff up to 40% and if you calculate the tariff to be recovered this will work out to little over 1.02000 lakh crore a year, if you consider 112 crore subscribers,’’ said Surjewala.

Title: Four new suspected coronavirus cases recorded in Hyderabad
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

HYDERABAD: Four new suspected cases of the novel coronavirus (2019 nCoV) were recorded in the city on Saturday. There samples have been collected and sent to the ICMR lab at Gandhi Medical College for testing. Meanwhile, 19 more people were referred by the airport authorities, Integrated Disease Surveillance Teams in districts and various airlines to be in home isolation.So far, 92 samples tested for the virus were found to be negative and 219 passengers, who had returned from China and other affected countries since January 15, continue to be under home quarantine.The health authorities are conducting thermal screening of all passengers arriving in flights directly from China, Hong Kong, Japan, South Korea, Thailand and Singapore. The state helpline for the virus, 040-24651119 is functional, and 381 calls have been received as of date.

Title: Dairy mela fails to draw farmers
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Karnal: A three-day national dairy mela was inaugurated at the National Dairy Research Institute ( NDRI ) here on Saturday. But only 25 farmers have registered for the mela and on the first day there were only 70 animals till 5pm.

The NDRI was expecting a gathering of nearly 15,000, including farmers and dairy entrepreneurs, from different parts of the country. However, the authorities are claiming that many visited the mela without registering themselves.

Meanwhile, a Sonipat dairy farmer, said, “I didn’t participate in the mela because it costs a lot to transport animals while the incentives like prize money are not big enough.” TNN

Title: Nirma charts inorganic growth story: cements its position among the top in India
Content: Ahmedabad: Homegrown Nirma Group once again grabbed the national headlines last week by acquiring the cement business of Emami Group for an enterprise value of Rs 5,500 crore. The acquisition has been made by Nuvoco Vistas Corporation Limited, which is a Nirma Group company.The deal involves buyout of Emami Cement Ltd (ECL)’s assets — cement plant and grinding units — with a total installed capacity of 8.3 million tonnes per annum. After the acquisition and the merger of its cement business in Rajasthan, Nuvoco will become one of the leading players in India’s cement industry with the installed capacity of 23.5 million tonnes and over 60 ready-mix plants dotted across East, North and West India.The man steering Nirma Limited’s inorganic growth is its managing director Hiren Patel, the younger son of Nirma founder Karsanbhai. Although he prefers to keep a low-profile, the 45-year-old second generation businessman leads from the front when it comes to charting growth trajectories for the group.The ECL acquisition is the second major clincher for Nirma under Patel’s leadership. In July 2016, Nirma had acquired LafargeHolcim’s India assets with 11 million tonnes per annum capacity for Rs 9,400 crore. Nirma then trounced biggies such as Ajay Piramal Group, Sajjan Jindal-led JSW Cement as well as Mexico's Cemex and China's Anhui Conch Cement Company to bag LafargeHolcim’s India cement business.Patel helmed the entire transaction starting from identifying the opportunity to negotiating the deal with Lafarge’s top management. Lafarge’s India business was later renamed as Nuvoco Vistas Corporation Ltd, which is one of the top building materials company in the country. Patel is the chairman of Nuvoco.This time again, Nirma pipped strong contenders like Ultratech, Ambuja Cements and Germany’s HeidelbergCement to clinch the ECL.After completing his bachelor’s degree in chemical engineering and MBA with specialization in finance and marketing from USA, Patel joined Nirma in 1998 as director and took over as its managing director in 2006, states Nuvoco’s website.Ever since the group made its first acquisition in 2005, Patel has led all the inorganic growth opportunities for the group. He has spearheaded the growth of the privately held group from being primarily in the consumer goods business to becoming a diversified conglomerate encompassing chemicals, cement, real estate and healthcare. At Nuvoco, he plays the role of mentor to the executive management.An active philanthropist, Patel is also a member of the managing committee of Nirma Education & Research Foundation, which runs the Nirma University with over 8,000 students across various disciplines, and Nirma Vidyavihar (K-12 schools).

Title: Bengaluru: Bitten by stray dog 4 months ago, woman dies of rabies
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: A 31-year-old woman died due to Rabies at a private hospital in Bengaluru on Saturday. A resident of Cox Town in east Bengaluru, she was bitten by a stray dog four months ago but was brought to the hospital only on February 12.

While doctors at Vikram Hospital confirmed the cause of her death, STOI could not immediately ascertain why she was brought to the hospital after so many months.

Doctors said her reports came positive from the Nimhans virology lab on Friday and that she succumbed around 10.30am on Saturday, adding that BBMP authorities were informed immediately.

“She was rushed to the hospital at around 3.30am on Wednesday with symptoms of breathlessness and disorientation. The family said she had suffered from psychiatric illness. But we noticed excess salivation. She refused to drink fluids and was afraid of drinking water, a clear sign of hydrophobia and a tell-tale sign of Rabies,” Dr Vijay Kumar Annayya Reddy, consultant, critical care medicine, said.

Doctors said her case was a bit misleading in the beginning, as she suffered from depression. They said she felt uncomfortable when the fan was switched on, which is aerophobia, another symptom of Rabies.

Although MRI and cerebrospinal fluid tests are the most confirmatory tests to be done in suspected Rabies cases, in this case, doctors could not do them as the patient was not in a condition to support this.

She suffered a cardiac attack after her admission and on resuscitation her condition only worsened.

While the family recalled that she had a dog bite four months ago when she brought home a puppy from the streets, they didn’t think it could lead to Rabies.

“They read on the internet and later understood the severity of the case. The victim’s 29-year-old younger brother was also bitten or scratched by the dog four months ago. We suggested that he be given anti-Rabies vaccination (ARV),” doctors said.

The 20 hospital staff, including housekeeping personnel, nurses and doctors who had treated or taken care of the woman have been given ARV. “While five doses of ARV have to be taken, so far two doses have been given to all the 20 members,” hospital authorities said.

Lamenting the lack of awareness among public about ARV, Dr Vijay said, “Had the patient taken ARV soon after the dog bite, she would not have died.”

Second Rabies death in BBMP limits this year

As per the data with the state health department, this was the fifth Rabies death in Bengaluru in 2020 — two involving dog bites within the BBMP limits, and three of patients who were treated in Bengaluru hospitals but were bitten by dogs elsewhere. A 40-year-old man from Hanumanth Nagar died due to Rabies Epidemic Disease hospital (isolation hospital) on Old Madras Road in mid-January, said Dr Ansar Ahmed, medical superintendent.

Title: Experts voice concern as Telangana HC gets new coat of paint
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

HYDERABAD: The Telangana High Court is getting a fresh coat of paint, and its domes, which could be seen from a distance, appear even more prominent now. The light hue has been darkened, drawing flak from activists who are asking if heritage norms are being followed.

A maintenance incharge at the high court said the work was being done as part of centenary celebrations. “Routine work is being carried out wherever the paint has peeled off. Since there are no repairs being undertaken, we are not consulting with conservation architects,” he said. He added that an internal panel had given the go-ahead for the work.

Heritage experts are skeptical of the work. Referring to Regulation 13, a stipulation of the Hyderabad Metropolitan Development Authority (HMDA), Sajjad Shahid, historian and heritage activist, said, “There is a provision for a Heritage Conservation Committee which decides all matters regarding the conservation of structures. Any decision must be taken in consultation with the committee, which is not being done as it has been defunct for years.” Shahid said the committee must be reconstituted immediately.

Anuradha Reddy, convenor, INTACH, Hyderabad, said, “The domes have their own natural beauty, strength and colour, which must be retained. Paint reduces the breathability of the structure.” She added that the quality and content of the paint also matters, as it can affect the original material. “Besides this, paint can also be tough to take off once applied.”

Speaking about the need for a comprehensive management plan, she said, “The structure has already suffered unsuitable interventions over the decades. The high court, which has given several heritage-friendly judgements must consider bringing a conservation architect on board with the requisite expertise, experience and a proven track-record.” Conservation architect SP Anchuri said, “Any work must be done after preparation of the base structure. When there is paint, cracks might go unnoticed. Authorities must ensure that previous layers of paint are removed and build-ups and cracks are filled appropriately.”

Title: HC quashes Jayalalithaa-era defamation case against TOI
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Chennai: Terming it a direct invasion and attack on media freedom, the Madras high court has quashed criminal defamation proceedings initiated by former chief minister J Jayalalithaa against TOI and a Tamil daily in 2014.

“Derailing the print media from publishing content, which in no way could be termed defamatory, by initiating prosecution, is nothing but an attack on the rights enshrined under the Constitution,” said Justice M Dhandapani.

He was quashing the government orders authorising the Chennai city prosecutor to initiate criminal defamation proceedings on behalf of the then chief minister.

The case relates to reports on BJP leader Subramanian Swamy’s statement accusing Jayalalithaa of trying to usurp credit for release of some Indian fishermen from the custody of Sri Lankan authorities.

TOI and Dinamalar moved the high court to quash the proceedings.

Allowing the pleas, Justice Dhandapani said: “The action of the state in initiating prosecution against the petitioners for their act of carrying the interview of Dr Subramanian Swamy to print is a direct invasion into the right of freedom of speech and expression, which cannot be curtailed by the invocation of Section 499 of IPC.”

“The freedom of press to bring to the people the happenings in and around them forthwith is the fulcrum of a democratic functioning of the state. Clogging the said system by curtailing the right and freedom is nothing but a direct invasion on the freedom of speech and expression, which is enshrined in Article 19 (1) of the Constitution,” he said.

“While it was the duty of the court to safeguard interests of those persons holding public office from being defamed for discharging their public functions, equally, the citizens should also be safeguarded from the governmental machinery against malicious prosecution,” said Justice Dhandapani.

Pointing out that the reports appeared on September 4, 2014, whereas the defamation proceedings were initiated within 24 hours thereafter, Justice Dhandapani said: “The sanction for prosecution, according to the Court, has been granted at such a pace, i.e., in a span of 24 hours, in which haste cannot be definitely ruled out. Haste could also be concomitant to non-application of mind. Application of mind in the grant of sanction is the foremost necessity.”

The judge also had a word caution for the media. While holding that the media had not traversed beyond its limitation in the present case, Justice Dhandapani said: “The media has also to satisfy itself as to the details, which are to be carried in print, as the faith reposed by the citizens on the media should be the foremost consideration for a better democratic functioning, lest the same will not only have a detrimental effect on the common man, but on the functioning of the governmental machinery as a whole.”

Title: Desai asks Sena functionaries to step up
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Kolhapur: Shiv Sena functionary and minister of state Shamburaj Desai on Saturday asked the party’s local functionaries to initiate the programmes and events to gain the lost ground in legislative assembly election.

The Sena lost four seats in the assembly elections last year which it had won in 2014 elections. Sena won both the Loksabha seats in the district, however in the assembly election held immediately after, the party just won one seat in the district.

The local functionaries claimed that several factors were responsible for the defeat. They met Desai at Government Circuit House and discussed in length the programmes to be organised to gain the lost ground. “Many local leaders have several hopes from the government. I have asked to start the work from now onwards to win back the assembly seats. The local leaders should have proper coordination. I have assured them that I will act as the communicator between party workers and functionaries. They have assured to take the government programmes to the citizens and help the needy people,” said Desai.

Some of them raised concerns about several local issues. Desai assured them that all the issues will be resolved through proper channels. The lack of co-ordination among the local leaders were one of the major reasons for Sena’s debacle in assembly elections. For the functionaries from the city, Desai said that they have to work on their strengths to get corporators elected back in coming Kolhapur Municipal Corporation election.

Desai also held meetings with the district authorities to urge them to use the Rs 60 crore allotted grant for the development work. He said that officers should spend every single rupee before the end of the financial year. “The government will hold the district authorities responsible if the funds allocated remains unutilised and goes back to the state government,” said Desai.

Title: India-Pakistan may face bigger locust attack this year, both to continue liaison to beat common enemy
Content:
Locust attack in Sri Ganganagar (file photo)

NEW DELHI: India and Pakistan have barely been on talking terms, with even the Kartarpur corridor not free of barbs, but the countries held five meetings unmarred by differences in the past few months to deal with a common enemy - the deadly desert locust .This liaison will continue as there is a forecast of bigger invasion of “greater magnitude” from June this year onward than witnessed in 2019 when farmers of certain districts in Rajasthan and Gujarat faced damage to their standing crops.“It is also predicted that, invasion could occur in scheduled desert area (2 lakh sq km) of India in June 2020 with advent of Monsoon by spring-bred swarms from southeast Iran, southwest Pakistan and the Horn of Africa that may be of a greater magnitude than last year,” said an agriculture ministry’s note on locust attack.The short-horned grasshopper targetted both India and Pakistan, attacking the standing winter (Rabi) crop before being finally controlled by January. Five meetings between the two countries were held at Munabao in India and Khokhropar in Pakistan during June-December last year to exchange information on tackling the menace.Though Pakistan had to declare a ‘national emergency’ due to the locusts, India could minimise the damage by successfully checking breeding and forward movement. India’s effort recieved a compliment from UN’s Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) which keeps a constant eye on locust situation and issues forecast.Asked about India’s preparedness in view of the likelihood of a bigger invasion in June, minister of state for agriculture Kailash Choudhary told TOI on Saturday that the Centre would procure 60 specialised sprayers (equipped with latest technology), use helicopters and additional drones for aerial spraying of pesticides.“We are fully prepared to control such situation in future. We have been in touch with home, civil aviation and defence ministries to enhance our aerial capabilities to deal with locust attack,” said Choudhary, MP from Barmer, one of the eight districts of Rajasthan vulnerable to locusts.The junior minister claimed “had India not controlled spread of locus effectively, it would have even reached Bangladesh” - as had happened in 1950 when then eastern Pakistan faced a massive attack and remained under locust influence for next 14 consecutive years.“There were five meetings held between India and Pakistani officials over the locust attack issue. We did not let it spread beyond five districts in India and FAO appreciated our efforts,” said the minister. He added FAO said India’s efforts could be showcased in African countries which are more prone to such attacks.FAO’s senior locust forecasting officer Keith Cressman , who visited India on January 16-17, noted India’s successful efforts in containing the outbreak. “Clearly if this had not been the case, tremendous crop damage would have occurred in Rajasthan that would have had significant impacts on food security and livelihoods in western India and beyond. There would have been a massive invasion of Pakistan and India by swarms originating in Rajasthan,” said Cressman in his report.India, which last faced such a situation in 1993, has more than 2 lakh sq km of vulnerable area (four times the size of Punjab) covering eight districts of Rajasthan and two of Gujarat. Globally, 30 countries (mostly African and west Asian) covering 16 million sq km are vulnerable to desert locust attack.Locusts inflict damage by devouring leaves, flowers, fruits, seeds, bark and growing plants, and also by breaking trees because of their weight when they settle down in masses. An adult desert locust can consume roughly its own weight in fresh food per day.“One sq km size swarm contains about 40 million locusts, which eat the same amount of food in one day as about 35,000 people, 20 camels or 6 elephants,” said the ministry’s note.

Title: Kolkata: Top cop promises to address noise complaints
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: Offering a helping hand to youngsters appearing for their board exams , police commissioner Anuj Sharma announced that his force would attend to every complaint that examinees lodge against loud music or use of loudspeakers.

The commissioner took to social media to say Lalbazar would directly deal with the complaints. “Wish the students all the best for their exams. In case of any disturbance to your studies due to loud music, miking etc or any other issue #Dial100 or call/Whatsapp message to the following numbers,” Sharma tweeted, tagging CM Mamata Banerjee. The numbers are 9432610443, 9432610446, 9874903465 and 9432624365. Fines and even arrests might follow severe violations, cops said.

Officers said this would help in two ways: cops can keep tabs on violation of the ban on loudspeakers and secondly, it would ensure that the police headquarters were aware whether the local cops at all took any steps to address the complaints.

Several officers TOI spoke to said thanks to the top cop’s message, junior officers would also take such calls seriously. Police have also decided to identify around 12 stretches, which house a mix of schools and hospitals, like College Street and Park Street, where they will disallow honking and put a ban on loudspeakers during exam hours. Cops will ensure smooth flow of traffic so that motorists don’t need to honk.

Title: Hotel industry relieved with govt clarification on section 144: TTAG
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Panaji: Hoteliers heaved a sigh of relief on Saturday after the state government clarified that the imposition of section 144 was part of general preparedness and there was no need to panic.

Some hotels received queries from agents and others whether travel plans need to be changed, but they were told there was no need to alter their Goa plans, Travel and Tourism Association of Goa (TTAG) president Savio Messias told TOI on Saturday evening after he spoke to some TTAG members.

“I could say that things are under control. There were calls in the first half with people wanting to cancel their bookings. But they are told that they need not do so following assurances by government officials,” he said.

The statement issued by district collector R Menaka was circulated among TTAG members so that they can inform their operators and agents about the ground reality, Messias said.

Members of the trade body could not meet chief minister Pramod Sawant as he was occupied with the visit of Portugual President Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa, on Saturday.

Messias said they would try and meet Sawant next week to ensure that such confusion doesn’t reoccur.

The TTAG president said that they were unhappy with tourism minister Manohar Ajgaonkar who had not bothered to help the industry. “On Friday, we tried to contact Ajgaonkar as things were getting out of control and chaos ensued. But he was not there to help us. We are disappointed,” he said.

Title: Delhi: Safe commute on mind, Mayur Vihar Phase-III residents seek metrolite link
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Residents say autorickshaw drivers charge Rs 80-100 to go to the metro station

NEW DELHI: No matter what the time, 18-year-old Niharika Bhatt always sends her “live location” through GPS and WhatsApp to her parents or brother, who track her movements till she is safely back home in Pocket-D SFS flats, Mayur Vihar Phase-III . She takes this “safety step” because the closest metro station is 5-6 kilometres away. Residents of the area said that the stretch between the colony and the metro station is not safe, particularly for women.

“The nearest stations are Mayur Vihar Phase-I and Noida Sector 15 and it takes 30 minutes to reach them. The roads leading to the metro stations are unsafe, that’s why my family tracks my live location or keeps calling to ensure my safety,” Bhatt said.

Yukta Pandey, Bhatt’s neighbour, said, “Autorickshaw drivers charge Rs 80-100 to go to the metro station, depending on their whim.
