The Wonderland School operates inside the upscale gated New Moti Bagh Colony in Chanakyapuri, which houses senior bureaucrats and even judges.

The court was hearing a PIL by a former employee of the school alleging several violations of not just RTE, but also the licence deed executed with NDMC, which governed its day to day functioning and other discrepancies in payment of the licence fee.

Appearing for the petitioner, advocate M Sufiyan Siddiqui cited that several RTI replies received from NDMC revealed that there had not been any audit or inspection of the school since 2012 even though it charged lakhs in fee annually. While the plea also raised issues of alleged failure to pay proper licence fee and encroachment, the court refused to examine them saying it couldn’t give directions without “proper establishment of facts” and left it to the government to take a call.

The bench noted that in a writ petition “we cannot arrive at a final conclusion about non-payment of appropriate licence fee or about a contract entered between the respondent and the school on allotment of land or the ‘so-called encroachment’ by the school on public land — all of which have been alleged by the petitioner.”

The school, however, rebutted the claims saying after the employee’s dismissal, “all wisdom has suddenly befallen the petitioner about the school having indulged in illegal activities.”

Title: Cultural festival for anganwadi kids held
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Kochi: The seventh edition of Kunjattakilikal , an annual cultural programme organized by the first year bachelor’s degree students of social work department of Rajagiri College of Social Sciences (RCSS), Kalamassery, for anganwadi kids was organized at Kalamassery town hall on Friday. Around 200 children from 49 anganwadis under Edapally Additional Integrated Child Development Scheme (ICDS) project at Kalamassery municipality participated in the event.

They took part in various events like action song, fancy dress and colouring competition. As part of the social work curriculum, the institution has collaborated with the Edappally Additional ICDS project to provide field training for the students by being part of the services delivered by anganwadis. The event was a culmination of the current academic year’s programmes.

“RCSS has undertaken various initiatives to join hands with the ICDS machinery in the state. The college is running a training centre in collaboration with social justice department to provide training for improving and maintaining the quality of performance of the project personnel at all levels in the implementation of ICDS activities and services,” said faculty coordinator Anil John.

Title: EC to LSG: Reserve seats of six new corporations by February 29
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: The state commission (SEC) on Saturday directed the department of local self government (LSG) to complete the process of reserving seats for six newly-formed municipal corporations by February 29 so that the elections could be conducted by April 18.

The six newly-formed Nagar Nigams are Jaipur Heritage and Jaipur Greater (Jaipur), Jodhpur North and Jodhpur South (Jodhpur), Kota North and Kota South (Kota).

“It is notable that, as per Rajasthan High Court order, the elections to the six newly-formed Nagar Nigams are to be conducted by April 18. For the same, the commission is required to announce the election schedule. Ahead of annoucing the schedule for the election, the process of reserving the seats of the newly-formed municipal corporations has to be conducted by your department," said chief election officer (CEO) Shyam Singh Rajpurohit in a letter to secretary department of local self government.

"Therefore, in order to comply with the High Court order, the process of reserving the seats must be completed by February 29 and the commission should be informed about it," the letter added.

While the draft notification of the electoral roll for the elections to the six newly-formed municipal corporations has been issued on February 15, the final publication will be issued on March 3.

Following the summary revision programme, the final electoral roll for the state of Rajasthan will be published by the Election Commission of India (ECI) on February 19. Over 6 lakh new voters have been registered in the state during special summary revision programme of the electoral roll. More than 3 lakh young voters have added their names in the voters' list.

The election commission's regional centre for state activities will be set up on a one acre land identified in Mansarovar and the land will be made available to the commission by Rajasthan Housing Board. The office of the chief electoral officer (CEO) and a separate wing for SVEEP activities will be housed here.

Title: Biker dies in accident near Tilak Maidan
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

VASCO: A resident of Khariawada lost his life in a accident after ramming his two-wheeler into a parked truck at Vasco early Saturday morning.

Vasco police said that Chandrashekar Saroj, 33, sustained head injuries after he lost control of his bike and crashed into a truck that was parked by the roadside near Tilak Maidan .

Residents said that the ambulance took around 40 minutes to reach the accident site.

Saroj was rushed to the sub-district hospital at Chicalim, where doctors declared him dead on arrival.

A large crowd of irate locals who had gathered at the accident site, urged traffic police to initiate strict action against trucks parked by the roadside in Vasco.

They also threatened to take law into their hands if the authorities ignore their demands.

Title: Pollution a violation of Article 21: Activist
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Garbage along Lawson’s Bay beach in Visakhapatnam on Saturday

Visakhapatnam: The untreated sewage and toxic industrial effluent directly being released into the sea in Vizag city will affect marine life, the livelihood of fishermen and consequently public health, said Bolisetty Satyanarayana, national convenor of Jal Biradari. He was on a visit to the coast near Jalaripeta on Saturday where the untreated sewage is being released into the sea.

Satyanarayana said that successive governments had failed to address the issue despite it having been raised it several times in the past. Rajendra Singh, popularly known as waterman of India, had also visited these drains in December 2019 and requested the authorities to look into the issue. Later, Satyanarayana wrote a letter to chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy on the issue.

“Untreated hazardous waste and toxic chemical effluents from pharma companies in Parawada and Bheemili, and most of the untreated sewage with garbage , has been flowing into the sea. The authorities, instead of addressing the issue, are hiding it to get awards for the city. This is damaging both the livelihood of the fishermen community and the health of Vizagites. This act of negligence by GVMC and Pollution Control Board amounts to infringing the constitutional right of people under Article 21 (Protection of Life and Personal Liberty),” Satyanarayana said in his letter.

Title: Novels take rebirth through his lens
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

D Manoj is exhibiting around 150 photographs based on the novel ‘Theekadal Kadanju Thirumadhuram’ written by C... Read More

Kochi: Many novels have been born out of photographs and paintings but to transform an entire novel into a set of photographs is no mean task.

D Manoj, a photographer based in Vaikom, for the past 20 years had been zooming in on Malayalam literary fiction with the sole aim of documenting real incidents and characters that might have influenced the authors. At the Krithi International Festival of Books and Authors, set to conclude on Sunday, Manoj is exhibiting around 150 photographs based on the novel ‘ Theekadal Kadanju Thirumadhuram ’ written by C Radhakrishnan.

Manoj works with still images but has the eye of a documentary filmmaker. He has documented an oracle from Kudalloor in Palakkad to portray folk incidents that influenced Ezhuthachan’s life. Another photograph is that of a martial artist performing Changambally Kalari, the traditional Kalaripayattu style performed in Mamangam festival. He also pays attention to the specific locations that are part of the novel’s historic background. As per the lore, the head of a 15-year-old boy was cut and thrown into the Mamangathara at Thirunavaya. This place has been captured by Manoj along with the beauty of its verdant setting.

Manoj says changes in climate was a major challenge while documenting the novel. He made repeated visits to some places to get good photographs in the same time frame as mentioned in the novel. In Shokanashini river, Manoj waited one whole night for the moon to be visible from the clouds and to get its reflection on the river.

His first photo-document was conceived in the year 2000 on the novel ‘Khasakkinte Ithihasam’ written by O V Vijayan. He studied the book to identify the most important events and travelled to the place to take the photographs. In 2006, he captured photographs based on the novel ‘Mayyazhipuzhayude Theerangalil’, written by M Mukundan and Punathil Kunjabdulla’s novel ‘Smarakashilakal’ in 2008.

Later, in 2009, he adapted the novel ‘Naalukettu’ by M T Vasudevan Nair. Photographs based on ‘Theekadal Kadanju Thirumadhiuram’ is his fifth project. Manoj feels that his presentation style has now found acceptance in the literary world. “I wish this book should have been my first work,” he said.

Radhakrishnan feels that it is the photographs that give people conviction that novels are rooted in reality and not just imagination. “Communication of the content becomes more reliable and forceful. It validates the narration of the writer. He has effectively captured the mood and emotional content in Ezhuthachan’s life. I wrote using alphabets, he wrote it using his camera,” said Radhakrishnan.

Title: Once a high-school dropout, now builds components for jet fighters and missiles
Content:
Rakesh Chopdar

HYDERABAD: From being ridiculed for securing single-digit marks to establishing a firm that manufactures blades for turbines and aerospace parts, Rakesh Chopdar , a high-school dropout , said that working in his father’s workshop, which manufactures nuts and bolts, has been his real education.He said despite putting in a lot of effort, he could never understand the subjects or remember anything during examinations.“Textbooks and theory never excited me during schooldays,” said Chopdar adding that although education is important, a degree is not everything. “A degree alone cannot make us a successful person. One needs vision, passion, courage and hard work.”Chopdar, founder and managing director of Azad Engineering said that after he dropped out of school, he felt that his life was directionless. “My life became miserable as everyone in the family and relatives started inquiring about my career and future,” he added.He said that he started his journey in his father’s factory, which manufactures fasteners (nuts & bolts).“Initially, I did not like sitting in the office and looking at files but when I started going to the workshop, I was introduced to the world of mechanical engineering and was fascinated with it. Initially, I just watched them working on manufacturing products,” added Chopdar and said that he learned about manufacturing different products and basics of engineering in a phased manner.“Our firm makes parts for aerospace & power generation OEMs,” he added.Chopdar said that his products are approved by companies like Mitsubishi, Toshiba, Skoda, Rolls Royce among others. He said that his firm has built blades for Sukhoi jet fighter planes and precision components for BrahMos missiles .

Title: Birdsong, a temple, and a love story
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Kootagal’s distinctive boulders trace their origins to a story of two lovers who wanted to be united for ever.... Read More

BENGALURU: The next time you visit Ramanagara to appreciate its rocky terrain,where movies like Sholay and Shalimar were shot, take some time to drive further into the countryside. About 10 km away from the famous Ramadevara Betta – which is now a vulture sanctuary –is a hillock worth a visit: Kootagal.

As you get out of the bustling town of Ramanagara and drive towards Magadi, the sound of cars and trucks slowly subsides, replaced by the occasional puttering of a two-wheeler. The village at the bottom of Kootagal is picturesque by itself. With a vast lake in the background, the village is dotted with mango, coconut and banana orchards.

Once you negotiate the narrow lanes of the village, visitors are greeted by the chirping of birds. Driving through the serpentine road cutting through huge boulders is an experience in itself.

As you park your vehicle at the end of the concrete road atop the hill, a vast spread of rocky outcrop welcomes you. And from there you get to see two huge rocks adjacent to each other. They look like a couple about to embrace – before deciding to draw back, as if they just noticed an observer. They give the name to the village (Kootagal means ‘union of rocks’ in Kannada).

If you are game for hiking, you can reach the bottom of the two rocks from where you have a majestic view of them.

The most interesting part of this rocky region nestling in the lap of greenery and the birdsong is the legend attached to the twin rocks. Villagers say that hundreds of years ago, there was nothing at the place where the two rocks stand now. The village had a washerman (Agasa in Kannada) and his wife who were in deeply in love with each other.

In fact, everyone in the village envied the bonding the couple shared. But destiny had something else for them. The couple entered a phase of life where they had to drift apart. The couple, however, was not ready to part. Instead they decided to end their lives by jumping off from the hill top. All of a sudden, a saint appeared before them and stopped them from taking the extreme step.

The couple prayed to the saint to turn them into rocks so that they could at least stay together as rocks. Legend has it that the saint blessed them with the wish and the couple remained frozen in time as rocks. As though to celebrate the eternal love of the washerman and his wife, the place also plays host to many young couples during weekends.

Just like the rocks elsewhere in Ramanagara, the huge boulders here also have a large number of holes which once played home to vultures. Though the place is devoid of large winged scavengers, the shrub forest here hosts many tiny birds whose chirping rent the air, especially during mornings and evenings. Many birders and photographers throng the area quite often. Understanding the diversity of the flora and fauna here, the Karnataka Forest Department has declared the habitat as mini-forest and maintaining it.

Kootagal hill is also famous for the temple of Thimmappaswamy or Venkataramana, an incarnation of Lord Vishnu. The old temple has been renovated in the recent years, losing its old world charm to painting and concrete . Some colourful designs and patterns on the pillars of the temple built in Mysore style does look special though. There is an old Kalyani (step well) with two lion sculptures next to it . Every Saturday, the temple is thronged by villagers and other devotees – many of whom cover long distances – to pray to the deity.

Kootagal is about 60 km from Bengaluru. From Ramanagara, one has to take a right turn towards Hanubhoganahalli (7 kms) and from there further journey of 3 kms would take you to Kootagal. Private buses ply to Kootagal from Ramanagara.

Title: MGNREGA: Centre approves 30 crore persondays for 2020-21
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Jaipur: The Centre has approved a labour budget of 30 crore persondays under Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act ( MGNREGA ) for the financial year 2020-21 in the state .

It also gave an assurance to approve 3 crore more persondays (labour budget) for 2019-20, making it 33 crore persondays (labour budget) for this financial year, which would be the highest since the inception of the scheme.

This would mean sanctioning an extra budget of Rs 660 crore for the last two months of this financial year, i.e. up to March 31.

The Centre had in December revised the labour budget to 30 crore persondays for the financial year 2019-20, sanctioning an additional fund of nearly Rs 1,500 crore. Initially, the labour budget for 2019-20 was 23 crore persondays.

“Of 30 crore persondays, the state has already generated 29 crore persondays for this financial year (2020-21). We will also be completing 5 lakh works this year having already completed 4.5 lakh works. If 33 crore persondays are generated, it will be highest since the inception of the scheme,” said state’s MGNREGA commissioner P C Kishan.

Box

Raj gets additional target of 86,816 houses under PMAY

Jaipur: The Centre has given a revised target of 86,816 houses to be constructed under Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana (Grameen) in 2019-20 in the state, apart from already sanctioned 3.64 lakh houses for this financial year. Additional chief secretary (ACS), rural development and panchayati raj, Rajeshwar Singh has directed all the district collectors to issue sanction for these houses in 7 days.

Title: Sharp rise in residential rents as capital dream gets closer
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Visakhapatnam: With Visakhapatnam set to become the state’s executive capital and the metro rail project getting underway, residential rentals in localities along NH-16 are witnessing a steep appreciation. While the average appreciation rate for flat rents in Visakhapatnam is 8-10 per cent, in the last two months rents have increased by as much as 15-20 per cent in some localities.

“In January last year, I had taken a two-bedroom flat on rent on the Madhurwada highway for a monthly rent of Rs 9,000. This year the owner has suddenly increased the rent to Rs 15,000. After a massive search I managed to find a two-bedroom flat for Rs 12,000, but it’s about a kilometre away from the highway,” said KV Prasad, who works with a private insurance company.

As per Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation (GVMC) estimates, around one lakh people from other areas of AP and other states migrate to Vizag every year, primarily for work and education. Most of these families look for rental accommodation. Many have even made Vizag their permanent home and have been living here for decades.

Experts said the increase in rents has come much earlier than expected. They say they expected the increase only in November or December 2020, but flat owners in some localities in the city have already started increasing the rent anticipating a rise in demand. “In fact, to some extent you can blame the tenants for this demand. Whoever is looking to rent a house on a long-term basis is eyeing localities close to the proposed metro rail stretch. The idea is to take a house on rent early while the rents are still low and extend the contract so that the rent appreciation is low even after five-six years,” said DK Raju, a property broker.

It seems even owners have caught on to this and many are reluctant to sign fresh agreements with the present tenant. The reasoning behind this move is simple. With the old tenant, the rent can only be increased by 10%, while for a new one it can be much higher.

“I had purchased my second flat on loan and am spending Rs 10,000 per month as EMI. Till now, whatever I was getting as rent, I used that to pay the EMIs. I see no problem in hiking the rent if I can save some amount for myself after paying the EMI,” said K Pravakar, who owns a flat in Carshed area.

Title: Time for India to give dharma to world: Mohan Bhagwat
Content:
The new headquarters has been built at a cost of Rs 5 crore after the demolition of the old RSS building.

Mohan Bhagwat inaugurating the building

(With agency inputs

AHMEDABAD: RSS chief Mohan Bhagwat said in Ahmedbad on Saturday that the rising population of our country is a cause for concern. He was speaking on ‘India’s Role in Global Context’ after inaugurating the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh’s new Gujarat headquarters — Dr Hedgewar Bhavan — in Maninagar on Saturday.“Our resources are limited but our needs are unlimited. Our population is going out of control. Gandhiji used to say that the world has enough for everyone’s need but not enough for everyone’s greed,” he said.He said that despite increase in comforts and materialistic pleasures, everyone is unhappy and is staging agitations. “Be it owner or servant, a party in opposition, the common man, students, teachers, everyone is unhappy and dissatisfied,” Bhagwat said.Stressing on the philosophy of Vasudhaiva Kutumbakam (the world is a family), he said India never invaded any country. “India needs to be powerful in all spheres to bring the world in order once again. India has to give ‘dharma’ to the world so that knowledge spreads but humans do not become robots. We have always talked about the concept of global family but not global market,” he said.The lecture was organized by ‘Madhav Smruti Nyas’, an organization backed by the RSS.Bhagwat lamented that Indian youths are “not ready to accept the knowledge power of the country, and think that whatever good in India has come from other countries”. He urged people to make India stronger “because the world listens only to the strong”.“US and Russia are super powers. China would become a super power too. Now, what super power nations did to others? They just took control of other countries for their selfish agenda. These super powers gave it back only when they were asked to do so. Otherwise, they never gave anything to others,” said Bhagwat.The new headquarters has been built at a cost of Rs 5 crore after demolition of the previous RSS building, which was around five decades old.The new complex has two basements for parking. It houses a large hall on the first floor, two small halls on the second and third floors, a library and rooms for stay, a release by the RSS said.

Title: 9 gram panchayats to turn into Swachhscape like Indore city
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Indore: Nine gram panchayats of Indore district will soon turn into Swachhscape like Indore city with district administration planning to implement cluster-wise waste management system to streamline and upgrade services. With this one-of-a-kind initiative, these ‘semi-urban’ gram panchayats will bid adieu to stinky open drainage system and haphazard garbage collection and also see plethora of sustainable Swachh initiatives.

According to zila panchayat CEO Neha Meena, a survey carried out for developing cluster-wise waste management system in Manglia revealed that these nine gram panchayats of vicinity generate around 16 tonne solid waste daily. “Some gram panchayats have resources for door-to-door garbage collection and segregation but the rest under the cluster lack arrangements to lift garbage and dispose it properly,” Meena told TOI.

She added that proposed cluster-wise waste management system — which first-of-its-kind initiative in state — also includes faecal sludge management (FSM) system to treat sewage water for reuse, especially in irrigation.

“The cluster-wise system will ensure door-to-door garbage collection from around 12,247 households and some 2,000 commercial establishments of nine gram panchayats facilitating around 65,000 population of the area,” said the CEO, adding the system will be developed on public-private-partnership (PPP) model, where gram panchayats will collect Swachhta Tax and ensure door-to-door garbage through vehicles while tenders will be invited to assign work of segregation, processing and disposal of garbage.

Administration will have no financial burden for starting cluster-wise waste management system while the firm, which will be assigned the work, will generate income by selling manure for farming and processed garbage as raw materials to different industries.

“In next part, we will install a system to recycle faecal sludge and water from it to be used for agriculture and industry purposes while rest will be used to produce biogas, biodiesel or electricity,” she said.

Currently, nine gram panchayats of Manglia cluster including Manglia, Budhibarlai, Pirkaradiya, Dakachya, Lasudiaparmar, Sullakhedi, Dhabali, Rampiplia and Kailodhala generate around 25 lakh litre of gray water (kitchen waste) daily while generation of black water (sewage) was yet to be ascertained.

Title: Delhi man beaten to death over petty fight
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: A man was beaten to death after he brushed against another person at a park in Khyala. The accused had got into an argument with the deceased for brushing against his shoulder and called his friends to “teach the man a lesson.” The gang thrashed the victim with baseball bats and pelted stones on him due to which he suffered head injuries. He later succumbed to them.

The man’s brother-in-law, who tried to save him, was also injured.

The incident was reported from B-2 Block in Raghubir Nagar area on Tuesday. The deceased, Saurabh, and his brother-in-law, Tarun, had gone for a stroll to the park after dinner. While walking on the paved path, Saurabh accidentally brushed his shoulder against a person coming from the opposite direction. This led to an argument between them. Soon, the scene turned ugly and the person called a few more friends from the locality, who started pushing Saurabh and Tarun.

When they resisted, the youth attacked them with bats, metal knuckles and beer bottles. Tarun managed to escape and reach home to inform the other family members about the attack. When he returned, he found Saurabh lying on the path, bleeding profusely. The family members took both Saurabh and Tarun to a government hospital nearby where Saurabh was declared dead on arrival. A case of murder was registered with the Khyala police station.

Police suspect role of local criminals to be involved in the murder and a manhunt has been launched to nab them. Sources say that some of the attackers have been identified from the CCTV footage installed in the area.

Title: Kochi Metro completes trial run to Petta
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Metro train enters Petta station on Saturday morning as part of the trial run from Thykkodam

KOCHI: Kochi Metro , which is gearing up to start commercial operations along the Thykoodam-Petta stretch, conducted a trial run on the route on Saturday. This is the last stretch of the phase I of the project.

Senior officials from Kochi Metro Rail Limited (KMRL) and Delhi Metro Rail Corporation (DMRC) attended the test run conducted in the early hours of the day. The test run started at 7.40am from Thykoodam and the train reached Petta at 8.00am. Officials inspected the functioning of the track and traction system. The return trip started at 8.20am and reached Thykoodam at 9.00am.

“The trial run was a success. In the coming days, further trial runs will be conducted. Once the trial runs are completed, the commissioner of metro rail safety (CMRS) will conduct and inspection and KMRL will proceed with commissioning of the stretch,” said KMRL managing director Alkesh Kumar Sharma.

Trail runs are conducted to identify flaws in the system. Signalling trials will be conducted on Saturday and Sunday night for track data checking. The Metro will also conduct load test to ensure that safety standards are met.

“As it is a small stretch, the trial runs will not be conducted for a long period of time,” said a Kochi Metro official, hinting at the possibility of opening the stretch without much delay.

The opening of the Thykoodam-Petta stretch is expected to increase Metro’s ridership. According to KMRL, ridership crossed two million in December 2019 and January 2020. During the month of December 2019, ridership touched an all-time high of 21,08,108 while it was only 12,48,874 in December 2018. The trend continued in January 2020 with 20,74,430 travellers opting to commute in Metro.

KMRL has maintained that since the opening of the stretch till Thykoodam, the agency has witnessed a steady increase in ridership.

However, sources pointed out that the relaying of Sahodaran Ayyappan Road and widening of Vyttila-Petta Road has led to an increase in the use of private vehicles. Many commuters had migrated to Metro when the roads in the city were in a bad shape.

“The opening of Vyttila and Kundanoor flyovers will ensure smooth movement of traffic through the roads. So, it needs to be seen how commuters would respond to the Metro. At the same time, it can be expected that the traffic congestion in Tripunithura and the Metro construction along the Petta-Tripunithura stretch could encourage more people to opt for Metro services,” said a transport expert.

Title: Give med degree to petitioner in 30 days, court directs MGM
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Indore: High court has directed MGM medical college to provide marksheet, degree and other educational documents to the petitioner, who’s got clean chit from CBI in Vyapam Scam.

The petitioner was earlier suspended for his alleged involvement in Vyapam scam. However, it was later revoked when nothing concrete was found against him. The order was passed by a division bench of Justice SC Sharma and Justice Shailendra Shukla while hearing petition of Pushpendra Singh Gurjar filed through counsel Pushyamitra Bhargava. The court had granted liberty to the state government to take action against the petitioner after receiving a forensic laboratory report. However, a favourable report was received and his suspension from college was revoked, said Bhargava.

During hearing, the CBI then said in an affidavit that the report received from Forensic Science Laboratory, Bhopal / Delhi stated that the petitioner Gurjar did not appear in the PMT 2009. CBI stated that some impersonator had appeared in PMT and the matter was still under investigation.

CBI however, submitted a supplementary final report giving clean chit to the petitioner. CBI’s advocate Bhagyashree Sugandhi, stated in court, “There is nothing against the petitioner and a report was submitted in the matter by the CBI.” The division bench then allowed the petition directing MGM administration to provide education document to petitioner within 30 days of the order. TNN

Title: SIT gets 3 more members to speed up probe
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Three new members have been included in the Special Investigating Team conducting an enquiry into the land scams in Visakhapatnam and its suburbs.

The three new members included are RK Meena, Visakhapatnam Police Commissioner; K Durganand Prasad Rao, retired IPS officer of the Chattisgarh cadre; and Rahul Pandey, the chief conservator of forests.

Making the announcement during a press meet at the collectorate here on Saturday, K Vijaya Kumar, the SIT chief investigating officer, observed that this was done to speed up the investigation process.

The SIT head further added, “The SIT had received a total of 1,400 petitions from the public. So far the investigating team has managed to investigate only 400 of these. (This means) we have to speed up the investigation process.”

Earlier, the SIT comprising retired bureaucrats, T Vijay Kumar, YV Anuradha and T Bhaskar Rao conducted a review meet with the officials and updated them on the investigation process.

Title: PIL on appointment of DGP dismissed
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Indore: High court dismissed a public interest litigation seeking quashing of an internal correspondence between the state government and UPSC for appointment of Director General of Police.

A division bench of Justice Rohit Arya and Justice Shailendra Shukla while dismissing PIL filed by Sheran Sheikh said, “PIL seeking quashing of internal correspondence between home department, State of Madhya Pradesh and Union Public Service Commission, New Delhi at instance of petitioner is not maintainable. It is not justiciable”. The petitioner had claimed that the state government, by rejecting a panel of three names recommended by UPSC for appointment of DGP after holding it for three months, hadn’t adhered to apex court judgement in the case of Prakash Singh and others Vs. Union of India in 2006.

Additional advocate general Ravindra Singh Chabhra while opposing the maintainability of petition said, “PIL in the context of public employment, particularly in appointment of highly sensitive post of DGP with vague allegations and narrations without facts is a misuse of process of law.” Petitioner in this case shouldn’t be considered ‘person aggrieved’, said Chabhra. He told court that appointment on such high post shall be made in accordance with law and with due regard to the orders of Supreme Court. The court accepted arguments of AAG over locus of the petitioner in the case. The court observed that petition with omnibus statement, assertions in facts and circumstances, appears to be motivated. Petitioner cannot be said to be 'an aggrieved person' to maintain the petition, added court. TNN

Title: IT checks introduced by CBSE for board exams
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The Central Board of Secondary Education ( CBSE ) has undertaken IT initiatives for the smooth conduct of Classes X and XII board examinations that began on February 15. The board has integrated portals for identifying discrepancies and various quality checks in order to ensure accuracy of data.

Two new portals have been developed to put in place a rapid communication system with schools and regional offices.

Photo-tagging of custodians and centre superintendents has been added with the image of the centre to ensure safe collection and delivery of examination material.

Admit cards for examinees have been redesigned with a QR code and are available online.

An integrated portal has also been developed for submission of internal assessment as well as practical marks for Classes X and XII with photo-tagging of practical exam labs and images of examiners and examinees.

The number of encrypted question papers has been increased from 19 to 50 this year. The portal for collecting real-time data of absentee students has been strengthened.

The board, in a press note, stated that any suspicious activity or rumours should immediately be brought to the notice of the parent(s)/guardian and the board.

Title: Gujarat: Class IX, XI exams between April 1 and 11
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: The Gujarat Secondary and Higher Secondary Education Board ( GSHSEB ) has announced that the class IX and class XI examinations will be conducted between April 1 and April 11. The decision to conduct the examinations was taken up after the department decided to prepone the academic session.

Earlier, the examinations were scheduled between April 7 and April 18. The new academic session will begin from April 20 and the summer vacation will be from May 4 to June 7.

The state government has earlier in order to bring uniformity to the academic years of the central board and the state board, had decided to begin the academic year from April 1 instead of June 1.

As of now, schools affiliated to the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) begin their academic year on April 1 while GSHSEB schools begin on June 1. However for the current academic year the new academic session will begin from April 20.

Title: Venus Circus tragedy and the rings of fire
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

There is something macabre about a circus fire – and the Venus Circus fire was among the worst of its kind

BENGALURU: Quite often, disasters are proof of our own failings, man-made transgressions of order, of throwing caution to the winds. By far, the biggest fire tragedy in Bengaluru’s memory is of the blaze on February 8, 1981, which sent the tent of Venus Circus crashing down on hundreds of people and took a toll of about 80 lives.

It was past 6.45 that evening and the afternoon show, a special one for school children, was to end soon. Trapeze artiste Basheer, after flinging himself from swings, had just descended and taken a bow. Moments later, cries of “Benki, benki!” echoed from the tops rows in the gallery. In the horrifying pell-mell that followed as the burning roof crumbled and the lights went off, adults jumped off the seats on the top, some throwing aside chairs and stamping everything in their way – planks, broken chairs, bags and footwear. Children staggering to their feet were caught in the stampede and, as reports put it, it was the pandemonium more than the fire that took the lives of the young ones. By next afternoon, the toll had crossed 70.

The circus crew was largely safe, reports said, except for Ayub, a stunt motorcyclist who performed inside the “Globe of Death”. Other than the spherical cage in which Ayub rode, most equipment and belongings were charred. The fire didn’t touch the menagerie so much, but for two horses and a hippopotamus who were injured. Alert rescuers had cut the tether that held some animals. Initial reports said: “Elephants and hippos were believed to have broken loose after being either injured or scared. Lions and tigers were found huddled in the corners of their cages.”

Outside on the busy road leading from the railway station to Rajajinagar, hundreds had gathered before the firemen could make their way in the dark. Amidst the wailing children and distraught parents, passers-by and autorickshaw drivers joined others in trying to save lives. Subramaniam, a 40-year-old teacher from Bapuji Teachers Association Middle School who had accompanied hundreds of students, rescued many. The papers also said another woman who had left the show just before the fire broke out, rushed back in to pull out three children but “fell victim herself”.

Rescue work was challenging, not only because it had to be done in the glare of the headlights of police and fire brigade vehicles, but also because of the location. The circus tent was pitched on a patch of parthenium-infested wasteland bound by an elevated railway track, a busy road, and a drain. In the eastern neighbourhood was the Gethsemane Lutheran Church. Today, this is the site of the Okalipuram eight-lane corridor.

Voluntary efforts weren’t found wanting. Camps sprung up outside the accident area and near Victoria Hospital . Charitable organisations worked overtime to collect blood and secure drugs. All India Radio too chipped in with frequent appeals for help.

As is common now, theories about the cause of fire did the rounds. Did it start in the circus kitchen? Was it because of a carelessly-thrown cigarette butt? Or was it because of the sparks from high-tension wires that ran pretty close to the tarpaulin-roofed tent? The rumour mills were abuzz too: word spread that the horses had bolted towards Majestic, a lion was prowling in the vicinity and a hippo was bounding the railway colony.

The city hadn’t suffered a tragedy of such scale in the past decades. The government – headed by R Gundu Rao -- ordered an inquiry, but members of the opposition wanted to know why the circus company was issued a licence to operate in such an unsafe place. D Devaraj Urs, Congress (U) president, sought suspension or transfer of all officials involved in the issuance of licence to the circus, to leave no room for tampering of records. Why weren’t the records with the circus company seized? And why, he asked, did a top police official inaugurate it? “I can understand a politician doing such things as inaugurating a project even before it is sanctioned because he is under pressure, but how can an official undertake the inauguration of a circus show without a licence?” Urs said. An inquiry later pointed to the high-tension wires in the circus area.

Within a week, reports noted that the circus had moved to Krishnagiri in Tamil Nadu. But the questions remained: Was it a tragedy waiting to happen? Was the fire-fighting equipment adequate for a city then inhabited by 25 lakh people? Could fire hazards elsewhere be prevented, to begin with around the many “tent-cinemas”? A TOI report reminded authorities of how only two years ago, on Diwali day in 1979, a fire that broke out in a cracker shop had killed over 20 people.Indeed, there are lessons to be learnt from every accident. In our memory, the circus tragedy is a wound that still bleeds.
