Title: VMRDA to spend Rs 150 crore to develop one cent layouts
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The state government has accorded administrative sanction to Visakhapatnam Metropolitan Region Development Authority ( VMRDA ) to expend Rs 150 crore towards development of one cent plot layouts for distribution to housing scheme beneficiaries.

As reported in these columns earlier, the government had entrusted the responsibility of developing around 6,100 acres to the VMRDA, land pooling for which is in progress. In return, the VMRDA will get a 15% share of the land. Around 1.5 lakh beneficiaries have been identified by district officials under ‘Pedalandariki Illu’ (housing for the poor) scheme, where the beneficiaries will get one cent land each.

VMRDA had sent proposals to the tune of Rs 1,400 crore for development of all the proposed pooled land, including farmers’ share and its own share of 15%. But it has received sanction for only Rs 150 crore for development of the one cent layouts with quarry rubbish roads for the 1.5 lakh beneficiaries. The one cent layouts will be developed in nearly 3,000 acres, officials said, while the remaining land will be earmarked for VMRDA as well as for farmers.

While the assignees will get 900 square yards land for one acre, the tenants/encroachers without any documents will get 450 or 250 square yards.

VMRDA has estimated that jungle clearance, land levelling and other basic works will cost them about Rs 2.2 lakh per acre in the one cent layouts, while the development of layouts for farmers as well as for the urban development authority will cost about Rs 52 lakh per acre.

VMRDA metropolitan commissioner P Koteswara Rao said their first priority is to develop the one cent layouts for distribution to the homeless. “As per the earlier government order, we have a time of four months to hand over the developed plots to holders of land pooling ownership certificate after the pooled land is given to us,” he told TOI.

A government order released on Friday has accorded permission to the VMRDA commissioner to immediately invite tenders in view of the urgency to cope up with the time-bound flagship programme.

The government plans to launch the housing site distribution process during Ugadi.

Title: ‘Ahmedabad emerging as new art hub’
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Ahmedabad: “The city of Ahmedabad has rich heritage and the potential to become a globally known art destination,” said Kiran Nadar. An eminent art collector from New Delhi, Nadar pioneered the trend of private art museums.

She is in the city for the world championship team-selection priors organized by the Bridge Federation of India. Nadar, also a professional bridge player, often visits the city for her passion for bridge and art.

“Art is my first love and so is bridge and both keep bringing me to Ahmedabad,” said Nadar, who is regarded as the champion of art in the country. “Currently, two of my art projects are running in the city. First, Kiran Nadar Museum of Arts (KNMA) — my decade-old art museum — has lent its collection of Madan Mahatta’s photographs for an exhibition tilted ‘Delhi Modern: The Architecture of Independence’.” The show at Livavati Lalbhai Library at Cept University will be on view till February 28.

Second, Nadar said, KNMA has sponsored a solo art project by Vishal K Dar titled ‘Sites of Ruin and Gatherings’. “The project aims to creatively conserve the grandeur of architectural marvels of stepwells of the country,” she said. “The artist, who perceives stepwells as inverted towers, is researching on the structures in and around Ahmedabad.” Nadar added that new art spaces in the city have heightened awareness. She said a new set of younger art collectors are coming forward and investing in emerging artists and contemporary art. She said the trend was heartening.

“Art is not an exclusive preserve of the elite,” said Nadar, who has been tirelessly working to help people appreciate art. “For me, opening my private art museum meant sharing my passion and my possessions with the public,” she said. Nadar owns two art museums in New Delhi and her third space near Noida will open up in the next couple of years. “I never planned to open a private museum but my collection was growing and I needed more space to house and exhibit it,” she said.

Title: Chief secy asks officials to speed up works
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Kochi: Chief secretary Tom Jose asked the district administration to speed up the works under Operation Breakthrough . He reviewed the progress of the works at a meeting convened on Saturday.

Currently, 36 works worth Rs 64.5 crore are going on as part of the first phase. The remaining 201 works will start immediately. But the respective departments should generate fund for the works to be done by them. A meeting will be held in Thiruvananthapuram on Wednesday to discuss about the future course of action in Operation Breakthrough.

District collector S Suhas informed the chief secretary that removing obstructions in canals is going on.

Meanwhile, a mapping of network of canals in the city will be done to identify the points of obstacles. The map will be in 2D version.

“The chief secretary told us that the state government will provide fund for undertaking rest of the works. But the fund will be channelled through different departments,” said an official.

Operation Breakthrough, which was launched last month, is scheduled to be completed by March 31. The operation, which is aimed at cleaning the canals to find a solution to the waterlogging issue, was launched after heavy rain led to waterlogging in various parts of the city on October 21 last year.

The Kochi corporation came under criticism of the high court over its inaction to clear drainage.

A committee, comprising officials from irrigation, LSGD, PCB and Kochi corporation, was formed in November to carry out the works.

Title: ‘We are not Gods’ to save docs from violence
Content: Ahmedabad: An internal survey carried out by the Indian Medical Association (IMA) in 2017 revealed that one in three doctors under survey had reported facing some sort of violence in their career. “Nobody has authentic statistics as the definition of violence is also broad. But we are now pushing for the stringent norms to stop it,” said Dr R V Asokan, secretary general of IMA.Dr Asokan was one of the speakers at IIM Ahmedabad (IIM-A) on Saturday at an event to launch a short film ‘We are not Gods.’ The short film, made in association of a city-based hospital and IIM-A, is based on a true story and highlights issues including doctor-patient relationship, importance of right communication and expectations of the relatives.Dr Rajesh Chandwani, chair of Centre for Management of Health Services at IIM-A, said that the film is aimed at creating awareness about the violence faced by the doctors that not only affects morale of the professionals but also creates trust issues. “The film has been submitted to IMA and it would soon be made public,” he said.When questioned whether IMA would also pay heed to the genuine complaints in cases against the doctors, Dr Asokan said that all have duty to prevent unfortunate incidents and surely they would think about it. “We have already pushed the law to prevent violence with the central government and are hopeful of positive outcome,” he said. Panel experts raised issues such as commercialization of doctor-patient relationship and general intolerance in the society.

Title: Policing gets cyber edge, new facilities launched
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan inaugurates Cyberdome on InfoPark campus on Saturday. DGP Loknath Behera and I... Read More

Kochi: The capabilities of the city police are set to go a notch higher with the launch of a slew of projects aimed at bettering policing in the city on Saturday. Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan on Saturday inaugurated the Cyberdome , the cybercrime police station, and the regional forensic science laboratory, among other things on Saturday.

With the launch of the app Yodhav, one among the major projects, residents can now report to the police anonymously about drug crimes. The messages can be sent to WhatsApp number 99959-66666.

Police can receive the messages but they will not be able to access the identity of the informer. Launching the app, CM Pinarayi expressed his dismay over the rise in the use of drugs among youths and urged people to cooperate with the police and excise departments to curb the menace.

CM said the Cyberdome has the additional responsibility of creating awareness about cyber security, apart from its primary aim of protecting people from cyber criminals.

The state-of-the-art facility would assist the police in identifying and taking pre-emptive actions against cybercrimes.

Title: ‘To breathe is a luxury’
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

BENGALURU: From struggling in the past few years, Maneesha Ramakrishnan (50) has progressed to liking her feeble, hoarse voice. Her presence at home is marked by her breathing through a tracheostomy tube (for oxygen) on her neck. “To breathe is a luxury. Now, children laugh as they hear me breathe. My voice sounds funny to them and that’s joy for me,” she says.

She is one of the survivors of the Carlton tragedy that shook Bengaluru. She was working in a private company on the seventh floor of the building. The toxic fumes she inhaled changed the course of her life. “My vocal folds and windpipe got stuck to each other. The larynx was affected equally. I lost my voice. That’s why I struggle to speak,” says Maneesha, whose smile is still infectious. “I had thought I would be given some injections or medicine and go home to see my child. But I ended up being in ICU for three months, and was in hospital for nine months, undergoing nine surgeries,” says Maneesha, whose weight was just 25 kg when she was brought home back. She underwent laser surgeries to remove the fibroids forming on her windpipe.

Sitting at her house off Hennur Bande Road on the outskirts of the city, Maneesha finds absolute peace in feeding over 25 stray dogs in her vicinity, apart from her two pets at home. “I don’t call myself a victim. I have braved it all through. I was never depressed. There was help pouring in from everywhere, even from across the globe,” she says.

Maneesha worked in an MNC after a year after the fire tragedy, but could not continue for more than 15 months. She changed her job to work with an NGO, dabbled in cooking and serving, worked as a counsellor. But she didn’t get into a full time job. “It’s self taught meditation that has brought peace,” she adds.

Title: Tirupati trust to get 100 acres to set up J&K temple
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

If all goes as per plan, then in two years from now, Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams will inaugurate a replica of Lord Venkateswara temple in J&K. The temple is likely to come up close to the Vaishno Devi shrine along the Jammu-Katra highway. The J&K government will allocate a 100-acre land to TTD to construct the replica temple, a kalyana mandapam, a Vedic school and a hospital.

A special TTD delegation recently held talks with the J&K government, followed by inspections of two proposed sites for the new temple at Dhummi and Majin. Last December, the TTD trust board had resolved to construct two temples , one in Jammu and the other in Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s constituency, Varanasi, in Uttar Pradesh.

A special TTD delegation comprising executive officer Anil Kumar Singhal , JEO P Basant Kumar and chief engineer Ramachandra Reddy along with special invitee to the TTD trust board J Sekhar and YSRC MP V Vijaya Sai Reddy recently held talks with the J&K government, followed by inspections of two proposed sites for the new temple at Dhummi and Majin.

Last December, the TTD trust board had resolved to construct two temples, one in Jammu and the other in Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s constituency Varanasi. The trust had already built a Lord Venkateswara temple in Kanyakumari in the southern-most state of Tamil Nadu in 2019 at a cost of nearly Rs 25 crore. It has also built the Lord’s temples in Haryana, New Delhi and Maharashtra.

At present, construction of temples by TTD is underway at Amaravati, Visakhapatnam, Hyderabad and Bhubaneswar.

Title: Congress to file review plea in Supreme Court over quota verdict
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Newly appointed Congress spokesperson Anshul Avijit, who was accompanied by party’s city spokesperson Atul Lon... Read More

NAGPUR: Accusing Prime Minister Narendra Modi-led BJP government of being anti-reservation and anti-SC/ST, Congress on Saturday said it would do everything, including filing a review petition against the Supreme Court ’s recent verdict that states were not legally bound to grant reservation in promotions.

“The BJP government is following RSS ideology of ending reservation. The SC’s orders came in a petition by the Uttarakhand government where the saffron party is in power. The party’s government at Centre didn’t oppose the move. This is an attack on fundamentals of the Constitution,” said newly appointed Congress spokesperson Anshul Avijit , who was accompanied by party’s city spokesperson Atul Londhe .

Stressing that deprived sections of the society have fundamental right of reservations, Avijit, who’s son of former Speaker Meira Kumar, said the BJP and RSS were against it since the beginning and their leaders’ statements proved it beyond doubts.

“RSS chief Mohan Bhagwat and senior leader Manmohan Vaidya had spoken about how reservation is dividing the country. Our forefathers had implemented reservation for benefits of dalits and poor and to stop their discrimination and humiliation. In 2017, over 33,208 cases of atrocities were registered which means 108 incidents per day, which is alarming,” he said.

Describing how caste-based discrimination is still rampant, Avijit, who’s grandson of former deputy PM Babu Jagjivan Ram, said they were not allowed used water in wells in rural areas. “We still need reservation to remove this discrimination. It was in 1995 that an amendment was made for reservation in promotion, as lawmakers of that time thought it was a fundamental right. However, the SC’s decision put the ball in states’ court which will be implementing it as per their whims and fancies,” he said.

Terming SC’s decision as a “conspiracy” by the BJP government, Avijit said Congress was very disappointed with the verdict and would raise voice against the government on every platform. He, however, declined to comment on the issue of some states like Maharashtra and Tamil Nadu breaching 50% reservation quota as set put by the apex court stating that it was sub-judice.

Londhe said the SC itself had stated that if backward class commissions of states submitted a report that particular sections of the society were backward and need reservation, the 50% quota can be breached.

Title: No rift in Maha Vikas Agadhi, says Uddhav Thackeray in presence of Sharad Pawar
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

CM Uddhav Thackeray and Sharad Pawar at the award function in Jalgaon

NASHIK: A day after Nationalist Congress Party (NCP) chief Sharad Pawar termed the state government’s move to hand over the probe of the Elgar Parishad case to the National Investigation Agency (NIA) as improper, chief minister Uddhav Thackeray on Saturday asserted that there was no rift whatsoever within the tri-party Maha Vikas Agadhi (MVA) government.

Thackeray, who shared the dais with Pawar at an agricultural award function at Jalgaon, said: “There is no problem between the alliance partners of this government. The central focus of the MVA government is to ameliorate the plight of the farming’ fraternity in the state”.

Speaking at another function in Muktainagar in Jalgaon on Saturday, which too was attended by Pawar, Thackeray dared the BJP to bring down the MVA government in the state.

“BJP has been claiming that our government will not last. I dare BJP to bring down the government. It will be unsuccessful as our government is strong and there is perfect understanding among the three alliance partners,” he said.

At a press conference in Kolhapur on Friday, Pawar had said that it was “not at all proper” for the state government to grant its consent to hand over the probe to NIA. Though-Pawar had said that it was the CM's prerogative to take the call, on Saturday, his party leader and state home minister Anil Deshmukh said that his office has sought legal opinion to know if a special investigation team (SIT) can still be formed to look into Pune police action in the Elgar case.

The developments have already fuelled speculations that all is not well within the MVA. Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) spokesperson Madhav Bhandari said that by handing over the Elgar case to NIA, Thackeray has send a message to Pawar’s party that he will not succumb to its pressure.

On Saturday, both Thackeray and Pawar did not make a mention of the Elgar case in their speeches, which were focused on the farming-related issues. Thackeray said government is working out modalities to provide adequate water and power to the farmers.

Title: CM meets law min, urges him to fast-track council abolition
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Vijayawada: Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy returned to the state on Saturday after his two-day visit to the national capital, during which he held meetings with Union home minister Amit Shah and law minister Ravi Shankar Prasad.

Jagan submitted a representation to Prasad on Saturday, urging him to take an early decision on the legislative council issue. The CM explained to him the background to the proposal of shifting the high court to Kurnool, and requested him to speed up the process. Citing the historic Sri Bagh pact, which was signed by senior leaders of the state in 1937, the CM said making Kurnool the judicial capital will honour the sentiments of the people of Rayalaseema. He requested Prasad to ensure that the abolition process of the legislative council is cleared before the budget session of the state assembly in March.

The chief minister also explained his government’s proposed decentralization initiative, which is aimed at developing the three regions of the state — Rayalaseema region by making Kurnool the judicial capital, north coastal Andhra by setting up the executive capital in Visakhapatnam, and coastal region with the legislative capital in Amaravati. He also reminded him the 2019 election manifesto of the BJP, which had supported decentralized development of the state, and requested Prasad to fulfil the promises.

Jagan also briefed the law minister about his meetings with the Prime Minister on Wednesday and home minister on Friday, where he represented the same issues. He told Prasad that both Modi and Shah promised him the fast-track the high court and legislative council issues. He also explained the salient features of Disha Act and its functioning in the state.

As Prasad also holds the portfolios of IT, electronics and communications, Jagan requested him to extend financial and other support to the state in IT promotion. He said that his government is holding talks with various IT companies and requested the minister to promote IT in Andhra Pradesh.

Title: Tirupati: Signature forgery case suspect attempts suicide
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

TIRUPATI: A suspect in the recent signature forgery case attempted to commit suicide after being questioned by the police at Chinnamandem in Kadapa district on Saturday. It may be recalled that Teneti Vanitha, minister for women development and child welfare, had lodged a complaint with home minister M Sucharitha and DGP Gautam Sawang two days back, alleging forgery of her official letterhead and signature by a person from Kadapa.

In her complaint, Vanitha stated that one M Reddeppa of Devalampeta village in Chinnamandem mandal of Kadapa district had submitted a forged letter to the district collector seeking 1.2 acres of government land to set up a small-scale industry. Following the complaint, Chinnamandem police registered a case against M Reddeppa who is absconding. Meanwhile, the police summoned Kiran, a close associate of Reddeppa, for questioning on Saturday.

“He pleaded not guilty and requested us to allow him to stay at his home as there was a possibility Reddeppa could get in touch with him. So we allowed him to go back but sent a police constable with him to keep watch,” the police said, adding that Kiran and Reddeppa had approached the minister together and that he was very much a part of the forgery.

After Kiran reached his home in Devalampeta village, he tried to commit suicide by consuming hair dye. However, the alert police constable immediately rushed the suspect to a nearby hospital. He is now recovering and out of danger, police said.

Title: No proposal of alliance with YSRC: Sunil Deodhar
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Sunil Deodhar

VISAKHAPATNAM: BJP national secretary Sunil Deodhar on Saturday made it clear that both YSRC and TDP are political rivals of BJP and there is no proposal of an alliance with either of the parties. Addressing reporters, Sunil, who is also the in-charge of BJP affairs in AP, said there was no proposal of an alliance with the YSRC “either through front door or back door”. He said he came to know that one of the ministers had commented that YSRC is ready to join the NDA government at the Centre.

“BJP already has an alliance with Jana Sena and we will jointly contest the local body polls. We will not go for any alliance, neither with YSRC nor with TDP. We are quite clear on this. We don’t want any debate, discussion or comments on this issue,” he asserted, while adding that “both YSRC and TDP are playing mind games in AP”. Sunil also accused both YSRC and TDP of indulging in corruption. “TDP chief Chandrababu Naidu committed irregularities during his tenure, now chief minister Jaganmohan Reddy is committing the same mistakes. Even though the state is reeling under revenue deficit, the YSRC government has been announcing freebies. The state will be in deep trouble due to this kind of practice. There was no corruption when NTR was the CM. It was Naidu who introduced corruption in AP,” he alleged.

He also claimed that the Centre is yet to give its consent to the three capitals proposal.

Title: Thane: Juvenile told to do community service, fined Rs 10,000 for 5-year-old's rape, murder
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

Title: Tirupati Urban Development Authority to set up 7,000 acre land bank for future use
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

TIRUPATI: Chevireddy Bhaskar Reddy, chairman of Tirupati Urban Development Authority ( Tuda ) informed on Friday that the civic body’s board has decided to set up a land bank of 7,000 acres land for future use.

Speaking to the media, Bhaskar Reddy said that pilgrims across the country and the world visit the temple city. “Consequently, vehicular movement has been increasing resulting in traffic congestion. Tuda will develop parking spaces with latest technology if the revenue department and TTD allocate land at Gandhi Road, near the TTD rest house and Tiruchanoor Road near Tirupati Railway Station,” he said.

The board has also decided to hire students and researchers from IITs, IIMs and other top institutions under its consultant programme to develop master plan roads within Tuda limits. Officials of the planning and engineering department will go on a study tour to observe developmental activities in developed cities like Mumbai and Chandigarh, the chairman informed.

Reddy further said that a special legal cell will be formed to fight cases in order to obtain lands that have been encroached upon. The board has also decided to develop land under the PPP model, he informed while adding that Tuda will allocate Rs 5 crore for the development of the Swaranamukhi river bank in Srikalahasti town.

Title: Avanthi demands ED probe against Naidu’s aide
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Visakhapatnam: State tourism minister Muttamsetti Srinivasa Rao (Avanthi) demanded the central government initiate a CBI or ED inquiry into the recent I-T raids against P Srinivas Rao, former personal assistant to Telugu Desam Party (TDP) president and former chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu. The minister also demanded that the government cancel the passports of Naidu and his son Nara Lokesh as I-T officials had unearthed assets worth Rs 2,500 crore from the residence of Srinivas.

Addressing the media, the minister said that Jana Sena chief Pawan Kalyan should also question assets unearthed in the raid, alleging that the money belongs to Naidu and his son.

The minister also said that the resurvey to include excluded beneficiaries for pension would be completed by Monday. “Around 80 per cent of the resurvey is over and all eligible persons would get pension irrespective of caste, religion and political affiliation,” he said.

Meanwhile, police arrested resource persons under the Mission for Elimination of Poverty in Municipal Areas (Mepma) when they laid siege at Avanthi’s residence on Saturday, demanding that their pending wages be released. The arrested persons alleged that the minister had insulted them and instructed police to arrest them.

The minister later said that all personnel would receive their pending salaries next week and the concerned minister has been requested to release salaries. On land pooling for housing projects, the minister said the process is underway and the government has not acquired land by force. Around 1.75 lakh applications have been received for houses from persons belonging to economically weaker sections.

Title: 38th annual Astronomical society of India meet underway in Tirupati
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Tirupati: The 38th annual meeting of Astronomical Society of India ( ASI ) began in the city on Friday. Young delegates seemed to dominate the session on the first day with 53% of delegates being students another 23% post-doctoral fellows. These bright minds have come together for the national-level annual event at the Indian Institute of Science Education and Research (IISER) campus in Tirupati .

ASI president GC Anupama said that the largest meeting of astronomers will discuss emerging areas in space science. Speaking to the media, Anupama, who is a senior professor at the Indian Institute of Astrophysics in Bengaluru, said that the plenary sessions will discuss galaxies, cosmology, compact objects like black holes and the future of payloads in space missions.

KN Ganesh, director of IISER said that hosting a major national event like the ASI annual meeting shows how the institute as grown in stature. Harvinder Kaur, a member of ASI’s Working Group on Gender Equity (WGGE) said, “113 of the 322 delegates at the meeting are women,” Kaur said.

On the first day, a lecture on ‘The central problem of star formation: Why so slow?’ was delivered by Prof Neal J Evans. On Saturday, a talk was organised on ‘India’s expanding lunar exploration programme’ by P Sreekumar, director of ISRO’s space science programme.

Title: Winners of naming contest felicitated
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Tirupati: Vidyasagar Daud and Ananyo Bhattacharya who won the ‘Exoplanet host star naming contest’ in December, 2019 were felicitated at the inaugural session of the ASI meet in Tirupati . Daud is a student of Class 8 while 20-year-old Anonyo is pursuing engineering.

Daud said that he suggested the name ‘Santamasa’ for the exoplanet. Meanwhile, Anonyo Bhattacharya who won after naming the exoplanet Bibha told TOI that Bibha is the Bengali pronunciation of the Sanskrit word Vibha which means a bright beam of light. “The name also honours Indian physicist Bibha Choudhary,” Anonyo said. - Raghavan Kumar

Title: Tirupati: BIRRD to adopt artificial intelligence to improve treatment
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

TIRUPATI: The Sri Balaji Institute of Surgery , Research and Rehabilitation for the Disabled ( BIRRD ) which is run by Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams (TTD) is planning to introduce robotic assistance for its artificial limb centre. Dr M Madan Mohan Reddy, director of the institute said on Friday that the institute is also planning to introduce artificial intelligence in a bid to augment efficiency and accuracy.

BIRRD which treats patients suffering from polio mellitus, cerebral palsy, congenital anomalies and spinal injuries attracts patients from all over the country and has a huge waiting list for surgeries. Director Reddy, who took charge in January, said that steps are being taken to get to a point where patients admitted for surgery can be taken to the operation theatre within 48 hours.

The director further said that while patients have to undergo pre-anaesthetic tests at SVIMS Hospital , hereafter, those tests will also be conducted within the institute. Dr Reddy said that the operation theatres are being upgraded in line with international standards aimed at achieving zero rate of infection in surgeries.

Talking about the institute’s fiscal situation, the director said that around 50 per cent of the budget is spent on implants, leaving the institute with little money for development and research.

Title: ‘State parties dancing to BJP’s tunes’
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Andhra Pradesh Pradesh Congress Committee (PCC) president Sake Sailajanath said that BJP is the first enemy to the interests of the state. Sailajanth, working president Tulasi Reddy and Mastan Valli were in the city on Saturday. They alleged that all the three major political parties in the state are dancing to BJP’s tunes.

“When injustice is being done to the people by BJP, opposition parties are not raising their voice but colluding with them instead,” Sailajanath said while adding that Andhra has become a BJP state where B means Babu, J means Jagan and P means Pawan. Tulasi Reddy, the working president said, “The central government has only given Rs 1,053 crore whereas the state was supposed to get Rs 2,43,000 crore. The BJP government has not developed anything in AP.”

Title: Mumbai: Soon, check app if missing person dead in railway mishap
Content:
Representative image

MUMBAI: People will soon be able to check if any missing person has met with a railway accident through a mobile phone app . The Accidental Death Report (ADR) app , that city railway police will introduce, will be integrated with missing persons bureau records, helping police stations in Mumbai and the state to get details of missing persons cases registered with them or those who could have died in railway accidents. Details will also be uploaded to the Mumbai railway police website too.There were 2,514 railway accident victims, whose bodies were unclaimed, and their families were not traced in 2017-19.The initiative was introssduced earlier this month after Mumbai crime branch, after 10 months, solved the case of Aarti Rithadia (17), who went missing from Nehru Nagar on March 30, 2019, and died that day. She had met with a train accident between Tilak Nagar and Chembur stations on the Harbour line, and her father committed suicide seven months later as he could not find her.Mumbai railway police commissioner Ravindra Sengaonkar told TOI, “The app will have information about missing persons cases registered with police stations. Rithadia’s case has nothing to do with introduction of the app. A test run is being done for internal purposes. It will be accessible to the public and city police within a fortnight.”Sengaonkar said the moment railway police get information about a rail accident, the officer should upload at least five photographs of the victim to the app.“After reporting and registering the matter with railway police, the officer must send the body to the hospital for post-mortem. The officer has to collect details like identity marks and upload it to the railway server using the app. The data will be relayed to missing persons bureau, with which the app will be integrated,” he said.Sengaonkar has instructed in-charges of railway police stations to gather information on unclaimed rail accident victims’ bodies cremated in 2017-19 and try to track down their families. “We will try to add data of previous untraced rail accident victims to the app, if proper photographs are stored,” he said.Railway accident data showed 3,014 accidental deaths in 2017 and railway police have tracked down family members of 2,115. In 2018, 2,981 died in rail accidents, while 2,090 where traced; and 2,691 died in 2019, while 1,967 were traced.

Title: Mumbai: 4 cops suspended for multi-crore land scam, action against two more sought
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

A 2018 photograph of the controversial 16-acre plot in Dahisar

MUMBAI: City police commissioner suspended four policemen on Saturday and wrote to state home department, recommending action against two assistant commissioners for alleged involvement in a multi-crore land scam at Dahisar. The home department on Friday granted sanction to Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) to prosecute the six for allegedly forcibly evicting the developer of a 16-acre plot in 2017. State police had written twice to the home department against granting of sanction to prosecute them.

A complaint had been lodged by Jude and Dominic Romell, directors of Romell Housing LLP, alleging police high-handedness. They had purchased the plot from two private firms and Kamruddin Shaikh.

Shaikh's family owned the land since 1971, but after his death, his grandson Salim approached police in April 2017, accusing Jude of dacoity, trespass and theft. Jude, arrested and subsequently released on bail, moved Bombay high court against the grandson and police. The HC directed the police commissioner to conduct an inquiry. A probe by a joint commissioner of police gave a clean chit to the cops. The HC expressed displeasure about the probe being transferred to CBI. The HC order was challenged in Supreme Court, but the apex court did not interfere.

CBI will submit a charge-sheet against the accused under sections 120 (B) (criminal conspiracy), 182 (false information with intent to cause public servant to use his lawful power to injury of another person), 192 (fabricating false evidence), 196 (using evidence known to be false), 211 (false charge of offence made with intent to injure) and 298 (public servant framing incorrect record or writing with intent to save person from punishment) of IPC.

Those suspended were inspector Sanjeev Tawde, assistant inspectors Anand Jadhav and Kakasaheb Shinde and sub-inspector Rekha Sayakar. "Orders for suspension of assistant commissioners of police Prashant Mardhe and Subhash Sawant will be taken by the home department," said the officer. After the allegations surfaced, Mardhe was transferred to the main control room, while Sawant was posted with Force1. Tawde is with special branch, Jadhav is with VP Road police station, and Shinde and Sayakar are with the Local Arms Unit.

The home department had given sanction to prosecute the six police personnel on Friday. The sanction had been sought by CBI mid-September. Police had written to the department against giving sanction. "The case is scheduled to come up for hearing in the HC, and the government does not want to take chances of the court pulling it up for causing a delay," said an official.

Title: Happy Birthday Darshan: A look at the journey of the Kannada superstar on his 43rd birthday
Content: Darshan is a prominent actor and producer in the Kannada film industry. Darshan, aff ectionately known by his fans as 'Box Office Sultana', 'Dasa' and ‘D-Boss’, is the eldest son of Kannada film actor Thoogudeepa Srinivas. In his nearly two decades of acting, he has been recognized as the favourite among Kannada audiences, appearing in over fifty films. Let’s take a look at the journey of his life. Darshan Thoogudeepa was born on the night of Shivaratri on February 16, 1977, to Kannada actor Thoogudeepa Srinivas and Meena Thoogudeepa. Darshan completed his education in Mysore, and he completed his acting studies in Ninasam, a theatre training institute in Shimoga. Divya and Dinakar are brothers of Darshan. In 2003, he got married to Vijayalakshmi and has a son named Vineesh.At a young age, Darshan lost his father who passed away because of a heart attack. The family lost all the money for the father's health treatment. Darsaah who didn't study well, worked at their own hotel and sold cow’s milk to earn money to run the family. He simultaneously looked up for some acting opportunities. Darshan was rejected by lots of people in the industry in the early days in his career and worked as a projectionist and light boy on many movie sets.Darshan, who completed his acting education in Ninasam, worked as a light boy and projectionist. He later worked under cinematographer B. C. Gowrishankar, as an assistant cameraman. Prior to this, he had been modelling at Jaganmohan Palace in Mysore. Darshan, who had come to Bangalore to seek acting opportunities, made his first acting debut in S. Narayan's television soap. In 1997, S Narayana made his big-screen debut in 'Mahabharata'. He then starred in the serial 'Detective Chandrakanta '. However, Darshan is best known for his role in S Narayan's 'Ambika' serial. He has also worked as a dubbing artist with voiceovers for some of the three cartoons. Overall, Darshan has played supporting roles in one Tamil and five Kannada films. Darshan made his first big debut in 2001 in the Kannada film industry from the movie ‘Majestic’ directed by P. N. Satya.Darshan made his lead debut from the movie ‘Majestic’. The film received a positive response and completed 100 days in many theatres in Karnataka. ‘Kalasipalya’ was another movie which gave him a big break, after more than ten movies, and Rakshita was paired with Darshan in this movie. In 2007, he starred with Upendra in the movie ‘Anataru’. Darshan starred in films like 'Ayya', 'Mandya', 'Gaja', 'Sarathi', 'Bulbul', 'Brindavana', 'Ambarish' and in 2012 acted in the historical film 'Krantiveera Sangolli Rayanna'. The film won the Karnataka State Film Award for Best Actor. Darshan played Duryodhana in his 50th film 'Kurukshetra', and he is currently busy with ‘Robert’ and another historical movie ‘RajaVeera Madakari Nayaka ’.After gaining stability in his career, Darshan went on to expand his territory and launched a production house. In 2006, Darshan and his brother Dinkara teamed up and opened ‘Thongudheepa Productions’ and produced their first film ‘Jothe Jotheyali’ which became a super hit. Later, many movies like 'Bulbul', 'Navagraha', and others were produced. They have even distributed many movies like 'Brindavan', 'Jai Lalitha', ' Ugramm ' and others.Darshan was an animal lover since childhood and has adopted many animals. The actor owns a farmhouse which has 120 animals including cows, goats, boars, horses, and other pets. Darshan, who goes to the Mysore Zoo very often has adopted many animals including a tiger and an elephant. He was also appointed as the Brand Ambassador for the Forest Department of the Karnataka Government in 2018.

Title: 2 kids die, ‘poisonous’ berry blamed
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Malda: Two children died and two are fighting for life at a hospital in Malda after they fell unconscious while playing near their home in Kadamtali village on Friday evening. Doctors suspect the children, aged 3-7, had consumed a poisonous wild berry . Residents said they were playing in an orchard. When they did not return after sunset, their guardians found them lying unconscious amid a bamboo thicket.

Thinking an evil spirit had cast a spell, the villagers took the children to soothsayer Rafik Ojha. He reportedly advised them to take the children to a hospital. By the time they reached Malda Medical College and Hospital, Firoj Ali (7) had died. Safikul Islam (5) died shortly after admission. The two others, sisters Sabnur (5) and Kohinur Khatun (3), are critical and being treated in the isolation ward. The sisters had vomitted on Friday night, which might have saved them.

Medical college vice-principal Amit Dawn said: “The delay in bringing them to hospital proved fatal.” A team led by the block medical officer of health was sent to the village on Saturdat afternoon.

Title: Mitra: Bengal’s revenues increased 3-fold in 10 yrs
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Kolkata: State finance minister Amit Mitra has told the assembly that Bengal’s own revenues have registered a steady growth over the years. He added that the Centre’s devolution to states has grown following recommendations of the Finance Commission.

While responding to CPM MLA Sujan Chakrabarty, Mitra showed how the state’s own revenue had increased from Rs 21,500 crore in 2010-11 to Rs 65,806 crore in 2019-20 under Mamata Banerjee’s regime. The state’s revenue generation is pegged at Rs 70,807 crore, with a projected three-fold increase in the 10 years since 2010-11.

Mitra then explained why state revenue as a percentage had fallen, as pointed out by the CPM MLA. “The state tax percentage is calculated as a component of central devolution, which is always greater for all states. A small increase in central devolution nomination always surpasses the increase in individual states’ revenue generation. It is si-mple arithmetic that the percentage falls if the increase in denominator (central devolution) is more than the numerator (state tax),” he said.

Mitra told the assembly the central devolution to states had grown from 32% during the 14th Finance Commission to 42% during the 15th. The central devolution includes a portion of CGST, IGST, corporation tax, income tax, union customs and excise duties, service tax and central grants.

The greater devolution with sounded fiscal management in the state has promp-ted the Bengal government to keep a lower debt repayment liability compared to the revised estimate of 2019-20. The loan repayment for 2019-20 was Rs 56,541 crore while the budget estimate for 2020-21 keeps it at a lower Rs 51, 047 crore. The state has also subsequently reduced the borrowing target for the next fiscal.

Mitra also claimed during his reply that though the state’s total debt stock has gone up, that should not be considered in isolation. “What is important is the debt to GSDP (gross state domestic product) ratio. This has gone down substantially over the years,” he said.

The ratio was 40.65% in 2010-11 when Banerjee came to power. It fell to 34% and is projected to fall further in 2020-21 to 32.90%.

Mitra said in his reply th-at the state has mostly repaid 10-year bonds taken during the Left Front regime. “We have repaid Rs 2 lakh crore of principal and Rs 1.5 lakh crore interest of Left regime.”

Title: Covid-19 outbreaks may turn endemic, fear doctors
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

KOLKATA: Covid-19, the disease caused by novel coronavirus that has taken more than 1,300 lives across the world so far, could turn endemic in India like the seasonal flu and strike again with devastating consequences, fear experts.A similar pattern has been noticed in at least two of the common coronaviruses that affect people.And, without a drug or a vaccine to counter the deadly virus , another outbreak could have a considerable impact, though there could be fewer deaths.“It is indeed one of the three major possibilities,” said K K Aggarwal, former president, Indian Medical Association (IMA). “While it could be a ‘hit-and-run’ case or a one-off outbreak, there is a high chance of the outbreak recurring. This has been observed with other strains of coronavirus. And if, indeed, the novel strain turns endemic, it will be no different from the common flu. It could turn out to have seasonal behaviour, flaring up in winter like the flu,” he added.The epidemiological definition of ‘endemic’ is ‘something that is characteristic of a particular population, environment, or region’.While early studies into novel coronavirus seem to indicate that it may burn itself out in a few months, if it turns endemic, it would come back next winter. That happened with the 1918 Spanish flu pandemic, which hit the world in two seasonal waves.The only saving grace would be that a second attack will have a lesser impact, said Aggarwal. “It should cause fewer deaths when it recurs. In any case, the coronavirus doesn’t have a mortality rate of more than 2% to 3%, which is the same as that of any other seasonal flu. The only big difference is that our immune systems can’t fight it yet, unlike the other flus,” he explained.Irfan Akhtar, a specialist in the infection control department of the Czech Rehabilitation Hospital in Abu Dhabi, also felt that there was a possibility of the virus turning endemic. “It could be dangerous, since our immune systems are not geared to fight the virus yet. It will take time to develop an antibody. It is highly contagious, which makes it spread faster than the other strains, and leads to death. That is why we need to develop an antiviral drug soon. A vaccine, too, will eventually have to be developed,” he said.The novel coronavirus will not be any more dangerous than other coronaviruses once it can be countered with drugs, added Akhtar. “Any virus of the group eventually attacks the lungs or the kidneys. A repeat outbreak could be deadlier, since there is nothing as yet to counter the virus. That is why we need to develop a medicine for novel coronavirus, or a vaccine.”It could take two years to develop a vaccine while an anti-viral drug could be developed even sooner, said Aggarwal. “Once we have a vaccine and a drug, it will be like any other flu,” he said.It will take six months to a year for the virus to be studied and an antiviral drug to be devised, said consultant Arindam Biswas. “But the human system will eventually develop an antibody in due course. It happened at the time of SARS. We had two outbreaks — in 2003 and 2015 — but the virus has since fizzled out. It hasn’t turned endemic. I don’t think novel coronavirus will, either,” he said. But there is a persistent danger as long as the virus is active and being transmitted, he added. “The worrying aspect is that 40% of those affected are between 50-55 years of age, who are not immuno-compromised. This means the virus can affect people who are perfectly healthy. Usually, the largest number of those to be affected by viruses have immune deficiency,” he added.

Title: West Bengal BJP president Dilip Ghosh links CAA protests to ‘biryani & funds’
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Dilip Ghosh

KOLKATA: West Bengal BJP president Dilip Ghosh raked up yet another controversy on Saturday by taking a dig at the “uneducated, unaware, poor people” who are “paid and fed biryani with foreign funds” for continuing with protests in defiance against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act.

Ghosh’s comment drew a scathing criticism from Trinamool Congress.

Ghosh, speaking on the role of the party in power in Bengal and other opposition parties who don’t have public support, said: “The ruling party and others have taken to the streets but they don’t have public support. Some uneducated, unaware, poor people have been lured with money and are being fed biryani with foreign funds to continue with the protests.”

Speaking at BJP’s organisational meet, Ghosh said this while narrating the falling standards of Bengal from the heyday of Ram Mohan Roy, Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose and Syamaprasad Mookerjee.

Trinamool senior and state parliamentary affairs minister Partha Chatterjee said Ghosh has taken Bengal’s political narrative to a new low. “Is this how a party leader should speak? People are the best judge. But I believe that the BJP leader is deliberately targeting a particular community for narrow political ends,” Chatterjee said. Ghosh had made similar offensive comments earlier, saying that 50 lakh Muslims will be chased out of the country.

On Saturday, explaining the Shaheen Bagh-Park Circus narrative, the Bengal BJP president pointed out how they have become the must-reach destination of the opposition. “Park Circus has become a must-visit place for Brinda Karat or Chidambaram. They do not want to address others. Only some burqa-clad women with children in their laps are their sole audience,” he said.

Ghosh also didn’t spare intellectuals and students participating in the countrywide protests, from Shaheen Bagh in Delhi to Park Circus in Kolkata.

“These people are writing poems asking people not to show papers. But you have seen during the Delhi assembly polls how the protesters flashed their voter ID cards. They show papers at airport, railways stations and examination centres, but ask people not to do that. I was surprised that the person who wrote kagoj dekhabo na (won’t show papers) is the first to show his papers when he goes to claim official benefits,” he said.

The BJP state president, taking a dig at state universities, said: “Now the state universities prohibit the entry of Union ministers and the governor in the name of autonomy. They won’t do that to Rohingya. All these are part of a plan to create a constitution within the Constitution and a country within a country. It appears that someone is willing to take West Bengal out of India like Muslim League leader Jinnah took away parts of Bengal.”

Title: Amit Shah set to visit Kolkata as BJP gears up for civic elections
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Union home minister Amit Shah

KOLKATA: Union home minister Amit Shah will come to Kolkata on March 1 to set a tall target for Bengal BJP as it warms up for the coming municipal polls.

Five years ago in 2015, BJP finished the civic race as a poor fourth, lagging behind even Congress. Congress had won 187 seats, while BJP won only 81 of the total 2,094 seats. The target this time is to make BJP the second party, if not the first. BJP functionaries present at the organisational meet at ICCR on the second day on Saturday held that there has been a massive change in ground reality since the 2019 Lok Sabha polls, which makes the target “achievable”.

A cursory look at the 2015 results in select municipalities shows that the situation in 2020 is different. In a host of municipalities in North 24 Parganas like Barasat, Bhatpara and Bongaon, BJP couldn’t even open its account. In the Barrackpore civic polls, the party could bag only a single seat. BJP had no representation in seven municipalities of Hooghly such as Tarakeswar, Serampore, Bhadreswar and Bansberia. The situation has also undergone change in north Bengal.

Bengal BJP has carved out a two-pronged campaign strategy for the municipal polls. It wants to make full use of CAA and earn confidence of the dormant sections otherwise invisible on the streets of Kolkata. BJP will pursue the CAA agenda as a long-term (polarisation) strategy. “The Union home minister is coming to Kolkata on March 1. He may lead a pro-CAA rally or hold a meeting in the city. BJP president JP Nadda may accompany him,” BJP state general secretary Sayantan Basu said. According to Basu, the rules under CAA would be in place ahead of Shah’s Kolkata visit.

BJP has appointed Mukul Roy as convener of the municipal poll committee to use his organisational experience. BJP will dovetail CAA with general development, an issue that it learnt the hard way in the Delhi assembly polls. “Pursuing the development path as we see in other places such as Bangalore, delivering a corruption-free municipality and using MPLAD funds of BJP MPs for area development are some of our campaign points,” Basu said. At the same time, BJP will campaign for central projects like Ayushman Bharat and Amrut, denied entry in the state.

Party office-bearers have set the guideline for selection of candidates. “The candidate should have a clean image, s/he should have potential to win polls,” a state BJP office-bearer said. BJP units at the grassroots have been asked to send names of candidates to the panel. The state party will directly monitor elections to corporations such as Kolkata, Bidhannagar, Howrah, Asansol and Siliguri. BJP district units will be in charge of the municipality polls.

Title: Varsha: From a hapless victim of illegal breeding to a mascot for ‘don’t shop, adopt’, this St Bernard’s come a long way
Content: A little over a year ago, on a rainy August night, a St Bernard was found lying in an empty plot near Madhapur. Cold, sick and unable to move from the wet blanket she was lying on, the hapless pooch was nearly dead. But thankfully, someone who lives nearby noticed the sad plight of this dog and notified animal welfare groups. And that was how Varsha found a name, a home and nine ‘moms’. “Her image was shared on our WhatsApp group. Two of our group members, Shashank Gupta and Priyanka Nagam , immediately reached the spot around midnight and took her to a hospital. The doctor said that had we been even two hours late in getting there, she wouldn’t have survived,” recalls Pratima Sagar , one of Varsha’s moms. Though the doctors managed to provide immediate medical aid, they were not very optimistic about Varsha’s survival.“But we were not ready to give up yet. We named her Varsha since she was found in the rain. A WhatsApp group called ‘Varsha’s Moms’ was created, which included Srilu Bhopal, Mayura Ratkalkar, Radhika Om Prakash Wakharkar, Aparajita Sinha, Alka Panday, Shirali Ratkalkar, Rebecca Gupta, Surabhi Sagar and me. Everyone pitched in to provide her with medicine, proper diet and everything else she needed. and now, here she is,” says Pratima, petting Varsha, who wags her tail happily.“It was Varsha who brought us all together,” says Mayura Ratkalkar, one of Varsha’s mothers. Though she was in Czechoslovakia when Varsha was rescued, Maurya was one of first persons who reached out to help Pratima with financial support for the treatment.Today, 15 months on, Varsha — who was just skin and bone when she was found — is a well looked-after, fluffy St Bernard, who’s happy to cuddle up with her foster moms all she can. But she’s more than just a cuddly pooch. She has also unwittingly become a mascot to spread the pertinent message — ‘Don’t shop, adopt’.“When we found her, she was paralysed below the waist. There was no fur on her skin, she was like a bag of bones, and had almost every kind of illness a dog could possibly have. It was evident that she was dumped in that state by illegal breeders who had no use of her anymore as she could no longer give birth. I can’t even imagine what the breeders must have done to her for her to be in that state,” says Pratima, her voice trembling with emotion.It took months of treatment for her to start walking again. “But she is a fighter, our girl...,” beams Srilu Bhopal, another proud mom of Varsha, who has been instrumental in getting 500 stray dogs sterilised at her own expense. Today, every time Varsha’s story is shared, it goes out with a strong message to pet lovers to stop shopping for pups from breeders. It is cruel, it’s illegal and these voiceless creatures are put through untold miseries at the hands of breeders who use the dogs as puppy making machines, say Varsha’s foster moms. “the illegal breeding scene in Hyderabad is quite horrendous. Despite the law prohibiting it, we still see advertisements on sites like OLX and Facebook announcing sale of pedigree pups,” says Mayura Patil, who has been trying to fight illegal breeding in Hyderabad for years. elaborating on the plight of these animals, she says, “These dogs are not given food and water because that would mean that the breeders will have to take them out for walks to attend nature’s calls or clean up if they dirty the place. They are usually locked up in crates and left on roof tops even in extreme heat or rain. Many are tied up in rooms without ventilation for days together and don’t even see daylight.”Taking advantage of the laxity of law enforcement and attitude of authorities who turn a blind eye to animal abuse, a lot of unqualified people are getting into breeding to make a quick buck. “Trust me, 99 out of 100 breeders do not care two hoots about the laws. Worse, they have no sympathy for the animals either. Even college kids start doing this as a side business, because it is easy money. Nobody cares about the ethics of this profession, except maybe a handful,” rues Aparajita Sinha, an animal lover who fostered Varsha.Every time you succumb to the desire to own a cute ‘pedigree pup’ and go to a breeder to ‘buy’ one, you are contributing to this vicious trade and helping illegal breeders thrive. “Instead, adopt..” says Mayura. “Varsha is just one of the many, many dogs left in an abysmal state after being used and abused. Once weak, they are just left to die, without even the kindness of euthanasia,” she adds.

Title: Varsha: From a hapless victim of illegal breeding to a mascot for ‘don’t shop, adopt’, this St Bernard’s come a long way

Cold, sick and unable to move from the wet blanket she was lying on, the hapless pooch was nearly dead. Title: 3 Bangladeshis held in Thane for illegal stay
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

THANE: Three Bangladeshis, including two women, were arrested by Kasarwadavali police for staying illegally in Patlipada, Ghodbunder Road.

On Friday evening, MNS city chief Avinash Jadhav went to King-Kong Nagar following information that some Bangladeshis were living there illegally. They traced three persons and handed them over to police for verification and investigations.

Lalbanu, Mola (30), Parvin Nur Islam Shaikh (40) and Parvesh Nur Islam Shaikh (19) had fake Aadhaar and PAN cards, which were seized, police said. They used to do odd jobs for a living, a police officer said.

Police said investigations were on to find out if some accomplices were also living in India or if they were involved in anti-national activities. A case was registered against them at Kasarwadavali police station.

The accused were remanded to police custody till Monday.

Title: Ghaziabad: Teen daughter, her boyfriend kill Delhi cop
Content:
Representative image

GHAZIABAD: A 15-year-old girl allegedly strangled her mother to death, a head constable with Delhi Police ’s PCR cell, in their house in Ghaziabad’s Brij Vihar colony last Friday. The teenager was detained for questioning on Saturday after her father, who was away in Bihar, lodged a complaint against her.Police believe the teenager and her boyfriend, 20-year-old Jitendra, attacked the woman (44) together, throttling her with a rope till she choked to death. Jitendra has been arrested. The duo had tried to make it look like suicide; both left the house after the murder and the girl returned after a while, feigning shock at the discovery of her mother’s body and raising an alarm for help. Neighbours helped take her mother to GTB Hospital in Delhi, where doctors declared her brought dead.The chain of events that led to the alleged murder began in the morning on Friday when the head constable found her daughter talking stealthily to someone over the phone, police said. On being questioned, the teenager told her mother she was talking to her boyfriend and he had gifted the phone to her a few days ago. This led to a heated exchange and snowballed. Jitendra came to the house and they attacked the woman together, police said, based on what they have learnt so far during questioning.The woman and her daughter had been living in the rented house for 15 years. The girl’s father, a farmer, spends most of his time at his hometown in Bihar. Devendra Singh Bisht, the SHO of Link Road police station, said they received a call from GTB Hospital around 6pm on Friday and started an investigation. “When we reached the hospital, we found that the deceased woman was a head constable with Delhi Police,” Bisht said.The SHO said though autopsy reports were awaited, doctors at GTB Hospital suggested it could be a case of murder as there were strangulation marks on the woman’s throat. “There was also a deep wound in the head, as if she had been hit with a blunt object. But the daughter kept telling us her mother had committed suicide. There were discrepancies in her statements and this raised our suspicion. We detained her for questioning,” Bisht added.Following sustained questioning, police said the girl admitted that she and her boyfriend had killed her mother. Quoting from the girl’s statements, investigators said when her mother came to know about her relationship with Jitendra, she chided her for not concentrating on her studies.“The mother was angry as the youth was from the neighbourhood. She allegedly slapped her a few times and went to the youth’s house to talk to his parents. There, she was told that Jitendra was not at home and would return after two to three hours. The woman asked his elder brother to send Jitendra to her home once he returned,” the SHO said.Jitendra went to meet the cop at her house around 1.20pm. As soon as she opened the door, an argument broke out, followed by a scuffle. “There was a container full of chilli powder lying nearby. The daughter passed the container to Jitendra and he threw the chilli powder into the woman’s eyes. She was caught off guard. Jitendra then hit her on the head with a blunt object. The woman fell unconscious. The two strangled her to death with a piece of rope,” said the SHO.To make it look like suicide, the girl went to a jewellery shop to get a gold chain repaired and Jitendra left the house, police said. According to SHO Bisht, “she returned home around 2.30pm and raised an alarm, saying her mother was lying motionless on the bed and had not responded to repeated calls from her”.Jitendra was arrested early on Saturday. A school dropout, he works as a helper at a grocery store in Delhi. The girl is supposed to appear for her Class X boards from open school.The murdered cop’s husband said he was in Bihar since early January. “All along, I was in Bihar and had no inkling about what was happening here. I had left Ghaziabad in the first week of January,” he sobbed. Jitendra is believed to have told cops he was in a relationship with the girl for over a year. “On the basis of the complaint lodged by the woman’s husband, an FIR has been registered under Section 302 (murder) of the IPC,” SHO Bisht said.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Confined to room, son hacks man to death
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Lalit has been sent to jail

GREATER NOIDA: A 25-year-old man was arrested for allegedly slitting the throat of his father with a reaping hook and killing him at their home in Jarcha . Primary investigation has revealed that the accused would blame his father for his impotence and killed him because he thought the latter had not done much to get him treated.

The deceased was identified as Rambhool Singh, a farmer from Kalouda village, where he lived with his wife and two sons — Arun and Lalit. While Arun had a wife and son , Lalit had separated from his wife a few years ago, apparently over his health condition.

The family came to know about the alleged murder around 7am on Saturday, when Arun, who stayed on the first floor, came down to check on his father and found him dead in his room. A police team reached the spot and sent the body for an autopsy. Lalit, who slept with his father in the same room, was missing.

DCP (zone 3) Rajesh Kumar Singh said Rambhool’s family had told them that the farmer had gone to sleep with Lalit on Friday night. The next morning, a bleeding Rambhool lay dead on his cot and the reaping hook lay nearby. “We started looking for Lalit, as he was the prime suspect. He was nabbed from the neighbouring Ghodi-Bacheda village and was taken into custody for questioning,” he said.

Police said Lalit had admitted to have killed his father as he would not let him go out of the house because of his condition. “As of now, the accused appears to be mentally unstable. So, the family, especially the father, was overprotective. Lalit has told us that they would keep him confined to his room as they felt he would leave the family or get into fights,” Singh said.

According to police, Lalit was being treated by doctors in Meerut and Aligarh and would get irritated easily after his wife left him. “He would blame his father for his condition,” the DCP said. Lalit has been booked for murder. He was produced in court and remanded in judicial custody.

Title: Section 144 in Noida: Section 144 imposed in Noida for a month
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

File photo

GREATER NOIDA: Police on Saturday imposed Section 144 in the district for a month due to upcoming festivals and board exams. The move comes against the backdrop of protests by farmers and several social outfits.

A circular was shared by additional DCP (law and order) Ashutosh Dwiwedi. The circular says the decision has been taken keeping in mind the protests and rallies over the past few weeks. “It is impossible to identify anti-social elements beforehand. That is why imposing Section 144 was required,” the circular read.

It further said no rallies or protests can be organised without permission from the authority concerned and no loudspeakers can be used during this period. The circular specifies that people should circulate videos or messages on social media with caution. During this period, there will be a ban on celebratory firing and consuming liquor in public places. Police have also got orders to immediately arrest those found making public speeches that can potentially hurt the sentiment of a particular community.

“Those found violating the norms made in the circular will be booked under Section 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant) and may also face imprisonment along with a fine,” said the circular.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Registry fee hike worries builders in times of slump
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

GHAZIABAD: The UP government’s decision to hike property registry fees has left both homebuyers and developers disappointed. They feel the new rate will lead to higher property prices, thus further dampening the investor sentiment at a time when the real estate sector is going through a slump.

Earlier, the registry fee was Rs 10,000 for properties up to Rs 10 lakh and Rs 20,000 for properties over Rs 10 lakh. The new rates — a flat 1% of property cost — came into effect on February 14.

This means that if the cost of a flat is Rs 50 lakh, the owner will have to shell out Rs 50,000 against Rs 20,000 earlier. And if the stamp duty at 7% — which would be Rs 3.5 lakh — is added, then the owner will have to shell out about Rs 4 lakh extra for that Rs 50 lakh flat.

Animesh Choudhary, a potential homebuyer, said, “For the time being, I may have to abandon my plan to invest in a ready-to-move-in flat worth Rs 75 lakh. The change in registry fee will definitely put the burden on the middle-class looking to buy a flat.”

Manoj Gaur, national vice-president of developers’ body CREDAI, said, “The projects in NCR are already dwindling and there are not many takers, and in this backdrop the government’s move that increases the price of a flat is definitely not a good one. It will further dampen sentiments. Instead, efforts should be made to improve the situation in the real estate sector.”

The move will also have a bearing in housing schemes by the Ghaziabad Development Authority (GDA) and other agencies such as the UP Housing Board.

“There are about 62 commercial properties worth Rs 400 crore and about 4,000 flats of the same worth, which the GDA is struggling to dispose of as there are very few takers for the same,” said Alok Kumar, member of the Federation of Apartment Owners Association (Fed AOA).

Title: Mumbai: Pushed out of train over Rs 100, youth survives
Content:
This story is from February 16, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: A commuter survived after he was pushed out of the luggage compartment of a moving train at Nahur station on February 13. Amit Tak (25) boarded a Dombivli-bound train from Bhandup to go to his Mulund (W) home, but got into a scuffle with two commuters who demanded Rs 100 from him at 1.43pm, he claimed in the FIR.

A case under IPC sections 34 (common intention) and 307 (attempt to commit murder) was filed against unknown persons. “We are going through CCTV footage from stations to identify the two,” said a Kurla railway police officer.

Tak said in his complaint, “The two, seated in the luggage compartment, demanded Rs100. I refused and went to the footboard.” Police said the two followed Tak, argued with him and pushed him out when the train slowed down at Nahur. “Tak, who was traumatised, left with his family after lodging a complaint,” senior inspector M A Inamdar said.

Content:

Due to the illegal parking outside our premises the fire brigade couldn't enter. This road outside our premises is just behind a police chowki. We have made umpteen complaints but it has fallen on deaf ears. The situation was luckily averted with help from members with water and fire extinguishers available. Requested fire brigade officials to give a letter stating that due to illegal parking their vehicle couldn't enter but they refused. A very sorry state in our city where there is no value for life as well as the complaints put forward. Location: Arvind Nagar Society, Kalina, Santacruz East.
